HEADLINE: Review/Television;
In 90 Minutes, 500 Years' Worth of Destruction

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
The Earth Day message from HBO is that America was a much pleasanter land when it was inhabited by more bison than human beings, and when none of the latter were white Europeans.
If pretentiousness were an ecological threat, "Earth and the American Dream" would face a heavy fine for fallout. Moving through 500 years of assaults on the environment in 90 minutes, Bill Couturie (who won an Academy Award for his 1989 documentary, "Common Threads: Stories From the Quilt," a work about AIDS) exploits visual effects the way American industry has exploited natural resources. 
 The program begins with highly unnatural-looking nature scenes that are meant to evoke the idyll that was supposedly North America before the invasion by the European horde. These are accompanied by portentous quotes from famous figures (Washington, Toqueville, Thoreau, Audubon) read in a somewhat hard-breathing way by even more famous actors (Edward Asner, Alec Baldwin, Ellen Burstyn, Gene Hackman, Anthony Hopkins, Dustin Hoffman, Jeremy Irons, you name them).
The westward movement is pictured as an invasion, every ground clearing an attack on the environment. A few old photographs, particularly one of a man, presumably a buffalo hunter, standing like a conqueror on a small mountain of buffalo heads, make the point better than all the fancy shots of sparkling streams and splashing fish. One real picture is worth a thousand imitations.
The program picks up as the 20th century comes in, when by a striking use of newsreels and, later, television commercials, set to peppy tunes, Mr. Couturie catches America's unstoppable drive to produce and its insatiable capacity to consume, with small regard for the long-range cost. One generation's progress becomes another's problem. A picture of a pile of junked automobiles echoes that pile of slaughtered buffalo.
In the final minutes, the documentary goes global, hopscotching the world for catastrophe. It is a phantasmagoria of oil spills in Alaska, famine in Ethiopia, disasters in Chernobyl, Bhopal and elsewhere, to a litany of sound bites about global warming, toxic dumping and acid rain. (Pictures of the homeless are dropped in, although the connection between their troubles and global warming remains smoggy.) The prolonged conclusion offers prophetic preachments from friends of the earth like Rachel Carson and Jacques Cousteau, and ends, as it began, with an appreciation of nature by an American Indian.
Presenting American history from the perspective of the land itself, although no longer novel, can still be enlightening, but "Earth and the American Dream" suffers from videoitis, a tendency to lay on visual stunts to disguise the conventionality of the ideas. Still, what reviewer wants to come across as a fan of strip mining, clear cutting, ocean dumping, leaded gasoline and holes in the ozone? So, happy Earth Day.
 
'Adam Smith'
PBS, tonight at 8 P.M.
(Channel 13 in New York)
"Now that the cold war is over, do we need a Central Intelligence Agency?" The question is posed by tonight's timely edition of this lively PBS staple. The most definite answer comes from Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan. The ever-eloquent New York Democrat says that since the agency has been "getting everything wrong for 30 years," this is a good time to hand out medals and send the snoopers into early retirement.
But others, like Adm. Stansfield Turner, a former Director of Central Intelligence, supports turning the agency's attention to economic intelligence, which he grants means spying on friends and allies, like Japan and Germany, who, no one doubts, are spying on American business. Senator Dennis DeConcini, the Arizona Democrat who heads the Senate Intelligence Committee, also seems to be inclined toward some such effort.
The half-hour, dotted with pictures of lock picking and a shady-looking photographer at work, ends with the reminder that the Soviet K.G.B., by whatever name, is still busy. The hope is expressed by a Russian critic that for a change, it is spying on the United States economy instead of on its own people.

HEADLINE: A Truce, or Else

BYLINE: By Winston S. Churchill; Winston S. Churchill, grandson of the wartime Prime Minister, is a Conservative Member of Parliament.

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
As a vast European tragedy unfolds a tragedy unprecedented in 50 years -- where is the Western political leadership that will halt this slaughter of the innocents?
Sanctions have not persuaded the Serbians to accept the Vance-Owen peace plan and honor a cease-fire. The case for Western intervention in Bosnia has become overwhelming. Margaret Thatcher may have been emotional in calling for military intervention against Serbians. But she struck a chord with millions. 
 It is no good that Western leaders wring their hands and shed crocodile tears as the butchery continues. They know that the Serbians began this conflict with a vast arsenal of modern weapons and a supply of ammunition sufficient for two years' fighting -- more than 10 times as much as the Muslims have. They also know that the consequence of imposing an arms embargo equally upon the victims of aggression, the Bosnian Muslims, and on the Serbian aggressors -- unprecedented in U.N. history -- is that the genocide will continue.
Nor is it just that women and children have become random victims of crossfires. There is abundant evidence that time and again atrocities have been deliberately inflicted on the civilian population, with little children being machine-gunned or bayoneted, old men shown no quarter and women slaughtered or kept to be gang-raped by Serbian forces.
Of course, all sides -- Muslim, Croat and Serb -- are guilty of atrocities. But overwhelmingly the perpetrators have been Serbian and the victims Muslim. So long as the U.N. policy of providing no more than food and care packages continues, requiring our troops to stand idly by while atrocities are committed, Serbians will remorselessly overrun Muslim towns and enclaves.
The grotesquely misnamed U.N. Protection Force, whose national contingents have done a magnificent job in bringing humanitarian aid and food and saving many thousands from starvation, has thus far been powerless to prevent Serbian forces from pursuing "ethnic cleansing." This policy may change now that Canadian troops in Srebrenica demilitarized the town yesterday.
Europeans and Americans are increasingly demanding action. But what, their leaders ask, can be done? For the West to become embroiled with ground troops would be a disastrous mistake. But no one is suggesting that.
What we can do first and foremost, with the threat of withholding European Community and U.S. economic aid to Russia, is to bring Russia, which has close links with the Serbians, back into line on this issue. Second, the Serbian Government and Bosnian Serbs must be given an ultimatum that unless they honor the cease-fire and accept the Vance-Owen plan, the West will lift the arms embargo on the Bosnian Muslims, and launch air strikes against military targets in Serbia and Serbian artillery positions in Bosnia. Possibly this threat alone will be enough to bring them to heel.
But if not, the gulf war showed us how "smart" weapons can achieve military feats unimagined a decade ago. The West, with fighters and bombers stationed in Italy and the Adriatic, outside the range of Serbian retaliation, can dramatically alter the military situation on the ground and help decisively redress the balance.
It is time for the West -- with the European Community for once in the lead, as this is our special responsibility -- to decisively halt the massacre of Muslims. All that is required is moral courage and political will.

HEADLINE: Essay;
MEGO of the Year

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Occasionally a speech is written of such apparently stupefying dullness that it rates the accolade "MEGO of the Year." (MEGO is the acronym for "My Eyes Glaze Over.")
This year's award -- a half-lidded eyeball on a field of z's -- goes to Alan Greenspan, Federal Reserve chairman, for his speech this week to the Economic Club of New York. Its stirring title was "Remarks," a come-on to become comatose. 
 You remember Alan, whose mournful countenance the cameras caught sitting next to the First Lady in the balcony during the President's Inaugural Address. I don't read any diminution of Fed independence into that; he thought he was going to sit way back in the Executive Box next to Alice Rivlin or some other functionary, and nobody told him he would be presented with the A-6 ticket in the front row inviting him to televised hand-holding with Hillary.
Greenspan's topic was inflation. At first, he acted unworried: "The inflationary pressures that so dominated the economic events of most of the last quarter-century appear largely, though not as yet wholly, subdued."
But then he wondered, in Fed-chairmanese, why long-term interest rates, though at the lowest level in 20 years, did not fully "reflect the benign view of long-term inflation" of a generation ago. This led to some really fervent rhetoric: "It is an open question," said Greenspan, "whether we have learned enough to skirt the dangers of budgetary and monetary excess that have triggered past episodes of debilitating inflation."
What he means, I think, is that the inflation premium built into the price of long-term bonds used to be 1 or 2 percent, and is now 4 percent. That curvaceous "yield curve" (not a description of Rosie Scenario's voluptuous hip) shows that investors still suspect that the Government isn't serious about holding down deficits and stopping inflation.
He's worried that if the political system does not cut deficits, preferably by reducing the growth of spending rather than by taxation, the whole burden of fighting inflation will fall on the central bank. This would require the high interest rates triggering recessions that infuriate voters -- which might cause a future Fed to cave in and print money like mad.
That sets up the key question: Is inflation on the way? The post-election revelation of President Clinton's urge to tax has been a bonanza for the "bond ghouls" -- those morbid souls who figure that new taxes will either reduce the deficit (good for bonds) or re-ignite recession (bad for everybody but bondholders).
Chairman Greenspan brushes aside "the recent firming in some materials prices" (translation: lumber is skyrocketing) and blames the weather for "the recent firming of wages" (overtime is way up). So long as banks are reluctant to lend, "it is difficult to envision inflationary pressures intensifying. . . ."
So we can relax? Nope: "we need to be especially vigilant not to be mesmerized," he warns, "by the current tranquillity of the inflationary environment."
O.K., let's help the chairman -- who in his dull way makes an exciting point -- unmesmerize:
1. Clintonites are regulators and environmentalists; that adds to costs to be passed on to consumers.
2. Whether it's a buck on a pack of cigarettes or a nickel on a can of beer, or an energy tax or national sales tax that pushes up the price of every product and service, the Clinton tax plan is inflationary.
3. Labor, which delivered for Clinton, wants a 20 percent increase in the minimum wage, special job protection for strikers and protection from foreign production -- all of which raises the price consumers must pay.
4. When you sock business with new mandatory health benefits to cover tens of millions of non-workers, you add to costs and prices.
5. The world economy is pulling out of the dumps, as our own has been; when plants operate at higher capacity, up go producer prices.
The only thing that could stop such cost-push inflation, if the Clinton economic plan goes through, is for the tax increases to trigger the Triple Dip. That prospect is welcomed only by bond ghouls and ballot ghouls.
Excuse me, usher, I thought I'd be sitting back in the 2 percent row of the Executive Box, but what's this number on my ticket? Four percent? Nobody told me . . .

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Pollution-control companies find little to celebrate on Earth Day.

BYLINE: By Alison Leigh Cowan

 BODY:
WHEN America's baby boomers elected one of their own, Bill Clinton, to the Presidency last November, he and his running mate pledged to put environmental protection at the top of their to-do list.
But for problems that may take millenia to fix, there's a temptation to put them off until tomorrow. And with bloodshed in Bosnia, holes in the health-care system, budget deficits and trade skirmishes clamoring for the Administration's attention, who has time to deal with the environment? 
 That's apparently what many Wall Street analysts have concluded, downgrading their 1993 earnings estimates on 12 of 14 companies that specialize in pollution control. "Environmental policy is likely to remain a low priority" this year, Vishnu Swarup, a Prudential Securities analyst, wrote recently.
Businesses are deferring hazardous waste and other cleanup projects, Mr. Swarup noted, awaiting guidance from policy makers. Washington, meanwhile, has been unsure how to proceed, aware that a rule-making spree could snuff out the economic recovery. Moreover, landfill operators are slashing prices before Bush-enacted regulations take effect in October. The rules are expected to drive up the operators' costs sharply, but the price-cutting is squeezing profits.
All in all, the regulatory haze gives green companies little to cheer about on Earth Day.

CORRECTION-DATE: April 24, 1993, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
A chart in the Market Place column of Business Day on Thursday, about Wall Street analysts' estimates of earnings for 14 pollution control companies, included erroneous data supplied by I.B.E.S. Inc., a financial research company, for Wheelabrator Technologies Inc. The data omitted reference to Wheelabrator's 2-for-1 stock split in January. Estimates for Wheelabrator have increased 1.9 percent since December.

HEADLINE: BankAmerica Signs A Lease for 8 Floors At the Trade Center

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
The BankAmerica Corporation announced yesterday that it had signed a 15-year lease to move 1,100 workers to eight floors of Tower One of the World Trade Center.
The move by the nation's second largest bank holding company was portrayed by bank executives and government officials as a vote of confidence in the Twin Towers after the terrorist bombing of Feb. 26. In the wake of the explosion in lower Manhattan, fears surfaced that security concerns would prompt many companies to move out when their leases were up and others to decide not to move in. 
 It was clear yesterday that the Port Authority, which owns the trade center, was forced to offer extraordinary incentives. Officials close to the negotiations said BankAmerica would receive two years' free rent, effectively giving it a square-foot rental lower than many other tenants in the towers pay.
The bank's decision to move workers from at least 10 other buildings in Manhattan followed weeks of rumors that it had changed its mind about moving into the tower after the bombing. Bank officials said at a news conference that it had looked at alternative buildings in New Jersey, Phoenix and California, and had, in fact, postponed any decision after the bombing.
But Dan Costello, the corporation's executive vice president in charge of real estate, said that after bank officials reviewed security systems in the World Trade Center, including improvements made since the bombing, they were convinced that the complex was "the safest building in New York, and perhaps even in the country."
BankAmerica executives announced their decision at a news conference attended by Mayor David N. Dinkins, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and other officials, who described it as a major expression of confidence in the troubled complex. "BankAmerica is sending an important message to the world that the World Trade Center is back," Governor Cuomo said.
Although not all details of the deal were disclosed, it was clear that the city, the state and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey had mounted an aggressive campaign for at least nine months to lure the company to the World Trade Center and prevent it from leaving Manhattan.
 
Sales-Tax Breaks
 The bank holding company, second in size to Citicorp, is to receive sales-tax breaks and other incentives from the city and state worth $15.5 million over the 15 years. The package includes a promise by New York City to buy some machinery and equipment to be used by BankAmerica.
BankAmerica, based in San Francisco, also said yesterday that it had signed a new 20-year lease and will retain 360 employees at the Bank of America Building at 335 Madison Avenue, near 46th Street. It will also retain 240 employees at 40 East 52d Street, the former Security Pacific Building. Its 1,700 Manhattan employees are in international banking, foreign exchange trading, stock trade processing and other operations.
Financial incentives have become all but routine in government efforts to attract and retain big business. In an example last year, Morgan Stanley & Company, which had threatened to move 4,100 employees to Stamford, Conn., received a tax-incentive package worth $39.6 million over a 10-year Manhattan lease.
But, according to people close to the negotiations, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, it was deep concessions offered by the Port Authority that were most critical in attracting BankAmerica. The effort almost certainly created political conflicts for the agency since it is accountable to both New Jersey and New York and was courting a large tenant that might otherwise have selected a New Jersey office building.
After BankAmerica begins paying rent, authority officials said, it will pay between $25 and $35 a square foot. Though they declined to be more specific, they said the Tower One space would have brought 20 percent more in the robust years for Manhattan real estate in the mid-1980's.
It was unclear yesterday whether the Port Authority had offered the free rent before the Feb. 26 explosion, or whether BankAmerica used the uncertainty after the bombing to extract the further concessions.
BankAmerica had made a verbal pledge to lease its World Trade Center space by December, several officials said. But by the February blast, they said, that oral promise had not been made formal in a legally binding contract, and a legion of economic development officials set out on a fresh campaign to persuade the bank holding company to sign its lease.
With BankAmerica occupying eight floors of Tower One, authority officials said the complex would be 92 percent occupied. The rate is higher than before the explosion, when 88 percent of the complex was filled.
BankAmerica's committment to the complex comes at a time when most tenants in the buildings say life has returned almost to normal.
No large tenants have left the complex since the bombing. But because all are required to meet legal requirments of their leases and would lose money if they left before the leases expire, it is not known whether some will elect to leave when they have the option in coming months and years.
 
Not Back in Offices Yet
 One of the last remaining World Trade Center tenants that has not yet returned to its offices in the complex is Deloitte & Touche, the accounting firm, which has seven floors in Tower Two and moved 1,200 workers to other buildings in Manhattan. Because of the pressures of the government's April 15 deadline for filing income tax returns, the firm had said it had not plans to return to its trade center offices until after that deadline.
Yesterday, Paul Higgins, a Deloitte & Touche spokesman, said the firm had still not returned. The reason, he said, is that cleaning the firm's Twin Tower offices -- the Port Authority's responsibility -- had not been completed. He declined to say when the firm would return.
But other companies said their return to the trade center complex was accomplished without any snags.
"There are no lingering problems," said George Mullen, executive vice president of Fiduciary Trust International, an investment management concern, which returned with 500 employees to five floors of Tower Two on March 25. Since then, it has signed a lease for an additional floor for 45 employees.

HEADLINE: Russian Official Links Defense Chief to Illegality

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, April 22

 BODY:
Just three days before a referendum on Boris N. Yeltsin's performance as Russia's President, Russia's top law enforcement officer today accused Mr. Yeltsin's Defense Minister of involvement in the illegal sale of military property in the former East Germany.
The charges against Gen. Pavel S. Grachev were made by Valentin G. Stepankov, the Procurator General of Russia, whose job is roughly that of an attorney general in the United States. They came only days after Vice President Aleksandr V. Rutskoi, who has broken with Mr. Yeltsin, accused various Yeltsin officials of corruption. 
 Since Mr. Rutskoi's speech, allegations of Government corruption have been the centerpiece of the anti-Yeltsin campaign before Sunday's referendum, which will offer Russians a chance to support Mr. Yeltsin and his vision of economic reforms or to repudiate them.
Mr. Rutskoi, a former air force pilot who has become the chief spokesman for the opposition, has announced his intention to run for President in any new elections.
 
Sale of Military Property
 In his speech to the Russian Parliament, Mr. Rutskoi concentrated in particular on assertions of the illegal sale of military property belonging to Soviet troops withdrawing from the former East Germany, suggesting an official coverup of the investigation. He promised to hand over his evidence to the Procurator General. Mr. Stepankov, who himself has been increasingly critical of Mr. Yeltsin and who spoke to the Supreme Soviet immediately after Mr. Rutskoi, acted quickly in what Yeltsin officials called a political maneuver.
In a statement issued to the Itar- Tass news agency, the Prosecutor General's office said that it had "discovered new facts of abuse of official position" by the commanders of former Soviet troops in Eastern Germany, known as the Western Group of Forces, and by officials in the Defense Ministry, "including Defense Minister Pavel Grachev personally."
 
Another Corruption Case
 General Grachev, who was in Siberia today reviewing troops, was unavailable for comment. He has urged the armed forces to maintain neutrality in the political struggle between Mr. Yeltsin and the Parliament. But General Grachev is regarded as an ally of Mr. Yeltsin, who appointed him, and the opposition is worried that Mr. Yeltsin may try to force through political changes after the referendum by threatening to use the army.
The prosecution statement also said that Gennadi Burbulis, a close adviser to Mr. Yeltsin who is despised by conservatives, would be questioned in another corruption case involving the smuggling of a substance known as "red mercury," which Western scientists regard as worthless.
It is not known if these charges will have any impact on the referendum due to take place across Russia on Sunday.
Mr. Yeltsin has admitted that some corruption exists, though not to the degree alleged by Mr. Rutskoi. But he criticized Mr. Rutskoi today for not submitting any documents on corruption sooner, "instead of accumulating them for months until the right moment and waiting for the referendum on the President to begin." Officials charged "should respond according to the law," he said.
In the four-question plebiscite, Russian voters will be asked if they trust Mr. Yeltsin as President, if they support the social and economic policies of his Government in 1992, and if they favor early elections for the Presidency and for the legislature.
Opinion polls suggest that between 55 percent and 60 percent of Russians will vote, with a small majority for Mr. Yeltsin and against new presidential elections, a small majority against his 1992 policies, and a more sizable majority for early legislative elections. The Russian Constitutional Court has ruled that the votes on early elections must pass with more than 50 percent of all registered voters, which is unlikely.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gen. Pavel S. Grachev, Russia's Defense Minister, was accused in the illegal sale of military property in the former East Germany. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: U.S. Agrees to Discuss Arms Directly With North Korea

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 22

 BODY:
Bowing to Chinese entreaties, the United States offered today for the first time to take part in high-level talks with North Korea to help resolve a crisis caused by North Korea's refusal to honor a treaty on nuclear weapons.
The offer, a substantial easing of the Administration's stance, was made largely at the behest of China, officials said. Until now, the Administration had urged that the standoff be resolved by the United Nations, and had warned of sanctions against North Korea. 
 If accepted by North Korea, the meeting, which was suggested by Under Secretary of State Peter Tarnoff during a visit to South Korea, would be the most direct dialogue between Washington and Pyongyang in more than a year. The proposal indicated the depth of distress over North Korea's continuing refusal to open its nuclear-weapons installations to inspection.
 
An Awkward Dependency
 Officials say the shift is the clearest indication of the degree to which Washington has sought Beijing's assistance in trying to put an end to North Korea's nuclear-weapons program.
Senior Administration officials say they have little option but to seek Chinese help. But other Government officials have expressed concern that relying on Beijing to help cajole Pyongyang could cause the White House to feel obligated to reward China by expanding trade, despite widespread criticism of its human rights record.
In his Presidential campaign, Mr. Clinton criticized the Bush Administration for overlooking China's repressive policies, and Democratic lawmakers introduced legislation today that would impose strict conditions on China in return for privileged trade status. But Administration officials said it appeared unlikely that the White House would agree to such a strict approach.
The trade proposal, by Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the Democratic leader, and Representative Nancy Pelosi of California, would grant China most-favored-nation trade status only if Beijing improved human rights and bolstered efforts to halt the spread of weapons.
 
Calculating Tit-for-Tat
 In interviews this week, senior officials insisted that the Administration's decisions on China would be made without regard to Beijing's cooperation over North Korea. But they also said the need for Chinese help could grow most pressing as the White House neared a June 3 deadline to decide Beijing's trade status.
"The consensus is that China is the key to solving the North Korea crisis," said a senior Government official who is concerned that the relationship may be too close. "The obvious question is going to be how much influence that gives Beijing, and how it affects our China policy."
According to American officials, Mr. Tarnoff told President Kim Young Sam of South Korea today that Washington was willing to join in talks with North Korea. Mr. Tarnoff, the State Department's No. 3 official, said he would represent the United States.
The State Department spokesman, Richard A. Boucher, later said that no meeting had been scheduled and no decisions made. But he said for the first time that the United States "would not rule out a meeting."
 
North Korea Wants to Talk
 Such a meeting would be the highest-level exchange between Washington and Pyongyang since January 1992, when the third-ranking State Department official in the Bush Administration met in New York with a leader of the North Korean Workers Party.
North Korea has sought new talks to reduce tensions between the two countries. But Washington's willingness to accept China's advice is surprising because Beijing remains a central obstacle to the economic sanctions that Administration officials believe may still be necessary to persuade Pyongyang to accept nuclear inspections.
Because China alone among the permanent members of the Security Council has threatened to veto such a measure, critics fear that the reliance on China will leave the White House unwilling to give offense to Beijing when it makes its trade decision.
 
A Nervous General
 But the Administration has clearly begun to grow wary about leaving North Korea feeling cornered.
Although a State Department official later described it as a worst-case scenario, the commander of United States military forces in South Korea said this week that he was "increasingly concerned that North Korea could slide into an attack" against South Korea.
The commander, Gen. Robert W. RisCassi, told a Congressional committee that Pyongyang's insular Government might launch an offensive "as an uncontrollable consequence of total desperation or internal instability."
Even though North Korea announced its withdrawal from the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty six weeks ago, it remains obligated to submit to nuclear inspections until at least June 12. Administration officials have said that if more gentle suasion fails to lead Pyongyang to honor that commitment by late May, they will renew their quest for United Nations approval of punitive sanctions.
The South Korean news agency Yonhap reported Friday that North Korea had in fact decided to honor the non-proliferation treaty, attributing the account to a North Korean diplomat in Cairo. But a senior State Department official said tonight that after numerous inquiries, the department had no information to corroborate the report.
The Administration protested loudly when Pyongyang withdrew from the accord, interpreting the action as a sign that North Korea was hiding evidence of its weapons program. As an indication of its new muted stance, however, officials pointed to a low-key statement the Security Council issued this month with Washington's support.
 
Treading Softly
 While the International Atomic Energy Agency had asked for assistance in compelling North Korea to submit to inspections, the 15-member body did little more than to declare that it was "concerned at the situation."
Such language is tepid compared to that used by the Security Council in the past to condemn Iraq's refusal to honor similar international commitments. But a senior official said the central role played by China had caused the Administration to "discard the Iraq template."
He declined to discuss where and when the consultations between American and Chinese diplomats had occurred, but he indicated that they had been extensive.
Senior Administration officials said they remained confident that Beijing shared Washington's unease about North Korean weapons, adding that they saw no reason why China would not serve as an honest interlocutor.

HEADLINE: Currency Traders Frantic Over Conflicting Information from Germany

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

DATELINE: LONDON, April 22

 BODY:
Market chaos surrounded the Bundesbank's announcement today of interest rate cuts, analysts said.
At least five news services, including Bloomberg Business News, ran urgent bulletins early today saying that German interest rates were not changed after the Bundesbank council meeting in Frankfurt. 
 A Bundesbank official, when asked about rate cuts after bank officials had met, said, "Nothing on rates," and that news was sent out. But a few minutes later, a press release detailing the rate cuts was handed out.
Those few minutes were enough time for traders to have bought or sold millions of dollars worth of currencies and other securities before the news services ran corrected reports.
 
 
'Could Be Improved'
 "We are not aware that we made any mistakes," the Bundesbank's spokesman, Manfred Kerber, said. "I might concede, however, that the procedure of releasing press releases at such press conferences could be improved."
Jeff Brooks, analyst at Credit Lyonnais, said, "I would imagine a lot of people have lost a lot of money on this."
Albert Soria, foreign exchange manager at Kansallis Osake Pankki in New York, said, "It cost hundreds of thousands of dollars for some people, maybe millions."
Mr. Soria said he sold dollars, basing his decision on the report that rates had been left unchanged, and then had to buy them back once the news was corrected.
A trader selling $10 million at an exchange rate of 1.60 marks to the dollar, who then had to buy back dollars to cover that trade when the dollar rallied, would have lost as much as $350,000 on the trade, calculations showed.
The dollar dropped half a pfennig to 1.5940 marks on the reports German rates had been left unchanged, only to rally as high as 1.6150 once it became clear interest rates had been trimmed.
 
 
Frantic Trading
 Alison Cottrell, an analyst at Midland Global Markets, said the clamor from the foreign exchange trading desk in her bank indicated that trading was frantic as conflicting news stories ran across traders' electronic news screens.
Officials at the Bank of France in Paris said they were surprised at the way the Bundesbank announcement was handled.
The French central bank announces interest rate changes through its money market repurchase operations, which it reports to news services by telephone, in theory letting all the services know the news at once. If the bank governor decides to cut interest rates outside the repurchase operations, the news is sent by fax simultaneously to news services.
The Bank of England has electronic feeds that it supplies to news agencies, supplying its own text on interest rate moves.
"People like the Bank of England seem to be well sorted, everything seems to come out at the same time," Mr. Brooks of Credit Lyonnais said.
The Bank of Italy, which cut its discount rate today to 11 percent, from 11.5 percent, after the Bundesbank move, announces its actions by telephone, beginning with the main Italian news agency Ansa, and calls other agencies in turn.
Traders have no redress against news agencies, which protect themselves by carrying disclaimers.
Because news services now operate on an instantaneous global basis, today's confusion affected markets worldwide.
 
 
'Chaotic in There'
 Trading volume on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange as much as doubled, with the market plunging amid "fast market" conditions, meaning the market was moving so fast that up-to-the-second quotes could not be assured.
"It was chaotic in there," said John Lavender, a currency futures and options trader who trades for his own account. "There were a lot of unhappy people. And I'm sure there were a few people who got lucky and were on the right side."
An equity trader at Barclays de Zoete Wedd in Frankfurt said: "It was totally unexpected. There were rumors that both rates would be left unchanged and there was some selling on the futures, but with the cut, all hell let loose. It was total panic."

International
The German central bank again lowered two of its key interest rates amid signs that Germany's recession had worsened substantially in recent months. HEADLINE: 12 IN STATE DEPT. ASK MILITARY MOVE AGAINST THE SERBS

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 22

 BODY:
In an unusual revolt against American policy in the Balkans, the State Department's top experts on the Balkans have sent Secretary of State Warren Christopher an impassioned letter that calls Western diplomacy a failure and recommends military action against the Serbs.
The experts, career diplomats serving in Washington, said in a petition to Mr. Christopher that the United States had a moral obligation to save the Muslims from "genocide" at the hands of Serbian nationalist forces in Bosnia. 
 "We are only attempting to end the genocide through political and economic pressures such as sanctions and intense diplomatic engagement," the letter said. "In effect, the result of this course has been Western capitulation to Serbian aggression."
 
Air Strikes Urged
 Senior Administration officials also said today that the American representative at the United Nations, Madeleine Albright, had sent the White House a memorandum urging air strikes to protect the predominantly Muslim towns and cities under siege in Bosnia.
If the European nations decline to take part, Mrs. Albright says, the United States should act on its own under existing United Nations authority. "We should not turn our backs on our international responsibilities," she wrote.
Taken together, Mrs. Albright's memorandum and the petition by the State Department experts provided a dramatic look at the internal debate in the Administration over whether to use American military force in the Balkans, and the degree of disagreement that remains after months of trying to frame a policy.
 
Meeting With Christopher
 The diplomats who appealed to Mr. Christopher, who included the desk officers responsible for virtually every Balkan country, are the sort of career officials who normally labor far from public view.
Mr. Christopher, who has been cautious in his public comments about military action, met with the State Department specialists on Monday, officials said.
Asked about Mr. Christopher's view of the meeting, a senior Administration official, who asked not to be identified, said: "Several Foreign Service officers who worked in the area asked to see the Secretary. He found the exchange helpful and timely given that the Administration is reviewing its options with respect to the former Yugoslavia. This Secretary of State does not consider such sessions a revolt against policy; he considers it a healthy part of the policy-making process."
The petition from the State Department specialists and Mrs. Albright's memorandum to the White House were described by officials on both sides of the debate over using force in the Balkans.
In her memorandum to the White House, Mrs. Albright argued that Western air attacks would reduce the military threat to the relief effort, slow the supply of arms from Serbia to the Bosnian Serbs and demonstrate American resolve.
While President Clinton has said that he is not prepared to act unilaterally, Mrs. Albright argued in her memorandum that the United States already had sufficient authority to stage air attacks under the United Nations Charter and the Security Council resolution authorizing "all measures necessary" to deliver relief aid.
A spokesman for Mrs. Albright, Robert Nevitt, declined to comment on her memorandum, saying her advice to the President was private.
The petition to Mr. Christopher by 12 State Department specialists is highly unusual. The appeal to the Secretary was signed by the State Department desk officers for Serbia and Montenegro, Bosnia, Albania, Romania, Bulgaria, Macedonia, Croatia, Slovenia, as well as other major officials involved in East European affairs and United States policy at the United Nations.
The drafter of the petition reportedly was Marshall Harris, the Bosnia desk officer. Other signers were Janet Bogue, Eric Rubin, Gordana Earp, Jon Benton, Jim Moriarty, Brady Kiesling, Ellen Conway, Scott Thompson, Drew Mann, John Menzies and Mirta Alvarez.
"It means the frustration level is high enough for them to undertake the somewhat risky tack of going around the normal hierarchy and stating their dissent," said a State Department official, who was not among the petitioners but who had learned about the effort.
"There are few people in State who believe the current policy is useful, consistent with our values, or has any prospect of success," the official said.
Mr. Clinton has been consulting with European allies over a range of options in the Balkan fighting, including lifting the arms embargo to the outgunned Muslim-led Bosnian defenders and air strikes against the Serbian attackers.
The Clinton Administration's debate has been brought to a head by brutal Serbian attacks on Srebrenica, a predominantly Muslim enclave in eastern Bosnia. Under an agreement arranged through the United Nations, a cease-fire has been established, and Bosnian defenders are surrendering their weapons to the United Nations in exchange for a halt in the Serbian shelling of the town.
But some Administration and United Nations officials are concerned that the cease-fire may break down, and that the Serbs plan to press the attack until they sweep the Muslims out of their remaining enclaves in eastern Bosnia in their "ethnic cleansing" campaign.
 
Britain and France Wary
 Britain and France have been wary of military action, fearing that it would lead to retaliation against their troops serving in Bosnia with the United Nations force. But some senior officials, including the NATO Secretary General, Manfred Worner, have said air strikes should be considered.
In the petition to Mr. Christopher, the State Department officials told the Secretary that they believed American policy toward Bosnia has failed.
"Today, Srebrenica is on the verge of falling, in part because we have failed to take forceful action against Bosnian Serb forces," it said, according to officials who have read the document. "We urge you to try to change the course of U.S. policy by advocating the use of military force to save these people and eastern Bosnia from the horrors of Bosnian Serb aggression."
The appeal said that without military intervention, the Bosnian Serbs would realize their goal of creating "an ethnically pure Bosnian state."
 
'Teach Would-Be Conquerors'
 A failure by the United States to take military action "would teach would-be conquerors and ethnic bigots throughout the world that their crimes will go unpunished," the letter said.
Discussing military force, the appeal called for lifting the arms embargo so the Bosnians can arm themselves. It also recommended that American air power be used to protect the Muslims in Srebrenica and urged the Administration to immediately determine whether air strikes alone could be used to destroy or drive back the Serbian forces threatening the Muslims.
As Mr. Clinton has reviewed his options on Bosnia, Pentagon officials have reached conflicting conclusions about the effectiveness of air strikes.
Gen. Colin L. Powell, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, has said he does not believe that air power alone would be decisive in halting the Serbian forces.
 
Aspin's View on Air Attacks
 But Defense Secretary Les Aspin has argued that the Serbian forces may be overrated and that air attacks might be effective in deterring Serbian attacks, Administration officials said.
Administration officials said the arguments by the State Department specialists had been echoed by other ranking officials in private communications to their superiors. But not all State Department officials involved in policy toward Eastern Europe agree with the group's recommendation for military intervention.
Still, the appeal from the State Department specialists, and the support it has received from officials who did not sign it, indicate that there is a schism between Mr. Christopher and his top aides and the key foreign service officers who are directly involved in managing American policy toward the Balkans.
The split is especially striking since Mr. Christopher has made an effort to include longtime Foreign Service officers in dealing with policy matters, unlike the Secretary of State during most of the Bush Administration, James A. Baker, who left many career Foreign Service officers out of key positions.
 
Balkan Update
 A tense standoff continued yesterday in the Muslim enclave of SREBREBICA in eastern Bosnia, with Serbian nationalist commanders saying that United Nations troops had made "a farce" of their effort to disarm the town's Muslim defenders.
In SARAJEVO, the United Nations Commander in BOSNIA, Gen. Philippe Morillon, gave assurances that the town and the United Nations contingent were safe."
In ZAGREB, Lars-Eric Walgren, the commander of United Nations troops in the Balkans, said his troops would use force to defend Srebrenica if it was attacked.
In WASHINGTON, President Clinton's hesitation in the Balkans created a diplomatic fissure in the Administration, with the United Nations Ambassador and State Department Balkan specialists urging the White House to use military force to stop Serbian attacks on Muslim areas.
In BRUSSELS, Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali of the United Nations and a Russian envoy warned against quick military action in Bosnia.
NATO's Secretary General Manfred Worner, said he was ready to back tougher measures against the Serbs, but only they were was supported by the United Nations.
In TUZLA, in Bosnia, as Muslims and Croats continued to fight, President Franjo Tudjman of Croatia urged former Muslim allies "not to be tricked" by the Serbs.
In BANJA LUKA, Bosnia, Serbs said they are preparing their final answer to the world on a peace plan for Bosnia.
In STRASBOURG, France, The European Parliament failed to approve a resolution that would have sanctioned the use of force to stop the war.
And in ATHENS, Lord David Owen, Balkans peace mediator, said he had constructive talks with Prime Minister Constantine Mitsotakis on ways to solve the name dispute between Greece and the former Yugoslav republic of Macedonia.

HEADLINE: Initial Jobless Claims Rise

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 22

 BODY:
The number of Americans filing first-time claims for jobless benefits jumped by 26,000 in mid-April, the first increase in three weeks, the Government said today.
The Labor Department reported that new applications for unemployment insurance totaled 359,000 for the week that ended April 17, up from a revised 333,000 for the previous week. The department originally estimated that claims totaled 335,000 for the week that ended April 10. 
 Many analysts had expected claims to increase by about 14,000 last week, to what economists at Mitsubishi Bank in New York called a "more trendlike reading" after two weekly drops from a weather-related surge in late March.
Claims had dropped to 373,000 for the week that ended April 3 after shooting up by 32,000, to 379,000, for the week ended March 27.
The four-week moving average of jobless claims -- which many analysts track because it smooths out the volatility of the weekly numbers and more accurately reflects the labor situation -- also rose in the latest reporting period. It totaled 361,000, up from 358,000 a week earlier.
The report also said 26,021 applications were filed under a Federal emergency unemployment program for the week that ended April 10, up from 23,498 for the previous week.

HEADLINE: Perot Steps Up Attack on Clinton and Trade Pact

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 22

 BODY:
Sharpening his attacks on the Clinton Administration, Ross Perot told the Senate Banking Committee today that he no longer believed that the North American Free Trade Agreement could be fixed through side agreements, as the Administration plans.
Mr. Perot also said that he would produce at least one and probably several half-hour television commercials criticizing the pact -- and implicitly, Mr. Clinton -- to be broadcast in the coming months. 
 Mr. Perot has emerged as a self-appointed gadfly on the trade pact, chastizing the Administration before Congressional committees. He has emphasized his split with Washington's political establishment by condemning the pact, which is supported by leaders of both parties, and appears to have struck an uneasy alliance with organized labor and conservative advocates of a more self-sufficient economy.
His opposition to the trade pact, and apparent willingness to spend money, threatens to make a daunting political battle even tougher for the White House. Labor and environmental groups have been campaigning against the pact, contending that it would encourage American companies to move factories to Mexico to take advantage of low wages there and to avoid pollution controls in this country.
 
Mounting a Pact Defense
 The Mexican Government and American business groups have responded by hiring at least a dozen lobbying and public-relations firms and preparing advertisements defending the agreement.
At a House Small Business Committee hearing on March 24, Mr. Perot said it might be possible to alter the three-nation pact to his satisfaction. But today he compared the agreement to a worn-out inner tube and said it was not worth patching.
In a brief interview after the hearing last month, Mr. Perot said, "I wanted to leave everybody and the Administration plenty of room."
Asked why he had initially taken one position and then changed it, Mr. Perot replied, "Frankly I was asked to give them plenty of room, and I did, and then I got tired of all you guys saying I wasn't specific."
Mr. Perot refused to say who might have made the request, and the White House refused to comment. But his remarks highlighted the delicacy with which both political parties have been handling him.
 
Warning About Lost Jobs
 The free-trade pact would eliminate import tariffs and other trade barriers between Canada, Mexico and the United States. Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr., the Michigan Democrat who heads the banking committee and scheduled the hearing hearing today, has been the Senate's leading opponent of the pact for the last two years.
Mr. Perot said at the hearing that up to 2.9 million American jobs could be moved to Mexico if the free-trade agreement is approved by Congress.
Anne R. Luzzatto, the press secretary for Mickey Kantor, the United States Trade Representative, said that the Administration believed the pact and three side agreements now under negotiation would "increase jobs for the American people and strengthen the economy."
The political diversity of the free-trade pact's opponents was illustrated by the trade experts who sat with Mr. Perot at the hearing. One was Pat Choate, a conservative critic of the influence of foreign lobbyists. The other was Lori M. Wallach, an aide to the consumer advocate Ralph Nader and a board member of Citizens Trade Campaign, a group of mostly liberal labor, environmental, consumer and religious groups that oppose the pact.
Ms. Wallach said the Citizens Trade Campaign was working with Mr. Perot's volunteers at the state level to oppose the free-trade pact. But she and Jim Jontz, a former Democratic Congressman from Indiana who is now the director of Citizens Trade Campaign, both appeared uncomfortable about being identified too closely with the wealthy Texas businessman and former Presidential candidate.
"There's no relationship, there's no agreement, it's a mutual interest," between the two groups, Mr. Jontz said.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Nintendo's Dominance in Games May Be Waning

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 22

 BODY:
The game may finally be over for Nintendo, which reignited the video game boom in the 1980's and used it to become one of the most profitable companies in Japan.
That, at least, is the view of a growing number of analysts, including some longtime supporters of the Nintendo Company who are suddenly switching their recommendations on the company's stock from "buy" to "sell." 
 There is little prospect that Nintendo will have more years of hyper-growth, they say, explaining that the Kyoto-based company is facing a more saturated market, tougher competition from its archrival, Sega Enterprises, and a seeming inability to define its future technological direction.
 
Recommendations Change
 "I recommended people get out of Nintendo two weeks ago," said Chuck Goto, senior analyst at S. G. Warburg in Tokyo, who until then had been bullish on the company for three years. "I really think the long-term fundamental trend is changing for the company."
David Benda of Barclays de Zoete Wedd Securities shifted his recommendation to sell, from buy, on both Nintendo and Sega a month ago. He expects Nintendo to post revenue and profit growth of only 2 percent in the fiscal year that began this month.
Nintendo, once a manufacturer of playing cards, has been virtually immune to the recession that has sharply cut the profits of nearly every other Japanese electronics company. Revenues for the fiscal year that ended in March are expected to climb 10 percent, to 560 billion yen, or about $5 billion at today's exchange rates. Net income is expected to reach 86 billion yen, or $774 million, up about 1 percent from the previous year.
Nintendo's stock, too, has done relatively well, staying at roughly the 10,000-yen level throughout 1992 as Japan's overall market declined.
But since the beginning of this year, as the overall Tokyo stock market has risen more than 15 percent, Nintendo shares have fallen nearly 11 percent, to 9,560 yen today from 10,600 on Dec. 30.
Analysts do not foresee a collapse of the video game market, like the one that devastated Atari in the mid-1980's But they see the market growing more slowly and becoming subject to more competition. "The cake is getting bigger, but it's getting carved up by more and more people," Mr. Benda said.
The biggest competitor is Sega, based in Tokyo, which is best known for its Sonic the Hedgehog game. While Nintendo is still the market leader by far in Japan, Sega's Genesis machine has drawn roughly even with Nintendo's Super NES in the United States and Europe, analysts say. New competition looms as well, including the threat posed by 3DO, a Silicon Valley start-up.
The competition threatens the core of Nintendo's business, which is software. Outside software companies that develop games for Nintendo machines must allow Nintendo to manufacture the game cartridges. The software companies then buy the cartridges from Nintendo and resell them. This gives Nintendo a profit on each software package and accounts for the company's extremely high profit margins.
 
 
Stronger Alternative
 But with Sega's market share rising, some software companies may desert Nintendo or demand more favorable terms. Capcom, a leading software company known for its Street Fighter II game, has already said it will start developing games for Sega as well.
"I think software companies will start taking back more of their profit," said Mr. Goto of S. G. Warburg. For Nintendo, he said, that means "the fundamental profit-making structure is changed."
Another concern for analysts is that Sega seems to be beating Nintendo technologically. Sega scored its big gains in market share because it was first to market a 16-bit game machine, which offered better images than the 8-bit machine Nintendo was selling.
Sega is also selling a CD-ROM attachment for its Genesis machine, offering games with video images and better sound, while Nintendo has not yet said when it will introduce its CD-ROM player. Sega said this month that it would distribute video games electronically over the cable television systems of the two largest American cable operators, Tele-Communications Inc. and Time Warner.
Nintendo argues that there is no need to rush into risky technological adventures. Company officials say that Sega's cable television distribution venture may not succeed or, if it does, will only anger the company's retail distributors. And Nintendo says there is no need to introduce a CD-ROM attachment until there is good software available for it. A Nintendo official says the company thinks it can keep growing by selling more software to a growing base of machines.
But some analysts say Nintendo risks falling behind if it does not move faster with new technology. "Right now, I think they are lost," said Kaori Hasegawa, an analyst with Salomon Brothers in Tokyo.
She agrees with the company that software sales can continue to propel the company's growth. She expects sales to climb 10 percent and net profits 14 percent, driven in part by a new hit game, Star Fox.
Still, Ms. Hasegawa is placing her stock recommendation on Sega. "Although Nintendo is still a growth company, it will not be a leader in the next generation of games," she said.

HEADLINE: By Pratt & Whitney's Math, Connecticut Costs Too Much

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, April 22

 BODY:
When Pratt & Whitney, Connecticut's largest private employer, said last week that it might have to close most of its state operations, it did more than send a shudder through the state's economy. It put a specific and startling price tag on just how badly Connecticut's business climate is out of step with its competition. 
 The company, which has made aircraft engines here since 1925, says the extent of Connecticut's competitive disadvantage is $6 to $8 an hour. That is how much more the company said it costs to pay a hypothetical middle-level manufacturing worker here, compared with the company's plants in Maine and Georgia. The figure includes fringe benefits, taxes and energy costs.
 
An Expensive Place
 Certainly, it scarcely came as news that Connecticut is an expensive place to do business, or that the state has lost tens of thousands of jobs from companies seeking cheaper havens.
But by putting Connecticut's cost differentials in such a stark light, the company has galvanized the debate over business costs in a way that Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. has not, for all his frenetic efforts to build what he calls "the New Connecticut."
State legislators said pressure immediately increased to pass a bill, now in committee, to overhaul workers' compensation laws. At a hearing today at the Capitol to discuss Pratt & Whitney, the talk centered on specific dollar figures: how the $6 to $8 an hour disadvantage could be reduced. The company has proposed a $2 pay cut for all union members across the board.
"I think we really have some lights going on here," said Peter M. Gioia, director of research for the Connecticut Business and Industry Association, the state's largest business lobby group. "If people do see it for the real crisis it is and react to it, we'll be reducing those cost differentials."
Economists and business experts say that while the company has not opened its books to allow a check of its figures, the findings do not sound exaggerated. What their release has done, primarily, is transform what had been largely a theoretical debate into one of hard numbers.
What the numbers show, the experts say, is the legacy of years and years when holding down costs was simply not a priority -- partly because of the state's long-term dependence on the military, and partly because of regional quirks.
Energy costs in New England, for example, exceed most of the nation's, largely because New England has few power plants and so must import more electricity than it produces.
Higher costs for expenses like workers' compensation, which, according to Pratt & Whitney figures, run about 10 times more than the level per hour in Georgia, are simply the result of a system that started on a more generous footing and stayed that way. The average wage for a manufacturing worker in Connecticut, $513 a week, is about 38 percent higher than in Georgia, where wages average $372.40, according to figures from the Connecticut Business and Industry Association.
The maximum benefits for that worker if injured on the job in Connecticut are about 240 percent higher, at $769 a week, than the $225 that a counterpart would collect in Georgia.
 
The Loss of Cost-Plus
 Perhaps most crucially, economists say, is that companies like Pratt & Whitney thrived in Connecticut so long despite these higher costs because of the Pentagon. Under military procurement rules called cost-plus, local expenses became essentially irrelevant because the price of a product, whether a jet engine or a transistor, was arrived at by taking local production costs and adding the profit margin.
In Pratt & Whitney's case, the loss of military business has been particularly acute. In 1981, for example, the company built 1,700 jet engines, about half of which were under the cost-plus system for the military. This year, it will produce fewer than 600 engines, with perhaps only 80 going to the military.
With high-tech centers growing up in formerly low-skill states like Georgia and the old high-profit cost-plus system of military contracts drying up with the end of the cold war, Connecticut's higher costs -- hidden by years of prosperity and Pentagon accounting -- have been exposed as never before.
Industry analysts who follow Pratt & Whitney and its parent company, United Technologies, say that the Maine and Georgia plants, both nonunion shops, are also newer and rely more on labor-saving devices like robots than the older Connecticut plants. About 2,500 people work in Pratt & Whitney's plant in Columbus, Ga., and North Berwick, Me., compared with 17,000 in Connecticut.
As a rule, the newer factories have younger workers. Once, seniority and experience might have been in Connecticut's favor, but now that no longer seems to be the case.
"Age might have been an advantage in days when things were less computer driven, but not now," said John W. Adams, an analyst at Adams Harkness, a securities firm in Boston.
Connecticut still has the highest proportion of college graduates in the nation, as well as the highest proportion of technical workers in such areas as electronics, optics and aerospace, according to DRI/McGraw-Hill of Lexington, Mass., an economic consulting firm.
But other states, notably Georgia, are gaining fast. Over the last decade, Georgia had the third-highest rate of growth in high-technology jobs in the nation, at 6 percent a year, said Sara Johnson, a regional economist at DRI/McGraw-Hill. Connecticut, meanwhile, had the nation's third-worst record, a decline of 0.6 percent a year in its high-tech work force.
If Pratt & Whitney's previously announced layoffs take place this year, Ms. Johnson said, Connecticut will very likely lose its first-place ranking in technical workers. The company said that it expects that by New Year's Day 1995 it will employ at least 6,700 fewer workers in Connecticut than it did at the beginning of 1993.

HEADLINE: Officers Cleared in Slaying of Fleeing Man

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI

 BODY:
A Manhattan grand jury has voted not to indict two police officers in the fatal shooting of an armed man who ran from the scene of a brawl outside a 24-hour diner last month, the Manhattan District Attorney's office said yesterday.
The man, Bekim Ahmeti, 20, of 83 Continental Place in Mariners Harbor on Staten Island, was struck by four bullets -- one in the hand and three in the back of his body -- as he ran from the front of the Moonstruck Diner at 23d Street and Ninth Avenue in Manhattan at 5 A.M. March 20. 
 On the day of the shooting, a police account said Mr. Ahmeti, an unemployed doorman, had been shot in the chest and abdomen. But the following day an autopsy contradicted that account.
 
Assumptions Offered
 The chief of the District Attorney's trial division, Nancy Ryan, said yesterday that the grand jury apparently decided not to indict the officers -- Lieut. Michael Herer, 37, and Officer Joseph Dalton, 32 -- because "There was independent civilian evidence in this case that the deceased did, in fact, have a gun and that as he was running across the street he pulled his gun out and that he was turning in the direction of police officers." A .38-caliber revolver was found in Mr. Ahmeti's possession.
Asked how Mr. Ahmeti could have been struck in the back if he was turning toward the police, Ms. Ryan said she could only "assume what inferences the grand jury drew from the evidence," but that "there were officers at various positions all along the street, and the ones who hit him, one could deduce, were located at some point behind him."
Of the four bullets that struck Mr. Ahmeti, Ms. Ryan said: "One of those was actually in his right side, slightly to the rear. There was another gunshot wound to one of his hands, and then there was one wound above the left buttock and one above the right buttock."
Told of the grand jury's decision yesterday, a lawyer hired by Mr. Ahmeti's family, David Breibart, said: "You're kidding. Three bullets in the back and no indictment?
"The witnesses that we've spoken to, many of whom were called into the grand jury, gave us no indication whatsoever that they saw him pull a gun," Mr. Breibart said. "They saw the cops shoot him down in the middle of the street as he was running away." Mr. Breibart said he intended to file a civil suit against the city and the officers.
 
Brother Is Angry
 Mr. Ahmeti's brother, Shkelzen, 24, said the grand jury's decision would devastate their parents. "They murdered my baby brother," Mr. Ahmeti said. "All the witnesses, his friends, even two other women who were not with him, said they saw him with no gun. This is a whitewash."
A Police Department spokesman, Officer Andrew McInnis, saying the department had not received official notification of the grand jury's decision, declined to comment on it last night. Departmental guidelines say an officer can use deadly force to stop a fleeing felon only under certain circumstances, including when the officer has probable cause to believe that a suspect is armed with a deadly weapon.
The day after the shooting, Suzanne Trazoff, the Deputy Commissioner for Public Information, said Mr. Ahmeti might have run from the officers because he was on probation on a gun charge and did not want to be caught with the pistol, which was unlicensed. In February 1992, Mr. Ahmeti pleaded guilty to criminal possession of a deadly weapon after his arrest for shooting at some bus shelters on Staten Island. He received five years' probation.

HEADLINE: Environmental Group Assails Electricity Deal With Quebec

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
Environmentalists in New York State and Quebec are trying to block renewal of a contract in which Consolidated Edison buys hydroelectricity from Quebec every summer, saying the deal helps finance dams that are destroying how Indians around James Bay live.
The environmentalists have proposed that instead of renewing the 15-year-old contract, New York should help Quebec use its electricity more efficiently. By doing so, they argue, New York would be able to buy the power saved and Hydro-Quebec, the utility owned by the Quebec government, would not have to build more dams. 
 But Hydro-Quebec, which is selling the power to New York, disputes the idea that the sales contracts have much relevance to its plans to build the dams in the sub-Arctic, hundreds of miles north of Montreal.
At the same time, company officials insist that the utility is already doing all it can to improve efficiency and is expected to spend $3 billion (Canadian) for energy efficiency programs over this decade.
"It's kind of cynical for someone consuming more energy to say there's something wrong here," Jacques Guevremont, a Hydro-Quebec official who has negotiated several purchase and sale contracts, said of environmentalists in New York.
 
Lawsuit Is Filed
 In another effort to block the sale of the power, a suit was filed yesterday in Federal District Court in New York City, challenging the legality of the New York Power Authority's agreement with Quebec. The suit was filed by two New York Congressmen, the Grand Council of the Cree Indians, individual citizens of New York and Vermont and several citizens' groups. The Congressmen, Maurice D. Hinchey, Democrat of upstate New York, and Jerrold Nadler, Democrat of Manhattan, argue that the contract violates Article 1 of the Constitution, which forbids agreements between states and foreign governments unless authorized by Congress.
At the heart of the dispute are the lands that the Inuits and the Cree Indians have hunted and fished for thousands of years.
Environmentalists say that the hunting land in the James Bay area would eventually be flooded after new dams are built while fish would be tainted by mercury bleeding into the area from rocks in the area of the dam.
They also say that the wholesale price of electricity has fallen and demand has dropped, creating less of a need for the new dams. The environmentalists won a battle last year when Gov. Mario M. Cuomo rejected a deal that would have allowed New York to buy 1,000 megawatts of new electricity year-round from Hydro-Quebec.
 
'No Time for the Land to Heal'
 Matthew Coon-Come, Grand Chief of the Cree, pleaded his case last week at a news conference at the Natural Resources Defense Council headquarters in New York. "We have no time to adapt, we have no time for the land to heal," he said. "There's no way they'd be allowed to build a project of this magnitude down south."
Ashokh Guptah, an energy expert on the resources council, said New York could better help Quebec by encouraging greater efficiency there, which would allow for a "conservation transfer."
Energy efficiency programs are in place in many states, including New York, to cut the need for new construction, but the money is generally spent in that state.
Because electricity costs three times as much in New York as in Montreal, Mr. Guptah said, New York can afford to spend far more on conservation. New York could then buy the saved energy from Hydro-Quebec, which would not have to build the dams and risk damaging the environment.
 
Environmental Studies Begun
 But officials at Hydro-Quebec said the dams will not cause substantial damage. The utility, which has offered various benefits to the Indians including cash, public works programs and some jobs, has begun a variety of environmental studies.
Meanwhile, the New York Power Authority, which would buy 800 megawatts and sell 20 to Rochester Gas and Electric Corporation, with the rest going to Con Edison, has asserted that the contract was economical and would cut air pollution in this country by reducing the need to burn fossil fuels.
Stephen Shoenholz, a spokesman for the authority, said that the price to Con Ed could fall to 4.3 cents a kilowatt-hour. Con Ed's other sources of power range substantially in price. It sells electricity to homeowners for nearly 14 cents a kilowatt-hour in summer.
The existing 15-year-old contract expires in 1998, and the renewal would pick up the next year and run through 2018. While the terms of the renewal have already been negotiated, the contract has an escape clause that allows either side to cancel between November of this year and November of 1994 if all the necessary regulatory approvals cannot be obtained.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
BANKAMERICA CORP. (N)

 BODY:
The BankAmerica Corporation reported a 60 percent rise in its first-quarter earnings, largely reflecting its acquisition of the Security Pacific Corporation last April. Its net income of $484 million included a $12 million charge from accounting changes related to employee benefits.
Still, BankAmerica, which has been plagued by the depressed California economy, is one of the few big banks to report earnings below analysts' expectations. Net interest income from loans and investments at the nation's second-largest banking company fell 5 percent for the quarter, partly as a result of a modest decrease in loans and interest payments from Brazil in the previous period. Its trading revenue increased while its fees and commissions fell. 
 BankAmerica's portfolio of assets that it intends to sell declined by 30 percent, to $2.6 billion, for the quarter. The bank plans to sell real estate assets carried on its books at $723 million to a partnership controlled by Morgan Stanley. Credit losses during the first quarter declined by 40 percent from the fourth quarter, to $303 million. BankAmerica's profitability was modest, with a return on equity of 13.6 percent, down from 16 percent for the period a year earlier.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Ad executives hear an impassioned warning against selling brands solely on their price.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

DATELINE: LAGUNA NIQUEL, Calif.

 BODY:
THE program for yesterday's general session of the 75th annual meeting of the American Association of Advertising Agencies resembled nothing so much as auditions for a revival of "The Music Man" to play on Madison Avenue rather than Broadway.
The three speakers -- who seemed to be trying out for the Robert Preston role of Harold Hill, that consummate charismatic salesman -- alternately cajoled, flattered, provoked and exhorted the audience at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel here with rhythmic cadences and alliterative phrases. 
 But in their versions of "Trouble," the pool-hall evils of River City, Iowa, were replaced by the menace that products sold solely on price posed to America's leading marketers of name-brand goods.
"The recession is not over, at least so far as consumers are concerned," warned James A. Taylor, managing partner and chief executive of Yankelovich Partners, a marketing and consumer research company in Westport, Conn. "They believe they are facing difficult times and they expect that to continue."
Exacerbating that threat to higher-priced brands, he added, is the "overchoice" that consumers perceive confronts them when staring at supermarket shelves.
Since "consumers are frustrated with the number of choices they're asked to consider when making the most trivial purchases," like gum, Mr. Taylor said, "they're opting for the simplest answer: the cheapest brand in the category."
Such behavior patterns, which Mr. Taylor called a manifestation of consumers' "downward nobility" of the 1990's, are reinforced by a growing willingness to consider retailers as "brand editors," he said. "They choose to believe the merchant understands their need better than the manufacturer."
Even worse, said Watts Wacker, managing partner and executive vice president at Yankelovich, "the only things consumers would like to have regulated more than advertising are things that will kill you," like hazardous waste.
That attitude results from "the accumulated impact of a lifetime of consumption," he added, which has produced a cynical market in which "there are no virgin consumers."
Larry Light, president of the Arcature Corporation, a marketing consulting company in Stamford, Conn., was the most emotional of the three would-be Harold Hills, blasting the growing obsession with selling a brand on its price instead of its image, benefits or performance.
"Brands do not have to die," he said. "But they can be murdered. And the marketing Draculas are draining the very lifeblood away from brands."
"Brands are being bargained, belittled, bartered and battered," he added, unleashing a torrent of B-words that caused the audience to buzz. "Market leadership can be bought through bribes. But enduring, profitable market leadership must be earned through building both brand value and volume."
"You do not build brand value by saying how cheap you are," he said. "You do build brand value by reinforcing how special you are."
A primary purpose of Mr. Light's speech was to proselytize for the Coalition for Brand Equity, an organization he heads as chairman. The coalition was formed last year by the Four A's, as the organization is known, the Association of National Advertisers and six media trade association.
"The enemies of brands have many guns in their arsenals," Mr. Light said, "but the builders of brands have not yet begun to fight."
He grew so emotional that not only did he declare at one point, "Thank God for the Coalition for Brand Equity," he appeared to choke up at the end of his address, when he said, "I plead with you" to make the coalition's mission "your mission."
All three speakers, like Harold Hill, offered the audience hope amid the gloom and doom. After all, as Mr. Taylor noted, "This is the year Charlie Brown hit a home run and won a ball game," referring to the uncharacteristic heroics of the "Peanuts" comic strip character.
Mr. Wacker stressed that advertising had an opportunity to help consumers who, as they increasingly declare themselves to be in charge of their own lives, are "looking for someone to delegate to, to edit what they need to know."
He cited advertisers that are successful in providing customers with "mastery of the basics," like Stouffer's Frozen Foods, with "consistency," like McDonald's, and those that are "fixing mistakes," like Saturn.
Mr. Light shared what he called "the best news of all: the consumer is on our side."
"In a world where trust is in trouble, consumers are looking for people, institutions, companies, retailers and even brands they can trust," he said. "They want reliable, dependable, trustworthy brand relationships. They want exactly what you should provide."
The meeting continues here through tomorrow.
