HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Long Bond Yield 6.75% for Third Day

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The yield on the 30-year bond remained at 6.75 percent for the third day in a row yesterday with most of the trading action in shorter maturities.
The price of the 30-year bond fell 1/32 , to 10428/32 . The prices of Treasury notes rose from 4/32 for the seven- year note to 1/32 for the two-year note. The price of the 10-year note was unchanged. 
 Traders said the lowering of short-term interest rates in Germany did not have a major impact on bond trading. But they said that the fall of the dollar to its 11th record daily low against the yen in the last 16 trading days did lead to comments from the Japanese that helped send bond prices lower in foreign trading.
 
Effect of Stimulus Defeat
 There seemed to be little response to the fact that President Clinton's $16 billion economic stimulus program had been defeated by the Republican minority in the Senate. That could have been viewed as a positive for the market because bond traders had been worried that the stimulus program could push the economy ahead too quickly, igniting inflation.
But some traders suggested that the defeat might have made some investors think that getting the President's budget and deficit reduction plan approved would be more difficult. If this becomes the case, that would be a negative because it appears that some of the recent decline in interest rates has been based on the expectation that Mr. Clinton's deficit reduction program would be successful.
Prices and yields moved up and down sharply during the day, adding a lot of volatility to the trading. But they ended little changed as traders and investors seemed to be waiting for signs to give the market a new direction.
"We're really in a holding pattern until we get some more economic data to see how fast the economy is moving along and find out exactly what Mr. Bentsen's definition of radical is," said Lawrence N. Leuzzi, head of fixed income at S. G. Warburg & Company. He was referring to Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen's promise, repeated again yesterday, that the Treasury would not make any change in its borrowing mix that would make a "radical" shift from long-term to shorter-term borrowing.
Speculation that the 30-year bond auction in May may be skipped as part of the shift to shorter-term borrowing addressed by Secretary Bentsen has been running through the market.
 
Awaiting the Data
 The new economic data Mr. Leuzzi is looking to are needed so that investors and traders can decide how quickly the economy is growing. The reports for March have shown a sharp slowdown, but because much of that was caused by bad weather, there is doubt about the pace of growth.
If the April data signal slow growth again, prices of Treasury notes and bonds could move higher because there will be more confidence that inflation is going to remain in check. But signs that the slow March was only a blip could unsettle a market that is still just off its highs for the year in prices and lows in yields.
Yesterday's report that initial jobless claims rose by 26,000, to 359,000 in mid-April, did not have a major impact, although the jump was more than predicted in many forecasts.
In the morning, prices of the 30-year bond and Treasury notes fell as their was talk of a major selling, which made some decide that the market had finally reached the top. Overnight, bond and note prices weakened and yields rose as a Japanese official said that the fall of the yen against the dollar could lead to higher prices in the United States and maybe even force some Japanese investors to sell some of their Treasury securities, especially the 30-year bond.
 
Buying of Treasury Notes
 But by later in the day, prices had rebounded, in part because there were reports that the Federal Reserve was buying Treasury notes, most likely for foreign central banks.
Treasury notes were also aided, traders said, from buying by state and local governments. These governments do the buying as part of the process of paying off older higher interest rate debt. The Treasury securities are bought with new lower-interest debt and put into an escrow account to guarantee the payments on the old debt.
Daniel Callahan, a managing director in charge of government securities at Paine Webber, said that this buying of Treasury notes by state and local governments had made the intermediate sector of Treasury securities the leader of the market recently, a role usually held by the 30-year bond.
"Watching the bond is the wrong story," he said.
He noted that yesterday, the current 3.875 percent two-year note, which was auctioned last month, was at its highest price since it was auctioned.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Broadly Lower, Despite German Rate Cuts

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Inaccurate news reports that Germany's central bank failed to cut interest rates touched off sharp swings in the dollar yesterday and misled many traders into money-losing transactions.
The reports early in the New York session were quickly corrected to show that the Bundesbank's policy-making council in fact had cut two key short-term rates. But market participants said many currency traders suffered significant losses because they initially sold dollars when they should have been buying. 
 Despite the rate cuts, the dollar ended broadly lower, dragged down by further appreciation in the Japanese yen.
Gold was mostly higher. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery edged up 50 cents a troy ounce to $340. The Republic National Bank quoted a late bid of $339.60 a troy ounce, up 35 cents.
The false news that the Bundesbank's policy-making council had decided to hold the line on interest rates caused the dollar to fall about half a pfennig, to 1.5940 marks.
Shortly after, the corrected news came out that the Bundesbank's policy-making council lowered the discount rate to 7.25 percent from 7.5 percent, and the Lombard rate to 8.5 percent from 9 percent. Lower German interest rates make dollar-denominated investments more attractive.
 
'Blood on the Street'
 Traders scrambled to buy dollars, and the United States currency swiftly shot up about 2 pfennigs, to 1.6135 marks.
"There's plenty of blood in the street," a currency trader in New York said.
However, the dollar gradually retreated against major world currencies as the Japanese yen continued to march higher, mostly undeterred by reports of further interventions by the Bank of Japan during Tokyo trading.
The yen's advance was encouraged by new remarks by world leaders expressing support for the yen's increase as a way to reduce Japan's bulging trade surplus.
In addition, the market took another look at the German rate cuts and decided they were largely expected, analysts said.
"We came back off because the market isn't really overwhelmed by the fact the Bundesbank cut 25 basis points on the discount rate," said Randolph Donney, research director at Pegasus Econometric Group, in Hoboken, N.J.

HEADLINE: Germany Cuts Two Key Rates

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BONN, April 22

 BODY:
Answering calls from France and elsewhere to try to stimulate the sagging European economy, the German central bank again lowered two of its key interest rates today amid signs that Germany's recession had worsened substantially in recent months.
Symbolically at least, the Bundesbank's rate cuts, the second round in about a month, amounted to a German gesture of economic solidarity with France, its most important European partner, whose new Government has been bringing down its own interest rates and calling for the Bundesbank to cut its rates further. 
 The bank reduced the discount rate, the interest rate it charges commercial banks for short-term loans, to 7.25 percent from 7.5 percent. The bank, which is not obliged to take instructions from the German Government, also cut a second important indicator, the Lombard rate, which sets a ceiling on money-market interest paid, to 8.5 percent from 9 percent.
 
Others Follow Cuts
 Long-term German interest rates have fallen to as low as 6.5 percent for some public issues.
The cuts are intended to stimulate economic growth by making it easier for German businesses to borrow money and for the authorities in other countries whose currencies are tied to the mark in the European Monetary System to cut rates, too. Belgium, Denmark, Italy and the Netherlands all announced small reductions this afternoon.
Despite the rate cuts, the dollar ended broadly lower, dragged down by further appreciation of the Japanese yen. [Page D15.]
The bank's announcement after its meeting in Frankfurt came amid a flood of bad economic news. German officials quietly told news organizations that their economy, the engine of European growth, might shrink by as much as 2 percent this year. Last year, according to a Dun & Bradstreet study, 210,000 enterprises went bankrupt all over Europe -- some 57,600 in France, more than 62,700 in Britain and almost 10,000 in western Germany, in the most severe European recession since the early 1970's.
Mercedes-Benz A.G. announced that it had sold 32 percent fewer cars in the first three months of this year than during the corresponding period in 1992, and the German Economics Ministry conceded that pessimism in German industry was growing deeper. Faced with declining tax revenues, the German federal budget deficit could rise to as much as $43 billion this year, twice as much as expected, officials said.
The central bank announced that it had taken cautious action on interest rates after the new French Prime Minister, Edouard Balladur, had completed his first visit with Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany. Mr. Kohl said that he and Mr. Balladur had discussed interest rates during lunch in the Chancellor's office, and that on the whole, the Bundesbank's cautious steps to reduce rates gradually over the last few months had been "positive."
In Washington, Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen said the United States welcomed the German move on interest rates.
Whether Mr. Kohl had pressed the French Prime Minister on trade issues as much as Britain and the United States would like was not clear. At a news conference, both men said they had agreed on the need to resolve the remaining issues holding up an agreement on global tariffs and trade as soon as possible.
"We all need GATT, but it requires readiness for compromise," Mr. Kohl said. Mr. Balladur said he hoped Germany would understand French concerns about agriculture. French rejection of a European compromise with the United States on agricultural subsidies prevented completion of an accord last year.
The Bundesbank's president, Helmut Schlesinger, said today that he expected to be criticized for not taking stronger action, but that continuing inflation and labor demands in eastern Germany for wage increases had forced the bank to continue its caution.
"Instead of setting clear investment signals with courageous interest rate reductions, the Bundesbank is prolonging the recession by its stubborn policy of tiny little steps," said Wolfgang Roth, a spokesman for the Social Democratic opposition.
Mr. Kohl's Finance Minister, Theo Waigel, welcomed the Bundesbank's step as a move toward renewed economic growth.
Mr. Schlesinger said in an interview two weeks ago that the bank would continue reducing interest rates as it saw "maneuvering room" opening up, but only in gradual steps that would not undermine the credibility of its anti-inflation policies or the exchange rate of the mark on European currency markets.
"It's been at best a snail's pace," said Irgeen Rust, an economist with the Westdeutsche Landesbank Girozentrale in Dusseldorf, speaking of the central bank's movement.
German inflation is running at 4.2 percent, higher than the Bundesbank would like. "If the economy is in such bad shape, you can't be worried about 4 percent inflation in the short term," Ms. Rust said.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
CATERPILLAR INC. (N)

 BODY:
Caterpillar Inc. reported first-quarter earnings yesterday that were much better than expected, as the heavy-equipment maker reversed a loss from a year earlier.
The company, based in Peoria, Ill., said the turnaround was a result of a 19 percent increase in sales, especially in the United States; a buildup in dealer inventories; higher prices charged for its products, and lower costs for wages and benefits. 
 "It was a blow-out quarter" for Caterpillar, said Tobias M. Levkovich, an analyst at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company in New York.
Caterpillar said that it expected all of 1993 to be profitable, but that the results would be dependent on the severity and duration of the recession in Europe, political and economic conditions in Brazil, and the strength of the American economy.
"We still have a long ways to go," said Len Kuchan, director of investor relations. "The U.S. economy is still improving, but it is in relatively early states of recovery."
Labor worries also hang over the company. While Caterpillar and the United Auto Workers ended a strike in April 1992, the two sides have yet to sign a new contract.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Mariners' Bosio Tosses No-Hitter

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:

Mariners 7, Red Sox 0
Chris Bosio of the Seattle Mariners pitched the first no-hitter of the season last night -- a 7-0 victory over the Boston Red Sox at the Kingdome. Bosio, signed as a free agent after going 16-6 with Milwaukee last season, walked the first two batters of the game. He then went on to pitch the second no-hitter in the history of the Mariners' franchise.
The 30-year-old right-hander got several outstanding defensive plays from his infielders, including the last out when shortstop Omar Vizquel barehanded a chopper by Ernest Riles behind the mound. The last time Boston was no-hit was by New York's Dave Righetti on July 4, 1983, at Yankee Stadium. 
 With the crowd of 13,604 standing for the ninth inning, John Valetin led off with a routine grounder to short. Tony Pena then hit an easy grounder to third for the second out.
Bosio then got his no-hitter when Riles hit a slow grounder over the mound. Vizquel made a barehanded pickup as the ball bounced off the turf and his running throw nabbed Riles by two steps. The Mariners mobbed Bosio after the final out, the crowd cheering for several minutes.
Bosio's performance was all the more remarkable considering he was pitching on three days' rest. "That turned out to be good," Bosio said, and then referred to his manager, Lou Piniella. "At the beginning of the season I told Lou he could move me up if he wanted to because I've done it before. But this was last thing that I ever expected."
Bosio (1-1) got out of a jam in the first inning after walking Riles and Carlos Quintana to start the game. He got Mike Greenwell to hit into a double play and then, with Riles at third base, struck out Andre Dawson swinging. Bosio walked two and struck out four for his ninth career shutout.
He got an outstanding play from first baseman Tino Martinez in the third inning. Martinez fielded Riles's hard-hit ball on his knees and then threw to the pitcher to get the out.
Bosio pitched his no-hitter in his fourth start for the Mariners. He pitched two two-hitters for Milwaukee -- in 1987 and 1991. His gem came after Randy Johnson, who pitched Seattle's first no-hitter on June 2, 1990, against Detroit, beat the Red Sox, 5-0, on a four-hitter Wednesday night. Bosio threw 97 pitches, 60 for strikes.
 
Twins 5, Brewers 4
 A year ago, Jim Deshaies was unemployed, hanging out at the Milwaukee Brewers' extended spring training camp in Ahwatukee, Ariz., and hoping to catch a break. Yesterday afternoon, he showed the Brewers -- and every other big-league team -- what they could have had for next to nothing by pitching Minnesota to the victory over visiting Milwaukee.
Deshaies (4-0), the majors' first four-game winner, allowed five hits and two runs in six and two-thirds innings. The Twins scored two eighth-inning runs off Bill Wegman (1-3). And they needed them when Rick Aguilera gave up two ninth-inning runs before nailing down his fifth save.
 
 
Blue Jays 6, Royals 3
 David Cone, an $18 million free agent, dropped to 0-4 as a rookie, Pat Hentgen, pitched four-hit ball for eight innings to help Toronto beat the Royals at Kansas City. John Olerud and Paul Molitor each drove in two runs for the Blue Jays.
 
 
Angels 8, Indians 0
 The rookie J. T. Snow homered twice, giving him four in his last three games, and Chuck Finley pitched a two-hitter at home as California beat Cleveland. The victory gave the Angels a three-game sweep of the Indians.
 
 
White Sox 3, Orioles 2
 Chicago scored two ninth-inning runs on an error by center fielder Mike Devereaux and beat Baltimore at Camden Yards.
Gregg Olson (0-1) started the ninth by giving up singles to Robin Ventura and Bo Jackson. Ellis Burks, running for Jackson, moved to second on a wild pitch. Both runners then scored when Devereaux couldn't handle Dan Pasqua's liner to center. Pasqua was credited with a sacrifice fly.
 
Marlins 4, Braves 3
 Catcher Benito Santiago retrieved a bouncing pitch and tagged Otis Nixon out at the plate as he tried to score the tying run with two outs in the ninth, preserving Florida's home victory over Atlanta.
Trailing, 4-2, entering the ninth, the Braves made it 4-3 on Jeff Blauser's sacrifice fly off Bryan Harvey. After a stolen base and a walk, Harvey threw a 1-2 pitch in the dirt to Terry Pendleton that got a few feet behind Santiago. But he ran down the ball, lunged toward the plate and tagged out a sliding Nixon with his bare hand.
 
Pirates 5, Reds 4
 John Smiley had a rough return to Pittsburgh, allowing five runs in five and two-thirds innings as the Pirates rallied from a three-run Cincinnati first inning to beat the Reds. Just one night after reliever Rob Dibble fractured his left arm in a home-plate collision, the Reds lost outfielders Roberto Kelly and Kevin Mitchell with pulled hamstrings. Kelly left in the first inning and Mitchell in the fourth, and both are listed as day to day.
Tim Wakefield (2-2) pitched the Pirates' first complete game of the season, despite walking nine. The knuckleballer has walked 25 in 29 innings. It was the second time this season he has walked nine in a game.
 
Expos 3, Dodgers 1
 Darrin Fletcher and Wil Cordero hit run-scoring doubles in the eighth inning as Montreal beat visiting Los Angeles. With the score tied, 1-1, Larry Walker hit a one-out single off Orel Hershiser (2-2) and scored the go-ahead run on a double by Fletcher. Cordero then added his run-scoring double.
 
 
Padres 2, Phillies 1
 Andy Benes gave up one run in eight and two-thirds innings for his third straight victory and Bob Geren hit his first major-league home run since 1991, leading San Diego Padres past Philadelphia at Veterans Stadium.
 
 
Cardinals 5, Rockies 2
 Todd Zeile broke a 2-2 tie with a run-scoring single to highlight a three-run eighth inning as St. Louis beat Colorado at home. Ray Lankford led off the eighth with a triple off Gary Wayne (0-2). Zeile then lined a 3-0 pitch from Jeff Parrett for his second hit of the day. Tom Pagnozzi added a run-scoring single and Jose Oquendo squeezed home a run later in the inning.

HEADLINE: The Art Market

BYLINE: By Carol Vogel

 BODY:

Double Dutch
The Metropolitan Museum of Art came this close to making an important purchase recently.
The museum reached an agreement several weeks ago, people in the art world say, to pay $2.3 million for an 18th-century still life of flowers by the Dutch painter Jan van Huysum. The painting had hung for decades at Sudeley Castle, a stately home in Gloucestershire, England, owned by Lord and Lady Ashcombe. But at the last minute, in a move that surprised many experts, the Metropolitan changed its mind. 
 After the purchase had been approved by the museum's acquisitions committee, the Met's curators discovered that what is probably the original version of the work was hanging in the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston. This raised questions about the painting the Met was on the verge of buying: Was it a duplicate painted by van Huysum himself? Or a copy by another artist? Or was it even a fake?
It's not as though the Museum of Fine Arts had kept its van Huysum a secret. A photograph of the still life appears in the museum's catalogue of its collection as well as in a book of its masterpieces.
But somehow, judging by reports from in and outside the museum, neither of the curators involved in the Met's transaction -- neither Everett Fahy, who heads the Metropolitan's department of European paintings and who was the painting's original and principal supporter, nor Walter Liedtke, a curator in Mr. Fahy's department who is in charge of Dutch paintings -- were aware of Boston's possession, which is regularly on view in the paintings galleries at that museum.
Nor did they find out about it during several months in which the Sudeley Castle picture was at the Metropolitan, ostensibly to be scrutinized and researched by the Met's staff. The discovery was made only after Otto Naumann, a New York-based Old Master paintings expert, heard about the pending purchase and called Mr. Liedtke to tell him of the existence of the identical van Huysum.
What followed has been two weeks of scrambling by the Met, by Richard L. Feigen, the New York art dealer who was acting as the agent for the trustees of Sudeley Castle, and by art experts on all sides. Fingers have been pointed privately in all directions, not only at the Met's curators for not knowing about the existence of a similar picture in a nearby major museum, but also at Mr. Feigen, since dealers usually supply detailed information about what they sell. But Mr. Feigen, who says he was acting only as a middleman here, says he did not know about the Boston picture either.
 
The Experts Are Puzzled
 So far, the experts trying to agree on what the Sudeley Castle painting actually is have reached no consensus.
Mr. Feigen says he is waiting for Sam Segal, a renowned expert on Dutch paintings, to examine the two works side by side to see what the true story is. Because of poor health, Mr. Segal has not been able to travel for the last three weeks, Mr. Feigen said. But experts in Mr. Feigen's office, he said, have flown to Boston to view the work at the museum there and believe that the Sudeley Castle van Huysum is authentic. "It appears likely that this is simply another version by van Huysum," he said. "While the composition of the flowers is identical, there are slight differences in color; therefore it's not an exact copy. But until the two pictures are studied side by side, the whole thing is up in the air."
Peter C. Sutton, the Baker curator of European paintings at the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston, disagrees. "I think it's a copy," he said in a recent telephone interview, referring to the Sudeley version. "There aren't any changes or adjustments, which are what is normally found in an authentic painting."
Mr. Sutton said that he had not seen the two works side by side, but that he had compared detailed photographs of the one the Metropolitan was considering with the van Huysum in Boston. "Our signature is subtler," he said.
Mr. Sutton called the painting the Metropolitan wanted to buy "an astonishingly high-quality studio work." But connoisseurship is a tricky business, he warned: "This kind of thing happens, but it's usually caught earlier."
 
'Our System Works'
 Experts at the Metropolitan, however, refuse to discuss the question of authenticity. Indeed, the Metropolitan does not wish to talk about the incident at all. At the museum's request, neither Mr. Fahy nor Mr. Liedtke would discuss the painting. Philippe de Montebello, the Metropolitan's director, would say only: "The Met had thought about buying the picture but changed its mind. These things happen all the time. It shows that our system works."
Mr. de Montebello added that while the acquisitions committee, which meets four times a year, had approved the purchase, such approvals are "conditional and preliminary." He added, "Our trustees often authorize things, but it's always pending further study."
If the museum had bought the painting, Mr. de Montebello said, the money would have come from the museum's general acquisitions fund.
 
The Situation: Sticky
 Mr. Feigen, who thought the deal was done, is in a sticky position. "I've never encountered anything like this in my 36 years in the art business," he said. "It's amazing the Met didn't know. They had three and a half months to study it. I'm just acting as the agent. Had I been selling the picture directly, I would have had my research department study the work carefully."
Mr. Feigen said that when the picture arrived in the United States, it was terribly dirty, so dirty in fact that the signature was not even visible. So the dealer hired Nancy Krieg, a Manhattan-based restorer, to clean the work. Ms. Krieg said that at the time it had not occurred to her that there might be a problem. "There was nothing to set off alarm bells," she said. "The signature seemed correct and normal for an 18th-century painting. None of the pigments struck me as being out of sync." After it was cleaned, the painting was taken to the Metropolitan on Jan. 21.
"The fact that they did not know there was another version is an embarrassing mistake," said Mr. Feigen. "The Met backed out because they can't have a version of a picture that is in a sister museum only one hour away."
 
The Modern's Massive Gift
 Ronald Lauder has just bought "Intersection II," Richard Serra's monumental new sculpture, as a gift to the Museum of Modern Art. But until the museum finds a secondary exhibition space that can accommodate contemporary art of such an enormous scale, as it is eagerly trying to do, the Modern has no place to put it. "It will go in storage temporarily," said Mr. Lauder, who is a member of the Modern's board of trustees. "I think this is the most important sculpture of the last decade and felt there was only one place in the world for it and that's the Museum of Modern Art." Mr. Lauder is reported to have paid just under $1 million for the work, which was on view at the Gagosian Gallery in SoHo.
The sculpture is gigantic -- it is made of four 2-inch-thick gentle curves of hot-rolled steel, each 55 feet long and more than 13 feet high -- and weighs a total of 240,000 pounds. The work had been on view for five weeks at the Gagosian Gallery, a renovated garage on Wooster Street, where it barely fit into the ground-floor space. The sculpture was dismantled this week.
If the Modern tried to put it in the West 53d Street building, the only conceivable space for it would be the third-floor East Wing gallery. "It would clear the ceiling by less than a foot," said Kirk Varnedoe, the director of the department of painting and sculpture at the museum. "I've looked into engineering studies and am not sure if the floor could bear the load or how it could be rigged. But it will be one of the crowning glories of a different space for the Modern." Mr. Varnedoe added that putting it in the Modern's sculpture garden was out of the question since it would overpower other works already in place. Besides, both the curator and Mr. Lauder say they feel strongly that such a piece should only be shown indoors. "The power of it is the tension between the curves within the confinement of walls," Mr. Lauder said.
The gift is a very important acquisition for the Modern. "Getting a masterpiece like this would not have been possible were this not a promised gift," said Agnes Gund, the Modern's president. Ms. Gund added that finding an alternative exhibition space for the museum is "not just a dream on paper."
"We're working hard to find an off-site space," she said. "The curators, the trustees and friends of the museum are keen to find a space that will make sense for the 21st century. It will be something that won't be just an extension of the museum but a re-invention."
 
Christie's Expands
 Christie's is going retail, sort of. The London-based holding company of the auction house announced this week that it had bought Spink & Son, the 327-year-old antiques gallery on King Street adjoining the Christie's London premises. Christie's paid about $10.9 million for the business. It will run as a separate entity from the international auction house.
Spink specializes in Oriental works of art as well as British paintings. It is also an international auctioneer and dealer in coins and metals. In addition, the company designs and commissions the production of commemorative and campaign medals and orders. It has been looking for a buyer since 1990, when the recession hit the art market.
"We're not trying to put together brand names," said Christopher Davidge, Christie's chief executive. "If we look at the emerging economy in Southeast Asia as a new third market for Christie's, it makes sense. Spink has a high profile there and it will give us a point of contact and understanding." Spink's assets include a long-term lease for its building on King Street, adjoining the auction house, so Christie's now has long-term leases for buildings on the entre block bordered by King, Duke, Ryder and Bury Streets.
Some experts see the purchase as a potential conflict of interest since Christie's could possibly manipulate the market by putting higher estimates on works that Spink might sell at auction, if the gallery was trying to liquidate its inventory. Realizing the possible conflict, Lord Carrington, who is retiring next month as the chairman of Christie's, is heading what Christie's calls a compliance committee. "In the event any conflict of interest issues arise or any public perception of a conflict of interest, we felt this was important," Mr. Davidge said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jan van Huysum's still life of a vase of flowers, from the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston. Art experts are scrutinizing another version.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Mr. Dole's Selfish Strut

 BODY:
"So, how do you think Clinton's doing?" One confronts that question everywhere these days. Except for his surprisingly worthy speech on the environment, the President has been in a blind stagger for several days. With Janet Reno's help, he made Waco a synonym for fiasco. On the economic-stimulus package, Mr. Clinton and his staff managed to make the Senate Republicans, usually a milling school of minnows, look like a pack of tiger sharks.
But the economic debate deserves a closer look. Mr. Clinton's sin was clumsiness. The Republicans' was one of indifference to the plight of working people and to untangling the economic wreckage left by the Reagan and Bush Administrations. So it's important to look behind the headlines congratulating Senator Bob Dole and his colleagues on their tactical brilliance in killing this Administration's $19.5 billion package. 
 In his time, Mr. Dole has groveled for Presidents of his own party (Richard Nixon) or treated them with contempt (George Bush). But his assault on the economic plan of this Democratic President shows us the essential Dole. He is a creature of the storm who is happiest when he can ride the wind of anti-Democratic oratory and strut about spouting platitudes on the obligations of opposition parties.
Mr. Dole wants to frustrate the President's effort to manage the economy. Fair enough, if Mr. Dole had a stronger idea or better record. But look at his history. As Senate majority leader, he helped Ronald Reagan launch his deficit rocket. During the Bush years, when unemployed families all over America and on the plains of his native Kansas were suffering, Mr. Dole and his party stood for the most grudging of remedies -- temporary extension of jobless benefits, with nary a bow toward creating jobs that would make the benefits unnecessary.
Now the Senator has seen to it that Mr. Clinton's modest attempt to spur the economy has been knocked off track in favor of the same shopworn idea about temporarily stretching out payments to the unemployed. Sure, by including $2.5 billion of pork-barrel projects in its stimulus package, the Clinton team handed Mr. Dole a weapon. But it wasn't just Mr. Clinton who got whacked with that club. Mr. Dole gave a good thrashing to the poorest, weakest and most undefended Americans, who might have profited by its job programs and by a stronger economy.
Mr. Dole, of course, had his stated reasons. He didn't want to add to the deficit he helped lift off.

HEADLINE: Bold Stroke in Japan's Retailing Art

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
Takashimaya, the Japanese department store chain, is opening a much-awaited specialty store today on Fifth Avenue in New York City that will challenge American notions of what a store is.
If it succeeds, not only will it change the conventional wisdom about store environments, it will also reverse the poor showing of Japanese retailers in the New York market. 
 Shoppers will not be able to dash through the heavy glass doors to buy lipstick, a purse or some perfume. On the ground and second floors, Takashimaya is selling culture.
In what many in the retail business consider a risky departure from protocol, Takashimaya has filled the first two floors with a soaring atrium and art gallery instead of the cosmetics bars, hosiery racks and jewelry cases that are staples of the American store landscape. Customers will take stock of fantasy landscapes in ink on paper and surreal photos printed on linen -- all for sale -- before they reach the collection of unusual home furnishings, jewelry, decorative items and accessories for sale on the third, fourth and fifth floors.
"Of course we have some concerns about the first two floors," said Corliss Tyler, senior vice president and general merchandise manager for Takashimaya New York. "We have a very short window of opportunity to catch a New Yorker's attention, but we think we have the means to do it."
She added, "And jewelry and cosmetics on the main floor are tired concepts anyway."
In addition to the art, which will change periodically, the atrium of the 20,500-square-foot store, between 54th and 55th Streets, will incorporate merchandise related to gardening and decorating patios and terraces. Rustic Japanese rice scoops are displayed as jardinieres, and scissors used to trim bonsai trees are presented as elegant substitutes for clunky gardening clippers.
Some retailing experts say America may be ready for stores that break the mold. Several said the combination of unusual merchandise in a fresh setting might distinguish Takashimaya from the rest of New York's pack of luxury goods retailers.
"Why do something everyone else is doing?" said Randall E. Gebhardt, principal in the Retail Marketing Group, a consulting firm based in Columbus, Ohio. "That's what's wrong with a lot of American retailing today. The time may be more right for that kind of adventurous retailing than at any other time."
The concept may also set Takashimaya apart from other Japanese retailers that have tried their hands in New York without much success. Despite their wide acceptance in Europe and East Asia, these retailers have failed in the United States either because they tried too hard to imitate American stores or they carried merchandise not easily incorporated into American life styles.
But will harried American customers take the time to smell the flowers? In a recent study on retailing trends by Yankelovich Clancy Shulman, a market research company, consumers indicated that time-saving convenience was their top priority in shopping.
They also, however, expressed a hankering for entertainment in stores, and it is to that yearning that Takashimaya's art gallery and unconventional merchandise may appeal. "People are looking for fantasy and entertainment from retailing more than sports events these days," said Watts Wacker, Yankelovich's resident futurist.
From bargain-basement discounters to trendy boutiques, retailers across the United States have been struggling to distinguish themselves from their competitors. Decades of knocking off one another's best ideas have led to intense and crippling price wars as sales promotions have become the only way to establish differences between store chains.
Kurt Barnard, president of Barnard's Retail Marketing Report, noted that Galeries Lafayette, the French department store company that has a store on 57th Street, has fared poorly in New York because it has failed to distinguish itself from American rivals in the neighborhood. "It has run into a stone wall of competition because it hasn't turned out to be very different," he said. "Its prices aren't even so different, so why should I shop there instead of at Bloomingdale's or Bergdorf's?"
For a Japanese retailer, daring to be different is unusual. Japanese businesses tend to be extremely wary of taking risks, and department stores in Japan typically spread their risks by sharing profits and losses with manufacturers and distributors, according to Larry R. Katzen, a partner at Andersen Consulting who has closely studied Japanese retailing. As a result, Japanese retailers have learned to live with much slimmer profit margins than their American counterparts.
But Takashimaya's margins are more stable than most American retailers'; since at least half of its merchandise is exclusive to the store, it can use pricing to protect profits.
Takashimaya is not the only Japanese retailer interested in making a run at the New York market. Felissimo opened on 56th Street just before Christmas. And Mitsukoshi, Japan's oldest department store chain, had planned a 40,000-square-foot store for 57th Street and Park Avenue, but postponed the opening because of the weak American economy and a somewhat saturated market for luxury goods, said Katsuhiko Nitta, vice president of Mitsukoshi U.S.A.
"We got the word from our headquarters in Tokyo to wait and see, and we're still waiting," Mr. Nitta said.
Takashimaya opened its first store in New York in 1958 and has had a presence here ever since, although its most recent location was a corporate office that also housed the home decorating and interior design services for which the company is known.
Jiro Shinohara, president of Takashimaya U.S.A., said he expected the new store to post about $15 million in sales this year, and he noted that business was not exactly booming in Japan these days.
"New York is still the No. 1 consumer city," he said. "And we are not thinking about the short term. We are thinking more about the 21st century, actually."
And Felissimo, a retail branch of a Japanese mail-order company, is doing very well despite initial fears that the recession would hamper sales, according to Haruko Smith, the store's director.
 
 
Tearooms, Too
 Like Takashimaya, Felissimo has an art gallery (albeit on the fourth and top floor of the store, in traditional Japanese style) adjacent to a tearoom. Ms. Smith said the store had recently added a lunch menu and installed a jewelry department on the same floor to help draw customers to the gallery. Takashimaya plans a tearoom for its basement this year.
While Japanese retailers have in the past ended up catering to the Japanese expatriate community, Ms. Smith said about 95 percent of Felissimo's customers were American.
"Most people are surprised by our Japanese connection," she said. "We do see quite a few Japanese businessmen -- but they just come to see the store."
Takashimaya's Japanese origins are evident in its name. But Ms. Tyler is determined to make her buyers' finds functional besides having curiosity value.
The store will sell chopsticks with a display that demonstrates how they can serve as a alternative to a salad fork. Rough-hewn wooden boxes used to raise silkworms will be featured as planter boxes. And Japanese kimono fabrics turn up in lingerie sets and men's vests.
"This is a store," Ms. Tyler said. "We're not trying to create a museum or a Japanese cultural center."

HEADLINE: An Issue of Bonds From Albany Is Given Moody's Highest Rating

BYLINE: By SARAH LYALL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, April 23

 BODY:
Saying that it was heartened by New York State's improved financial position, an important Wall Street credit agency today gave its highest rating on a relatively small, but closely monitored, portion of the state's debt.
The agency, Moody's Investors Service Inc., said that the improved rating, MIG1, the highest for the state since 1990, reflected the fact that New York ended the most recent fiscal year with a surplus of $671 million and that it was borrowing far less than in previous years to cover its spring expenses. The higher ratings could translate into lower interest payments on the state's debt. 
 At the same time, Moody's refused to upgrade New York's ratings for two other important types of bonds that account for the bulk of the state's more than $23 billion in long-term debt. It left the rating for bonds backed by legislative appropriation at Baa1, which ranks the state in a tie with Louisiana and ahead only of Massachusetts. It is barely above the level for high-risk, or junk, bonds. And it left the rating for those bonds that must be approved by voter referendum at A, the second lowest in the country, ahead only of Louisiana.
Today's new MIG1 rating, Moody's highest grade for short-term debt and an increase from last year's MIG2 for a similar offering, affects only $850 million in short-term notes that the state intends to borrow to cover spring operating expenses and that it must repay within a year.
Standard & Poor's Corporation, the other major bond-rating service, is expected to announce its rating on the short-term notes next week.
State officials immediately heralded the new rating as evidence of the state's fiscal comeback. "I have said that New York has been successfully fighting its way back from the punishing effects of the national recession," Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said in a statement.
But George W. Leung, a managing director at Moody's, warned that the new rating reflected only a thin slice of debt and was far from a ringing endorsement.
"These are very narrow issues that you focus on for these short-term notes," Mr. Leung said. "Over the long term, there still needs to be structural reform."

HEADLINE: Cesar Chavez, 66, Organizer of Union For Migrants, Dies

BYLINE: By ROBERT LINDSEY

 BODY:
Cesar Chavez, the migrant worker who emerged from the poverty of an agricultural valley in Arizona to found America's first successful union of farm workers, was found dead yesterday in San Luis, Ariz. He was 66.
Mr. Chavez, who lived in Keene, Calif., and was in Arizona on union business, died in his sleep, the local police said. An autopsy is planned. 
 Blending the nonviolent resistance of Gandhi with the organizational skills of his mentor, the social activist Saul Alinsky, Mr. Chavez captured worldwide attention in the 1960's. Leading an initially lonely battle to unionize the fields and orchards of California, he issued a call to boycott grapes that soon became a cause celebre.
Mr. Chavez, who was described by Robert F. Kennedy in 1968 as "one of the heroic figures of our time," was widely acknowledged to have done more to improve the lot of the migrant farm worker than anyone else.
Fighting growers and shippers who for generations had defeated efforts to unionize field workers, and later fighting rival unionists, Mr. Chavez for the first time brought a degree of stability and security to the lives of some migrant workers.
Largely because of him, the California Legislature in 1975 passed the nation's first collective bargaining act outside Hawaii for farm workers, who are largely excluded from Federal labor law coverage. "For the first time," Mr. Chavez said when asked to describe the union's achievement, "the farm worker got some power."
Asked what had motivated his stubborn fight, he said, "For many years I was a farm worker, a migratory worker, and, well, personally -- and I'm being very frank -- maybe it's just a matter of trying to even the score."
But he ultimately failed to realize his dream of forging a nationwide organization. In most of America, farm workers continue to toil for low wages, without job security, vulnerable to exploitation. Even in California he found it difficult to translate the early triumphs of what he called La Causa into a viable labor organization.
The union that Mr. Chavez founded, the United Farm Workers of America, became troubled by dissent and other problems and was unable to organize more than 20 percent of California's 200,000 farm workers.
The tactics that he used so effectively in the 1960's and early 70's -- strikes and boycotts, fasting and the long march -- eventually lost their magic. And, as the United Farm Workers were no longer seen as a social cause but as a conventional labor union, he was disappointed by the disaffection of politicians and other supporters.
 
Gains From Unionization
 In 1965, when he formed the union, farm workers in California averaged less than $1.50 an hour. They had no fringe benefits, no seniority rights and no standing to challenge abuses by employers or exploitative labor contractors.
Unionization brought sharp pay increases. For the first time, migrant workers were eligible for medical insurance, employer-paid pensions, unemployment insurance and other benefits, and they had a mechanism to challenge employer abuses.
And the union's impact extended far beyond its membership. The threat of unionization by Mr. Chavez raised agricultural wages throughout California.
 
Born On Arizona Farm
 Cesar Estrada Chavez was born on March 31, 1927, near Yuma, Ariz., the second of five children of Juana and Librado Chavez. His father's parents migrated from Mexico in 1880.
His early years were spent on the family's 160-acre farm. But in the seventh year of the Depression, when he was 10, the family fell behind on mortgage payments and lost its farm.
Along with thousands of other families in the Southwest, they sought a new life in California. They found it picking carrots, cotton and other crops in arid valleys, following the sun in search of the next harvest and the next migrants' camp.
Mr. Chavez never graduated from high school, and once counted 65 elementary schools he had attended "for a day, a week or a few months."
Beginning with the Industrial Workers of the World at the turn of the century, unions tried for decades to organize immigrant unskilled workers, first Chinese, then Japanese and later Filipinos and Mexican-Americans, on whom California growers depended. But the field hands, their organizing drives vulnerable to the competition of other poor migrants seeking work, found themselves fighting not only powerful growers, but also the police and government officials.
In 1939 Mr. Chavez's family settled in San Jose. His father became active in a successful effort to organize workers at a dried-fruit packing plant, giving Mr. Chavez his first glimpse of workers taking collective action.
After World War II, in which he served two years in the Navy, Mr. Chavez resumed his life as a migrant. He married Helen Fabela in Delano, which he later made famous far beyond its dusty corner of the San Joaquin Valley.
Besides his wife he is survived by eight children, 27 grandchildren, a great-grandchild, three brothers and two sisters.
The pivotal role in Mr. Chavez's emergence as a labor leader was played by Mr. Alinsky, the Chicago-based organizer who described himself as a "professional radical." In the early 1950's he helped Mexican-Americans organize into a political bloc.
Mr. Alinsky sent an aide to recruit potential leaders, and among the first people he met was Mr. Chavez, then working in a San Jose apricot orchard.
Mr. Chavez joined Mr. Alinsky's Community Service Organization, registering Mexican-Americans to vote and helping them deal with government agencies. But he later criticized the organization as dominated by non-Hispanic liberals, and in 1958 he quit, went to Delano and formed the National Farm Workers Association.
 
Five Years of La Huelga
 By 1965 Mr. Chavez had organized 1,700 families and persuaded two growers to raise wages moderately. His fledging union was too weak for a major strike. But 800 workers in a virtually moribund A.F.L.-C.I.O. group, the Agricultural Workers Organizing Committee, struck grape growers in Delano, and some of the members of his group demanded to join the strike.
That was the beginning of five years of La Huelga -- "the strike" -- in which the frail labor leader, who was 5 feet 6 inches tall, became familiar to people in much of the world as he battled the economic power of the farmers and corporations in the San Joaquin Valley.
With its charismatic leader, song-filled meetings and the fundamental appeal of its struggle, depicted as a downtrodden minority battling an exploitative oligopoly, Mr. Chavez's organization reminded many old-timers of the industrial battles that they had waged generations earlier.
He was shy and not an outstanding public speaker. But he showed a humility that, with his shyness and small stature, piercing dark eyes and facial features that hinted at Indian ancestors, gave him an image as a David taking on the Goliaths of agriculture.
Mr. Chavez's style was monastic, almost religious. He said his life was dedicated only to bettering the lives of the exploited farm workers. He was a vegetarian, and his weekly salary of $5 was a virtual vow of poverty. Articles about him often spoke of his "saintly" and even "messianic" qualities.
Soon, priests and nuns, college students and unionists from around the country marched with Mr. Chavez. Supporters sent money for La Causa. Most of the farm workers who enlisted had meager resources and were asked to pay only the dues they could afford, often only a few cents a month.
Borrowing from Gandhi, Mr. Chavez sometimes went on fasts or invited arrest to call attention to his battle with the growers. But he ran the union along authoritarian lines.
With music and singing and hundreds of fluttering flags bearing the union's symbol of a black eagle on a field of red, union rallies had the quality of ritual. Typically, Mr. Chavez arrived late at the rallies, appearing to a roar of approval after a musical group had played and other speakers warmed up the audience.
In 1968 he began his most visible campaign, urging Americans not to buy table grapes produced in the San Joaquin Valley until growers agreed to union contracts. The boycott proved a huge success. A public opinion poll found that 17 million Americans had stopped buying grapes because of the boycott.
On July 30, 1970, after losing millions of dollars, growers agreed to sign. It was probably the high point in the union's history.
More successful boycotts and organizing successes followed, but soon many of the largest growers, in an effort to stave off Mr. Chavez's union, invited the International Brotherhood of Teamsters to organize their workers. Mr. Chavez complained that the teamsters were signing "sweetheart contracts," and before long his hard-won gains in Delano seemed to be slipping away.
More growers, many charging that the United Farm Workers was poorly run and undependable, signed with the teamsters. But two things kept his dream alive: First, the teamsters' leaders, smarting from charges of corruption, made a truce.
Second, Edmund G. Brown Jr., a Democrat who had marched with the farm workers before his election as Governor in 1974, won adoption of the state Agricultural Labor Relations Act, a landmark bill establishing collective bargaining for farm workers and granting the union concessions. Among these concessions was a "good standing clause," which in effect permitted union leaders to deny work in the fields to any worker who challenged their decisions.
The teamsters virtually abandoned the fight against Mr. Chavez in 1977. In the years that followed, the United Farm Workers signed occasional contracts with growers but never attained the dominance that Mr. Chavez envisioned. A decade after the Delano strike, fewer than 10 percent of the grapes in that community were harvested by his union's members.
In the mid-1970's Mr. Chavez, who had built a commune-style union headquarters called La Paz in a former sanitarium in Keene, near Bakersfield, began to complain that "spies" were trying to undermine the union.
This occurred after Mr. Chavez befriended Charles Dederich, the founder of Synanon, a drug rehabilitation organization. Some Chavez associates said Mr. Dederich advised him to be autocratic. Soon, Mr. Chavez purged the union of non-Hispanic officials.
After Mr. Brown's departure from the governorship in 1983, Mr. Chavez battled with the successor Republican administration of George Deukmejian, whose campaign was backed by the growers. In 1983, Mr. Chavez, expressing determination to recapture the union's momentum, revived the use of the boycott, directed at nonunion table grapes and Salinas Valley lettuce.
By the end of 1985 growers said the high-tech boycott was having little effect on sales.

CLINTON SPEAKS OF AIR STRIKES
President Clinton, explaining that other nations are also reassessing their options, said that he was giving "serious consideration" to air strikes against Serbian positions in Bosnia. If there is to be any intervention, air strikes are likely to be most acceptable to the allies. 1
 
OFFERING SERBS A COMPROMISE
In a new twist to the Vance-Owen peace plan for Bosnia, Bosnian Serbs who rejected the original plan are being offered a wedge of territory that would connect areas populated by ethnic Serbs. 6
 
TRYING TO HEAL THE HOPELESS
Operating without experience, without anesthesia, without blood supplies and without rest, a 32-year-old pathologist became a practiced surgeon in Bosnia's killing fields. He was the only hope of the dying, and after a brief respite from the horrors, he is returning. 6
 
A VOTE FOR ERITREA
Residents of the region of Ethiopia known as Eritrea are making a bid for secession, and analysts say that the cohesiveness of the people and their organized approach adds up to what should be an overwhelming victory. 3
 
FROM COMRADE TO OPPONENT
Aleksandr V. Rutskoi has been transformed from President Yeltsin's running mate to the leader of the forces who oppose him. 4
 
WORLD BANK TO AID RUSSIA
The World Bank has agreed to help finance a $1 billion project to increase Russia's oil output by reopening 1,200 oil wells that have been closed because of a lack of parts, inadequate maintenance and other problems. 4
 
CONTROL FOR PALESTINIANS
Israel said it would offer Palestinians greater control over their lives, including their own police force, an announcement pounced upon by the right-wing opposition and by Jewish settlers in the territories. 3

Three Glen Ridge, N.J., men who were found guilty of sexually assaulting a retarded schoolmate were sentenced to serve time in a campuslike complex for youthful offenders. Though they were sentenced to up to 15 years, they could be released after as little as 22 months. And the three were allowed to remain free on bail until exhausting their legal appeals, which could take years. 1
 
WEB OF DECEIT IN YONKERS
The Yonkers Police Department dismissed two officers for fabricating a story about an assault on an officer by a black man, when he was actually beaten by a fellow officer. Three other officers who played a part in the episode were suspended and a sixth resigned. The Westchester County District Attorney's office is investigating for the possibility of criminal violations. 1

HEADLINE: CONFLICT IN THE BALKANS;
CLINTON CONSIDERS BOSNIA AIR STRIKES; SEES ALLIED ACCORD

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 23

 BODY:
President Clinton said today that he was giving "serious consideration" to air strikes against Serbian positions in Bosnia and Herzegovina amid indications that Britain and France were softening their opposition to military intervention.
Asserting that "other nations involved are also genuinely reassessing their position," Mr. Clinton said that he would complete his policy review on the Balkans within the next several days and that agreement among the allies was likely. "I do not think we should act alone, unilaterally, nor do I think we will have to," he said at a news conference. [Excerpts, page 7.] 
 Officials from Britain, France and Canada have long opposed air strikes or the lifting of an embargo against weapons shipments to the Bosnian Muslims because those countries have ground troops stationed in the Balkans and fear retaliation.
 
View Has Changed
 But during meetings with Administration officials in recent days and in interviews, British and French officials have said they are now convinced that Washington will feel compelled to take some military action soon. They have indicated their preference for air strikes over other options, like lifting the arms embargo for the Bosnian Muslims.
Key Administration officials have also increasingly begun to see limited air strikes in the Balkans as their best remaining option.
European foreign ministers are to meet this weekend in Copenhagen to discuss possible options in Bosnia. A United Nations Security Council team arrived today in Zagreb, Croatia, on a fact-finding mission to last several days.
 
Awaiting Russia's Vote
 In addition to awaiting the results of these meetings, the Clinton Administration was also not interested in taking any new steps against the Serbs before the referendum Sunday in Russia on President Boris N. Yeltsin's performance. Mr. Yeltsin has feared that new action against the Serbs could reverberate against him.
Mr. Clinton, who reiterated his opposition to sending American ground troops to Bosnia, said that any new policy would require "heavy consultations" with Congress; but a senior Administration official said these should be considered to be only routine discussions, not a signal that a final decision has been made to pursue military action.
"If the United States takes action, we must have a clearly defined objective that can be met," Mr. Clinton said. "We must be able to understand it, and its limitations must be clear. The United States is not -- is not, should not, become involved as a partisan in a war."
Mr. Clinton offered few clues about what his final policy would be; but his words suggested that he was contemplating military intervention aimed at limited goals like forcing a cease-fire, freezing the current military situation or protecting declared "safe havens" from attacks from any military force in the area.
By speaking of the need to avoid partisanship, the President seemed to indicate that the United States was not contemplating broader strategic strikes that might be aimed at destroying the Serbian military or rolling back Serbian territorial gains.
Mr. Clinton spoke at a news conference called by the White House to provide him with a forum to discuss his first months in office as the 100-day mark approaches.
Mr. Clinton addressed the question of military intervention in Bosnia at a time when his Administration is embroiled in a debate over how forceful the United States should be in trying to stop the fighting in the Balkans.
Mr. Clinton said that he had made no promise to hold off action until after the voting in Russia is completed, but that Russia must play a significant role in any action that affects the Serbs. Moscow has supported the Serbs in the past, and they are still considered allies by some Russian politicians.
Malcolm Rifkind, the British Defense Secretary, who had previously opposed the use of military force in the Balkans, said this week in Washington that air strikes "clearly would be an important and powerful signal to the Serbs that the international community is increasingly concerned."
Mr. Rifkind, who met on Thursday with Secretary of Defense Les Aspin and with Anthony Lake, the President's national security adviser, also said, "The spectrum of possible activity ranges from warnings to the Serbs to the hard brutal use of physical force."
Mr. Clinton said a final decision on what steps to take would be made when a policy review is completed during the next several days, but the measured tone of his comments indicated that he is still weighing the international and domestic ramifications.
"We're not at the endgame yet," a senior Administration official said.
Calling the situation in Bosnia "the most difficult foreign policy problem we face," Mr. Clinton said the United States must lead other Western nations in the drive to end ethnic cleansing in Bosnia.
"That does not mean that the United States or the United Nations can enter a war in effect to redraw the lines, geographical lines of republics within what was Yugoslavia, or that that would ultimately be successful," he said. "I think what the United States has to do is to try to figure out whether there is some way, consistent with forcing the people to resolve their own difficulties, we can stand up to and stop ethnic cleansing, and that is the -- obviously, the difficulty we are wrestling with."
His comments drew quick support from one of his most vocal critics on domestic politics, Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader. In a television interview, Mr. Dole said he would back Mr. Clinton if he chose to use targeted force in Bosnia with the cooperation of allied nations.
"I don't think we just act unilaterally, even if we are the only superpower left," the Republican leader said. "I think we have to have international support. But I think this will be a time to test whether or not President Clinton is persuasive enough to make the case to our NATO allies."
 
Consensus Evasive
 But Mr. Clinton is having considerably more difficulty in winning consensus in Congress on aid to Russia and seemed today to have lost some of his confidence about his ability to win support for the new aid that he pledged at the Vancouver summit.
In response to a question, he said the outcome of that aid package, which requires Congressional approval, would depend in part on how well his own plans to increase domestic spending fare.
"The question is: Can we get any more aid for Russia that requires a new appropriation by the United States Congress?" Mr. Clinton said. "And that is a question, I think, that will be resolved in the weeks ahead in part by what happens to the American workers and their jobs and their future."
Mr. Clinton's comments on the future of the Russian aid package reflected some of the new caution seen in his assessment of the difficulty he encountered trying to break a filibuster over his economic stimulus plan.
Mr. Clinton said he is open to developing a new approach to win some of the battles he lost so publicly during the last few weeks.
"What I want to know from our folks and from our friends in the Senate -- Republicans or Democrats -- is: What could I have done differently to make it come out differently?" he said. "Because the real losers here were not the President and the Administration. The real losers were the hundreds of thousands of people who won't have jobs now."
