SECTION: Section 1; Page 7; Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 3470 words

HEADLINE: Excerpts From Clinton News Conference: 'The U.S. Should Lead' on Bosnia

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 23

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from President Clinton's news conference today, as transcribed by The Associated Press:
Q. Mr. President, there's a growing feeling that the Western response to the bloodshed in Bosnia has been woefully inadequate. A holocaust survivor, Elie Wiesel, asked you yesterday to do something, anything, to stop the fighting. Is the United States considering taking unilateral action such as air strikes against Serb artillery sites? 
 A. Well first, let me say, as you know, for more than a week now we have been seriously reviewing our options for further action.
And I want to say, too, let's look at the last three months. Since I became President, I have worked with our allies and we have tried to move forward, first on the no-fly zone, on enforcement of it; on the humanitarian airdrops; on the war crimes investigation; on getting the Bosnian Muslims involved in the peace process.
We have made some progress and now we have a very much tougher sanctions resolution. . . .
I think we should act. We should lead. The United States should lead. We have led for the last three months. We have moved the coalition. And to be fair, our allies in Europe have been willing to do their part, and they have troops on the ground there.
But I do not think we should act alone, unilaterally, nor do I think we will have to.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Q. Do you see any parallel between the ethnic cleansing in Bosnia and the Holocaust?
A. I think the Holocaust is on a whole different level. I think it is without precedent or peer in human history.
 
Holocaust 'to the Nth Degree'
On the other hand, ethnic cleansing is the kind of inhumanity that the Holocaust took to the nth degree. The idea of moving people around and abusing them and often killing them, solely because of their ethnicity, is an abhorrent thing, and it is especially troublesome in that area where people of different ethnic groups lived side by side for so long together. And I think you have to stand up against it. I think it's wrong.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Q. Mr. President, by any count, you have not had a good week in your presidency -- the tragedy in Waco, defeat of your stimulus bill, the standoff in Bosnia. What did you do wrong and what are you going to do differently?

 	 	 		. . .	 	A. You know, I don't really believe that the situation in Bosnia -- it's not been a good week for the world, but I don't know that the Administration could have made it different. On the stimulus package, I think -- I'd like to put it into the larger context and remind you that in this hundred days we have already fundamentally changed the direction of an American Government.
We have abandoned trickle-down economics. We have abandoned the policies that brought the debt of this country from one trillion to four trillion dollars in only a decade.
The budget plan which passed the Congress which will reduce the deficit and increase investment has led to a 20-year low in mortgage rates, dramatically lower interest rates. There are probably people in this room who have refinanced their home mortgages in the last three months or who have had access to cheaper credit.
That's going to put tens of billions of dollars coursing throughout this economy in ways that are very, very good for the country. And so we are moving in the right direction economically.
 
Regret on Stimulus Package
I regret that the stimulus did not pass, and I have begun to ask and will continue to ask not only people in the Administration but the people in the Congress whether there is something I could have done differently to pass that. Part of the reason it didn't pass was politics, part of it was the difference in ideas.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Q. (inaudible) -- Waco, Texas?
A. Well, with regard to Waco, I don't have much to add to what I've already said.
I think the -- I think it is a -- I want the situation looked into. I want us to bring in people who have any insights to bear on that. I think it's very important that the whole thing be thoroughly gone over. But I still maintain what I said from the beginning, that the offender there was David Koresh. And I do not think the United States Government is responsible for the fact that a bunch of fanatics decided to kill themselves. And I'm sorry that they killed their children.
Q. Mr. President, to follow up partly on Helen on your stimulus package and on your political approach to Capitol Hill, Ross Perot said today that you're playing games with the American people in your tax policy. He was strongly critical of your stimulus package. He said he's going to launch an advertising campaign against the North American Free Trade Agreement. How are you going to handle his political criticisms? Will it complicate your efforts on the Hill with your economic plan? And do you plan to repackage some of the things that have been in your stimulus program and try to resubmit them to the Hill?
A. Well, let me answer that question first. We're going to revisit all of that over the next few days. I'm going to be talking to members of Congress and the others to see what we can do about that.
With regard to the economic plan, I must say I found that rather amazing. I don't want to get into an argument with Mr. Perot. I'll be interested to hear what his specifics are, but I would -- go back and read his book and his plan. There's a remarkable convergence except that we have more specific budget cuts. We raise taxes less on the middle class and more on the wealthy. But, otherwise, the plans are remarkably similar.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Q. Mr. President, to go back to Bosnia for a minute. You continue to insist that this has to be multilateral action, criteria that seems to have hamstrung us when it comes to many options thus far and makes it look as if this is a state of paralysis. The United States is the last remaining superpower. Why is it not appropriate in this situation for the United States to act unilaterally?
A. Well, the United States -- surely you would agree that the United States, even as the last remaining superpower, has to act consistent with international law under some mandate of the United Nations.
Q. Well, many people think that you have a mandate --
A. They do, and that is one of the things that we have under review. I wouldn't -- I haven't ruled out any option for action. I would remind all of you, I have not ruled out any option, except that we have not discussed and we are not considering the introduction of American forces into continuing hostilities there. We are not. So we are reviewing other options.
But I also would remind you that, to be fair, our allies have had -- the French, the British and the Canadians -- have had troops on the ground there. They have been justifiably worried about those. But they have supported the airdrops, the toughening of the sanctions, they welcomed the American delegation now in Europe working on how to make these sanctions really work and really bite against Serbia.
So I'm not -- and I can tell you that the other nations involved are also genuinely reassessing their position. And I would not rule out the fact that we can reach an agreement for concerted action that goes beyond where we have been. I don't -- I don't have any criticism of the British, the French and others on that.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Q. Mr. President, a week ago a group of gay and lesbian representatives came out of a meeting with you and expressed in the most ringing terms their confidence in your understanding of them and their political aspirations and their belief that you would fulfill those aspirations. Do you feel now that you will be able to meet their now-enhanced expectations?
A. Well, I don't know about that, and I don't know what their -- it depends on what the expectations are.
But I'll tell you this. I believe that this country's policies should be heavily biased in favor of non-discrimination. I believe when you tell people they can't do certain things in this country that other people can do, there ought to be an overwhelming and compelling reason for it.
 
Views on the Gay Issue
I believe we need the services of all of our people, and I have said that consistently, and not as a political proposition. The first time this issue came up was in 1991 when I was in Boston. I was just asked a question about it.
And I might add that it's interesting that I have been attacked -- obviously, those who disagree with me here are primarily coming from the political right in America. When I was Governor I was attacked from the other direction for sticking up for the rights of religious fundamentalists to run their child care centers and to practice home schooling under appropriate safeguards.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Q. Mr. President, getting back to the situation in Bosnia. We understand you haven't made any final decisions on new options previously considered unacceptable. But the two most commonly heard options would be lifting the arms embargo to enable the Bosnian Muslims to defend themselves, and to initiate some limited air strikes, perhaps to cut off supply lines.
Without telling us your decision -- presumably you haven't made any final decisions -- on those two options, what are the pros and cons that are going through your mind -- right now and will weigh heavily on your final decision?
A. I'm reluctant to get into this. There are -- those are two of the options. There are some other options that have been considered.
All have pluses and minuses. All have supporters and opponents within the Administration and in the Congress, where, I would remind you, heavy consultations will be required to embark on any new policy.
I do believe that on the airstrike issue, the pronouncements that General Powell has made generally about military action apply there. If you take action, if the United States takes action, we must have a clearly defined objective that can be met, we must be able to understand it, and its limitations must be clear. The United States is not -- is not, should not become involved as a partisan in a war.
With regard to the lifting of the arms embargo, the question obviously there is the -- if you widen the capacity of people to fight, will that help to get a settlement and bring about peace or will it lead to more bloodshed, and what kind of reaction can others have that would -- that would undermine the effectiveness of the policy? But I think both of them deserve some serious consideration along with some other options we have.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Q. Sir, do you think that these people who are trying to get into war in Bosnia are really remembering that we haven't taken care of hundreds of thousands of veterans from the last war, and we have -- we couldn't take care of our prisoners and get them all home from Vietnam, and now many of them are coming up with bills on the treatment of Agent Orange. How could we afford to go to any more of these wars?
A. Well, I think that's a good argument against the United States itself becoming involved as a belligerent in a war there. But we are, after all, the world's only superpower. We do have to lead the world.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Q. Did you make any kind of agreement with Boris Yeltsin to hold off either on airstrikes or any other kind of aggressive action against the Serbs until after Sunday, and in general how has his political situation affected your deliberations on Bosnia?
A. No. I have not made any agreement, and he did not ask for that. We never even discussed that, interestingly enough. The Russians, I would remind you, in the middle of President Yeltsin's campaign, abstained from our attempt to get tougher sanctions through the United Nations in what I thought was the proper decision for them and one that the United States, and I'm sure the rest of the free world, very much appreciated.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Q. Mr. President, since you said that one side in the Bosnian conflict represents inhumanity that the holocaust carried to the nth degree, why do you then tell us that the United States cannot take a partisan view in this war?
 
Stand Against Ethnic Cleansing
A. Well, I said that the principle of ethnic cleansing is something we ought to stand up against. That does not mean that the United States or the United Nations can enter a war in effect to redraw the lines, geographical lines of republics within what was Yugoslavia, or that that would ultimately be successful.
I think what the United States has to do is to try to figure out whether there is some way, consistent with forcing the people to resolve their own difficulties, we can stand up to and stop ethnic cleansing. And that is the -- obviously, the difficulty we are wrestling with. This is, clearly, the most difficult foreign policy problem we face and that all of our allies face.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Q. Mr. President, would you care to make your assessment of the first 100 days before we make one for you?
A. Well, I'll say if -- I believe, first of all, we passed the budget resolution in record time. That was the biggest issue. That confirmed the direction of the Administration and confirmed the commitments of the campaign that we could both bring the deficit down and increase investment and that we could do it by specific spending cuts and by raising taxes, almost all of which come from the highest income people in the society, reversing a 12-year trend in which most of the tax burdens were borne by the middle class whose incomes were going down while their taxes were going up, while the deficit went from $1 trillion to $4 trillion. The total national debt and the deficit continue to go up.
We have a 20-year low in interest rates for home mortgages. We have lower interest rates across the board. We have tens of billions of dollars flooding back into this economy as people refinance their debt.
We have established a new environmental policy, which is dramatically different.
The Secretary of Education has worked with me and with others and with the Governors to establish a new approach in education that focuses on tough standards as well as increasing opportunity.
We have done an enormous amount of work on political reform, on campaign finance, and lobbying reform.
And I have imposed tough ethics requirements on my own Administration's officials.
These things are consistent with not only what I said I'd do in the campaign, but with turning the country around. The Vice President is heading a task force which will literally change the way the Federal Government operates and make it much more responsive to the citizens of this country.
We are working on a whole range of other things. The welfare reform initiative to move people from welfare to work. And, of course, a massive amount of work has been done on the health care issue, which is a huge economic and personal security problem for millions of Americans. So, I think it's amazing how much has been done. More will be done.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Q. Mr. President, the Tailhook Report came out this morning documenting horrendous and, you know, nearly criminal conduct on the part of the Navy. How much did you discuss the incident and what might be done about it with your nominee to be the Secretary of the Navy?
A. First let me comment a little on that. The inspector general's report details conduct which is wrong, and which has no place in the armed services. And I expect the report to be acted on in the appropriate way.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
Aid to Russia
Q. Mr. President, to go back to Russia for just a minute, the latest polls show that Mr. Yeltsin will probably win his vote of confidence, but there seems to be a real toss-up on whether or not voters are going to endorse his economic reforms. Can you live -- well, can you live with a split decision, though, or do you need both passed in order to then build support for Russian aid.
A. I believe -- the answer to your question is that for the United States, the key question should be that which is posed to any democracy, which is who wins the election. If he wins the election, if he is ratified by the Russian people to continue as their president, then I think we should do our best to work with him toward reform.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Q. Mr. President, Mr. Perot has come out strongly and put his prestige on the line against the free trade agreement, N.A.F.T.A. How hard are you going to fight for this free trade agreement, and when do you expect to see it accomplished?
A. I think we'll have the agreement ready in the fairly near future. You know, our people are still working with the Mexican Government and with the Canadians on the side agreements. We're trying to work out what the environmental agreement will say, what the labor agreement will say, and then what the fairest way to deal with enforcement is.
Q. Mr. President, there was a tremendous flurry of interest earlier this month in the Russian document that purported to show that the Vietnamese had held back American prisoners. General Vessey has now said publicly that while the document itself was authentic, he believes that it was incorrect. Do you have a personal view at this point about that issue? And more broadly, do you believe that in fact the Vietnamese did return all the American prisoners at the time of the Paris peace accords?
A. . . . As to whether the document had any basis in fact, let me say that the Government of Vietnam was more forthcoming than it had been in the past and gave us some documents that would tend to undermine the validity of the Russian document's claim.
I do not know whether that is right or wrong, but we are having it basically evaluated at this time. And when we complete the evaluation, we'll tell you, and, of course, we want to tell the families of those who were missing in action or who were P.O.W.'s.
Q. If I could follow up on that, before the U.S. normalizes relations, allows trade to go forward, do you have to be personally sure that every case has been resolved, or would you be willing to go forward on the basis that, well, it may take years to resolve these cases, the Vietnamese have made sufficient offerings to us to confirm good faith?
A. Well, a lot of experts say you can never resolve every case, you know, every one, that we couldn't resolve all the cases for them, and that there are still some cases that have not been factually resolved going back to the Second World War. But what I would have to be convinced of is that we had gone a long way toward resolving every case that could be resolved at this moment in time and that there was a complete, open, and unrestricted commitment to continue to do everything that could be done always to keep resolving those cases.
 
A Clarification on Bosnia

 	 	 		. . .	 	Q. Mr. President, could I ask you for a clarification on Bosnia? You said that you were not considering introduction of American forces. Does that include any air forces as well as ground forces, sir?
A. Well, I said ground forces.
Q. You said ground forces?
A. Correct.
Q. Could I ask you, sir, if you fear that using U.S. air strikes might draw the United States into a ground war there?
A. I just don't want to discuss our evaluation of the options anymore. I've told you that there's never been a serious discussion in this country about the introduction of ground forces into an ongoing conflict there.
Q. Mr. President, with hundreds of thousands of gays in Washington this weekend for the march, did you ever reconsider your decision to leave town for this weekend? Did you ever consider in any way participating in some of the activities?
A. No. I -- because I -- and basically, I wouldn't do -- participate in other marches. I think once you become President, on balance, except under unusual circumstances, that is not what should be done.
But more importantly, I'm going to the American Society of Newspaper Editors, a position -- a trip that presumably most of you would want me to make, to try to focus anew on what I think are the fundamental issues at stake for our country right now.
And I expect that I will say something about the fact that a lot of Americans have come here asking for a climate that is free of discrimination, asking basically to be able to work hard and live by the rules and be treated like other American citizens if they do that and just that. And that's always been my position, not only for the gays who will be here but for others as well.
Thank you very much.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
Orders for big-ticket factory goods slumped 3.7 percent in March, a widespread decline that was the biggest in 15 months, the Commerce Department said. The report further dampened analysts' hopes for stepped-up economic expansion. [Page 37.]
Vehicle sales continued to strengthen in mid-April, with domestic auto makers reporting a healthy 19.5 percent gain. [39.] 
 Moody's upgraded its rating on a relatively small but closely monitored portion of New York State's debt, saying it was heartened by the state's improved cash position. [28.]
 
Companies
R. H. Macy is searching for an expert merchandiser, after serving as a training ground itself for legions of young merchants. Executive recruiters say the company's task will not be easy. [37.]
I.B.M. has established its information storage unit, Adstar, as a wholly owned subsidiary. It named Ed Zschau, a Silicon Valley entrepreneur and ex-Congressman, as the operation's chief. [39.]
Consumers are buying even the most modest of products with the same discretion once shown only big-ticket items like air fares, computers and designer clothes. The result: a growing popularity of cheaper private-label products and the likelihood that price wars among consumer goods could lead to further consolidation. [37.]
Travelers has agreed to pay more than $80 million to settle a lawsuit filed by pension funds over its management of a real estate investment account. [36.] An unorthodox cancer test used by Transamerica Occidental Life Insurance to screen some applicants has increasingly come under fire. [36.]
Robert Mondavi Winery intends to go public with an initial stock offering of 3.7 million shares. [39.]
A U.S. District Court judge refused to dismiss a bondholders' suit aimed at blocking a plan that would split Marriott. [39.]
Harris Corp. said it had named Phillip W. Farmer president and chief operating officer. [39.]
 
International
Commerce Secretary Brown pressed Japan to agree to measurable goals for increasing its purchases of American products. But he also said during a visit to Tokyo that the target need not always be a specific share of a Japanese market. [37.]
The World Bank said it had reached an agreement to help finance a $1 billion project to increase Russia's oil output. [4.]
 
Markets
The stock market continued its melancholy decline, with the Dow industrials off 15.40 points in a fifth straight losing session. Even the most notable gainers, the gold stocks, seemed to be caught up in the gloom, with traders bracing for political upheaval because of the Russian referendum tomorrow. [37.] Gold futures prices jumped to a six-and-a-half-month high. [48.]
The dollar declined in heavy trading against all leading currencies except the Japanese yen. [48.]
Treasury bond prices fell amid perceptions of political turmoil in Russia and problems for the Clinton economic plan. [46.]
 
Your Money
People with large damage claims can turn to public adjusters, who review insurance contracts to make sure no aspect is overlooked. In return, they receive an average of 10 percent of settlements, giving them an incentive to obtain the most for clients. [35.]
 Neighborhood banks are offering a baffling array of mutual funds, intent on keeping depositors from wandering. But funds offered by banks usually come with higher charges than no-load funds. Allen R. Myerson: Investing. [35.]
Finding treasures in the attic may be easier than identifying them and getting an idea of their worth. Jan M. Rosen: Assets. [36.]

HEADLINE: Clinton Seeks Change in Tax Rule That Scuttled Baird Nomination

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 23

 BODY:
President Clinton is seeking a change in the decades-old Social Security tax laws that were a factor in dooming Zoe Baird's nomination as Attorney General.
In a letter that the White House made public today, Mr. Clinton told Joseph R. Biden Jr., chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, that he had asked officials from the Treasury Department to examine alternative proposals. 
 "It is clear that the law has been misunderstood by many well-intentioned people," Mr. Clinton wrote in the letter, dated April 19, "and as a result, compliance has been inadequate. The financial threshold in the law is outdated, having remained unchanged for the past four decades. It is time to amend the law."
 
Request From Senator
 Mr. Clinton was responding to a letter nearly two weeks ago from Mr. Biden, a Delaware Democrat, who asked the President to "set forth a policy governing all nominations, communicating your own views on the issue as it relates to qualifications for government service."
Under a law that took effect in 1950, employers must pay Social Security and Medicare taxes for every household worker who is paid more than $50 in a calendar quarter, even teen-agers who baby-sit. The unemployment insurance tax is due if the worker is paid more than $1,000 in a quarter.
The law has hardly ever been enforced, and scofflaws are usually not punished.
But the law became the subject of great public debate when Ms. Baird was forced to withdraw, largely because she had employed a nanny and chauffeur who were illegal immigrants and had failed to pay the required taxes. Since then, Administration officials have been unsure whether to appoint to lower-level posts other people who may have also violated laws relating to household and part-time workers.
 
'The Nanny Problem'
 Several potential Administration officials were later deemed not eligible for jobs because they had what White House officials described as "the nanny problem."
In the letter, Mr. Clinton said he was seeking to simplify the reporting requirements and increase the dollar threshold of people who would have to pay Social Security taxes.
The changes would more likely affect people who had temporary workers rather than situations like that of Ms. Baird, whose employees were hired on practically a permanent basis.
"I believe that a past failure to comply does not necessarily preclude a qualified person from serving the Government," Mr. Clinton wrote, "and that is, indeed, the policy of this Administration."
Mr. Clinton said he had instructed Howard Paster, his chief lobbyist with Congress, to give Mr. Biden details of a new proposed policy.
In a letter to Mr. Biden that is also dated April 19, Mr. Paster offered more details about how the White House wants to change the policy. But it lacked specifics of how the policy would be carried out.
Mr. Paster referred to "considerable confusion" over whether job candidates were disqualified because they had hired domestic workers.
"This confusion may have been exacerbated by news accounts that have led some to conclude that past failure to comply with any employer's obligation will be considered automatically disqualifying for every Federal position," he said. "That is not the policy of this Administration."
 
Drawing the Line
 But, Mr. Paster said, candidates could be disqualified if there were instances in which their relationship with current or past household workers "was particularly wanton or willful." He added, "This will be determined on a case-by-case basis."
To comply with the current law, employers must file five to eight separate Federal forms each year. State forms must often be filed as well. Some officials have said that very few people routinely filed because of the amount of record-keeping involved.

HEADLINE: Banker Is Convicted of Embezzling Millions

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 23

 BODY:
The former bank president widely blamed in Rhode Island's worst banking crisis since the Depression was convicted today of embezzling $15.8 million and creating false documents to cover the theft.
A Superior Court jury deliberated nearly three days before returning guilty verdicts on all 26 counts against Joseph Mollicone Jr. 
 Mr. Mollicone, 49, faces up to life in prison when he is sentenced.
The former president of the Heritage Loan and Investment Company fled in 1990 as examiners were scrutinizing the small neighborhood bank's books and questioning him about millions of dollars in what he said were "off-line," or undocumented, loans.
Investigators proved the loans did not exist and traced the money to Mr. Mollicone's business ventures and personal banking accounts.

HEADLINE: Gold Shares Surge While Market Falls

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
The stock market continued its melancholy decline yesterday, its fifth losing session in a row.
Even the most notable gainers, the gold stocks, seemed to reflect some of the gloom. Their rise indicated that many traders were bracing for political trouble in Moscow after tomorrow's referendum on President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia.
Several gold-mining stocks rose to new highs during yesterday's trading. Gold bullion also surged, with the spot price jumping $6.50 an ounce, to $346.50, its highest level since early October. [Page 48.] 
 Meanwhile, the Dow Jones industrial average fell 15.40 points yesterday, closing at 3,413.77. Broader market indexes also declined. But trading volume, at 259.8 million shares, was lower than Thursday's busy 310.4 million shares. For the week, the Dow lost 64.84 points.
The Dow fell right at the opening of trading and never fully recovered. Indeed, it was down more than 25 points shortly after 11 A.M.
Contributing to the morning selloff was the Government's report that orders for durable goods fell an unexpected 3.7 percent in March.
The Dow was dragged down by six of its component stocks that fell 1 1/8 of a point or more: Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing, Exxon, Alcoa, International Paper, Goodyear Tire and A.T.& T.
Exxon lost 1 5/8, to 64 1/4, after reporting flat first-quarter earnings and a slump in refining. 3M also lost 1 5/8, to 113 1/8, even though some analysts had raised their earnings projections.
Amid such declines, the gold-mining stocks stood out. Homestake Mining jumped 1 5/8, to 16, and was the third most active stock on the Big Board, on volume of 3.3 million shares. It hit a 52-week high of 16 1/4 during the day. Newmont Mining, American Barrick, RTZ, and Placer Dome also saw their shares rise.
Analysts attributed much of the rise in gold and the mining stocks to fears that Mr. Yeltsin might lose the Russian referendum and be ousted. Russia is a leading gold producer, and a political upheaval could disrupt production.
In the gold market, institutional investors, bullion brokers and other industry professionals appeared to be snapping up options to buy gold. In one case, a huge option for 700,000 ounces or more of gold was traded.
"But I'd be more encouraged if some Swiss banks or some Arab sheiks were buying and physically removing gold off the market," said Edwin Arnold, a metals specialist at Merrill Lynch in London. "That's when the price goes up and stays up."
Still, Ian C. MacDonald, manager of precious metals marketing for Credit Suisse in New York, said more fundamental factors might support gold prices even if tensions eased in Moscow. New demand, especially for gold jewelry, is likely to push prices upward, he said.
Elsewhere in the stock market, the Dow Jones transportation average dropped 9.26 points, to 1,618.02, its fourth decline in five sessions, amid growing concerns about the airlines' latest price war and its effect on earnings.
Four stocks -- UAL, Ryder System, XTRA and AMR -- accounted for nearly all of the decline. For example, UAL, the parent of United Airlines, dropped 2 5/8, to 144 1/4.
Intel continued to be one of the most actively traded stocks of the week, with unusually heavy volume of 9.65 million shares yesterday. Yesterday's trading was the most frenzied for Intel since Monday, the first session that investors could react to a court ruling in which Advanced Micro Devices, Intel's chief rival, won the legal right to ship its cheaper clone of Intel chips. Intel closed down 3 1/4, to 92 3/4.
 
Advanced Micro Off
 Advanced Micro Devices was the most active stock on the Big Board with volume of 3.8 million shares. It closed down 1/2, to 30 1/2, although some analysts raised their earning projections for the company. The biggest percentage loser on the Big Board was Tandycrafts, which plunged 3 points, or 14 percent, to 18 1/4. The specialty retailer reported earnings that were a record for the company but apparently did not meet investors' expectations.
Among the broader market indicators, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index lost 2.43 points, to 437.03, while the New York Stock Exchange composite index declined 1.23 point, to 241.85, and the Nasdaq composite index lost 5.10 points, to 658.41.
In Tokyo yesterday, stocks rebounded slightly after falling for five straight sessions. The Nikkei index of 225 issues gained 112.84 points, to close at 19,704.15. For the week, the Nikkei lost 593.71 points.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Court Declines to Dismiss Marriott Bondholders' Suit

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
A Federal judge has refused to dismiss a bondholders' suit aimed at blocking a restructuring plan by the Marriott Corporation that would split it into two companies.
Lawyers for the bondholders called the ruling Thursday by United States District Judge Alexander Harvey 2d in Baltimore "a major setback to the company's spinoff plan." Marriott officers countered that the next stage in the suit would find that the bondholders' claims were "without substance." 
 The ruling was not made known to both parties until yesterday. The court dismissed the bondholders' claim of negligent representation against Marriott and said the claims did not apply to bonds bought before April 1992, but it ruled that the law at least permitted the bondholders to raise the issue of securities fraud.
 
Suit Filed Last Fall
 The bondholders' suit was led by PPM America Inc., a unit of Prudential Insurance P.L.C. of Britain, which owns about $120 million of Marriott's $2.9 billion of debt. It was filed last fall when the price of Marriott's 20-year bonds plunged by 30 percent after the company announced its planned reorganization.
PPM America was a conspicuous holdout last month when Marriott reached an agreement in principle with plaintiffs in eight class-action suits and with representatives of institutions holding about $400 million of Marriott bonds.
The company agreed to issue new bonds at higher interest rates and to shift about $450 million of debts and assets from Host Marriott, the proposed real estate company, to Marriott International, the company that would manage hotels and restaurants.
Yesterday, the PPM side was jubilant. "I think we hit a home run," said Lawrence Kill, its lawyer. "The judge sustained the essence of our claims."
 
Ruling a Technical One
 Robert Sours, a Marriott spokesman, said the ruling did not address the merits of the claim. "In filing to dismiss their suit," he said, "our arguments were technical and legal."
Mr. Kill agreed. "This ruling is on the complaint," he said. "But without a complaint you can't go to trial. The ruling says we alleged sufficient facts to enable us to proceed to try to prove violations of Federal securities law and common law. So this ruling is the ticket you need to get into the theater."
Mr. Sours contends it will be an empty theater. "The judge decided the law permitted PPM to raise the issues," he said, "but the next step will be to see what substance there is to those claims, and when they are weighed on the merits, we will prevail."
Judge Harvey set a scheduling conference for May 26, before the June 22 annual meeting at which Marriott shareholders are scheduled to vote on the restructuring.

HEADLINE: World Bank to Help Russia Increase Its Oil Output

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 23

 BODY:
In one of the biggest Western efforts to assist Russia's oil industry, the World Bank announced today that it had reached an agreement to help finance a $1 billion project to increase Russia's oil output.
The World Bank said it would provide more than $500 million in loans for the plan, which aims to boost output by $1.5 billion a year by reopening 1,200 oil wells that have been closed because of a lack of spare parts, inadequate maintenance and other problems. 
 The plan would increase Russia's output by about 240,000 barrels per day, the World Bank said, helping to increase Russia's annual production by 3 percent.
 
'Major Support'
 World Bank officials said they hoped the plan would enable Russia to increase its exports and hard-currency revenues, thus reducing its dependence on Western aid and easing its painful transition to a market economy.
"This is very major support for the rehabilitation of Russia's oil industry," said a senior World Bank official. "It's a $1 billion investment."
Western officials say modernizing Russia's huge oil sector is essential for transforming its economy.
The agreement announced today comes after the United States and other wealthy industrial nations pressured the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund to step up their pace of aid to Russia, in part to demonstrate support for President Boris N. Yeltsin and other economic reformers.
Three oil-producing associations have joined in the accord, which involves oil fields in the Tyumen Province of western Siberia. World Bank officials said they expected the oil-producing associations to reinvest some of their profits to make up a portion of the $1 billion project.
 
Other Sources
 Under the agreement, funds will also come from the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development and from the export credit agencies of several countries.
World Bank officials said they hoped the project would be the first step toward meeting the $6 billion that they say Russia needs to reopen the more than 10,000 wells that have been shut. One oil specialist at the World Bank said such an investment might increase Russia's oil output by more than $7 billion a year.
A senior World Bank official said he hoped that some of the money to reopen these wells would come from private Western investors. He estimated that Western companies had invested less than $200 million in projects to reopen closed wells.
The World Bank estimates that between now and the end of the decade, Russia will need $50 billion in investment, from home and abroad, to keep its oil production from declining from its current level of about 2.5 billion barrels a year.

HEADLINE: Treasuries Fall After Early Strength

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices fell yesterday amid perceptions of political turmoil in Russia and problems for the Clinton economic plan in the United States.
The price of the Treasury's closely watched 30-year bond was down 5/8 point, or $6.25 for each $1,000 in face value, while its yield rose to 6.79 percent, from 6.75 percent late Thursday. Bond prices and yields move in opposite directions. 
 Bond prices were strong in early dealings yesterday after the Commerce Department said new orders to factories for durable goods plunged an unexpectedly large 3.7 percent in March, despite a rebound in orders for military equipment.
 
Russia Is Worry
 But the problems in Russia of President Boris N. Yeltsin, who is facing a referendum on Sunday, pushed gold prices higher and sent bond prices retreating. Rising gold prices are frequently seen as an indicator of inflation, which can wipe out gains on fixed-income instruments like long-term bonds.
There is also doubt about whether President Clinton's full economic package will ever get through Congress, said Marshall B. Front, president of Stein Roe & Farnham Inc., a Chicago investment consulting firm.
"The credibility of the President to effect this deficit-reduction program is being called into question," Mr. Front said.
A rising deficit can spur inflation and also increase the supply of bonds, pushing down their value.
Short-term Treasury issues fell 1/32 point to 1/16 point and intermediate maturities fell from 5/32 point to 9/32 point, the financial information service Telerate Inc. reported.
 
Funds Rate Lower
 The discount rate on three-month Treasury bills rose 1 basis point, or one-hundredth of a percentage point, to 2.83 percent. The discount rate on six-month bills rose to 2.92 percent, also up a basis point. The discount rate on one-year bills rose to 3.04 percent, up a basis point. Yields are the interest bonds pay by maturity, while the discount is the interest at which they are sold.
The Federal funds rate, the interest on overnight loans between banks, was 213/16 percent, down from 215/16 percent late Thursday.
In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds closed at 10111/32 , down 1/32 from Thursday. The average yield to maturity was 5.93 percent, up from 5.92.

HEADLINE: U.S. Steps Up the Pressure in Tokyo

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 23

 BODY:
Saying that no other approach will work, Ronald H. Brown, the United States Secretary of Commerce, pressed Japan today to agree to measurable goals for increasing its purchases of American products. But he also said that the targets need not always be a specific share of the Japanese market.
Mr. Brown is on a three-day trip here only a week after President Clinton met with Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa in Washington and told him that the United States wanted Japan to accept specific targets for opening its markets. 
 Japan is fiercely resisting the idea, calling that approach "managed trade," and arguing that it is impossible to agree in advance to the purchase of a certain amount of foreign products without knowing the price and quality of the items.
Officials in Tokyo have had a frustrating time recently dealing with trade issues and the related matter of the yen's sharp rise against the dollar. Today, a senior official of the Bank of Japan abandoned the customary reserve of a central banker and delivered a tongue lashing aimed at President Clinton over Mr. Clinton's support for a strong yen.
The yen has appreciated sharply against the dollar since February, but it was given a special impetus a week ago when President Clinton said at a news conference in Washington that a strong yen was desirable because it would help reduce Japan's huge trade surplus. A strong yen would tend to cut Japan's exports by making them more expensive for foreign buyers; it would also tend to increase Japan's imports by making foreign goods cheaper here.
After the President's remarks, the dollar tumbled to a post-World War II low of 110.25 yen, a 12 percent decline since the start of the year.
The Bank of Japan official spoke today to a group of foreign reporters on the condition that he not be identified. He warned that playing with the foreign exchange markets was a dangerous game that could backfire on the United States and he questioned whether Mr. Clinton was well prepared and adequately informed to deal with the situation.
 
Chip Accord Is Cited
 Mr. Brown at his news conference here said that gaining a specific share of a Japanese market was only one of the ways to measure results of changes in trade relations. He said other gauges could include the number of joint ventures between American and Japanese companies, the number of instances in which American components are used in Japanese products, or the overall increase in American exports.
"We have not argued that every solution has to mirror the semiconductor agreement, although we do believe that was a good agreement," he said. Mr. Brown was referring to an agreement that called for foreign computer chips to have 20 percent of Japan's market by the end of 1992, a goal that was met.
Washington and Tokyo are now working on two trade agreements, Mr. Brown said. One will be aimed at altering the structure of the Japanese economy to make it easier for foreign companies to compete. This program will be the successor to the so-called Structural Impediments Initiative undertaken during the Bush Administration.
The other, which Mr. Brown called a "strategic export initiative," will involve trying to improve market access in specific industrial sectors. Mr. Brown and Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, have identified several sectors that could be candidates for these negotiations, including computers, semiconductors, supercomputers, construction and cars.
In a speech this morning to the American Chamber of Commerce in Japan, Mr. Brown continued the Clinton Administration's blunt criticism that has hit Japan like a sledgehammer in recent weeks, and he made it clear that America's dissatisfaction with Japan on economic matters would no longer be tempered by considerations of long-term security arrangements between the two countries.
"No approach seems to work," Mr. Brown said. "Where our exports to almost every other nation -- from Korea to Germany to Mexico -- are up, they aren't in Japan. Where tariff reduction spurs commerce in every other market, it hasn't in Japan. Where years and years of negotiations have yielded tangible results with Canada and the E.C., for the most part, they have not in Japan.
"Removing barriers and changing structures has almost become an end, rather than a means," the Commerce Secretary continued. "The Clinton Administration intends to end the obsession with process. Our focus will be on results."
But Mr. Brown, in the news conference, was somewhat vague when asked how the United States would get Japan to agree to targets or what the United States would do if Japan did not agree.

HEADLINE: Scalping on Stolen Credit;
2 Arrested and 1,428 Tickets Seized in a Pure-Profit Scheme

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI

 BODY:
It was a sure-fire, pure profit venture: selling tickets for the biggest Broadway hits, more often than not at face value, because there simply was no overhead. Then the police got a tip.
Two Queens men were arrested Thursday night outside the Shubert Theater on West 44th Street, where "Crazy for You" is playing, and charged with ticket speculation -- better known as scalping -- with a twist. 
 The twist, according to investigators, was that all speculation had been taken out of the scheme because the tickets -- $70,000 worth of them -- were purchased with pilfered credit cards or credit card numbers.
"It cost them nothing to do this," Deputy Inspector Michael Fox, the commander of the Midtown South Precinct patrol, said at a news conference yesterday afternoon. "Maybe they bought a stolen credit card on the street for $50, but that's about it."
Spread before Inspector Fox on a table at the station house were 1,428 stolen tickets. Had they all been sold at inflated rates on the street, the police said, they could have brought in $130,000 in pure profit.
 
Tickets for Most Major Shows
 The suspects -- Howard Schwartz, 31, of 75-46 113th Street in Forest Hills, and Joel Steinberg, 30, of 69-03 Kissena Boulevard in Flushing -- were charged with grand larceny, possession of stolen property and ticket speculation. The police said that Mr. Schwartz is an accountant with the city's Human Resources Administration, while Mr. Steinberg is otherwise unemployed. Inspector Fox said a third suspect, whom he called the ring leader, remained at large.
"These are known scalpers, and they were selling tickets to most of the major shows -- 'Miss Saigon,' 'Guys and Dolls,' 'Les Mis,' 'Phantom of the Opera,' " said Sgt. Robert Lowe, one of the arresting officers.
 
Officers Pose as Theatergoers
 Inspector Fox said the police received a tip at 5 P.M. Thursday from American Express indicating that people were scalping tickets outside the Shubert Theater. Four officers posing as would-be theatergoers went to the theater about 5:30 P.M., the inspector said, but they did not spot the scalpers.
"They came back at 6 P.M.," Sergeant Lowe said. "A security guard pointed them out to us. We asked if they had any or knew anyone we could buy some from. They produced the tickets at that point.
"When we questioned them, their answers were very vague," the sergeant added. Soon after, however, the suspects led the officers to their car, a gray Toyota, parked around the corner on Eighth Avenue. In the car were 1,300 tickets that, in addition to the fistfuls the suspects had with them at the theater, brought the total to 1,428.
 
400 Tickets on 1 Card
 Officer Michael Egan, who participated in the arrests, said American Express had begun investigating the case after a card holder called to say that someone had purchased $2,000 worth of tickets by using his card number.
Inspector Fox said most of the tickets had been bought with more than 40 stolen credit cards or card numbers. The largest number of tickets charged to a single card was 400. Tickets had been purchased for performances between last month and March 1994, he said.
"They may be organized, but I don't think they're too bright," the inspector said. "If you're going to sell tickets through March 94, you would think they'd realize they would eventually have gotten caught because they had to be out there every day for a year."

From left were Police Officers Donald Graves, Michael Egan, Tony Quagliariello and Sgt. Robert Lowe. (Stephanie Berger for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Sales of Domestic Vehicles Up 19.5% for 10-Day Period

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: DETROIT, April 23

 BODY:
Vehicle sales continued to strengthen in mid-April and domestic auto makers reported today that their overall vehicle sales rose a healthy 19.5 percent in the 10-day reporting period.
The figures confirmed generally optimistic assessments from dealers. 
 "It seems like it's getting a little bit better," said Tony Ursomarso, who sells Pontiacs, Hondas, BMW's and GMC Trucks in Wilmington, Del. "It's not a straight arrow up and not what everybody would like it to be, but it's moving forward."
Sales of passenger cars seem to be rebounding with the arrival of spring. A rise of 16.3 percent in mid-April followed gains of 10 percent and 8 percent in early April and late March.
 
Nice Weather and Tax Refunds
 Mike Pisano, sales manager at Larry Roesch Chevrolet in Bensenville, Ill., just west of Chicago, said: "I'm sure the low interest rates have something to do with it. So does nice weather and income tax refunds."
Sales of light trucks, which have carried the industry's recovery for the last year, remained strong in the April 11-20 period. The segment, which includes mini-vans, pickups and sport-utility vehicles, had 23.8 percent higher sales.
The annual sales rate for North American-built cars in the period was 6.6 million, slightly better than in early April and the same as in late March. The annual rate for domestic cars in mid-April last year was 5.8 million.
All vehicles built in North America are considered domestic for reporting purposes.
 
Trucks Doing Well
 Trucks sold in mid-April at an annual rate of 5 million, the same as in early April. The annual selling rate for trucks in mid-April last year was 3.9 million.
Tom Pappert, the Chrysler Corporation's vice president of sales, said that total United States vehicle sales, including imports, had been running at an annual rate of slightly more than 14 million this month.
Chrysler, which does not report 10-day sales, had another strong period, according to estimates by Ward's Automotive Reports, a trade publication. Ward's estimated that the No. 3 auto maker's car sales were up 47.8 percent and that light-truck sales were up 32.6 percent.
The General Motors Corporation reported a rare period of sales strength in both cars and trucks. Despite drastically cutting the number of cars sold at low profit to car-rental companies, its car sales were up 15.5 percent. Four of its five car divisions and the Saturn unit reported higher sales. Oldsmobile was the sole division reporting lower sales.
A G.M. spokesman, John Maciarz, said fleet sales were down 9 percent in the period while retail sales to individuals were up 23 percent. G.M.'s truck sales were up 31.4 percent.
The Ford Motor Company continued to gain compared with a year earlier, with car sales up 15.2 percent and truck sales up 7.7 percent.
Combined Big Three sales were up 20.8 percent. Sales of cars and trucks by Japanese makers with plants in the United States were up 9.9 percent.

HEADLINE: Discount Brands Flex Their Muscles

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY

 BODY:
As the economy continues crawling toward recovery and job security is worrying an increasing number of families, consumers are buying even the most modest of products with the same discretion once shown only big-ticket items like air fares, computers and designer clothes.
The result: a growing popularity of cheaper private label products and the likelihood that price wars among consumer goods could lead to the kind of consolidation that occurred in the airline and electronics industries. 
 Moreover, analysts say, changing buying habits will force premium brand marketers to lower their prices to protect their positions, as Philip Morris did recently with Marlboro cigarettes and Procter & Gamble did with Pampers diapers. These companies may also upgrade products to distinguish them from private labels and promote their brands more aggressively than ever -- a bounty perhaps for the packaging and advertising industries but a further drain on marketers' margins.
"Consumers are forcing product innovation," said Leo J. Shapiro, founder of a Chicago-based market research company. "Products have to be sold on merit. As a result, there will be fewer brands of significance but the significant brands will be stronger."
In an written strategy report, Gail M. Dudack, an analyst for S. G. Warburg Securities, stressed, "We believe brand loyalty only exists when, or if, value is provided."
Americans have demonstrated a willingness to experiment with discount brands since their introduction in the late 1970's. But the pace of change has quickened as consumers' craving for value intersects with corporate reorganization, sluggish job growth and the expectation of higher taxes.
And the potential market for discount brands is widening.
"The unique nature of the recent recession is that it has stretched into higher-income groups," said Roy D. Burry, a stock analyst for Kidder, Peabody & Company. "It has shaken up those between $50,000 to $100,000, who used to go down the aisle and pull off Coke, Crest toothpaste and Budweiser and not think anything about it. But now, with consumer confidence shaken, people think: 'Maybe I don't need Crest. I can buy some other brand.' The consumer is going to walk out having spent 10 to 15 percent less."
That attitude has been a boon to discount brands and supermarkets' own labels, like the Loblaw Companies' successful President's Choice line, which is sold in their chain of supermarkets, as well as in stores like the D'Agostino Supermarkets.
Recent data from Information Resources Inc., a Chicago-based survey company, show that nearly 23 billion private label items were sold in supermarkets last year, a slight increase over 1991. That represented sales of $26.3 billion, an increase of 2.2 percent for the same period. That might not sound like much, but the increase represented about $500 million in added private label sales.
As a result, private label goods now account for 18.3 percent of all units sold in supermarkets, up from 16.4 percent in 1989, according to Information Resources. Its market share in dollars for that period rose to 13.8 percent, from 12.5 percent. And private label items in 115 of 195 product categories tracked by Information Resources gained share in their respective markets last year.
Particularly vulnerable are brands that perennially rank third or fourth in their product category and generics, the no-names sold at price clubs and elsewhere, which have been passed over by consumers in favor of the more expensive private labels. According to figures gathered by the Private Label Manufacturers Association, supermarket shoppers spent $721 million on generic goods last year, less than 1 cent of every dollar they spent, as a once-fashionable option continues to fade.
"Consumers are now committed to using store brands," said Brian Sharoff, president of the Private Label Manufacturers Association. "That's a major, major problem for the big national brands, and what they do is replicated by everybody else."
Only a few companies feel safe from private label encroachment. Jack L. Stahl, the chief financial officer of the Coca-Cola Company, said last week that the premium soft-drink brands like Coca-Cola were relatively immune because their costs had remained constant. An ounce of Coca-Cola, which cost 2 cents in 1980, cost the same last year. By comparison, he said, the price of branded cigarettes increased, on average, from 58 cents a pack in 1980 to about $2 a pack in 1992.
"That left a price umbrella open for the private brands," Mr. Stahl said.
More vulnerable brands have embarked on careful counteroffensives against the private labels. Some companies have hedged their bets by also making private label versions of the same products. They include the Campbell Soup Company's Vlasic pickles, the American Safety Razor Company and Union Carbide for garbage bags.
In some cases, the big-name companies produce private label brands in other categories. The H. J. Heinz Company, for example, the leading producer of ketchup, makes about 80 percent of the private label soups sold in supermarkets.
Manufacturers are also enhancing their premium products to justify their higher prices, introducing, for example, multipurpose cleaners that come in refill packages and selling tuna packed in oils with less saturated fat. Fred C. Meendsen, a vice president at CPC International, the food products company, promised analysts recently that a combination of sensible pricing and innovation with a strong brand name "can stabilize your market share."
Mr. Meendsen cited four new CPC International products as examples of innovation: a Hellmann's mayonnaise with a reduced fat content; a new Mazola oil with canola oil replacing some of the corn oil to reduce saturated fat; Thomas's English muffins in sandwich size, and a new product, Homestyle Ranch salad mix, in which milk or sour cream can be added to make a salad dressing.
Reformulated or repackaged products are typical examples of innovative attempts to solidify market share. H. J. Heinz is introducing new containers, including a 20-ounce squeezable and recyclable plastic bottle, and is returning to a 20-year-old advertising theme, using the Carly Simon song "Anticipation." Procter & Gamble is test-marketing a diaper that is 50 percent thinner and is cutting costs and prices on Pampers and Luvs.
With an eye toward high-quality candies from Germany, pasta from Italy and even President's Choice products from Canada, Bert Flickenger, a marketing specialist with Booz, Allen & Hamilton, a management consulting firm, suggested that the big companies might have to adopt even more unconventional strategies.
"This may be considered heretical," he said, "but they should consider not only packaging and selling private label brands but also helping the chains actively market private label brands. Like, if Colgate-Palmolive brings out a new toothpaste, Pathmark gets the old product. Sure, there's a risk that might cut the market share. But the greater risk is choosing a monolithic brand strategy. There are a lot of very sophisticated companies out there looking at American retailers. Before you know it, private labels could be 40 to 50 percent of the action."

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Gold Jumps Amid Jitters About Russian Referendum

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Gold futures prices jumped to a six-and-a-half-month high yesterday as jitters about the Russian referendum added fresh fuel to a rallying market.
Silver and platinum futures also rose sharply. On other commodity markets, livestock and meat futures were lower, oil futures rose and grains and soybeans were mixed. 
 Gold for April delivery surged $6.50 on the Commodity Exchange in New York, to $346.50 an ounce, the highest settlement for spot deliveries since Oct. 9. Silver for May delivery rose 3.8 cents on the exchange, to $3.954 an ounce. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, April platinum deliveries climbed $5.30, to $380.20 an ounce.
Gold has gained $17.20, or 5.2 percent, since March 1, persuading many analysts that the market is emerging from a long slump linked to low inflation, slack investment demand and dumping by Russia and Middle Eastern banks. Demand appears to be rising for supplies of gold, which have shrunk because low prices have made it unprofitable to mine, said Ian McDonald, manager of precious metal trading for Credit Suisse.
Peter Cardillo, research director for Westfalia Investments Inc. in New York, said investors were buying gold this week as a hedge against the possible ouster of President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia.
 
Seeking Safety During Turmoil
 Investors tend to seek the safety of gold during times of international political turmoil.
Analysts said commodity funds became aggressive buyers when the market crossed several key chart points, including $342.50 in the spot price.
"The only thing that really could upset any potential rally in gold's price would be another central bank coming in to sell," Mr. McDonald said.
Livestock and meat futures sank on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange ahead of a quarterly report from the Department of Agriculture.
The department said there were 8 percent more cattle at feedlots on April 1 than on the date last year. The number exceeded expectations and could prompt selling of cattle futures on Monday, analysts said.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Off in Heavy Trading But It Gains Against the Yen

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar declined in heavy trading yesterday against all leading currencies except the Japanese yen.
Attention in the world's currency markets was focused on the European currencies, which gained at the expense of the dollar. Traders continued to evaluate two interest rate cuts by the German Bundesbank on Thursday. 
 Frank Pusateri, a vice president at the Bank of Boston, noted that the cut in the discount rate -- to 7.25 percent from 7.5 -- was small enough to leave Germany with an interest-rate advantage over the United States. The discount rate is the Bundesbank's cheapest fee on loans to commercial banks.
A United States Government report showing a surprising decline in new orders to American factories for durable goods also dampened demand for the dollar. The Commerce Department said orders plunged 3.7 percent in March, the worst showing since December 1991. The drop came despite a rebound in orders for military equipment.
 
A Technical Rise
 Trading was heavy until activity tapered off around midafternoon.
The dollar, which has been trading at record lows against the yen, rose against the Japanese currency in a technical move.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 110.40 yen, up 0.20 yen from Thursday's record closing low. Later in London, it rose to 110.61 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 110.50 yen, up from 109.86 on Thursday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.5745, from $1.5480 late Thursday. In New York it cost $1.5747 to buy 1, more expensive than Thursday's $1.5575.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's rates, included: 1.5825 German marks, down from 1.5965; 1.4270 Swiss francs, down from 1.4495; 5.3415 French francs, down from 5.3900; 1,490.50 Italian lire, down from 1,513.00, and 1.2618 Canadian dollars, down from 1.2633.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Thursday's rates, included: 1.5833 German marks, down from 1.6065; 1.4305 Swiss francs, down from 1.4579; 5.3440 French francs, down from 5.4225; 1.7783 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8058; 1,491.50 Italian lire, down from 1,526.50, and 1.2613 Canadian dollars, down from 1.2622.

HEADLINE: Durables Orders Post 3.7% Drop

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 23

 BODY:
Orders for big-ticket factory goods slumped 3.7 percent in March, a widespread decline that was the biggest in 15 months, the Commerce Department reported today.
The report was more negative than expected and further dampened analysts' hopes for stepped-up economic expansion, although the East Coast blizzard was once again cited as contributing to a poor or lackluster March statistic. 
 While orders might not have been affected as much as, say, industrial output or retail sales, economists said the midmonth storm did disrupt the process by keeping executives from their offices and aggravating any unwanted buildup of inventory.
 
Lowering Expectations
 "We are also watching some slowdown in overall economic activity from what we came to enjoy" in late 1992, commented Brian J. Fabbri, chief economist at Midland Global Markets. Mr. Fabbri is among a large group of forecasters expecting thatgrowth in the gross domestic product for the first quarter will be about half the 4.7 percent pace of the fourth quarter of 1992. The G.D.P. figures for the January-March period are to be reported on Thursday.
Today's report also showed that shipments of durable goods rose seven-tenths of a percent in March while backlogs of unfilled orders fell 1.1 percent, their first decline since November.
Durable goods, which are items that last three years or more, ranging from microwave ovens to 747 jetliners, are the backbone of the industrial sector of the economy. Unfilled orders are a widely followed predictor of general business conditions.
The biggest factor in the drop in new orders, to $130 billion, was a 10.2 percent decline in transportation equipment, mainly aircraft and parts, after sizable swings in January and February that largely offset each other. Airplanes are a notoriously "lumpy" item statistically, since airlines place orders sporadically.
 
Declines Were Widespread
 But there were also declines in every other major sector except for military goods, which rose only enough to partly recover from a 27.9 percent collapse in February.
Orders for electronic and other electrical equipment eased five-tenths of a percent, while orders for industrial machinery and equipment fell four-tenths of a percent, and orders for primary metals fell three-tenths of a percent.
"It's a little worrisome," said Christopher S. Rupkey, an economist at Mitsubishi Bank in New York, referring to the widespread nature of the March order decline. "But we don't view it as alarming."
Mr. Rupkey, noting that overall orders for durables soared 9.7 percent in December, said that some retreat was probably inevitable. January's 2.3 percent decline was followed by a 2.2 percent February gain, a figure that was trimmed today from the 2.4 percent that was initially reported.
 
Military Purchasing
 The rise in military goods was 6.5 percent, the report also showed, but this left the sector about $2 billion shy of the $8.8 billion level posted in January. Excluding the military sector, new orders over all fell 4.2 percent in March.
A particular favorite of statistics watchers -- new orders for nonmilitary capital goods, excluding commercial aircraft and parts -- declined 2.2 percent last month, nearly wiping out a 2.6 percent gain in February.
Ronald H. Brown, the Commerce Secretary, said in a statement from Tokyo that the durable-goods data were more evidence "that the pace of recovery is slowing and that action is still needed to stimulate economic growth." The Administration hopes to revive pieces of the economic stimulus plan it abandoned this week in the face of Republican opposition in the Senate.
 
A Hint of Optimism
 While the March rise in shipments of durable goods, to $135 billion, was small, it was the fourth gain in five months. Some analysts were moved to predict that orders would soon follow.
For the first quarter, orders advanced 3.5 percent while shipments advanced 3.2 percent, today's report also showed.
On the other hand, a broad $5 billion decline in unfilled orders, erasing gains made earlier in the year, was a clear negative and pointed to possible economic faltering ahead. Slipping backlogs "is usually a sign of weaker demand," said Marilyn Schaja of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.
The 3.7 percent decline in new orders last month was the steepest since December 1991, when orders dropped 5.3 percent.

HEADLINE: INVESTING;
Banks Are Trying Hard To Peddle Mutual Funds

BYLINE: By Allen R. Myerson

 BODY:
PRODUCT glut, the bane of supermarket shoppers, has hit the neighborhood bank full force. The choices among detergents and dry cereals are simple compared with the range of mutual funds that many banks are brandishing.
Chase Manhattan customers are now confronted with more than 600 mutual funds. Vista, Putnam, Alliance, Massachusetts Financial, Franklin, Nuveen, Colonial, GNA . . . "I could go on," said Mitchell Ratliff, a Chase marketing manager. 
 The banks are intent on keeping depositors from wandering to fund groups and brokerages. But investors should shop around. The funds available through banks almost always come with higher charges, sometimes disguised, than no-load funds.
For customers faced with the choice of renewing a certificate of deposit at barely the rate of inflation, a stock fund yielding 4 or 5 percent or a bond fund paying 6 or 7 percent can seem like a terrific deal. The stock, bond and money market funds that banks manage themselves have grown from $35.5 billion at the end of 1987 to $90.2 billion on March 31. The stock funds alone have grown tenfold.
Banks are promoting their investment alternatives so heavily that their offices are often cluttered with as many brochures as a travel agency. Their mutual funds do offer many conveniences. Why not keep all your money at one place, especially when you can move it by telephone among checking, savings and mutual funds? Investors who buy funds managed by banks can often count their holdings toward the minimum deposits needed to avoid direct charges for checking (an arrangement that banks insistently call "free checking").
Banks also boast that institutional and trust accounts have given them ample skills in managing money. Stock mutual funds managed by banks and by other institutions have performed identically over the last five years, gaining 83.99 percent before any loads, according to Lipper Analytical Services. The Vista Growth & Income Fund, managed by Chase Manhattan, won the top ranking among similar funds in the current Consumer Reports magazine.
But the major reason customers buy mutual funds through banks is sheer inertia. When Dean Witter executives boast that their partnership with Nationsbank will give them access to the bank's customers, they are betting that most will be too scared or lazy to shop elsewhere.
Almost nobody but depositors buys mutual funds through a bank. No bank need fear that crowds surging in to buy their mutual funds will ever knock their revolving doors askew.
Banks devote their greatest efforts to selling the mutual funds they manage, where all the commissions and fees flow to them. Most of their other funds are also available through brokerage firms, with the same commissions, often 4.5 percent or more.
Some financial advisers recommend buying funds through a brokerage firm instead, but with caution. Remember that, in house, brokers are called salesmen. A hard sell, with a barrage of follow-up calls, is more likely from a brokerage firm than a bank, which usually emphasizes the more conservative funds.
Anecdotal evidence and common sense, however, suggest that brokerage firms are more familiar with a variety of investments, and more likely to ask the right questions. "If I'm comfortable getting advice from a brokerage, the bank has few advantages," said J. Heywood E. Sloane, institutional markets director of CDA/ Weisenberger mutual fund consultants.
More self-reliant investors might gravitate toward no-load or low-load funds: the Vanguard, Fidelity, Dreyfus and other groups, which sell primarily by telephone and mail. There, the telephone sales representatives are often not licensed brokers. They can readily check fund performance, but might be less qualified to deal with asset allocation.
The payoff is low annual expense and sales charges of at most 3 percent, often nothing. Although banks and brokerage firms contend that their funds are worth the commissions, most studies conclude that even after the charges, they perform no better than the low- or no-loads.
The funds sold with fees have also countered by offering what might be called loaded no-loads, with features that allow banks and brokerage firms to say that there are no sales charges. Some Putnam funds, among others, now come in three flavors: with a 5.75 percent sales charge; with no sales charge but, for six years, high annual charges and redemption fees, and with no sales charge but high annual charges forever.
Ideally, these arrangements -- clearly disclosed in Putnam prospectuses -- offer customers the flexibility to minimize charges. But many could find themselves worse off in the long run than if they had simply paid the sales charges up front.
The greatest danger to investors who buy mutual funds through banks, however, comes from more fundamental confusion. For all the warnings banks may give about the funds, many customers still believe that a Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation decal on the door guarantees the full return of their money.
To avoid mix-ups, regulators used to forbid the marketing of mutual funds under a bank's name. Citibank therefore sells the Landmark funds, Bank of America the Pacific Horizon funds. Over the last year, however, several banks bestowed their names, and by implication an aura of soundness, on their mutual funds.
