HEADLINE: Hiring an Adjuster for Damage Claims

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

 BODY:
After the ocean crashed into their waterfront home in Point Pleasant Beach, N.J., during December's storms, soaking and crushing the furniture, smashing the windows and staining the walls, Judith and Victor Lolli faced a complex and costly insurance claim.
Their losses, which also included damage from last month's storms, exceeded $100,000 and were settled partly in February and finally on Thursday. They had to press their claims on two fronts: the National Flood Insurance Program, a federally chartered agency, for water damage, and Allstate Insurance for losses like roof damage from high winds covered under their regular homeowners' policy. 
 "We were going to do it all ourselves," Mr. Lolli said. "But there was so much paperwork." They were also worried they might overlook some damages.
So the Lollis decided to follow a neighbor's recommendation and hire a public adjuster -- in this instance, Andrew K. Knox & Company in nearby Toms River. Unlike the insurance company's own adjusters, who process a claim on behalf of their employers, public adjusters work exclusively for the claimants. They handle fire, storm and other covered risks.
"There was so much sand and flotsam and jetsam inside the house that sitting in the living room was like being on the beach," said Leslie Knox, president of the company.
On behalf of their clients, adjusters review the contract to make sure no aspect of coverage is overlooked. They take a detailed inventory of the losses, down to the last ruined pair of socks. They work with engineers, appraisers and contractors to prepare estimates that reflect the cost of repairs or replacement and then they negotiate with the insurer after its adjuster has made an estimate.
They write and present the claim in a way that fulfills the technicalities that can derail the amateur claim filer. A decision by the New York State Court of Appeals last month confirmed that unless "proofs of loss" were filed within 60 days of a catastrophe, as required by the contract, the insurance company retained the right to reject the claim.
Mr. Knox is a second-generation public adjuster, taking over his father's business in 1985. He earned degrees in history and economics and then worked for six years as an economist for an oil company before joining his father.
For their work, public adjusters receive an average of 10 percent of the settlement, but the percentage is negotiable. Thus they have every incentive to obtain the most for their clients. "You can usually count on 25 percent more than if you go it alone," said Robert E. Mackoul, a certified financial planner and independent insurance agent in Lynbrook, L.I., who recommends hiring public adjusters to deal with claims that exceed $10,000.
Some claimants do even better. Frank Cottone, a carpenter whose $175,000 single-story home in Cutter Ridge, Fla., suffered extensive damage from Hurricane Andrew last fall, said he received $75,000 after turning to a public adjuster. His insurer had originally offered to settle his claim for $38,000.
Yet if many customers are satisfied, some people do not like the way the adjusters seek business, sometimes descending uninvited at the front doors of families with losses. "There were four cards stuck to the front of our house even before we got back," Mrs. Lolli recalled.
Many excesses of the profession have been reduced in the last few years through licensing laws -- New Jersey enacted one in March -- and by stronger efforts of the National Association of Public Insurance Adjusters for a stricter ethics code and better training.
Victims of losses should never sign with an adjuster simply because one shows up at the door -- at least not until credentials and references have been thoroughly checked. Referrals may be sought from the family lawyer, insurance agent or real estate agent. The public insurance adjusters association at (202) 371-1258, which represents 91 firms, will also provide referrals.
"Our accountant was the one who suggested the idea to us," said George Gridelli, a lawyer whose late father's beachfront home in Bayville, L.I., was extensively damaged in the December storm. "Even I didn't have the very specialized expertise we needed."
Some people say that having an independent adjuster is more important than ever. "Claims are not being processed as fully or as quickly as they used to be," said Dennis T. D'Antonio, a lawyer with Weg & Myers in Manhattan, a firm that specializes in insurance claims litigation.
Insurers are dragging their heels, he maintains, because profits are under siege from the number of recent natural disasters. Insurers have also taken a beating from bad real estate loans, he added.
"I'm seeing coverage being denied on the flimsiest of excuses," Mr. D'Antonio said.
Insurance companies vehemently deny such charges. "We really do try to treat policyholders fairly," insisted Mary DiLeo, a spokesman for Aetna Life and Casualty. Claims are treated the same whether filed by the victim or a public adjuster, she said.
Moreover, she recommends waiting at least until the insurance company makes an offer to see if it is satisfactory. "Ask yourself whether you will really be ahead after paying his fee," she said of the public adjuster.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Leslie Knox, an adjuster who works for policyholders, assesses damage at Point Pleasant Beach, N.J. (Chet Gordon for the New York Times)

HEADLINE: ASSETS;
Treasures in the Attic: Stalking the Good Stuff

BYLINE: By Jan M. Rosen

 BODY:
A TINPLATE Mickey Mouse was sold for the equivalent of $18,400 at Christie's in London this month, setting a world record for a Disney toy. "A woman found the 1931 toy, which features Mickey as an organ grinder, in her attic two months ago," The Economist magazine reported.
Treasures in the attic. It sounds like a dream, but items of value are not actually that rare, experts say. The tough part is identifying them and getting an idea of their worth. 
 Jay Goldinger, president of Capital Insights, a Beverly Hills, Calif., brokerage house, who helped a client sell some collectibles last year, did some research and wrote about his findings in his firm's newsletter, "Early Warning Wire." He says he has received an enormous response. "Americans are finding a mother lode of potentially profitable possessions stashed away," he said. "Norman Rockwell plates, old books on fishing lures, a watercolor of Mickey Mouse painted by Walt Disney."
The pendulum swing of fashion has made many once-rejected items from the 20's, 30's and 40's goals of collectors. "I think a lot of senior citizens may be able to create some liquidity this way," Mr. Goldinger said.
He cautioned, however, that "90 percent of the items unearthed are worthless, according to dealers and collectors in vintage Americana."
If there are no valuables at home, what about mining flea markets or tag sales for resale to collectors?
"A flea market is unlikely but not impossible," said Madeline I. Noveck, president of Novos Planning Associates in New York and chairman of the Institute of Certified Financial Planners. She found a gold-plated Art Deco pin from the 1930's at a street sale. She bought it for $10, wore it a couple of times, discovered it was signed and sold it for $175.
Ms. Noveck has the advantage of knowledge. She was a curator at the Brooklyn Museum before she became a financial planner.
"Your only armor in the art world is knowledge, and to go around unarmed is foolhardy," she said. People who ask a dealer naively about the value of an item they hope to sell can be fairly sure of getting a low price. They should begin by visiting dealers and markets, Ms. Noveck said, because "there are easy comparisons in lower-priced items; it's not like 18th-century French furniture or Faberge eggs."
"You've got to have the passion, the interest," she added. "If not, you'll never have the knowledge, the discerning eye."
The next educational stop should be the public library. "Warman's Americana & Collectibles," and books on specific areas can help owners distinguish between trash and treasure.
If an item looks really promising, an appraisal may be in order. The American Society of Appraisers, a 6,500-member nonprofit professional organization based in Washington (1-800-ASA-VALU or 1-703-478-2228) has a directory of certified specialists who adhere to a code of ethics calling for no selling, which would be a conflict of interest, and flat or hourly fees, no percentage fees.
John V. Lanterman, a Bethesda, Md., appraiser and international governor of the society, who is preparing a report for the Smithsonian Museum on first-edition Little Golden Books, warns that authentication of collectibles is difficult because there are many skillful fakes.
Even mass-market reproductions can excite an amateur. Mr. Lanterman asked one man who called him about a violin, "Does it have a paper label inside saying Stradivarius?"
"Yes," the caller replied breathlessly.
Sears, Roebuck sold thousands of those for $3 to $5 in the early part of the century, Mr. Lanterman said, and they are worth about $75 today.

HEADLINE: Russia's Reform, on the Line

 BODY:
Russians go to the polls tomorrow to choose sides in President Boris Yeltsin's fight with the legislature. For Americans, the referendum is one vital sign that democracy is taking hold in harsh Russian soil. For Mr. Yeltsin, it's a chance to renew his shrinking popular mandate. But unless voters rally to him in unexpectedly large numbers, it won't be easy to translate that mandate into new momentum for economic and constitutional reform.
The ballot drawn up by the Congress of People's Deputies puts four questions to voters: whether they have confidence in President Yeltsin, whether they approve of his social and economic policies, whether they want early elections for president and early elections for Parliament. 
 A majority in the Parliament prefer a go-slow approach to privatizing land and ending subsidies for industrial dinosaurs -- and for good reason. These steps could destroy their political base. A majority of legislators also opposes new parliamentary elections that could cost them their seats, their pay and their privileges. Even reformers shrink from facing voters now.
Pre-election maneuvering by opposition legislators, and a curious set of rulings this week by Russia's Constitutional Court, may prevent tomorrow's referendum from breaking the political deadlock. Instead, the vote could prolong the blame-mongering and postpone the tough measures needed to extricate Russia from its grave crisis.
In one ruling, the court made it easier for Mr. Yeltsin to claim a mandate. It said that he could claim victory if he gets half the votes cast in the vote of confidence. In another ruling, the court made it more difficult for him to capitalize on that mandate. It said that a majority of registered voters is needed to force new elections. Given the current climate of public disaffection, it's not at all clear whether enough registered voters will actually show up at the polls.
Recalcitrant legislators also hope that a vote of approval for Mr. Yeltsin will be neutralized when voters register their opinion of his reform program. The ballot's multiple questions invite voters to say yes to Mr. Yeltsin personally, while blaming him for the drastic decline in living standards. The result could be paralyzingly ambiguous, taxing his considerable political skills to keep his political and economic reforms on track.
Some of his supporters were reluctant to take these issues to the electorate. But Mr. Yeltsin himself understood that trust in the people's judgment is a hallmark of democracy. And popular backing is essential for the tough reform measures that need to be taken.
Plebiscites alone are not the measure of democracy. Russia also needs courts that don't arbitrarily thwart the popular will. And after the vote Mr. Yeltsin and his opponents will still need to seek common ground in order to rescue Russia. A willingness to do that remains in short supply in Moscow's dog-eat-dog politics today.

HEADLINE: Air Strikes? Not Yet.

BYLINE: By Lee H. Hamilton; Lee H. Hamilton, Democrat of Indiana, is chairman of the House Committee on Foreign Affairs.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The Bosnian situation is critical, the peace process remains stalled and opportunities for reaching agreement are receding. The world is horrified by the scenes of helpless refugees and the evidence of mass killings and forced expulsions. As frustration mounts in America and elsewhere, President Clinton is reviewing his policy and is under intense pressure -- even from State Department officers -- to take other steps, including military strikes. While it is important to keep military choices under review, we need a clear idea where they lead and what they will accomplish.
The Administration has correctly ruled out unilateral deployment of U.S. ground forces. Such action has little public support. Because we can't resolve the crisis alone, we have been committed to a multinational approach. But action on that front has been slow and halting. Today, we would not be able to obtain U.N. Security Council approval for any international military operation to force a settlement. 
 Attention is now focused on alternatives: lifting the U.N. arms embargo and ordering selective air strikes against Serbian targets. Proponents say such action is doable, would put great pressure on the Serbians and force an early end to the conflict.
But these options are not within easy reach. Gaining U.N. approval is by no means certain. Nor are there any assurances that these actions would achieve their objectives.
Those who seek to lift the arms embargo on Bosnia want to equalize the relationship between the besieged Bosnian Muslims and the Serbians. But who would arm the Bosnians: Iran? Libya? Who would provide the training: America? Further, most military experts agree that lifting the ban, without additional outside military intervention, would only prolong the killing but not change the outcome.
Before the Muslims obtained heavy weapons and learned how to use them, the Serbians, with their preponderance of arms, could unleash a fury unseen even in this bitter war. This slaughter would create even greater pressure on the U.S. and the international community to get directly involved on the ground in Bosnia and possibly Croatia.
Nor can the embargo be lifted for the Muslims alone. Weapons entering Bosnia must pass through Croatian ports or airports and travel on Croatian roads. Throughout the war, Croatia has taken a share of illegal arms flowing to the Muslims. So lifting the embargo on Bosnia means lifting it on Croatia; further arming of Croatia could jeopardize the shaky truce in the Croatian-Serbian conflict. The Croats are waiting for their chance to regain territory lost to the Serbians, and renewed fighting in Croatia would be another setback for peace.
Selective air strikes are no solution. Air strikes alone, without ground forces, would not roll back Serbian territorial gains. It is debatable whether they would force the Serbians back to the negotiating table. This action might well stiffen their resolve and prompt further aggression.
In addition to their questionable military value, air strikes and lifting the embargo would surely destroy humanitarian assistance. Key contributors to the U.N. Protection Force would remove their troops rather than expose them to retaliatory attacks. Hundreds of thousands of refugees would be the first to suffer.
The only durable solution is a negotiated settlement among the Muslims, Serbians and Croats. The peace process may be flawed, perhaps fatally; if so, it will have to be replaced by another negotiating track. Our efforts should remain focused on stopping the killing, not on contributing more weapons or violence to the region.
We must tighten the sanctions on and isolation of the Serbians in accordance with the new U.N. mandate. If the sanctions prove insufficient, we should seek termination of all diplomatic and economic ties. Military force remains available if other measures fail -- and if an allied consensus emerges.

HEADLINE: Observer;
Could Be A Long Season

BYLINE: By RUSSELL BAKER

 BODY:
President Clinton's bad week at the Capitol brings to mind Casey Stengel, Franklin Roosevelt and Lyndon Johnson. "Can't anybody here play this game?" asked Stengel when he was put in charge of a major league baseball team on which nobody could.
It was the New York Mets, a brand-new expansion team, that provoked Stengel's cry of anguish. The Clinton Administration is also brand-new. What's worse, it is beginning to look like a typical baseball expansion team. 
 That means, in case baseball is not your dish, a comical bunch of greenhorns and tired old-timers who don't win very often. Thus: Because the President couldn't change four votes in the Senate, he lost his economic stimulus program Wednesday.
The three television reporters I happened to catch pronounced it a "major defeat," and even The New York Times called it "serious." What makes it serious, and possibly even major, is that new Presidents shouldn't lose showdowns like this during their first hundred days.
This is when a new President ought to be proving he is a winner, somebody you mess with only if you don't mind getting your block knocked off. In the fight over the economic stimulus program, it was the President who got his block knocked off.
The reason: He couldn't buy four senators. He had 56, which is a majority, but he needed 60 because a Republican filibuster was preventing the Senate from voting, and the quaint Senate rule says a majority isn't enough to squelch a filibuster. It takes 60.
Which is why Lyndon Johnson comes to mind. Johnson's demonizers have done such a good job blackening his name that people have forgotten he was the last President who understood the science of domestic politics. It is inconceivable that L.B.J. would have accepted a Senate defeat for lack of four votes.
Without cataloguing Johnson's full line of equipment for changing senatorial minds, I merely point out that the most formidable part of it was knowledge: he knew what every senator most needed, and what every senator most desired.
And every senator, like every other politician, is a mass of needs and desires, some of which are of absolute urgency, and most of which Presidents can happily fulfill. Or frustrate.
In "The Best and the Brightest" David Halberstam tells of Frank Church, Senator from Idaho and critic of Johnson's Vietnam policy, meeting with L.B.J., and Johnson asking where Church was getting material for his powerful anti-war speeches. Getting it from Walter Lippmann, the newspaper columnist, said Church.
And L.B.J. said: Next time you want a new dam out in Idaho, Frank, just ask Walter Lippmann for it.
Such is a President's power to sway senators' minds once he understands what makes them swayable. Cynics, who are often right anyhow, say that almost everything in politics has its price, including senators.
It is a graceless way to state the matter, but a President who can't buy a few senators when a few mean the difference between triumph and embarrassment probably didn't do his homework in President's school.
Which is why Franklin Roosevelt comes to mind, and a story I heard told at a long-ago Washington dinner by Thomas (Tommy the Cork) Corcoran, once one of Roosevelt's bright young men:
Counting votes on an important bill, F.D.R. was astonished when an adviser warned him that he would have to do a large favor for a distinguished Senator from the cactus belt or lose his vote. Roosevelt observed that he had just recently granted this statesman a considerable boon.
"How often do we have to buy him?" he asked. And was told: "Every time, Mr. President. Every time."
What efforts more persuasive than collegial discourse President Clinton may have made to win four crucial senators have not been publicly disclosed. One hesitates to assume there was an attempt to buy a few. The mere suggestion sounds brutally uncouth for an Administration rich in young Ivy League lawyers come to Washington to do good.
Which brings Franklin Roosevelt again to mind, for he too was surrounded by brilliant young lawyers who, as the old Washington wheeze has it, "came to do good, and stayed to do well." The present crop will do neither unless they learn that senators, even the Republican kind, are as human as the rest of us.

HEADLINE: Home Radon Curbs Need Not Be Costly

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The Environmental Protection Agency recently released two documents on indoor radon, a radioactive gas found in many homes. Your April 7 report, whose headline states we urge radon curbs in new homes, needs clarification. 
 Unlike many E.P.A. programs, E.P.A.'s radon-abatement program is nonregulatory. E.P.A. issues only "guidance" standards, based on recent research and technology, to be implemented on a voluntary basis.
You also report that some agency economists and home builders say the cost of new construction standards and testing requirements for radon could be $1 billion to $2 billion a year nationwide. The agency vigorously disputes such cost estimates.
After extensive collaboration with the National Association of Home Builders, E.P.A. estimates that these new construction guidelines, if adopted, would cost about $75 million if used in all 145,000 new homes built annually in the highest risk radon areas. If you add real estate testing cost estimates of $130 million to test all homes sold annually, the total would be about $200 million -- a stark contrast to $1 billion to $2 billion.
The agency and major health organizations, like the American Medical Association and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, have concluded radon is the second leading cause of lung cancer after smoking. From National Academy of Sciences studies, radon exposure is estimated to cause 7,000 to 30,000 lung cancer deaths yearly in the United States.
Radon is a naturally occurring pollutant, invisible, odorless and tasteless. The only way to determine if a home has a radon problem is to test for it. A home can be tested for as little as $25 to determine if there is a radon problem. Most homes won't have a radon problem. But if high levels are found, radon levels can be successfully reduced with straightforward techniques. Individuals can take simple steps to prevent this serious health hazard, unlike most other environmental pollutants, in their home.
 
MICHAEL H. SHAPIRO
Acting Assistant Administrator for Air and Radiation, Environmental Protection Agency
Washington, April 16, 1993

HEADLINE: Debacle on Times Square

BYLINE: By David W. Dunlap; David W. Dunlap is a real-estate reporter for The New York Times and the author of "On Broadway: A Journey Uptown Over Time."

 BODY:

HIGH RISE
How 1,000 Men and Women
Worked Around the Clock
for Five Years
and Lost $200 Million
Building a Skyscraper.
By Jerry Adler.
Illustrated. 374 pp. New York:
HarperCollins Publishers. $25. 
 WHETHER welcomed or despised, the many towers that bounded skyward in New York City during the 1980's seemed as inevitable as if produced by natural forces. On learning about the coincidences, accidents and sheer chance that shaped a single skyscraper, however, one marvels that anything got built at all.
The "High Rise" of Jerry Adler's narrative is 1540 Broadway, on Times Square, which sprouted during a building boom and limped to completion during a recession. Led by the developer Ian Bruce Eichner, hundreds of people spent hundreds of millions of dollars to produce an empty box 44 stories tall. (It has since been acquired by the Bertelsmann media conglomerate and renamed the Bertelsmann Building.)
Dramatic as they are, real-estate debacles are not easy to chronicle. When a property tips over the edge into bankruptcy or foreclosure, the developer usually hides behind lawyers who will not comment.
What makes "High Rise" a valuable postscript to the latest boom-and-bust cycle is that Mr. Adler, a senior editor at Newsweek, witnessed the tumultuous process firsthand, thanks to the cooperation of Mr. Eichner and his associates, and recorded in detail those episodes that they would probably rather forget.
Money was consumed in prying hold-out tenants from existing buildings and shoring up the landmark Lyceum Theater next door on 45th Street when it developed a large crack during excavations. Mr. Eichner wrestled with his architects over design and materials. And he struggled with his retail partners over a multimedia electronic display called the "Whiz Bang," which was supposed to animate the shopping atrium at the building's base but succeeded only in driving the development team apart. Meanwhile, prospective office tenants came and went.
Punctuating this tale are fascinating digressions about zoning, financing and construction. For instance, to explain why engineers must factor human metabolism into the design of ventilation and cooling systems, Mr. Adler notes that the working population of 1540 Broadway was expected to give off heat that was the caloric equivalent of three pizzas every minute. To explain why elevator consultants tend to specify more cabs than are absolutely necessary, he says: "The consequence of underelevatoring -- riots in the lobby by lawyers forced to wait a whole minute to start making money -- is too awful to contemplate."
A small shadow is cast on the book by errors like the description of the RCA Building as having a spire. By themselves, these mistakes do not compromise the points Mr. Adler is trying to make, but they raise the suspicion that other details may not be entirely reliable.
A larger shadow is cast by the relationship between author and subject. The Bruce Eichner who emerges in this account is a terribly earnest and hard-working man compromised by forces outside his control; he is far more admirable than the arrogant, devil-may-care figure portrayed in the popular press. Did Mr. Adler discover the true Bruce Eichner or fall too far under his spell? Although the author offers the assurance that the opinions in the book are his own, it would have helped to know what conditions, if any, were imposed on his reporting.
When the differences over the building project erupt into litigation, Mr. Adler briefly describes the lawsuits and the various accusations of malfeasance, but declares, "This is not the place to determine the truth of these allegations." Why not? Given his singular knowledge of the subject and his presumed disinterest, Mr. Adler would have been the perfect guide through the tangle of conflicting assertions on which the story ends.

HEADLINE: The Scientist Who Took Pictures

BYLINE: By Andy Grundberg; Andy Grundberg is the director of the Friends of Photography and the Ansel Adams Center in San Francisco.

 BODY:

PICTURING TIME
The Work of Etienne-Jules Marey (1830-1904).
By Marta Braun.
Illustrated. 450 pp. Chicago:
The University of Chicago Press. $65.
 
ETIENNE-JULES MAREY
A Passion for the Trace.
By Francois Dagognet.
Translated by Robert Galeta
with Jeanine Herman.
Illustrated. 204 pp. Cambridge, Mass.:
Zone Books/The MIT Press. $26.95. 
 THE 19th-century French scientist, inventor and photographic innovator Etienne-Jules Marey has long been consigned to the margins of the history of photography. Compared with Eadweard James Muybridge, a contemporary whose stop-action images of human and animal locomotion are frequently reproduced and exhibited, he is a virtual cipher. One might suspect that this disparity is because Muybridge made better pictures than Marey, especially since their subject matter and interests often overlapped. Or perhaps it is because Muybridge, who murdered his wife's lover in addition to taking photographs of everything from Yosemite Valley to galloping horses, led a more intriguing life.
Neither supposition is accurate. Marey was never a professional photographer like Muybridge, but the photographs he produced between 1882 and 1901 are not only unexpectedly beautiful, but also useful in a sense that Muybridge's pictures are not. And Marey's career was phenomenally fruitful and varied; he had an effect on physiology, aviation, physical education, industrial management, cinema and 20th-century art in profound and often startling ways.
Trained as a physiologist, Marey dedicated his life to finding ways to record the workings of the body. His first invention was an ungainly, strap-on machine that charted the pulse. This was the first "graphic inscriptor" used in modern medicine, according to Marta Braun -- a professor in the department of film and photography at Ryerson Polytechnical Institute in Torono -- whose "Picturing Time: The Work of Etienne-Jules Marey (1830-1904)" is a paragon of judicious historical reassessment. The camera, Ms. Braun argues convincingly, was merely another recording device for Marey, albeit one with the essential ability to chart movement through both space and time.
Marey's experiments with what he called "chronophotography" led him to develop cameras with oscillating shutters controlled by clockwork-style gears, so that each exposure occurred at a precise interval from the one before it and the one after it. Despite the practical difficulties of getting sufficient exposure and contrast to illustrate human movement clearly, Marey persevered with stop-motion photography for some 20 years. Many of his pictures are masterpieces of economy, capturing all the phases of a complex activity like pole-vaulting within the confines of a single frame and possessing what the art historian Aaron Scharf has called a "poetic force."
There is no disputing that Muybridge's early motion studies of horses, done under the patronage of the railroad tycoon Leland Stanford, predate Marey's first involvement with photography. Indeed, it was Muybridge's visit to Paris in 1881 that inspired the Burgundy-born physiologist to develop his own stop-action cameras. But whereas Muybridge kept one eye on the camera and one on the marketplace, Marey was the model of a disinterested scientist. Marey intuitively recognized what Ms. Braun reveals as the scandal of Muybridge's corpus of locomotion studies: they are so full of gaps, rearrangements and seemingly willful deceptions that they are useless as objective data. Marey's chronophotographs, on the other hand, scrupulously adhere to the scientific method of the time.
Marey can also claim to have developed the first workable motion picture projector, which he devised as a means of synthesizing the aspects of motion he took such pains to isolate. (As Ms. Braun's recounting of 19th-century experiments with pre-cinematic devices like the phenakistoscope and zoopraxiscope suggests, Marey, like Thomas Edison and the Lumieres, was only one of several "fathers" of the cinema.) In addition, his interest in how birds fly led him to experiments that paved the way for the Wright brothers' flight, and his motion studies of athletes created new methods of physical training and inspired subsequent studies of how workers perform tasks in industrial settings.
"Picturing Time" is a first-rate model of what is called the new art history or, more modestly, contextualist art history. While much of it is devoted to a well-researched and presented biography of Marey, its importance lies in Ms. Braun's insistence on treating Marey's images as more than esthetic tokens. Marey, in her view, was not an autonomous producer of marvelous, revealing pictures but a representative of the 19th-century positivist faith in objective measurement and recording. Thus his photographs are more complex and interesting than heretofore imagined.
This is not to say that Marey's pictures had no influence on the art world. As Ms. Braun demonstrates, Cubists, Futurists and Dadaists all made use of his images in their attempts to forge a new perspective reflective of modernity. She says that the impact of Marey's pictures on early modernist artists was "probably greater than any scientific work . . . since the discovery of perspective in the Renaissance," citing Marcel Duchamp's "Nude Descending a Staircase" and Giacomo Balla's "Girl Running on a Balcony" as two well-known examples. Just because artists used Ma rey's pictures as models, however, one should not be tempted to conclude that Marey intended his photographs as works of art.
If Ms. Braun's thoughtful and well-organized explication of Marey's achievements and influences exemplifies the virtues of the contextualist method of art history, Francois Dagognet's "Etienne-Jules Marey: A Passion for the Trace" is a model of most of the method's faults. The title perhaps is sufficient warning, but Mr. Dagognet, who teaches epistemology at the University of Lyons, is capable of overheated, undocumented generalizations apparently beyond the remedial grasp of any editor or translator. Contextualism? Here is Mr. Dagognet on the impact on Futurism of what he calls "Mareyism": "Marey made it possible for the avant-garde to become receptive to new values: instead of escape into the past, the unreal or the dream, there was the double cult of machines and their propulsion. . . . One could hear the beating and hum of Marey's motors as well as his hearts. This was the double idolatry of powerful machines and their speed -- the simultaneous overtaking of space and time!"
Just how Marey's photographs "made it possible" for the avant-garde to enter the machine age is left to the reader. But while Mr. Dagognet's enthusiastic text is no match for Ms. Braun's detailed arguments and scholarship, he agrees with her about the importance of Marey's work -- as an example of 19th-century positivism and as a precursor of 20th-century modernism.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Chronophotograph of a high jump, 1886, by Etienne-Jules Marey. (Cinematheque Francaise/From "Picturing Time")

SECTION: Section 6; Page 29; Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 6407 words

HEADLINE: Angels' Angels

BYLINE: By Bruce Weber; Bruce Weber writes the On Stage, and Off column for The New York Times.

 BODY:
In a bright morning in mid-March, the splashy, old-fashioned lights outside the Walter Kerr Theater on West 48th Street in Manhattan suddenly flashed on and began their Busby Berkeley-ish dance around the the theater's empty marquee. As photographers on the street snapped away, a crane hoisted a billboard announcing the next attraction -- "Angels in America" by Tony Kushner.
The billboard presents an eerie painting by Milton Glaser: a dark figure, human but winged, crouching in an attitude that could be interpreted as supplication, obeisance or grief. It's a fair representation of Kushner's play, a two-part, seven-hour epic that considers the AIDS plague as the defining metaphor for a national spiritual decline during the 1980's and as the starting point of a social order for the next century. 
 At a time when Broadway, dominated by ostentatious British musicals and American revivals, seems to have virtually abdicated its role as the prime showcase of new plays, "Angels in America: A Gay Fantasia on National Themes" is the most eagerly awaited production of the last several seasons. Part 1, "Millennium Approaches," which just won the Pulitzer Prize, opens on May 4. President Clinton has been invited; so has Madonna. (Kushner is rewriting Part 2, "Perestroika," which will go into rehearsals over the summer and begin showing in repertory with Part 1 in the fall.)
So the billboard being fitted on the marquee was a moment hard to beat for symbolic value -- the glitz of Broadway meets the sobriety of ambitious drama. And it certainly wasn't lost on the men posing for pictures below it: Rocco Landesman, president of Jujamcyn Theaters, which owns the Kerr; Gordon Davidson, whose Center Theater Group in Los Angeles produced both parts of "Angels in America" for the first time last fall, and Kushner himself, a 36-year-old playwright who lives in Brooklyn and who was relatively obscure until enthusiasm for "Angels" escalated into a kind of hysteria during the staging of "Millennium Approaches" at the Royal National Theater in London a year ago.
For these three men -- one a kind of upstart entrepreneur bent on forcing the commercial theater to acknowledge the late 20th century, another a theater guy in a movie town 3,000 miles from center stage and the third a sudden star who has emerged from the minority fringe to test his artistic power in the mainstream spotlight -- the arrival of "Angels" in New York is a climax of aspirations. Their fortunes -- and the show's -- are being handicapped all over the theater world with the outcome viewed as a bellwether for the future of innovative drama on Broadway.
In "Angels in America," eight actors play some 30 roles, including voices, ghosts and hallucinations. But the main figures are a gay couple, one of whom is dying of AIDS; a Mormon man, who is just waking to his homosexuality, and his agoraphobic wife, and Roy Cohn, the power-mongering reactionary lawyer who died of AIDS in 1986. The dialogue, some furious, some anguished, some uproariously comic, is pitched to searing, wicked condemnation of the nation's collective conscience during the Reagan-Bush years.
Though it is an unconventional and challenging work, you would be hard pressed to find anyone who doubts that "Angels in America" deserves the wide audience only Broadway can attract. In London and Los Angeles, critics have gone berserk; even longtime theater professionals who generally reserve their superlatives for the dead have checked in. "I believe it will be seen as perhaps the most important theatrical event of the latter part of the century," says Jason Steven Cohen, the producing director of the Joseph Papp Public Theater in Greenwich Village, where the play was supposed to appear before a fevered auction among Broadway producers and theater owners kidnapped it for uptown.
The story of "Angels in America" is a case study of how theatrical art and commerce coalesce, an illustration of the well-worn path from inspiration to collaboration. But it's also a tale of the hunger in the theater world for hits, for art, for attention to a medium that has been eclipsed by movies and television. As the 11 producers' names above the title attest, this is a show that everyone wants to put a thumbprint on. Yet nobody thinks it'll make a lot of money. By the producers' estimates, it will have to run a year -- a dicey bet -- to recoup its backers' $2.2 million investment. And as Rocco Landesman points out: "What does recoup mean? It means we're back to where we started."
In a startling theatrical moment at the end of "Millennium Approaches," an angel crashes through the ceiling of a dying man's bedroom. It's fair to ask about the play what audiences ask about this symbol. Where does this angel come from? What does this angel portend?
IT WAS IN THE MID-1980'S, AFTER HE GRADUATED from Columbia and the graduate theater program at New York University, that Tony Kushner wrote a poem about Mormons and the paradox of their biased ways in the service of good works.
A recently uncloseted gay man with an intellectual bent, an interest in Freud and feminism, fiercely left-leaning political views and what he describes as "a guilty affection for this country," Kushner was, at the time, on a directing fellowship at the St. Louis Repertory Theater. The poem, written on an introspective whim, was called "Angels in America" and was bad enough, Kushner says, that he won't show it to anyone now. But it contained the seeds of the play he began writing in 1987, commissioned by his friend Oskar Eustis, a like-minded (if heterosexual) and visually inventive dramaturg, then the artistic director of the Eureka Theater in San Francisco.
"All I knew," Kushner says, "was that I wanted to write about gay men, Mormons and Roy Cohn."
A tall, oddly cherubic-looking man with a small earring in one ear, Kushner, the son of musicians, grew up in Lake Charles, La. He has spoken freely about the influence that harboring his secret homosexuality had on his play. He also acknowledges the influence of Kimberly Flynn, a fellow student at Columbia with whom he spent thousands of hours discussing Marxism and feminism and sexual politics and who remains his closest friend.
"The thing I learned most from her," Kushner says, "is that justice is part of the human condition. Injustice is anti-life."
There is more to Flynn's contribution to the play, however. In 1984, Flynn was involved in a taxicab accident, leaving her brain-injured, a condition from which she is, at long last, recovered.
"The business of helping her handle the sequellae to the accident was my most direct experience with serious health problems," Kushner says. "To that extent, there are elements of her story that have become incorporated in 'Angels.' I feel ambivalent about using them. Going through a terrible crisis with someone is, after all, not the same as going through the crisis."
As Kushner tells it, the play could not have been written without Flynn. Nor could it have been written without Oskar Eustis, whose serendipitous meeting with Kushner one evening in 1985 happened only because he was late for the theater.
"I'd missed a curtain at the Public and a friend of mine said, 'Why don't you come to a play with me?' " Eustis recalls. "It was at a loft in the 20's and I was bowled over by it."
The play was Kushner's first full-length work, "A Bright Room Called Day," a drama that drew parallels between the fall of the Weimar Republic in Germany and the Reagan years in the United States. Eustis quickly glommed onto it, announcing his interest by singing the Internationale along with the cast at the end of the first act. Eventually he produced and directed its professional premiere at the Eureka in the fall of 1987.
By that time, Eustis and Kushner were a team, well into the planning of their next project, which Eustis describes as short and humorous but with serious intellectual underpinnings having to do with the shared migratory experience of Jews, Mormons and homosexuals.
"The idea had to do with the exodus history of America," Eustis says. "You set out from an oppressive old place, go into the wilderness and reinvent yourself, start a new community free of the plagues of the old one. And yet you can never do that, really.
"We were terribly excited about this 90-minute comedy. But then in the fall of 1988, the first draft came in and we knew we were in trouble. It was 240 pages long and didn't come close to the end of any story. The angel just came in through the roof."
The long manuscript, delivered late, was the start of tensions between the two friends, as their aspirations for it began to diverge. It was, essentially, a struggle between collaborators over whose vision should be chiefly served and it was resolved only when Eustis suggested that someone else -- anyone else -- direct the play in New York. But that was still four years away.
By that time, an inexorable force had gathered behind the play, the initial signs of which became apparent to Kushner at the the first reading of it, which took place two days after Thanksgiving 1988 at the New York Theater Workshop under the auspices of its artistic director, James C. Nicola.
"I was in the lobby apologizing to people, telling them it was so long they could get up and walk out if they wanted," Kushner remembers. "But during the breaks they told me to shut up and let the actors finish. And when it was over, Jim Nicola came up to me and said: 'I want to produce this play. Immediately.' "
While that was impossible because of the Eureka commission, it was, Kushner says, his first inkling that he was on to something unusual. He decided rather than go ahead with the scheduled opening at the Eureka that spring to continue writing a play that he felt, even at more than four hours long, was only half finished.
Not surprisingly, this angered the board of the Eureka, a struggling company financially (it's now moribund, having not staged a full production since last spring), which at the last minute had to revamp its spring schedule without the show meant to be its centerpiece. Everyone ended up mad, and the future of the show might have been far different if another bit of serendipity, in the form of Gordon Davidson, hadn't materialized. It was owing to Davidson's instinct and opportunism that the play took its next step up the theater ladder.
AS ARTISTIC HEAD OF THE center Theater Group, which operates the Mark Taper Forum and other theaters in Los Angeles, Davidson, 59, is essentially the theater godfather of Southern California. He has shipped many shows dealing with social issues east from the Taper, some of them turning out to be hits (notably "Children of a Lesser God" and "Jelly's Last Jam"). But as a New York expatriate in a city where movie executives buy up subscription tickets to his theaters and then don't show up for the play, he has been working in relative obscurity for 26 years.
A paternal, if occasionally self-promoting gray eminence, Davidson admired Eustis's work, and in early 1989 he invited Eustis to become a resident director at the Taper. Eustis, fed up with the Eureka, accepted, and on a kind of unofficial basis brought "Angels" with him. Discussions between the Taper and the Eureka ensued, and Davidson eventually made a deal: the Taper would develop the play on its own, but the Eureka would stage the world premiere.
One immediate consequence of the Taper's acquisition was dividing the play into its two present parts. Kushner says it was Robert Egan, the theater's associate artistic director, who first suggested to him that his play wasn't half done; rather, Egan told Kushner, there were two related plays and that Part 1 could stand alone.
"I now believe he was completely right," Kushner says, living up to his reputation for mulishness. Davidson, for his part, wasn't sure either, but he promised Kushner up front that the Taper would present both plays together, thereby earning the playwright's loyalty.
"I honestly didn't know if he had one long play or a two-part play," says Davidson. "But when you heard it, when you saw it, you knew you were in the presence of a writer."
The work on "Millennium Approaches" subsidized by the Taper was substantial. There were dozens of readings and workshops and finally a nearly full-scale production, with an $80,000 budget, held in the spring of 1990.
By that time, the play was causing a buzz. The final Taper workshop, reviewed locally with enthusiasm, was attended by representatives of the Royal National Theater in London, who, with the prescient instinct of outsiders and the British curiosity about the Colonies, expressed a desire to present it.
Eustis and Kushner were satisfied that "Millennium" was a finished product -- "We felt we could ship it to England," he says -- and they set their sights on the world premiere of "Angels in America" in San Francisco, a production that was to include "Perestroika," which was scheduled for the following spring.
The problem was that "Perestroika" was still an embryo, and Kushner, an anguished writer under the best of circumstances, was distracted over the summer by the death of his mother. "They wouldn't let me off the hook," Kushner says, still evidently smarting from the Eureka's pressure on him to meet his deadlines.
Indeed, the draft of "Perestroika" he submitted at the end of the summer was concluded in abrupt, absurd fashion. "All the characters are standing at the base of the Empire State Building and an atom bomb goes off and that's the end of 'Angels in America,' " he says. "It didn't work, but it's what I did to get out of my obligation."
Nonetheless, the play went on as scheduled, directed by David Esbjornson, then a Taper artistic associate who, unlike Eustis or Kushner, had no ax to grind with the Eureka board.
"Frankly, I think both Oskar and Tony knew it was going to be a very difficult situation," Esbjornson says, reflecting on why the job came to be his. And though Esbjornson, who is now artistic director of the Classic Stage Company in New York, calls the production of "Millennium" perhaps his best work, the whole episode was, apparently, an odd one. "Millennium Approaches" was a great success, in spite of incidents of scenery collapsing and other low-budget catastrophes. But "Perestroika" was still so far from completion that it was a little ludicrous to have put it on at all.
"At the time we started rehearsals, I had one act of 'Perestroika' written," says Kushner, who with "Millennium" in rehearsals, went off to a cabin on the Russian River in Northern California. There, he says, "in 10 days I wrote 293 pages."
The Eureka staged 17 readings of it, "but it was so long," Kushner says, "we had to skip over some of the larger parts."
Thus the twins were split-up: as "Perestroika" went back to Los Angeles for rehab, "Millennium Approaches" went to England and became a star.
DECLAN DONNELLAN, the man who made "Angels in America" a sensation in England, first heard about it in Brazil. That's where he was in the summer of 1991, on tour with his production company, Cheek by Jowl, when Richard Eyre, the director of the Royal National Theater, sent him a copy by courier and asked him to direct it.
He was immediately attracted to the American-ness of the story, which he felt deserved a wider audience than just America. And it reminded him, he says, "in its complete lack of sentimentality" of the 17th-century plays he's more accustomed to staging. As both director and author point out, Kushner was the first living playwright Donnellan had ever worked with.
"During most of the rehearsal period, he seemed very likely to join the ranks of the dead," Donnellan says.
With the opening scheduled for January 1992, Kushner flew to London in December, where, by both his and Donnellan's reckoning, he made a pest of himself. He objected to, among other things, the set, which presented the action inside a large stars-and-stripes decorated box, as though it were illustrative of wretched American excess.
"I thought, 'Oh, God, they don't really like the play -- they just want to do this play to knock America,' " Kushner says, adding, "Declan wasn't used to getting anybody else's input, much less a writer's."
For Kushner, a self-confessed control freak who in rehearsals is used to providing directors with pages of unasked-for and unwanted notes, the experience in London was a trial that bore rewards. After seeing one run-through and panicking, he recalls, Donnellan laid down some ground rules: Kushner would not be allowed to see the first preview. At the second preview, he had to sit in the audience, not stand at the back, and he couldn't take notes.
"I was stunned when I finally saw it," Kushner says. "It had blossomed in a way that hadn't seemed possible. And what I learned is that directing is not sculpting. It's about releasing energy, not imprisoning it."
Still, it was not until opening night that Kushner had his catharsis. He can't bear watching openings, so instead he was invited to partake of a Royal National Theater tradition. He set off the Ralph rocket -- a firework launched over the Thames at the moment the curtain is raised -- named for Ralph Richardson, who initiated the rite.
"I went up to the balcony and shot this Roman candle-looking thing off," he says. "And this enormous purple explosion lit up the sky. That was the happiest moment for me."
There were more of them: sterling reviews, the Evening Standard Award for the year's best play and an agreement with Donnellan that they'd work together again on "Perestroika."
Meanwhile, if producers in New York had not heard the rumble in Los Angeles, the thunder in London got their attention. Rocco Landesman saw it there; so did Bernard B. Jacobs and Gerald Schoenfeld, the president and chairman respectively of the Shubert Organization, New York's largest theater-owning group. And so did Frank Rich, whose glittering encomium in The New York Times in March 1992 compared the playwright to John Dos Passos. "Mr. Kushner has created an original theatrical world of his own," Rich wrote, "poetic and churning, that, once entered by an open-minded viewer of any political or sexual persuasion, simply cannot be ignored." As perhaps the most palpable signal of Kushner's emerging stardom, the Gap asked him to pose for an ad.
The focus on the show shifted back to Los Angeles, where Gordon Davidson prepared to make good on his promise to stage the whole kit and caboodle. And by then, rumors had already begun to circulate that after Los Angeles, "Angels" would bypass a previously arranged engagement at the Public Theater in New York and go straight to Broadway. A commercial run!
"When it was a big critical success at the National," Oskar Eustis says. "it changed the stratosphere in which we were moving."
BUT FOR KUSHNER, Eustis and Davidson the excitement meant headaches. For them the project was not just a matter of moving the London production across the ocean. Donnellan had other obligations, and besides, Davidson had spent more than $100,000 of the Taper's money developing the play. He wanted a Taper production with the Davidson imprimatur.
For that matter, so did Eustis, who expected, at last, to direct it. This was a debt Kushner intended to honor.
"In a sense," Kushner says, "the play was written in dialogue with Oskar. I started out writing it for him to direct."
Mounting a seven-hour play with less than two months' rehearsal time is more or less impossible. In addition, "Perestroika" was still unfocused, flabby. As deadlines accumulated -- for set designs, lighting schemes and the like -- the pressure ratcheted up significantly. And when work on "Millennium" was complete and that on "Perestroika" began, worry burgeoned into discontent. Some of the actors began to feel Eustis was overwhelmed. His disagreements with Kushner were mounting, even though a co-director, Anthony Taccone, had been appointed to share the mammoth task.
"There was an attempt to hedge the bet," Davidson says. "Taccone's strengths would complement Oskar's weakness, but it was an idea better in conception than execution."
Kushner absolves Eustis -- "I love watching Oskar's work on other people's shows," he says -- and, in fact, he takes much of the blame on himself. "This was the first, the flagship, production. I needed it to be the way I wanted it to be."
Kushner was rewriting madly to the last moment; an 11-page monologue delivered by the angel had to be memorized by the actress, Ellen McLaughlin, the night before the critics' opening.
"We ended up exposing 'Perestroika' not unfairly but dangerously," Davidson says. "It hadn't benefited from the gestation the first part had."
The problems in Los Angeles were symbolized by the angel, which never quite managed to fly right; the complicated rigging left McLaughlin, after crashing through the ceiling, hanging there spinning, slowly and helplessly.
"The designs were redesigned," Kushner says, "but then her wig would get caught in it. Finally, we got it so that if nobody breathed in the theater and we got the lights off quickly, you wouldn't see her start spinning. But she always sort of torqued a little bit to the left."
WHEN "Angels in America"opened for a limited run at the Mark Taper Forum in October, it quickly became a celebrated ticket. The screen stars came out for the day-night marathons -- they laughed! they wept! -- and cast members began hearing from agents they hadn't heard from in years.
Stephen Spinella, an actor who had been with the project from the outset in San Francisco, tells the story of eating lunch with a new agent for the first time and being approached at his table by a vaguely familiar man.
"He came over to the table and said, 'Don't I know you?' And I said, 'I don't know.' And he said: 'You were in 'Angels in America' and I thought you were terrific. I'm Paul Mazursky.' That was the best, and I'm sitting there with my new agent."
Reviews, though superb overall and gentle in their acknowledging that "Perestroika" was still a work in progress, nonetheless took notice that more work needed to be done before the show came to a Broadway stage, which, by the beginning of November, began to seem inevitable. All three Broadway theater-owning groups -- the Shubert Organization, the Nederlander Organization and Jujamcyn Theaters -- and several independent producers expressed interest. Jujamcyn even commissioned an audience survey at the Taper, the better to discuss with Kushner their plans for marketing the show.
More ominously, Frank Rich, reviewing the show for a second time, while lionizing Kushner as a playwright with the promise to both "change the world" and "revolutionize the theater," compared the direction and the set design at the Taper unfavorably with those in London, which worried those who wanted to produce the play in New York. It was a surprise to no one when Davidson announced what had already been decided but kept unpublicized, that when the show moved East, it would have another director and designer, which meant the production would have to be mounted from scratch. Again.
For Kushner, however, the move to New York loomed as a genuine moral crossroad. Where did this play belong? In a small, nonprofit theater that has been traditionally devoted to new work, experimental work, politically argumentative work? Or in the commercial world where more people would undoubtedly get to see it, but where art is frequently compromised by the profit motive?
He spent two weeks mulling over his options, consulting frequently with his agent, Joyce Ketay, his old friend Jim Nicola and Davidson.
At the same time, he was having the dizzying experience of being wooed by independent producers and given his choice of New York's most prestigious theaters. The Shuberts even ignored some of their empty houses and offered the Booth, a lovely, intimate theater on prime 45th Street real estate, suggesting they would move the show that was already there, "Someone Who'll Watch Over Me," somewhere else.
But Kushner had not yet ruled out the Public, the flagship of the New York Shakespeare Festival, whose then-artistic director, JoAnne Akalaitis, made a final, fevered pitch to land the show that went directly to Kushner's conscience. The play is, after all, a proud cry on behalf of a maligned minority, and indeed it speaks with bruising intellect and emotion against the status quo, the very people whose embrace it would ask for on Broadway.
"JoAnne made a very, very moving speech to me," Kushner says. "She said: 'This is a play that comes directly from the downtown community. It needs to be seen as our play before it goes to a larger community.' That made it hard to say no."
IN THE END, OF course, that's what he said. He also said no to Bernie Jacobs, the venerable Shubert president, who at the last minute summoned Kushner to his office for a two-hour meeting. The meeting, on Wednesday, Dec. 9, impressed Kushner and left Jacobs with the sense he'd won the young man over.
But Kushner wanted everything for his play -- maximum exposure and fidelity to its roots -- and over the course of the play's journey he'd learned a lot about the power he had to get his way. The day after his meeting with Jacobs, he chose the Walter Kerr Theater, a Jujamcyn house whose creative staff would also be active producers of the show along with a passel of other producers who pledged to make the show inviting to a less affluent downtown community.
It was Gordon Davidson who made the call to the Shuberts, with whom he has considerable business ties (among other things, his wife is a press agent who handles many Shubert shows on the road). The news unleashed from Jacobs a stream of vivid vituperation. "It's going to take a while to repair that relationship," Davidson said at the time.
For the Shuberts, the commercial theater's most powerful entity, it was a bitter moment. Their theaters house the long-running Lloyd Webber musicals and their reputation for being canny businessmen rather than supporters of art is built partly on the fact that these houses are filled with highly profitable tourist attractions instead of spicier new works. Jacobs and the organization's chairman, Gerald Schoenfeld, fervently object to this characterization and constantly collect chits to support the contrary argument: "Dancing at Lughnasa," "The Sisters Rosensweig," "Someone Who'll Watch Over Me" and "Falsettos," among others, all found Shubert homes.
But unlike Jujamcyn, the Shuberts are rarely involved with the creative end of production and in recent years have pulled back on their investments, preferring the safer role of landlord. And so their reputation persists, and "Angels in America," the biggest chit of all, got away.
The other big loser was JoAnne Akalaitis, who last month was ousted by the board of the New York Shakespeare Festival, in large part because projects that cause this kind of excitement were not ending up at the Public Theater. Akalaitis was slow in warming to "Angels," or at least she didn't get heated up over the play until it looked as though she'd lose it. In the end, all she managed to land for the Shakespeare Festival was its name listed as associate producer and tickets for its subscribers.
For Rocco Landesman, meanwhile, it was a huge victory in what has become Jujamcyn's war against Broadway business as usual. In the last five years under Landesman's stewardship, Jujamcyn, which owns just five theaters in New York, has been aggressively trying to reinvigorate the Broadway scene and expand its audience beyond the middle-aged and older white middle class.
Clearly, "Angels in America" is a project that fits Jujamcyn's goals. And it also suits Landesman, 46, a slight, jittery man with thinning red hair and a pointy beard who is an unrepentant gambler; when he isn't betting on long-shot shows, he's off playing the ponies.
"This is what I took the job for," he says. "If we're not going to try to make something like this work, where's the fun?"
At the time, Kushner said he made his decision for all of these reasons, which essentially boils down to his favoring the style of Landesman and his creative director, Jack Viertel, to that of the Shuberts. But asked again, weeks later, he says simply: "Rocco and Jack are the people who came up with the idea of George, and that was a really good idea."
GEORGE IS GEORGE C. Wolfe, the writer and director of "Jelly's Last Jam" and currently perhaps the most sought-after theater talent of any kind -- actor, director, writer or producer. He is known for being in touch with the modern world in a way that few mainstream theater types are these days. At age 38, black and gay, he has fringe-culture credentials and an ear for for what's humming downtown. At the same time, with "Jelly's" -- famous for its inventively brisk staging and its black-on-black social politics -- he's shown he can make those things palatable, even alluring, in the more staid Broadway environment. The same qualities were cited by the board of the New York Shakespeare Festival when it tapped Wolfe as its new producer last month.
Naming Wolfe was, in effect, the producers' first salvo in marketing the show to New York, though the move was not without intrigue. Declan Donnellan was actually approached first, but he was busy. Wolfe was the idea of Margo Lion, one of the show's producers who had worked with him on "Jelly's," and as Landesman says, as soon as she brought it up, everyone knew it was a natural fit.
The problem was that Wolfe also had a previous commitment; he had agreed to direct "Marisol," a play by Jose Rivera, at the Hartford Stage, which was about to go into rehearsals. The offer to direct "Angels" forced him to make a decision it still pains him to recall. It pained the Hartford Stage, too. In a public statement, its artistic director, Mark Lamos, called Wolfe's move, and the "Angels" producers encouragement of it, "reprehensible."
"It was the first time in my career where what I was supposed to do, because of the journey it would take me on as an artist, was counter to what I was supposed to do because of decent, correct behavior," he says. "It was awful. It was like, 'What do I honor?' " Wolfe says no ego was involved in his final decision, though he's keenly aware of his growing stature -- the show's costume designer, Toni-Leslie James, refers to Wolfe as George Corleone -- and his landing the "Angels" job was an anointment of sorts. It was certainly a factor in his ascension at the Public just a few weeks later. "I didn't know how to do the play, at first," Wolfe explains. "It scared me. And I sort of have this rule for myself, which is: If something artistically scares you, you must do it."
The New York production has had some rocky moments but not the grievous conflicts that dogged the play elsewhere. The first preview was postponed because of more trouble with the angel's harness, and at the first night before an audience, the ceiling didn't open on cue for the falling angel. After that, the producers decided to postpone the opening for five days to work on the technical problems.
But Wolfe is the first director who has not given Kushner conniptions. And the cast members, uniformly delighted by the opportunity to work on just one play for seven weeks, express excitement, even though three of the eight are performing in the play for the first time.
As a director of actors, Wolfe's style is to be challenging, literary. "You try to find as many truths as you can," he says. He's encouraged Ron Leibman, for instance, to make his Roy Cohn a little less bludgeoning, a little more plaintive, particularly in his relationship with Joe, his ambitious but conscience-stricken protege, whose occasional waffling and moralizing Roy finds frustrating and unforgivable.
"I'm playing the same notes," Leibman says, "But a lot of Roy's anger has become a kind of pleading. Instead of trying to hit Joe over the head, he's trying to make him understand. Then when the boy betrays me, it hurts more. It was George's suggestion. He's been saying to me, 'Try to make him see.' It's another way of playing the music, and I think it's fuller."
Says Stephen Spinella: "It's going to be bleaker than it was in Los Angeles. You know, the sun doesn't shine here as much. It'll be a New York show."
ON MAY 4, IT FINALLY arrives, a New York show indeed, with New York problems, namely the harsh economics of Broadway. With the exception of Wendy Wasserstein's comedy, "The Sisters Rosensweig," the few new shows on Broadway this season have had to struggle. There are no bankable stars attached to "Angels," and its homosexual banner will not help. Indeed, a couple of weeks ago Rocco Landesman asked Kushner to drop his subtitle, "A Gay Fantasia on National Themes," but Kushner wouldn't do it.
"This is no 'Falsettos,' the family gay musical," Kushner told him.
"We wanted to bury the gay fantasia themes," Landesman concedes. "Tony and I had a tough conversation about it. He effectively reminded me why I was drawn to the play. It's tough stuff. We should probably present it that way."
At $2.2 million just to get it ready, the show is already hugely expensive for a nonmusical play and weekly production costs are budgeted at about $180,000. Rehearsals for "Perestroika" begin in August, which means that for several weeks performances of "Millennium" will be cut to four. And there are other revenue-reducing factors as well. The producers' agreement stipulates that the New York Shakespeare Festival and the New York Theater Workshop get tickets for their subscribers at subscription prices. Most tickets have been priced at $50 or $60, a record high for a nonmusical. But to accommodate Kushner's insistence that the show not be out of the economic reach of people who should see it, second balcony seats are to be offered for prices as low as $7.50 for Wednesday matinees. Finally, the show has agreed to donate $1 to Broadway Cares/Equity Fights AIDS for every ticket sold.
What all this adds up to is that a lot of tickets have to be sold, and because the Kerr, at 945 seats, is a relatively small theater, that means the play has to run a long time.
"Angels" will be the last nonmusical play to open this season, and the opening itself was scheduled craftily -- even with the delay, it sneaks in just under the deadline for Tony nominations. Auspiciously, on the day of the first preview, "Millennium Approaches" won the Pulitzer Prize for drama, but as Landesman concedes, this show will need all the awards.
"The Tonys will be very important," Landesman says. "I would say decisive. A play as tough as this one without the imprimatur of the Tony that says this is the year's snob hit, it'll have a tough go."
The question, obviously, is why bother? Why not leave plays like this to regional theater, to the world of nonprofit? Theater professionals tend to have long memories and when they talk about Broadway today, even pragmatic producers like Landesman and Gordon Davidson wax nostalgic about Broadway back then, a place where hundreds of shows once opened annually, a veritable supermarket of theatrical goods.
It's that spirit that partly explains their involvement in "Angels in America," a play they believe in so deeply that it has grown almost to represent the crisis for serious drama on Broadway. If this show doesn't make it, what will?
But it also has to do with a belief in the power of art. Unfashionable as it is to accept high-mindedness as a motive, the producers of "Angels" are basically resigned to the show's producing only a modest return at best.
"I think it'll run a season, recoup its investment," says Frederick Zollo, one of the producers. "I don't expect it to be 'Life With Father.' " Zollo had wanted the Shuberts to get the show because they have theaters available with more seats than the Kerr. But he describes the experience of watching the play as "sticking your finger in a light socket -- and liking it," and he was determined to help produce it no matter where it went. For Zollo, and many of the others, too, a project like this is important because it's responsible, both to the theater and to theatergoers. In lowbrow times, it's a way of not giving up.
"I wanted to do this one very badly," Zollo says. "And I think there's an audience for it. There's an audience for risk. We don't test the audience much. If we tested the audience more, they'd come. What's the line from the Kevin Costner movie? 'If you build it, they will come'? Well, we don't build it very often."
IT IS A MORNING IN March, and in the strangely bomb-shelterish auditorium of the American Place Theater, a few floors below ground on West 46th Street, the "Angels in America" cast is rehearsing. The scene is tricky, with the action on stage separated like a split-screen film and the dialogue ricocheting like verbal pinball.
On one side, in a hospital room, Louis (played by Joe Mantello) is leaving his AIDS-afflicted lover, Prior (Spinella); across the stage, Joe (David Marshall Grant) is explaining to his wife, Harper (Marcia Gay Harden), that he has finally faced the fact that he is homosexual.
Wolfe asks the actors to read through the scene quickly, for lines and timing, and they do so, perfunctorily, several of them munching Harden's homemade bread. At this moment, it's hard for an observer to imagine this play, this uninflated thing, as a harbinger of the future of Broadway.
But then Wolfe suggests, "Let's do it with movement," and the scene begins anew, this time the actors doing their full turns and now a current builds as thedialogue on stage -- anguish mirroring anguish, back and forth, back and forth -- rises to two separate climaxes, four lives facing ruin, one moment of truth.
"If I could get up now, I'd kill you," Prior says to Louis.
"I recognize you now," the hallucinatory Harper says to Joe, identifying him as the recurring figure in her nightmares, "the man with the knives."
Louis leaves. Harper leaves.
"I hurt all over," Prior says, alone on one side of the stage, as Joe sobs on the other. "I wish I was dead."
The theater is uncomfortably silent for a long moment.
"Let's try it again," Wolfe says.
