HEADLINE: Hanoi Two Decades After the War

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON; PHILIP SHENON is the Bangkok bureau chief of The Times.

 BODY:
UNCLE HO never stops smiling as the bicycles whiz past him hour after hour in the middle of the busiest intersection in Hanoi. The bikes converge there beneath a giant billboard that shows a youthful, grinning Ho Chi Minh -- Uncle Ho, or Bach Ho, as he is still affectionately known in north Vietnam -- with a young child held tight in his thin arms.
The Vietnamese bicyclists rarely look up at the billboard, but that is no sign of disrespect for the founder of the Socialist Republic of Vietnam. It is a matter of simple survival. 
 The intersection of Trang Tien and Hoang Streets is a ceaseless blur of rubber and chrome -- there are relatively few private cars in the Vietnamese capital, so it is mostly bicycle and motorbike traffic -- and to lift your eyes from the road at this midtown crossing is to risk catastrophe.
The bicyclists pay no attention to a white-gloved, olive-uniformed traffic cop who stands on a small metal platform in the middle of the intersection. His directions, given with precise blasts of a whistle clenched between his front teeth, are ignored.
I tried to gaze up at Ho as I maneuvered my handsome new Vietnamese two-wheeler beneath the billboard and nearly collided with a farmer on the wrong side of the road, carting his potatoes to market.
Miraculously, I did not see a single serious bike collision during a week spent peddling my way through the streets of Hanoi and, apart from that one chaotic intersection, the traffic was remarkably civil.
The North Vietnamese are a determined, practical people -- they tend to win their wars, as they will diplomatically remind you -- and a bicycle is much too valuable a piece of property to allow to be damaged in a foolish accident.
"We are very, very careful if we see a foreigner on a bike," said Mr. Van, the young English-language student from Hanoi University who would prove himself an invaluable companion on my first bicycling tour of the city. "It would be very bad if we ran over an American," he said in the deadly serious tone typical of Northerners, who are also an earnest bunch. "It would be bad for foreign policy." (While the Vietnamese are not prohibited from having contact with foreigners, it can bring them under suspicion from the police, and for that reason I use only one of Mr. Van's three names.)
From a distance Hanoi seems to many foreign travelers a gray, hostile, even frightening place. Certainly for many Americans, the city is inseparable from the ugly headlines of the Vietnam War.
I've met several Americans who, planning a trip to Hanoi, gird themselves for what they assume will be a Southeast Asian Dresden, a bombed-out shell of a city. In fact, the city survived the war largely intact. It is arguably the most beautiful capital in Southeast Asia, a city of quiet, dignified, dilapidated charm borne of 1,000 years of history and struggle. The streets are lined with the architectural legacy of the French colonizers of Vietnam: crumbling but still elegant 19th-century ocher-colored villas and storefronts.
Despite still-primitive tourist facilities, Hanoi is also among the friendliest, most inviting capitals of Asia. The Vietnamese are unfailingly polite to travelers, especially to Americans, whose help they want to revive an economy that is only now beginning to recover from that long-ago war.
That Hanoi retains so much such Old Asian charm is a mixed blessing for the Vietnamese. The colonial-era architecture and greenery have survived not so much because of far-sighted urban planners; they reflect rather Vietnam's long economic stagnation.
After decades of war and disastrous Soviet-style central planning, Vietnam is one of the world's poorest countries, and progress -- as measured in much of the rest of Asia by skyscrapers and shopping malls and dirty air -- has yet to arrive for the three million people of Hanoi.
The question for the Vietnamese is how long Hanoi will remain this impoverished, and also this tranquil. The Vietnamese would never admit it, but they have been inspired by the recent economic model offered by their great rivals, the Chinese. In 1986 the Hanoi Government announced a Chinese-style policy of renovation -- doi moi, in Vietnamese -- intended to introduce a free market to Vietnam without dislodging the authoritarian government.
IT seems to be working. The Vietnamese economy is growing quickly, even with an American trade embargo in place, and visiting foreign investors and economists say it is only a matter of time before Hanoi begins to resemble its overdeveloped sister cities elsewhere in Southeast Asia.
Already the old South Vietnamese capital of Saigon, now Ho Chi Minh City, has taken on the appearance of a Bangkok suburb, complete with trendy restaurants and traffic congestion.
Hanoi may be the last major city of Southeast Asia best toured by bicycle -- a gentle breeze rustling through the tamarind and milkwood trees that line the narrow streets, the only other sound that of the tinkling of the handlebar bells on bicycles.
A bicycle tour of Hanoi begins with the search for a bike. The advice I had been given by Vietnamese friends -- and I'm glad I listened to it -- was to buy a new bicycle at the central government emporium on Trang Tien Street, across from the billboard of Uncle Ho. A new bicycle in Vietnam costs a small fraction of what it would in the West, $25 to $45. That guarantees you new wheels and new brakes, no small considerations. And while Vietnamese bicycles are not especially sturdy, they will doubtless survive several days on the capital's pancake-flat streets. Among the rows and rows of bicycles, I was immediately drawn to a sleek model with the brand name of Hanel. It had a price tag of 400,000 Vietnamese dong, or about $40.
It really was handsome, forest green with blue trim, and several wide-eyed children watched enviously as the saleslady pumped up the tires, dusted off the handlebars and raised the seat to accommodate a six-foot American. In her broken English, she thanked me, offering the most memorable line of my trip to Vietnam -- "Happy bike, mister America" -- as I waltzed my two-wheeled treasure to the street.
On my first day of touring, I chose a route that would take me from my hotel, the newly restored colonial-era Pullman Metropole on Ly Thai To Street, past some of the city's most memorable sites and picturesque neighborhoods, and on to its most important landmark, the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum.
I set off alone but I was quickly joined by a friendly Vietnamese student in his early 20's, Mr. Van, who wanted to test his English, the foreign language that many Vietnamese consider their ticket to prosperity. I welcomed the company.
"Where are you from? Are you from America?" Mr. Van asked as his bicycle pulled alongside mine. "I would be honored to speak English with you." I readily agreed, so long as he would be my tour guide.
We first turned left down Trang Tien Street, in the heart of Hanoi's commercial district, toward the splendid Opera House, built in 1911 by the French as a replica of the Paris Opera. It is now used as a government meeting hall.
Little did the French know that three decades after its construction Vietnamese nationalists would rush to the balcony of the gingerbread Opera House and declare independence from their occupiers.
Most of the city's largest shops and galleries are found at the other end of Trang Tien Street. Mr. Van and I parked outside the Foreign Language Bookshop at 61 Trang Tien Street. Only a year and a half earlier, on my first visit to Hanoi, the shop had been stacked high with Russian-language books. Now, the Russian books had been relegated to a dusty corner, replaced by stacks of English-language texts and the Vietnamese translations of popular modern American novels.
At the end of the block, Mr. Van and I turned right onto the busy thoroughfare that is Hoang Street, which runs along the tree-shaded Hoan Kiem Lake, or the Lake of the Restored Sword. The lake is the heart of the city.
Legend has it, and some variation of the legend is known by all Vietnamese schoolchildren, that this is the home of the magic tortoise that provided the Vietnamese hero Le Loi with a sword he used to liberate Vietnam from the Chinese in the 15th century.
The lake is at its most enchanting in the early evening, when lovers sit beneath delicate willows on its grassy banks. The tiny Tortoise Pagoda in the middle of the lake is the city's emblem.
A few blocks along Hoang Street, past the central post office, the road branches in several directions, all of them leading into the Old Quarter. A tricky place for a bicycle because of the narrow, rutted streets, the Old Quarter is the best place to glimpse colonial-era Hanoi.
We turned left down Hang Bong Street, full of Parisian-style row houses and tiny shops, the most interesting of which were the pharmacies selling traditional medicines.
As Mr. Van explained it to me, the dark-brown juice made from pulverized geckos, the small lizards found throughout the tropics, is thought to be a magic elixir for impotence and respiratory ailments. "You do not think about the taste," he said.
AT 53 Hang Bong is the The Duc The Thao Shop, where a family makes many of the gold-and-red cloth banners that are strung between street lamps during Communist Party celebrations. They take custom orders, as well, and for very little money they will sew together a grand banner that meets the requirements of a foreign tourist. I had one eight-foot-long banner made to welcome the birth of a niece in Northern California: Vietnam Welcomes Birth of Glorious Child! The price was about $5, and it took only a day to make.
We headed a few blocks south, turning right on Hai Ba Trung Street, where we encountered the grim Hoa Lo Prison. It is perhaps the only structure in Hanoi that large numbers of Americans know, if only by the nickname given it by American prisoners of war: the Hanoi Hilton. Many Americans were imprisoned, and tortured, at Hoa Lo during the Vietnam war.
The prison, which for obvious reasons is not included in tours organized by the government tourist agency, was built in the earlier part of the century by the French and is still used as a prison.
There are only a few windows in the blocklong building, and they are covered by rusting metal grills. Across the top of the 20-foot walls are both electrified barbed wire and shards of glass.
As I reached for my camera, Mr. Van whispered anxiously, "No pictures, no pictures." There was indeed an unsmiling, armed soldier watching my every move from across the street. The prison may soon be no more. The land is now so valuable that Singaporean developers are planning to pull it down to make way for an office complex.
We pedaled on toward Dienbienphu Street, named in honor of the momentous 1954 battle that ended a century of French rule.
Dienbienphu Street is a fitting address for the Army Museum celebrating Vietnam's military victories over the French, the Americans and, most recently, the Chinese, who were driven out of northern border areas of Vietnam after a 1979 invasion.
The museum was in the headlines in the United States last year after the announcement that Vietnam had turned over thousands of artifacts, including photographs, from the museum archives that could be useful in determining the fate of more than 2,000 American troops still missing from the war.
When Mr. Van and I stopped at the museum, a team of American investigators from the Defense Department could be seen on the patio on the second floor, photographing artifacts including pilot helmets and flight suits.
Many Americans, especially veterans, find the museum jarring, especially with its unsubtle outdoor display of a Soviet-built MIG-21 jet fighter perched over the charred debris of a downed American B-52 bomber. Across from the museum is Chi Long Park, which serves as a stark reminder that, while the economy of Vietnam is undergoing something of a revolution, the political system is not. Vietnam is one of the last of the satellites of the former Soviet Union to hold on tight to the trappings of Communism, and Chi Long Park is dedicated to the memory of Lenin. There is an enormous, heroic statue of the Russian leader set in well-tended gardens.
I was eager to go down the road toward the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum, but pulled over to the sidewalk when I heard a distinctive hiss. I turned to look. My rear tire was flat -- my brand-new rear tire.
"Your bike, no problem," Mr. Van said, pointing a block away to a group of young men sitting on the street corner with bicycle pumps and small plastic buckets. Bicycle mechanics are found on most large street corners in Hanoi.
A small bidding war erupted among the mechanics for the chance to fix my tire. The winner was a smiling fellow who had bid 10,000 dong, or about $1.
As he worked away I watched the stream of bikes down Dienbienphu Street, wide and lined with shade trees.
The women bicyclists are an enchanting sight not only for their grace, but for their determined efforts to prevent their skin from having a moment's contact with the sun. It is serious business, for fair skin is much prized among Vietnamese women, who consider a tan evidence of field work. Many pull their bikes off the road every few blocks to readjust their conical bamboo hats.
My bike repaired, we set off on the final few blocks to the resting place of Ho Chi Minh, the imposing, gray-marble mausoleum set in the center of a complex of museums and other monuments.
WHATEVER his eventual place in history, Ho Chi Minh will be remembered as the Vietnamese leader who faced down two Western nations -- the United States and France -- in a dream of uniting his country. He never married and lived a modest life in a small house near the opulent colonial-era Presidential Palace, in which he refused to live.
His house, made of dark hardwood and supposedly preserved by Vietnamese curators just as Ho left it, is a short walk from the mausoleum and borders a pond in which he raised carp.
Mr. Van and I parked our bikes beneath banyan and frangipani trees outside the One Pillar Pagoda. The miniature pagoda was rebuilt in the mid- 1950's after the original, dating from the 11th century, was burned by vengeful French soldiers as they retreated.
Ho's mausoleum is, it would seem, exactly what he did not want. In his handwritten will, which is available in English translation at bookshops throughout Hanoi, Ho asked that his body be cremated, and the ashes divided between three sites, in north, south and central Vietnam. He asked that at each site there be a simple wooden memorial with plenty of shade for visitors.
Instead, after his death in 1969, Ho's successors in the Communist Party released a falsified version of his will and built him the hulking stone memorial. They did not cremate his body but instead put it on display, Lenin-like, under glass in a refrigerated chamber. (Once a year, Ho's embalmed corpse is shipped to Moscow for maintenance by the same technicians who tend to Lenin's body.)
Mr. Van stopped suddenly, remembering where he was. "I hope you can forgive me," he said. "I must leave because the police will watch you very carefully here," motioning to the many guard stations around the memorial, which is as heavily fortified as any place in the city. "Maybe I will go home now."
I thanked Mr. Van, and we parted with a promise that he would serve as my guide on my next visit to Hanoi. As I turned down Hung Vuong Street, I was met by one of the blank-faced honor guards who accompany all visitors in the final 100 yards or so toward the mausoleum.
The guard walked slowly alongside me until we reached the entrance, and he pointed me toward a long red carpet leading inside. Over the entrance was a sign bearing Ho's most famous slogan: "Nothing is more precious than independence and freedom."
Up a separate staircase within the structure, I found myself in a cavernous room bathed in a ghostly, pinkish light. At the center of the room, beneath a Vietnamese flag, was the glass sarcophagus bearing Ho's frail body. Ho's wispy white beard had been carefully groomed and set on a stiff gray shirt. His hands had a waxy sheen and were crossed over his chest.
In each corner of the room was a guard in a chocolate-colored uniform, apparently to insure that guests walk single file past the body and not linger. I stopped for a moment, and a guard approached me and nudged my elbow, indicating I should move on.
With the knowledge that Ho did not want to be remembered with this sort of bleak, even ghoulish monument, I found myself unmoved by the sight of his corpse.
The reaction of Vietnamese visitors was different, and I was met outside the mausoleum by several old men and women who appeared by their dark-colored, modest clothing to be from the countryside. They had just come from inside the mausoleum and all brushed tears from their eyes. Looking me up and down, they seemed perplexed that a visitor to the city of Ho Chi Minh could be so little affected by the sight of his earthly remains.

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY;
Hong Kong Is Booking Now For June 30, 1997

BYLINE: By Barbara Basler

DATELINE: HONG KONG

 BODY:
Hong Kong is the most popular travel destination in Asia, drawing more international visitors than China or Japan and eclipsing such exotic spots as Bangkok. Last year the territory counted seven million visitor arrivals -- a remarkable increase of one million over the year before. And the Hong Kong Tourist Association, a Government-financed body, estimates the number of visitor arrivals will increase 6 to 9 percent this year.
This growth comes at a time when the future of the British colony has never been more precarious. In 1997 Britain will return the freewheeling territory to China, which has one of the most repressive regimes in the world. While China has promised to leave life here relatively untouched, no one can be certain how the territory will fare. 
 But several years ago, with a flair and resourcefulness that is typical of the colony, hotels here began taking reservations for June 30, 1997, the eve of the handover of Hong Kong. Hotel managers estimate that more than 1,000 rooms have already been booked for that historic night.
The travel industry appears optimistic about life after 1997. The number of hotel rooms in Hong Kong has been increasing (from 17,000 in 1988 to 33,000 today), older hotels are renovating and expanding, and money has been budgeted to more than double the size of the glittering convention center.
But there are troubling signs. Hong Kong's Kai Tak airport will reach maximum capacity in the next few years. And China, angered at the colony's push to expand democracy here before the handover, has refused to approve plans for a huge new airport complex to be completed after 1997.
"No one doubts the airport will eventually be built," said one hotel manager. "It's in China's interests. But the delay could hurt us."
Meanwhile the travel industry here has continued to flourish despite recessions in the United States, Europe and Japan, because a booming regional economy has given many Asians more money for travel, and travel restrictions in countries like Taiwan, Malaysia and South Korea have eased recently, according to a spokeswoman for the tourist association.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: CHINA (97%); HONG KONG (94%); ASIA (93%); JAPAN (93%); UNITED KINGDOM (93%); THAILAND (92%); SOUTH-EASTERN ASIA (79%); MALAYSIA (79%); EUROPE (79%); UNITED STATES (79%); TAIWAN (79%); 

CITY: BANGKOK, THAILAND (92%);

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: Sonny Mae Mortgages;
New Rate Is 5.75%, The Lowest Ever

 BODY:
The steady drop in mortgage interest rates over the last several years has been a boon to The State of New York Mortgage Agency, which through subsidized mortgages has paved the way to home ownership for more than 49,000 moderate-income families throughout the state.
Now the agency, also known as Sonny Mae, is offering the lowest interest rate ever, 5.75 percent for its Low Interest Rate mortgage program. The previous rate was 6.50 percent. 
 In general, the state-sponsored mortgages are for first-time home buyers. But the requirement can be waived for purchases in target areas, those designated for revitalization. Loans are available for one- to four-family houses as well as co-ops and condominiums. Borrowers have the option of 20-, 25- or 30-year terms. The minimum down payment can be as low as 5 percent for qualifying borrowers.
No points are charged for home loans made on existing properties but there is a charge of 0.50 percent for mortgages on newly constructed residences.
Income and purchase price limits vary according to the location of the home. In New York City, for example, the limit on the purchase price on existing two-family homes is $201,800 in target areas and $165,100 in nontarget areas. Likewise, the income limit for borrowers of properties in nontarget areas of New York City is $47,720 for households of three or more persons.
The loans are available through 75 participating lenders. For more information call the agency mortgage line at (800) 382-HOME.

HEADLINE: MUSIC;
A Busy Week for Benefit Concerts

BYLINE: By ROBERT SHERMAN

 BODY:
BENEFIT concerts seem to be an increasingly popular method of fund-raising, perhaps because the donors know that they are not only contributing to a worthy cause but also receiving musical dividends in the bargain. At least five such events are on the calendar this week, two of them this afternoon at 3.
The Westport School of Music is holding its 34th annual scholarship benefit at that hour in Pequot Library in Southport, with the pianist and teacher David Korevaar playing works of Bach, Beethoven, Liszt and Chopin. "We really need a successful event this year," said the director of the school, Martha Hisey. "The economy has affected so many of our families that we have allocated more scholarships than ever before." 
 "In keeping with our tradition of saluting noted people in the arts," added Ms. Hisey, "we are delighted to say that the noted composer John Corigliano will be our honored guest. His family used to have a home here in Westport, and John spent many summers in town in his younger days." The number to call for reservations is 227-4931.
The Connecticut branch of the Tibetan United States Resettlement Project is the beneficiary of a 3 P.M. program today at the Merryall Center for the Arts in New Milford. Four New York City singers, directed and accompanied by a pianist on the Yale faculty, Brian Suits, will offer arias and ensembles by Verdi, Rossini, Mozart, Puccini and Gounod, and an abridged version of Bizet's "Carmen."
Merryall's president and program chairman, Jim Brown, described the effort as important. "Any money raised will help an individual from a ravaged country make a new beginning here in Connecticut," he said. "We are most pleased to extend our assistance, and at the same time offer a great concert with these fine musicians." For tickets, call Mr. Brown at 792-4849 or Amanda Quaintance, benefit coordinator, at 261-0247.
Friday evening at 8, Woolsey Hall at Yale resounds to "A Battle of the Bands," but the winner will be the Hillhouse High School music program, which intends to use the profits to purchase band instruments and uniforms. The battling bands are, however, the Tommy Dorsey Orchestra, under the direction of Hillhouse alumnus Buddy Morrow, and the Willie Ruff Orchestra, using original charts from the Benny Goodman archives at Yale. Each group will also field a vocalist, Mr. Ruff introducing M. B. Singley, a Yale junior who was a hit last October in the Duke Ellington fellowship concert. Mr. Morrow brings Bridgeport native Walt Andrus, whose credits include a stint with the Pied Pipers (432-4158).
Opera New England of Northeastern Connecticut is looking forward to an ambitious educational program next fall that will bring a free production of Rossini's "Barber of Seville" to some 3,600 area children; to help pay for it, a spring musical event has been set for 7 P.M. Saturday in the Pomfret School, a recital by the bass-baritone James Rensink that promises "a combination of serious music, Broadway tunes and funny songs" (928-2946 or 429-5813).
For the past three years, the Hartford Camerata Conservatory has been holding a benefit cabaret to swell the coffers of its scholarship fund, and the fourth annual one starts at 8:15 P.M. on Saturday at the West Hartford Town Hall. "I'll Be Seeing You" is the theme of the evening, the music hailing from the World War II era, and audience members are encouraged to wear clothing of the period -- military attire, snoods, sweaters and bow ties, etc.
The conservatory's dean, Peter Harvey, will be one of the featured artists, along with the Faculty Jazz Ensemble and several other singers, instrumentalists and artists adding their talents to the evening in some unusual comic roles. Last year's cabaret was a sellout, so call 246-2588 to make sure reservations are still available.
Two events today at 3 P.M. include Wesleyan professor Neely Bruce turning away from the Americana that normally occupies much of his on-stage time to give a harpsichord performance of Book I of Bach's "Well-Tempered Clavier" in the World Music Hall (344-7444), and the Armstrong Chamber Concerts continuing at First Congregational Church-on-the-Green in Washington. There will be more Bach -- the Trio Sonata in F -- and Mozart, Martinu and Bartok, played by Helen Armstrong, David Krakauer, Masao Kawasaki and Kazuko Hayami (868-0522).
A pair of 10th anniversary seasons conclude an hour later, the Camerata Ensemble offering Beethoven and Dohnanyi Trios, along with Schubert's "Trout" Quintet, at the Kingswood-Oxford School in West Hartford (233-0288); while the Filharmonia Quartet, its members drawn from the moonlighting ranks of the New York Philharmonic, has invited the Juilliard professor Martin Canin to join them for Beethoven's Op. 16 Piano Quartet and Franck's Piano Quintet. The concert will be at St. John's Episcopal Church in Salisbury (435-0439).
Also at 4 P.M., the Connecticut Chamber Choir is tendering "A Serenade to Spring" in the First Congregational Church of Stratford, with Richard Erickson conducting Mozart's "Missa Brevis," the "Wedding Cantata" of Daniel Pinkham and John Rutter's "Te Deum" along with a raft of shorter works (438-7928, evenings).
The Russian-American pianist Bella Davidovich makes it an international evening, playing the Grieg Concerto in the course of the touring Danish National Radio Symphony's 8 P.M. Thursday visit to Jorgensen Auditorium in Storrs (486-4226). Jazz is also an option at that hour, when the Preservation Hall Band will raise the roof at the Stamford Palace (325-4466), or Puccini, since "La Boheme" is Connecticut Opera's spring offering at the Bushnell, with 8 P.M. performances scheduled Friday and Saturday as well (527-0713). Another couple of evenings with the Preservation Hall Jazz Band will be offered Friday and Saturday at the Jorgensen.
Finally, 8 P.M. Saturday options include a concert at the Westport Arts Center by the Manhattan Chamber Sinfonia, with David Gilbert conducting Mozart's "Posthorn Serenade" and, with the double assistance of the violinist Mayuki Fukuhara and the pianist Jeffrey Jamner, the rarely encountered Mendelssohn Double Concerto (661-4667). At the same time, Tibor Pusztai leads a Hartford Symphony program at Trinity Episcopal Church titled "I Hear American Singing" with the orchestra joined by Trinity's own chorus and the Hartt Children's Choir (246-8742). Other options are the finale of Orchestra New England's season in Battell Chapel at Yale with James Sinclair conducting Mozart's Serenade in B-Flat and a dramatized edition of Stravinsky's "Histoire du Soldat" (934-8863), and a "South of the Border" program in Crowell Hall at Wesleyan that brings together the university's orchestra under Melvin Strauss, and that of Connecticut College, directed by Peter Sacco, for music by Villa-Lobos, Chavez and other Latin American composers (344-7944).

HEADLINE: On the Road With Cary Edwards

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO

 BODY:
AT 9 P.M. last Sunday, after a day spent attacking the policies of Gov. Jim Florio, the man he would like to displace, Cary Edwards stood before a group of 60 Republicans in New Providence and fielded a question from a local resident.
"Why are you the best Republican candidate to run against Florio in November?" Robert Dougherty asked. 
 At campaign stops in seven towns in six counties, Mr. Edwards had made scarcely a reference to his four rivals in the June 8 primary, including his most formidable opponent, Christine Todd Whitman. Ms. Whitman has followed a similar strategy.
"If they're all going to be nice to each other and not point out the differences between them," Mr. Dougherty said later, "how can we make an intelligent choice?"
At the meeting, Mr. Edwards spoke of his extensive experience in state government as making him more qualified to govern than his Republican opponents. "We're talking about running a $15 billion, 65,000 employee service business," Mr. Edwards said. "That's not a job for amateurs. I understand this system and I know the buttons that have to be pushed."
He told his listeners that "the best way to demonstrate my ability to beat Christie Whitman is to demonstrate my ability to beat Jim Florio."
In fact, he is fighting an uphill battle against Ms. Whitman, who came within a breath of defeating Senator Bill Bradley in November of 1990 and has remained in the public eye ever since.
"Christie Whitman has been at this for two and a half years," Mr. Edwards said later. "If I had been working at this for two and a half years, there wouldn't even be a primary."
The campaign day began for Mr. Edwards at 9:30 A.M. in the kitchen of his Oakland home as he finished the first of many cups of coffee he would consume over the next 14 hours. Outside, his white campaign van, equipped with two telephones, a fax machine and a television set, was waiting in the driveway. His wife, Lynn, had already left so she could be on hand to help organize the first campaign stop: a meeting of volunteers at the Bergen County Republican headquarters in Hackensack.
Seven Republican county organizations have endorsed Mr. Edwards, he said, while nine have endorsed Ms. Whitman; the remaining five are uncommitted.
"Make a left at the next corner," Mr. Edwards told the driver of the van, Bill Labonak, a retired state trooper. Until that moment, it had seemed that Mr. Edwards was so deep in conversation he could have no idea where the van was headed.
Riding with the candidate were Doug Doyle, a former New York City Legal Aid lawyer who is now a full-time campaign aide, and Robert B. Thompson, a former reporter who is the campaign press secretary.
At 10:35 Mr. Edwards entered the back door of the Hackensack campaign headquarters. His wife, who was in the front of the room, rushed to greet him and then rushed back to the people she had been talking to. A slim woman with a broad smile and seemingly endless energy, Mrs. Edwards is widely seen as one of her husband's major political assets.
"She's a great campaigner," said Jane Burgio, who was Secretary of State under Gov. Thomas H. Kean and is now a leader in the Edwards campaign. "Just watch her work the room."
Mr. Edwards's first speech of the day was a short one, delivered without benefit of notes or a microphone. The tall, silver-haired lawyer is an engaging speaker who seems totally at ease at the podium, his deep voice rising and falling, his gestures smooth and forceful.
In Hackensack, he roused cheers from about 70 volunteers who were given a quick course in grass-roots campaigning. He emphasized the importance of educating Bergen County voters about the issues and striving to bring more volunteers into the campaign. "In Bergen County, we know more about what Mayor Dinkins is doing in New York than what is going on in Trenton," he said.
 
'He Inspires Me'
 Antoinette Cassavitis, a 29-year-old single mother from Hackensack, later explained why she had joined the Edwards campaign.
"He inspires me," Ms. Cassavitis said. "He knows what our problems are. He knows what it's like to be stuck in traffic on Route 17 and to be afraid of parking your car at a mall. And he knows how hard it can be to be a single mother because he was raised by one."
Political experts have been saying that one of Ms. Whitman's advantages is that women may be more likely to vote for her than a male candidate. And one of the major campaign strategies of Mr. Edwards's campaign is to portray him as a man who appreciates the role women play in raising families.
"It was kind of like 'me and my mother against the world,' " Mr. Edwards said, settling back in the bucket seat behind the driver in the seven-passenger van. It was 11:07, the next campaign stop was scheduled for noon in East Hanover and once again Mr. Edwards interrupted himself to give Mr. Labonak instructions. "Take Hudson Street to Route 80," he said.
W. Cary Edwards, 48, was born in Ridgewood and grew up in Bergen County. When he was 11 years old, his parents separated, and he moved with his mother, Virginia, and a brother and a sister to East Paterson.
"I did odd jobs," he said about his teen-age years. "I was a baby sitter, believe it or not."
After working his way through high school and Seton Hall University and its law school, he was admitted to the New Jersey bar in 1970 -- and married Lynn Cozzolino the same year. The couple, who have two daughters, moved to Oakland in 1974, and Mr. Edwards was elected councilman there in 1975.
Two years later he was elected to the State Assembly, and in 1982 he became chief counsel to the newly elected Governor Kean, who had been his mentor in the Assembly. He became the state's Attorney General four years later.
 
'An Offer I Couldn't Refuse'
 "He made me an offer I couldn't refuse," Mr. Edwards said, adding that the job of Attorney General, though technically a "step down from a staff position to a line position," was the perfect position from which he could do battle with one of his major social concerns. "My faith was shaken in the ability of government to deliver any serious solutions to the crime problem," he said.
Today, Mr. Edwards's campaign makes much of his record as an Attorney General who was "tough on crime." The candidate said: "If we're going to have tough criminal laws, we better be ready to enforce them. If we're going to need more jail cells, we better be ready to build them."
At 11:58 the campaign van pulled up in front of the Hanover Manor in East Hanover, where the Livingston Republican organization was sponsoring a brunch. Soon Mr. Edwards was moving from table to table, chatting and joking with guests. He appeared comfortable and relaxed, shaking hands with the men, kissing some of the women on the cheek, giving a light touch on the shoulder to people seated at tables.
"You better get on line," he told a group of people waiting to talk to him. "You don't eat if you don't get on line."
After a brief speech criticizing Mr. Florio's record and outlining the problems that the winner of the November election will face, Mr. Edwards and his aides were back in the van at 12:37.
Mr. Edwards talked about his style of campaigning. Conventional political wisdom, he said, always held that "if you've got holes in your shoes, don't put your feet up on the desk." But in today's political campaigns, he said, it is difficult, if not impossible, to fool the public.
"I've always believed that if I let everybody know everything about me -- the good, the bad, and the ugly -- then I would be fine," he said. "I've always tried to be open and honest."
One example, he said, was his voluntary disclosure that he had employed an illegal alien in his household. "No reporter dug that out," Mr. Edwards said. "I released it on my own. I voluntarily came forward because of the Zoe Baird matter." Ms. Whitman also acknowledged that she had employed an illegal alien; her announcement, on the same day as his, was made first.
The campaign van's next stop was at the Coach and Paddock Restaurant in Hampton Township, where the Hunterdon County Republican organization was meeting.
"O.K., fill me in, guys," Mr. Edwards said as the van approached the entrance.
Mr. Doyle read from a stack of green index cards that held the day's itinerary.
"It's a fund raiser; Christie was here and Wallwork was here, so you're the last to speak," he said, referring to Ms. Whitman and to James H. Wallwork, a former State Assemblyman who is also running for the nomination. The other Republican candidates are J. Patrick Gilligan, a Morristown businessman, and Charles P. Hoffman of Brick.
Thirty minutes after his arrival, Mr. Edwards was on the road again, headed for Basking Ridge, where the former supporters of Ross Perot had gathered in a suburban living room. About two weeks before, the group had formally endorsed Mr. Edwards.
During this session, and another later in Holmdel, Mr. Edwards offered a more detailed description of his campaign platform. It includes the appointment of more judges who believe in the death penalty, mandatory sentences for possession of guns in or near schools and mandatory sentences for violent crimes against the elderly.
He said his plan for stimulating the state's economy included tax reductions for individuals and businesses, investment tax credits and research and development credits for new and expanding businesses. He also favors the end of the "double taxation" that the state's "Subchapter S" corporations now face.
The money to make such tax reductions possible, he said, would come from the $500 million spending cut that Republican leaders in the Legislature have promised for next year's budget.
At 10:30 P.M. the campaign van pulled into the parking lot of a diner in Wayne for the campaigners' first and only meal of the day. Removing their jackets, Mr. Edwards and his aides engaged in comfortable, friendly banter.
"The yuppie wants cheese on his onion rings," he said of the 27-year-old Mr. Doyle when the waitress took the order.
An hour later, the white van parked in the driveway of Mr. Edwards's sprawling split-level home in Oakland. A splash of reflected light illuminated his tired, craggy face. Then Mr. Labonak turned off the lights and the ignition, and for a few moments the occupants of the van sat in silence.
"Thanks," Mr. Edwards said to no one in particular, "it was a good day."

Top, Mr. Edwards in van with Doug Doyle, left, an aide, and Robert B. Thompson, press secretary. (Photographs by Suzanne DeChillo/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: War Over Cigarette Machines

BYLINE: By STEVEN HART

 BODY:
EACH of New Jersey's 11,000 cigarette vending machines carries a warning, reflecting a state law passed six years ago that bans the sale of tobacco products to anyone under the age of 18. But public officials and anti-smoking groups say many under-age residents are using the vending machines, and a number of towns have moved to ban or control them.
The issue, which has been fought out in town councils and courts, is now before the Appellate Division of State Superior Court. Whichever way the court decides, it is certain to have a major effect on the approach towns take to the machines. 
 The case before the court concerns East Brunswick, which in 1990 passed an ordinance banning cigarette vending machines. Some of the 60 New Jersey companies in the industry sued to overturn the ordinance and won in Superior Court last year.
The township has appealed that decision. Oral arguments will be heard on June 1.
 
Other Suits Withdrawn
 Two other communities -- Mount Olive Township and Bernards Township -- jumped into the fray, passing ordinances that would control rather than ban the machines. They, too, were sued by the cigarette machine vendors, but in the wake of East Brunswick's court defeat, the suits were withdrawn and the ordinances stand.
Princeton has used the Bernards ordinance as a blueprint for a measure of its own, which was unanimously approved on Monday by the Princeton Regional Health Commission. The commission administers the Princeton Regional Health Department, which covers Princeton Borough and Princeton Township.
The Bernards solution, some town officials say, seems to offer a middle path satisfactory both to municipalities seeking to answer a public-health concern and an industry ready to fight it out in court. But that could change with the appeals court ruling on the East Brunswick ordinance.
"Many other towns are watching to see what happens with the case," said Irv Green, president of the C.I.C. Corporation of Springfield, one of the vendors that filed the lawsuits. Should East Brunswick win, Mr. Green said, the vendors would continue to challenge the town's ordinance in court.
"I think it's important to agree with the concept that minors shouldn't have access to cigarettes," Mr. Green said. "But it doesn't seem to me they should obliterate an entire industry to do so."
The Bernards Township ordinance, which took effect in 1991, restricts the machines to businesses not open to unsupervised children and young teen-agers -- bars and taverns, restaurants, factories and private companies -- and requires that the machines be placed "under the direct visual supervision" of employees.
The Mount Olive ordinance, enacted in 1990, similarly specifies that the machines be in plain view to keep minors from surreptitiously buying cigarettes. It also requires any business with a vending machine to appoint an attendant to insure that no illegal purchases take place.
After the passage of the state law, the Bernards Township Health Department decided to gauge its effectiveness, said Dan Jordan, the health officer. The department deputized a 13-year-old girl to visit a number of business where cigarettes were sold. Even though she "looked really young," Mr. Jordan said, the girl was able to get cigarettes "at about 70 to 75 percent of the places." Of that number, he added, roughly 15 percent of the sales were from vending machines.
After the businesses visited were alerted to the result of the survey, and groups of concerned parents visited some of the locations, the Health Department sent out a pair of 14-year-olds who "really did look like kids," Mr. Jordan said.
They were able to buy cigarettes at about 60 percent of the businesses, he said, and the Board of Health decided to combine educational efforts with a law covering cigarette vending machines.
The Bernards ordinance took effect in April 1991 and was soon challenged by a group of vending machine companies: Coast Cigarette Sales of Asbury Park; the C.I.C. Corporation; the Eskin Vending Company of East Brunswick, which is now owned by C.I.C., and the Amusement and Music Operators Association, a national trade organization that has 60 members in New Jersey. The group contended that Bernards had usurped the powers of the state.
"We disagree completely with the idea that vending machines are a significant source of sales to minors," said Keith Biebelberg, the Springfield lawyer representing the vendors.
In this he was seconded by William Treger, president of the Amusement and Music Operators Association, and a sales representative for H. Betti Industries, a Carlstadt-based distributor of coin-operated machines.
"Only 3 percent of all cigarette sales in the country are done by vending machines," Mr. Treger said. "It's really blown out of proportion. If you've got kids working at 7-Elevens and convenience stores, you know they're going to be selling to their friends. That's the kind of thing that needs to be cracked down on."
 
East Brunswick Actions
 Jack Sinagra was Mayor of East Brunswick in 1990 when he saw a young man he said was "obviously" under-age buying cigarettes from a vending machine. Mr. Sinagra went to the Township Council with a proposed ordinance banning all vending machines within the township's borders, and it took effect in January 1991.
Mr. Sinagra, now a State Senator, said he had sponsored bills in the Legislature to stop smoking in day-care centers, to forbid cigarette advertising on public lands and to prevent advertising in the vicinity of public schools.
"I'm not someone who tries to keep adults from doing what they want to do," Mr. Sinagra said. "I'm trying to keep kids from killing themselves."
Steve Rattner, a Mount Olive Councilman, was chairman of the township's Board of Health when its cigarette vending machine ordinance was introduced. "We didn't have a major problem, but we did have a lot of businesses that had cigarette machines," Mr. Rattner said. "There was nobody keeping an eye on what was going on. It was the physicians that were really pushing to do what we could to control smoking."
The township had about 25 cigarette vending machines within its borders when it decided to restrict the placement of the devices and require businesses to make someone responsible for their proper use.
Both the Bernards Township and Mount Olive ordinances were attacked in court by the vendors, but their real target was the East Brunswick ordinance. Their complaint was being heard by a Superior Court judge.
The judge had delayed a decision pending the outcome of a state bill, proposed in the summer of 1991, that would restrict vending machines to locations inaccessible to minors. In other locations, under the bill, the machines could be used only after an employee had determined that the purchaser was at least 18.
The bill passed both houses of the Legislature but was vetoed by Gov. Jim Florio on the ground, Mr. Biebelberg, the vendors' lawyer said, that it would prevent municipalities from enacting their own, more restrictive, ordinances.
Shortly after East Brunswick's ordinance was voided, the vendor challenges to Mount Olive and Bernards Township were withdrawn.
"Frankly, we didn't really mind certain restraints," Mr. Biebelberg said. "East Brunswick is looking to use a bazooka when all it really needed was a small weapon that we were willing to give them. What we were willing to do was go along with a restraint."
Why, then, did the vendors sue Bernards Township and Mount Olive in the first place?
"We knew other municipalities were watching, and we wanted to send a message," Mr. Biebelberg said. "We felt that the whole subject matter was pre-empted by state regulation, and we wanted to show that we were willing to back up our beliefs in court. After the East Brunswick decision, we mollified our position somewhat, and we felt there was no more to be gained by continuing this litigation. Also, there was an economic consideration. Lawsuits are expensive, you know."
The withdrawal of the vendors' suit was welcomed by Mr. Rattner, the Mount Olive Councilman. "At the time of the lawsuit, it was scary," he said. "The municipal budget of Mount Olive couldn't have afforded a prolonged fight."
 
Princeton Copies Bernards
 For that reason, the Princeton Regional Health Commission, which was on the verge of adopting an East Brunswick-style ban in February, pulled back and decided to go with a restrictive measure along the lines of Bernards Township's ordinance. The Princeton ordinance takes effect on May 12.
"We've duplicated the ordinance, basically, and changed the name Bernards to Princeton," said William Hinshillwood, health officer for the Princeton Regional Health Department.
The same goes for Mount Olive, Mr. Rattner said.
"We've done research on East Brunswick's ordinance," he said. "We are watching what happens with the appeal."
 
Anti-Smoking Group's View

So is the Group Against Smoking Pollution (GASP), a Summit-based anti-smoking organization that filed a friend of the court brief on behalf of East Brunswick.
Regina Carlson, executive director of the group, said the Bernards Township ordinance was "an appropriate strategy for a township to pursue while the appeal is pending." She made it clear that her organization, which encourages communities to take on the cigarette industry by disseminating information on the health hazards of smoking, preferred East Brunswick's sterner approach.
"It makes the most sense," Ms. Carlson said. "We wouldn't tolerate having vending machines for beer or alcoholic beverages. This is the same kind of health issue."
Ms. Carlson said the vending industry's own studies showed that while older teen-agers were more likely to buy cigarettes over the counter, younger teen-agers "used vending machines to a greater extent."
James Feinberg, of Manny's Cigarette Service, a distributor and a member of the Amusement and Music Operators Association, said his industry was being unfairly attacked by politicians with the encouragement of groups like GASP.
"I think the rationale for these ordinances is that it's politically correct right now," Mr. Feinberg said. "Politicians can get a lot of coverage by doing this."
Since the vendors abandoned their lawsuit against Bernards Township, Mr. Jordan said, the township's Health Department has used undercover teen-agers in two more surveys of local merchants, the last about a month ago.
Though the number of businesses selling cigarettes has grown to 35, the teen-agers were able to buy cigarettes at only four businesses. Summonses and fines resulted, Mr. Jordan said, and the Somerset Hills Health Department -- which includes Bernards Township in its administration area -- plans to enact vending machine ordinances in Bedminster, Bernardsville, Mendham, Peapack- Gladstone, Chester and Far Hills.

HEADLINE: A SENSE OF PLACE

BYLINE: By Michael Norman

DATELINE: MONTCLAIR

 BODY:
WE are a textbook town: we have a bottom, a middle, a top. Many of the people at the top, those who possess enough money and property to be called "rich," live, literally, above the rest of us -- on the side of a small mountain that forms Montclair's western border.
The homes on the mountain cost millions. They have sweeping front lawns and carriage houses, stone balustrades and cobblestone drives. Some of the town's oldest families live up there -- bankers and doctors and lawyers -- and some of the town's newest, too: actors, producers and entrepreneurs. 
 I live in a sage green box on a side street a short walk from a supermarket. I do not have gold-leaf trim and walls of trompe l'oeil, but I think I know something of the people who do. We may be separated by a fortune or two, but in our sense of place we think alike.
Here, leagues away from the tough precincts of the big city, life seems somehow safer and more salubrious. In the spring our asylum is a place of pink dogwoods and ovals of green. We are close with nature here. We put down roots.
A man should know his neighbors, on both sides of the tracks, so a week or so ago on a warm night I found myself on the mountain, passing between stone pillars, then up a long drive to an English manor, an elegant home of mortar and stone and peaked arches, 29 rooms ("more or less," as the owner put it) on some two acres, with a tennis court on the side and a swimming pool in back.
The great room of the manor has oak beams and architectural paneling; in the middle of the room on a palace Tabriz rug sits a huge tufted tuxedo couch covered in Jacquard silk. In the right wing is a library, an Elizabethan reading room with a balcony. In the left wing is the dining room and beyond that a petite salle a manger for breakfast.
The basement holds a wine vault, a room with racks of concrete sleeves, and a table in the middle for tastings or dinners. Nearby is a game room with a pool table, a jukebox and a pinball machine. Upstairs are bedrooms, offices and a gym with a mirrored wall.
The three full-time servants -- a husband and wife housekeeping team and a nanny -- have a private suite larger than most Manhattan apartments.
Throughout the house, the walls are hung with millions of dollars in art -- Picasso, Pissarro, Raphael Soyer, Gorky, Guy Wiggins, Reginald Marsh. There is a work by Rodin so famous it is mentioned in most encyclopedias.
The effect of all this -- the scale of the house, the style and charm of the trappings, the great beauty of the art -- sometimes isolates the family (the man, woman and two children, who for reasons of safety prefer to remain anonymous) that lives here.
"It sometimes gets to the point," the woman said, "where I hate having people up. As soon as they get a load of this place, all of a sudden our jokes are funnier, and everything we say is taken as more intelligent than it really is."
She is sharp-tongued, ebullient, full of fire; he is polite and affable, with soft eyes and a diffident smile.
By many measures, we are neighbors. We shop at Kings supermarket and buy our Easter treats at Mary's candy store. We complain about outrageous property taxes -- more than $30,000 for them -- and the new traffic light on Valley Road that seems designed to snarl traffic.
We are equally disillusioned by the public schools and send our children to a private academy. We like the pasta in Rispoli's, the internecine bickering over the Iris Gardens, the way the big clock by the bank looks down on Valley Road.
The couple came to town six years ago from Manhattan. They wanted a place to raise children; they wanted a place to settle down. They looked for texture and rough edges, not a pampered enclave for the rich.
"We didn't want to live in East Egg or West Egg drinking martinis," she said. "That's not us. I like to pick up the sticks in the yard." Now they have the same profound sense of belonging as the rest of us.
None of this is to say that they are just folks. The Governor comes for dinner; the State Attorney General drops by for a few sets of tennis. And yet there's something familiar on the hill. The pattern of life in the manor house and the unseen forces that have shaped it are not that different from the tangled dynamics that drive the lives in the valley below.
The man of the manor is the second of four sons of immigrant parents who were confined in a labor camp by the Nazis during World War II. After the war, the family drifted for a while, landing finally in a large city in the Midwest.
The father worked on a road gang at first, then in a battery factory, then began a modest business. This odyssey of survival and success became a kind of parable, a legacy left to instruct his son.
"I understood early that American society was based on business and wealth and your ability to make money," the son said. So after a degree in engineering, he went to a well-known business school, then worked for an investment firm on Wall Street. But a job yields only a paycheck, and he "wanted to become the center of society, a player, a doer."
He took the lessons of his youth, his ambition, $10,000 in savings and a lot of borrowed capital and bought a mechanical parts company. He worked a hundred hours a week, every week of the year, turned enough profit to buy another company, then another and another until he was able to come to our town and spend a million dollars to put his family in a house on the hill.
On the night of my visit, he was at a turning point. We were sitting in the great room at a Charles X table, nursing drinks in crystal glasses and arguing the ontology of wealth.
He's through with leveraged buyouts and corporate resuscitations. "It isn't fun anymore," he said. "As you get older, you get interested in other things -- the life of the mind and the spirit."
He thinks the fortune he created has made him its victim. "If you set out to get it as I did, then you become a captive of the ideology that created it. Your entire happiness depends on the score." Which, in part, is why he collects painting and sculpture. "All day you're an economic animal. One of the things that humanizes you is art."
Perhaps, like the men his age in the valley, he has simply reached the point in life when one either steps aside or is carried away in the flow. He's gone from poverty to wealth, from bedrock Republicanism to Democratic activism, from guarding the status quo to calling for change. He can afford another turn now. "When you don't have to worry about taking care of your stomach," he said, anything is possible.
Besides, he has luck, and luck is everything. "I have many people working for me who have great talent, energy and imagination. The difference between me and them is pretty much luck. I have a friend who was the president of a major bank. He just got fired. Last year he was making a million dollars. Now he's making zero. Luck."
Maybe something more, too. His car is a late model sedan, the kind favored by factory workers and bus drivers and postal employees. The car is a kind of homily.
One day a long time ago, the immigrant turned battery mechanic took his son with him to his place of work. On the way inside they passed a new Cadillac at the curb. The car caught the boy's fancy, and later in the day, he carefully approached his father and asked, "Why don't you own a car like that?"
The old man suddenly turned dark, grabbed the boy by the ear and dragged him to a window. A strike was under way, and the street was lined with pickets. Some of their cars were on either side of the Cadillac. "Which one," said the father, pointing to the line of cars, "which one do you think belongs to the boss?"
The lesson was clear: don't flaunt good fortune; don't advertise success.
"It's dumb," the son says today, to stand beside the have-nots and "stress the difference." So he drives what his wife calls "sardine cans."
He also keeps quietly -- inconspicuously, one might almost say -- to his manor on the hill, thanking his luck and his God for a good marriage and healthy children, for his wealth and his power and his "damn interesting" life. And if he should ever forget his provenance, his father is likely to bring him back.
No one in the family can forget what the old man said the first time he came up the drive and saw the stone manor with the peaked arches, the 29 rooms -- more or less -- and the tennis court, the swimming pool, the artworks, the rare wines, the golden glow of all that money can buy and some of what it can't.
"My stupid son," he said, "you did all right."

HEADLINE: A Woman's Quest for Her 3d World Championship in Karate

BYLINE: By PHILIP GOOD

DATELINE: FORDS

 BODY:
WHEN Debra Bressaw aims a deadly kick at her husband's head, he doesn't seem to mind it at all. For Bill Bressaw, it's all in an evening's work. His days are spent practicing law in Woodbridge, but he's also the owner and operator of Bressaw's Middlesex Karate School here.
As for Ms. Bressaw, she has a black belt and has twice won the world championship in the women's lightweight division of a karate style called shukokai. On Saturday in Coimbra, Portugal, she is scheduled to start another quest for the championship, held every two years. 
 For weeks Ms. Bressaw, 31, has trained six hours a day, at 90-minute classes in the dojo, or school, or pounding a punching bag at the school or in the basement of her home in Edison. She will be competing against women from 13 countries, some of whom operate their own schools.
Beside her bed, as motivation to get her up and practicing each morning, she keeps photographs of her competitors. "I have to train harder because I know there are other people out there training," she said.
 
A Bow to the Teacher
 One recent evening, there were 14 students in the dojo, standing barefoot on a large blue mat and dressed in white uniforms. They bowed to Mr. Bressaw, their sensei, or teacher, and simultaneously sounded a series of "oos," a martial arts greeting.
Their first assignment: to perform the kata, an ancient routine of movements that resembles a dance. Each breath was taken to correspond precisely with a step and extension of the arm. Then they practiced punching, kicking and blocking as well as throwing an opponent.
Ms. Bressaw's partner, Ray Gatarz, who holds a third-degree black belt, blocked one punch but missed a high spin kick. In each case, the blows stop short, doing no damage.
Eventually, the students watch individual sparring matches, with Mr. Bressaw awarding points for successful blows or blocks. And then they kneel in a closing meditation ritual that speaks to the mental aspect of their art.
Shukokai differs from most karate styles, Mr. Bressaw said, "in our quest for knowledge and the fine points." He added: "We have taken the technique to train each muscle in the body. We try to learn which muscles should be relaxed and which should be used on a punch."
The style was introduced in the United States 23 years ago by Shigeru Kimura, who runs a dojo in Tenafly. He is the organizer of the international championships.
"She's going for a third time and that's going to be a record," he said of Ms. Bressaw. "I think she has to overcome the pressure within herself. The enemy is within herself. She's working very hard to get that pressure off to bring her better results."
Ms. Bressaw's road to karate started when she was a student at Douglass College at Rutgers. "I would work in the library till 2 in the morning, and I didn't feel safe walking in the parking lot," she recalled. "When I saw a course in self-defense was being offered, I took it."
She moved on to Middlesex County College in 1981 and signed up for karate, taught by Mr. Bressaw. Eventually, she received a bachelor's degree in economics and married her sensei. They have three children.
 
Black Belt at 30,000 Feet
 Ms. Bressaw won her first championship title in 1989. Flying back from the tournament in Finland, Mr. Kimura presented her with her black belt. She had won the championship while still holding a brown belt. "I always tell people I got my black belt at 30,000 feet," she said.
Skill in karate is indicated by the color of the belt; black is the highest in the color rankings. Further expertise is indicated by degrees, or by stripes in lower-ranking colors. The highest is an eighth-degree black belt, which Mr. Kimura holds.
At the next tournament, in 1991 in Switzerland, Ms. Bressaw successfully defended her title.
Her pregnancies didn't seem to slow her down. With her first child she trained until the eighth month. She received her brown belt in 1987, not knowing at the time that she was pregnant with her third child.
All three children study karate. Christopher, 7, has a green belt; Nicole, 6 1/2, has a yellow, and Alison, 4 1/2, has a white belt with a yellow stripe.
"Sometimes I ask myself, how did I do all this?" Ms. Bressaw said. "I just think it was a real roller-coaster ride. I remember sensei Kimura once said to me, 'If you want to get something done, you give it to a busy person.' "
Ms. Bressaw acknowledges that her husband's skills have helped her competitive career in karate. "I have an advantage because I respect his abilities," she said. "He really brings out the best in me."
Mr. Bressaw sees another championship in his wife's future. "I think she'll do it again because her punch has improved," he said. "Remember in karate it's not so much the muscle but the technique, and Debbie has the technique." She is 5 feet 6 1/2 inches tall and weighs 120 pounds.
He also thinks, he said, that female competitors have "a greater emotional drive" than most of the men.
Ms. Bressaw agrees. "I feel when the females are competing, they have a little more fire in them. I rough it up every day with the guys, and the girls in shukokai are tough."

HEADLINE: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Norristown, Pa.;
County Seeks To Sell Offices

BYLINE: By David J. Wallace

 BODY:
MONTGOMERY COUNTY is renewing efforts to find a buyer for the Stony Creek Office Center here, a 50,600-square-foot project it took over three years ago because it had guaranteed a loan for its renovation.
The county has been auditioning brokers and property managers since choosing to accept bids from companies that say they can find new ways to cut expenses and lure bidders. It has already rejected two offers as inadequate. 
 The complex was built in the 20's as the home of the Adam Scheidt Brewing Company. Brewing ended in 1974 and the property was idle until a major subsidized rehabilitation in the 80's produced a seven-story glass-block and aluminum office tower.
The tower, the former brewhouse, with 38,600 square feet, is 88 percent rented at about $12 a square foot a year. Other buildings on the 5.5-acre property, 20 minutes by car from downtown Philadelphia, remain as 12,000 square feet of small office or warehouse space.
Led by Montgomery County, the rehabilitation was done with a $2.6 million loan from the Department of Housing and Urban Development through the Montgomery County Development Corporation and a $1.2 million Urban Development Action Grant from Norristown Borough. The developer, Windon Capital Management, made a $2.5 million equity investment, which qualified for Federal tax credits because the building is a historic structure.
When Windon defaulted on its loan in 1990 the county took over the property and continued the leasing, hoping to raise rents enough to increase its market value.
The hope in 1986 had been that the renovation would be a catalyst for Norristown's west end, an area of small, underutilized factory and office buildings and private residences. But many of the tenants were county agencies, with existing offices principally in the county courthouse two blocks away or private buildings nearby.
Jerry Birkelbach, the county's director of Economic Development, said income from Stony Creek had been repaying some of the loans, but he would not disclose the amount outstanding. He said the county's search for a new broker was intended to speed up a sale.
It has been suggested that the complex be retained for county offices. The county's day-care center leased 3,200 square feet last summer. Other tenants include Mr. Birkelbach's department, other agencies and a few private companies.
Arthur Weisman, president of Keystone Real Estate, which manages the property, said that the county's asking price for Stony Creek began at $3.9 million last year. Recent offers of about $1.5 million were not seriously discussed, he said.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
Can Tokyo Shake Off a Soaring Yen?

BYLINE: By James Sterngold

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
INVESTMENT analysts here have come up with their own version of a classic joke to describe the stock market's latest gyrations. How do you invest in Japanese stocks when the yen is rocketing out of control? Answer: very carefully.
The soaring value of the yen last week, to a postwar high against the dollar, took some of the steam out of the stock market's first convincing bull run in a year. With lingering memories of the market's many failed attempts at recovery since 1990, there was something of a collective groan as investors confronted a new set of scenarios and counted the stronger yen's toll on the economy. 
 Exporters could be hit hard, some fear, stifling the recovery from a recession almost before it begins. Will this prove yet another occasion for share prices to slide back into a rut?
Even after a harrowing week, most analysts say no, that the rally is here to stay. But, they generally add, care must be taken in approaching the Japanese market. There could be some knocks ahead if the yen races much higher -- it briefly hit 110 yen to the dollar last week -- and some sectors may perform poorly. Yet analysts' confidence in this rebound remained unshaken.
"This won't hurt the market too much as long as it doesn't get too much out of hand," said Jeff Bahrenburg, a senior stock market analyst with Merrill Lynch Japan. "I'm not lowering my ratings on this market yet, and if stocks do take a hit from another surge in the yen, we'd double up on them."
Kathy Matsui, the strategist here for Barclays de Zoette Wedd Securities, generally agreed. "This isn't as negative as some people are playing it up to be," she said. "The speed of the yen's rise and the volatility has a lot of people very concerned, but it's not that bad in our view."
She added that she is sticking to her forecast that the Nikkei stock market index will reach 23,000 before the end of the year.
Getting there will require some recouping of recent losses; the Nikkei index peaked on April 13 at 20,740.29, its highest level in more than a year. Since then it has lost 5 percent, closing Friday at 19,704.15.
In a way, the shudders that spread through the market last week and caused the decline were understandable, because they were spread mostly by the Government.
As the yen crashed through a series of postwar highs, partly as a result of comments by President Clinton that appeared to encourage the movement, concern turned to fear that the Government had lost control of its own currency. The bottom line was that there was a policy conflict between Japan and the United States over the currency's value, and America won -- at least for now.
The Clinton Administration has pushed for a stronger yen as a means of reducing Japan's yawning trade surpluses with the United States; it encourages Japanese imports by making foreign goods cheaper here, and makes Japanese exports more expensive abroad, thus discouraging them.
The Japanese Government says it agrees with yen appreciation as a means of reducing its massive surpluses, but it opposes the run-up that has occurred. Throughout the last week officials from the Prime Minister on down warned that too steep a rise in the yen would nip the economic recovery in the bud.
Private analysts and economists agree that there will be some downward pressure, but add something that Government officials involved in the verbal tug of war with Washington did not: the Government is expected to take strong countermeasures to insure that the economy does expand smartly this year. If the yen does rise further, say to 100 yen to the dollar, most expect the Government to reduce interest rates or to increase a previously announced public works program to stimulate growth.
"The higher yen rate has created the opportunity for short-term interest rates to decline," said Susumu Kato, the economist here with CS First Boston (Japan). He added that the Bank of Japan may lower its official discount rate a half-point, to 2 percent, which would be bound to add a fillip to the economy and counter the impact of a stronger yen.
The basic reason for the optimism is the view that the economy has hit bottom and that corporate profits have only one way to go after four straight years of declines: up, and fast. The strong yen simply has not changed that, although it has made some wary of the stocks of companies that rely heavily on exports.
The overall ratio of share prices to expected earnings per share of the stocks on the first section of the Tokyo Stock Exchange is currently 70, about three times the level on Wall Street. But analysts say they are not concerned because of the expected surge in profits next year.
"When you're at a point in the cycle when earnings are so distressed, there's room for a real snapback," said Mr. Bahrenburg. "This is the time when stocks do well. We still believe that." He said that he is projecting the Nikkei index will hit 22,500 in the next several months and 27,000 by mid-1994.
Even some of the more vulnerable stocks, such as electronics companies, which are heavy exporters, are doing reasonably well.
Steven Myers, an electronics industry analyst for Jardine Fleming Securities here, commented: "The strong yen obviously will have some impact because a lot of these companies are not sufficiently hedged. They didn't expect such an abrupt movement in the currency. But the market seems to think this won't be prolonged. The stocks aren't doing badly."

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
The Rails Warn That Business Is Weakening

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
IS this a recovery that won't pick up speed?
Signs that the economy is slowing again have begun to appear, and while it is possible to dismiss some of them as reflecting bad weather in March, that is not true for all of them.
Some of the earliest indicators of industrial health come from the railroad industry, where the pickup after the March blizzard on the East Coast turned out to be brief. "The week prior to Easter was very strong, but it did not come out of Easter as strong as it had in the past," said Howard Keen, chief economist for Conrail. 
 Conrail, heretofore a Wall Street darling, jolted investors last week when it reported its earnings. It wasn't that profits were so bad, but the company warned that revenue apparently would grow much less this year than was expected.
The biggest part of that problem is coal. Exports are down sharply, largely because of Europe's recession, and domestic utilities have been paring inventories. But those trends are well known. What is new is the sluggish pickup in business in other areas. "There is not the spark we are all looking for," reports Mr. Keen. An increase in industrial traffic in January soon vanished, and Mr. Keen says that unless that turns around soon he expects to see industrial production begin to suffer.
Rail stocks are among the most economically sensitive. Their good performance beginning in the fall of 1990 signaled the economy had bottomed, and a renewed surge last fall began just as investors discovered the economy was starting to grow. But last week the Standard & Poor's rail index fell 5.7 percent, far more than the 2.7 percent drop in the
 S.&P. 500. Conrail tumbled $6.50, or 11 percent a share, to $52.625, but it is still up 56 percent from its low last October.
By no means are the signs all negative. The auto industry has picked up, and steel is doing acceptably well, notes Graeme Anne Lidgerwood, a railroad analyst for First Boston. Or, as Robert Fort, a spokesman for Norfolk Southern, put it, "the economy is sluggishly picking up." But Friday's report of a fall in durable-goods orders in March, coming on the heels of a drop in housing starts, provides ample reason to wonder whether the steam is going out of the recovery.
There is an optimistic way to view this, one that sees slow but consistent growth for years to come. With luck, such growth will not push up interest rates, but will allow corporate profits, and stock prices, to make solid, if unspectacular, gains.
The trouble with that forecast is that it ignores the impending tightening of fiscal policy. President Clinton's puny proposal for economic stimulus was talked to death by Senate Republicans last week, but his plans for new taxes are still on track. Such taxes are no doubt needed someday if the budget deficit is ever to be controlled, but they will slow the economy. It would be nice if the economy could pick up some speed before the fiscal brakes are applied.
