HEADLINE: Changing Course at American Airlines

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
He spreads his hands in frustration. He openly admits that he does not have the answers. He is impatient with strategies that have worked before. Only now and again, as when he talks about a new route to London, does the old confident, ebullient Robert L. Crandall burst through.
Mr. Crandall, the hard-charging chairman of American Airlines, led his industry on an expansionary binge in the 1980's that has now come back to haunt him and the industry. He was the one who pioneered the frequent-flyer program, innovative discount fares and a two-tier wage system that enabled the airline to cut costs while it expanded. And he was the one who built a dominant computer reservation system that often made his airline the first choice of travel agents. 
 Yet instead of the cocky corporate titan and industry champion, he's now more like the bewildered general who led a successful charge against an enemy, only to end up encircled by new and unknown forces. And so he has begun a retreat that is slow and painful and full of danger. When it's over, the airline he built into the largest carrier outside of Russia will be cut and perhaps seriously weakened.
Although executives at other airlines are staring at some of the same problems that beset American, only Mr. Crandall has been so vocal about the pain.
"It is a very hazardous time," said Mr. Crandall. "I am profoundly worried."
The wrenching reorganization through which he is now prodding the airline and its parent, the AMR Corporation, is far riskier than anything he has done before. Although last week's earnings report for the first quarter showed some recovery in American's operations, it didn't change Mr. Crandall's assessment. He believes he has a serious long-term problem; its name is American Airlines.
To help solve it, he plans to focus more on subsidiary businesses, like helping other carriers with such services as data processing, where earnings are more reliable.
He also believes he must make the airline smaller. He is stopping or stretching out the delivery of many aircraft, grounding or retiring some of its existing planes, pruning capital spending and dropping some short-haul flights that bleed cash. He is contemplating closing some of American's hubs. And in a move that jacked up the anxiety in the ranks, American said recently that it would lay off 500 pilots and 400 mechanics, the first layoffs since the early 1980's.
 
Making the Cuts
 Yet how far can Mr. Crandall cut before the airline becomes too small to sustain itself -- and leaves too many new opportunities for rivals big and small? What torments him is that he is not convinced any of his strategies will work. His anguished -- and at times public -- soul searching seems to generate more questions than answers. He is so frustrated by the process that he has been turning to outsiders for help: professors, critics, journalists and analysts, even industry gadflies he wouldn't have gone near years ago.
One thing is clear. Because more than 90 percent of AMR's revenues come from the airline, "he has to fix the airline," said Julius Maldutis, airline analyst at Salomon Brothers. He and other analysts are skeptical of Mr. Crandall's comments that he will largely abandon the airline business if he cannot produce higher returns. But Mr. Maldutis believes the non-airline segment of the business will rise to 20 percent of revenues in five years, double what it is now.
Mr. Maldutis also thinks that by the end of the decade, American Airlines will rely more heavily on international routes and remain a major competitor on transcontinental flights, fed by strong hubs like Chicago, Dallas-Fort Worth and Miami. Weaker hubs, like Raleigh-Durham, N.C., San Jose, Calif., and Nashville, may well be shut or scaled back, and American will pull out of many of the smaller markets it now dominates. That could offer rivals the short-haul routes that now feed into those hubs, and make for livelier competition and perhaps lower fares. Indeed, those rivals might then weaken the hub-and-spoke system -- and change the flying patterns of millions of Americans -- by offering more nonstop flights to medium and small cities instead of flights that stop in big cities.
Mr. Maldutis also believes that American's fleet will be smaller, although he will not estimate by how much, and that it may consist mainly of medium-sized jets. A possible source for the supply of those planes is Russia, which is eager to sell its new planes -- some equipped with Western avionics and engines -- to win a foothold in the private aviation market.
Mr. Maldutis and other analysts believe that American could emerge as a highly profitable carrier. It would, however, be more vulnerable to events that devastate international traffic, like the Gulf war, they added.
 
'Impossible Situation'
 As change sweeps through his airline, Mr. Crandall continues to raise troubling questions. Some regard his public vulnerability with cynicism, calling it an orchestrated plan to soften up his unions for concessions down the road. But it is at odds with the management style he has cultivated over the years and he has little to gain from being so embarrassed so publicly. He likes to put his cards on the table and let the other side know exactly what he wants. The problem is that the cards often come up blank these days.
"He is caught in an impossible situation," said Robert W. Iverson, chairman of Kiwi International Air Lines, an upstart, Newark-based carrier poised to move into markets that Mr. Crandall may be forced to abandon.
So is it time for the 58-year-old Mr. Crandall, who has led the airline for 13 years, to step down? His board and his management appear to be behind him. Even his critics say he is firmly in control, of his company and himself. But the appearance of such a high-profile corporate leader raising such serious questions is, to say the least, quite rare -- especially when other airline chiefs, like Stephen Wolf at United, seem more optimistic that they can ride out tough times with such proven methods as winning concessions from unions and cutting costs and unprofitable routes.
"The problem for chief executives is that their egos prevent them from reaching outside their own spheres," said Paul Dempsey, professor of law at the University of Denver, who has been advising Mr. Crandall. "Crandall is bright enough and has the self-confidence to go to the outside. That speaks well of him."
The news for American and the rest of the industry has been a bit better lately. Airline traffic for the industry has been up in recent months and that is expected to continue through the summer. Last week's first-quarter report at AMR showed a net loss of $22 million, which some analysts said was less than expected. In fact, its operating earnings were up 1.8 percent and costs reduced about 1 percent, even in the face of higher fuel costs. "This underscores our continuing commitment to control every possible expense," Mr. Crandall said.
Still, he believes the company is earning an inadequate return on its investment and sees "a continuing proliferation of discount fares of every type" and a continuing recession in many overseas markets. The company's stock rose $6, to $71.25, the day the first-quarter results were announced, but the numbers did little to change Mr. Crandall's downbeat assessment. He calls his problems more fundamental and says they grow out of forces beyond his control.
 
Threats From All Sides
 Consumers, he says, will continue to demand lower fares. Huge foreign carriers, like British Airways, are trying to elbow their way into more domestic markets. Hobbled airlines operating under the protection of bankruptcy courts -- Continental, Trans World Airlines, America West -- are emerging as healthier rivals.
What's more, not since the early 1970's have so many small upstart airlines taken to the skies. And fare wars have been cropping up recently and more are likely. Just last week, Northwest Airlines cut fares sharply on domestic routes and some Atlantic markets, forcing American and others to match.
Washington, too, poses a concern. For the first time since 1979, the Government has started to flex its muscles on industry issues; it recently moved to protect an upstart carrier, Reno Air, against price-cutting moves by Northwest.
The turmoil that these changes have produced -- fueled by Mr. Crandall's reaction to them -- is evident everywhere at American. Some mid-level executives and rank-and-file employees say they are confused and concerned by all of Mr. Crandall's public probing.
Last spring, for example, employees saw him suffer a major loss of face -- and a sharp drop in profits. In response to a temporary sale by Northwest, Mr. Crandall cut all discount fares by 50 percent and dropped restrictions. That set off the largest spree of ticket buying in industry history -- and a spate of huge losses.
Legal troubles are also cause for concern. Several carriers, including Continental, T.W.A. and America West, have filed suits against Mr. Crandall, charging him with predatory pricing to drive them out of business with last spring's fare cuts. Although Mr. Crandall is normally willing to blast other carriers, he is now very cautious when talking about other airlines that could use his remarks against him in their lawsuits.
Some employees are troubled. "You have to watch out for yourself," said one flight attendant, who asked that she not be identified. She has been with the carrier five years and has begun to build up a decorating business on the side.
Sherry Brownell, a flight attendant for 23 years, said she has started studying retailing, "just in case," even though her seniority will likely keep her job safe.
Some top executives have tried to explain the current turmoil as a manifestation of Mr. Crandall's long-time management style, which is open and frank and intended to allow new ideas to percolate. The Crandall style, said Don Carty, senior vice president of finance and strategic planning, is "to challenge what you are doing as you are doing it."
 
From Optimism to Pain
 Mr. Carty conceded, however, that there are some conflicting feelings about the current course. Shifting from quick growth to retrenchment can be disconcerting. One strategy, after all, is full of optimism; the other is simply painful. And the shift away from building an airline to increasing investment in less visible businesses -- say, computer reservations systems -- is also less exciting, he said.
Yet the shift, he stressed, must be made. "There is an ambivalence about how we feel," he said, "but no ambivalence about what we must do."
While it is relatively easy to cut flights and even to close hubs, it takes much longer to cut the remaining overhead to make up for the loss of revenue. "The fixed cost of buildings does not change," Mr. Crandall said.
Rising labor costs are a problem, but Mr. Crandall is reluctant at this point to go to his unions for concessions because he believes they would seek an equity stake in the airline.
The unions have shown little willingness to give concessions. To the contrary, Randy Edwards, a spokesman for the Association of Professional Flight Attendants, which is in talks to replace the contract that expired in December, said that union negotiators are looking to reap some benefits as a payback for concessions they agreed to 10 years ago. American's other major contracts, for the pilots and the machinists, expire in August 1994 and March 1995, respectively.
Labor costs now make up about one third of the carrier's costs. They have increased about 11 percent since 1988 while revenue has risen only about 6 percent. And they are hardly the only costs that are up. Fuel expenses, for example, have risen about 14 percent since 1988. Although American has about $800 million in cash, it had losses of $240 million in 1991 and $278.2 million last year.
 
Weighing the Hubs
 One way to cut costs is to sell off hubs or parts of them. American is thinking about selling off the relatively new terminal at its hub in Raleigh-Durham, which was built only six years ago for $150 million. It is also studying whether to close or cut back in San Jose.
Mr. Crandall "has to give up market share and get out of hubs where they are not making money," said Ray Neidl, an analyst for Furman Selz Inc. But, he added, "this gives a chance for the new low-cost carriers to get stronger to challenge the big guys."
This is even a bigger risk because of the more activist stance that the Government is taking toward the industry. The new Secretary of Transportation, Federico Pena, has shown in the Reno Air case that he will intervene to give new carriers a better chance against their bigger brethren, vowing to enforce antitrust laws that were largely ignored by the past two Republican Administrations.
As Mayor of Denver, Mr. Pena witnessed some of the destructive aspects of deregulation first hand. It was in Denver that Frontier Airlines met its demise during a frenzy of takeovers, and it was there, too, that United and Continental battled in brutal fare wars that helped put Continental into bankruptcy.
Professor Dempsey, from the University of Denver, said he believes the industry is ready for more Government intervention to help find its way out the hole it has dug. Mr. Crandall and other industry leaders have expressed support for a new Government commission that is charged with trying to find solutions to some industry problems.
But Mr. Crandall still believes that the company's fate is largely in its own hands, making it that much more urgent to find the right strategy for the long haul.
"I'm not entirely satisfied with the answers," he said. "We have to keep probing at every front if we're going to meet the challenge."
 
 
 
THE GADFLY HAS HIS DAY AT 58,000 FEET

DONALD PEVSNER, a Florida lawyer who has filed numerous suits on behalf of flyers to get lower fares and better service, is hardly the sort of person Robert Crandall, chairman of American Airlines, would consult.
Yet just such an odd arrangement began in April 1990, when Mr. Pevsner and Mr. Crandall were on the same Concorde flight to London. Mr. Pevsner sent Mr. Crandall a note, baiting him. Is it time, he asked, to regulate airlines again?
To Mr. Pevsner's surprise, Mr. Crandall came back to his seat. At 58,000 feet over the Atlantic, the two men wrangled over deregulation and other issues. To Mr. Pevsner's greater surprise, Mr. Crandall gave him his card with his private phone and fax numbers and made a request: Could he travel as American's guest -- for up to 12,000 miles on different routes -- and report back his impressions?
Over the next year, Mr. Pevsner sent Mr. Crandall hundreds of faxes and then met with top executives. He told them that fares in many markets were too high for business travel and that discount fares carried too many restrictions, inhibiting travelers from impulse trips. He also said that there should be more direct flights between cities and that the hub system often caused "too much of a hassle for travelers."
Mr. Crandall said his managers factored Mr. Pevsner's suggestions into their thinking. And Mr. Pevsner was impressed. "He wanted an outsider to troubleshoot," he said. "That was a relatively creative step. No other C.E.O. but Crandall would have done something like that."
But unwilling to let his critic's role lapse, Mr. Pevsner said he felt little came of his suggestions.
"I was banging my head against the wall," he said.

HEADLINE: Ikea's New Realities: Recession and Aging Consumers

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

DATELINE: JARFALLA, Sweden

 BODY:
It is a cold, gray morning in this suburb of Stockholm, but hundreds of people are lined up for the opening of a vast new Ikea store.
"Welcome to cheap land," says Anders Moberg, the genial president of the Ikea Group, using a pun based on Smaland, the name of the region of Sweden where the furniture retailer was founded. Then he cuts a large yellow and blue ribbon and watches, smiling, as the crowd rushes past in search of sofas, tables, beds and other goods that the company aims to sell for 10 percent to 30 percent less than other furniture retailers. 
 Ikea, virtually unknown outside Scandinavia two decades ago, has grown accustomed to opening-day crowds as it has pushed rapidly into Europe, North America and Asia. Along the way, it has built something of a cult following, especially among young, price-conscious consumers.
But Ikea executives have fewer reasons to smile nowadays. After an expansion binge that nearly doubled the number of stores and nearly quintupled sales in less than a decade, the company is stopping to catch its breath. And as it looks around, what it sees is not entirely encouraging.
The worldwide economic slowdown has hit the company's most important markets especially hard. Germany, which accounted for 29 percent of Ikea's sales last year, has slipped into a downturn, and Scandinavia, with 22 percent of sales, has been unable to pull itself out of a two-year slump.
Worldwide sales this year should be roughly flat, excluding revenues from new stores, Mr. Moberg said. And there is no way of knowing whether the downturn will end soon or deepen. "Since we have such a chaotic situation in the world it's difficult to make predictions," Mr. Moberg said.
Ikea is also facing demographic shifts that are forcing it to try to broaden its appeal to older and wealthier consumers.
It plans to open 11 stores this fiscal year, which ends Aug. 31, down from 17 last year. And it has no immediate plans to add to the existing 12 stores in the United States. Openings will drop even lower over the next several years, and Ikea executives are pausing to take stock. "Of course growth is important," Mr. Moberg said. "But the first priority for me is to take care of existing Ikea."
From 10 stores in five countries in 1974, Ikea will have grown by the end of this summer to 119 stores in 24 countries.
Millions of customers have gone to the stores -- large showrooms next to huge self-service warehouses usually situated just outside of large cities -- and lugged home heavy cartons of Ikea furniture, which is packed and sold unassembled to keep the company's costs and prices low. They have spread out the dozens of pieces and stared hard at the sometimes incomprehensible instructions, wondering whether the savings are worth the hassle of do-it-yourself assembly.
Some have muttered, "Never again." But enough have kept going back for the moderate prices, the simple Scandinavian designs and the large selection of colors, styles and materials to make Ikea one of the world's fastest-growing retailers.

WHILE Ikea has no direct rival in store size and selection of goods, its designs and pricing strategies have been widely imitated.
Sales in the last fiscal year were reported at $3.2 billion at current exchange rates. A nonprofit Dutch foundation set up by Ikea's founder, Ingvar Kamprad, owns Ikea and does not disclose its profits. The foundation, Stichting Ingka, sometimes makes investments outside of the Ikea Group. It recently acquired the Habitat chain of home furnishings retailers from Storehouse P.L.C. of Britain (except for the Conran's Habitat stores in the United States). It will operate them separately from Ikea.
Company executives said the bulk of any profits go back into Ikea itself, financing its growth and keeping debt levels low. Ikea's challenges will not end with the recession. Most of its customers are relatively young and its furniture has always been designed with their tastes and financial limitations in mind. But worldwide the population is aging. Ikea is already expanding its product line to include more traditional -- and more expensive -- styles favored by older consumers -- fully assembled sofas, for example, that customers can order with a wide choice of fabrics and have shipped to them directly from the supplier.
But in trying to broaden its appeal, Ikea risks diluting its identity and becoming just another big furniture retailer. "We can't have something for everybody," said Mr. Moberg. "But we will have a reasonably wide range, enough to be an option for 40 or 50 percent of any country's population."

IKEA was founded in 1943 by Mr. Kamprad, who was then just a teen-ager, to serve very price- and quality-conscious neighbors. Sweden at the time was a relatively poor nation, particularly the residents of the central region known as Smaland.
A native of the region (the name Ikea comes from his initials plus the first letter of his village, Elmtaryd, and his parish, Agunnaryd), Mr. Kamprad developed a furniture line to meet those needs. He sold it first through a catalogue and then through a showroom in 1954. The first real store didn't open until 1958, in Almhult, the Smaland town that remains the headquarters of Ikea's Swedish operations and its spiritual home.
As Ikea became successful, and Mr. Kamprad grew older, he confronted a common problem in Sweden: extremely high inheritance taxes. Concluding that the company would have to be broken up or sold off if it remained Swedish-owned at his death, he set up the Stichting Ingka foundation in Amsterdam, with himself as chairman, and transferred to it 100 percent ownership of Ikea. He moved the company's international headquarters to Denmark. He himself moved to Switzerland.
Today, at 66, Mr. Kamprad -- whose wealth is estimated by Forbes at $2.8 billion -- is a Sam Walton-like figure. He appears unannounced in stores for a look around. He oversees product development and purchasing operations. He guards against any weakening of the corporate culture he imposed, a culture that spurns hierarchy and bureaucracy and virtually outlaws perks. (Mr. Moberg, the president, and all other top executives travel coach class and stay at budget hotels. At dinner the night before the store opening in Jarfalla, Mr. Moberg and his top lieutenants discussedwhich bus to take from the airport to save a few dollars.)
Nowhere is penny pinching more important to Ikea than in its dealings with its 1,800 suppliers. Ikea does little manufacturing of its own, so is always seeking ways to exert more influence over the companies from which it buys the furniture it sells. Its sheer size helps. But Ikea executives said they were increasingly becoming more active in helping the suppliers to become more efficient.
Goran Stahlgren, Ikea's top purchasing executive in Sweden, recalled a recent meeting at which the company decided to help the suppliers shop around for better quality materials, lower prices, or both.
"Maybe they have the competence, but they don't have the time or the temperament to search the world for raw materials," Mr. Stahlgren said. "We can help with that."

IKEA also sends people to study suppliers' operations and to suggest more efficient methods. At Brantorp, a Swedish maker of wooden drawers and doors for kitchen cabinets and bureaus, Ikea recommended that the supplier move up to two shifts a day, and helped justify the change by ordering larger quantities. The move allowed Brantorp to reduce its unit costs. Ultimately, Ikea executives said, the change should lower the supplier's prices by 15 percent to 20 percent.
Some Ikea executives said the company had sometimes concentrated too much on what its suppliers could build efficiently rather than on asking consumers what they wanted to buy.
In the United States, for example, Ikea made a classic outsider's mistake by selling beds only in European sizes, which standard American mattresses and sheets don't fit. It later stocked compatible sheets in some stores, but sales were not good, so it recently decided to simply order American-sized beds.
That's the kind of shift in thinking, said Marvin S. Traub, the former chairman of Bloomingdale's, that will help Ikea as it expands into markets farther and farther from its home base. "They're learning more and more about the U.S. market," said Mr. Traub, who last fall purchased the American stores of Conran's Habitat. "There will be opportunities for them to grow."
Because Ikea has continued to open new stores even as other battered retailers slowed or stopped, Mr. Moberg said his company could benefit some from the continued economic sluggishness.
"I see this as a good opportunity to take market share," he said. "Value for money is very important to the consumer."
 
 
 
THE AMERICAN CONNECTION
 "The United States has been a good market for us, and there's a huge potential there," said Anders Moberg, president of the Ikea Group.
"But when as a Swede you go to a huge country like the U.S. and say, 'Ooh, markets, markets, markets,' it can be dangerous," he added. "It's not one market, it's a lot of different markets. We have to concentrate on areas rather than trying to be everywhere."
Unfortunately for Ikea, its biggest American market is the Los Angeles area, which has five of the company's 12 American stores. California has seen few signs of the recovery that seems to be taking hold in much of the nation.
Since establishing a beachhead outside Philadelphia in 1985, the Ikea Group has also opened stores near New York -- in Elizabeth, N.J., and Hicksville, L.I. The other American stores are outside Washington, Baltimore, Pittsburgh and Houston.
"They've put together a critical mass of furniture and furnishings," said Walter K. Levy of Levy Kerson Associates, a retail consulting firm in New York. "It's value priced and pretty well made. It's ubiquitous-contemporary in style. The chances of finding what you want are pretty high -- and you can take it home with you. That's a pretty good formula." One that is very hard for competitors like Crate and Barrel and Pier 1 to match.
The company plans to spend the rest of this year concentrating on improving its supplier relationships in the United States and improving its distribution system.
Only then will Ikea consider expanding, Mr. Moberg said, most likely on the East and West Coasts, where the company has good distribution and invested in marketing efforts to build up its name.

HEADLINE: Business Diary/April 18-23

BYLINE: By Hubert B. Herring

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
Isn't That Bob Dole, With Democratic Feathers in His Mouth? 

This round goes to Bob Dole. The Senate minority leader held his troops firmly in line last week to kill off President Clinton's economic stimulus bill, rejecting all compromises aimed at ending a Republican filibuster. But Mr. Dole, far from gloating, even seemed a bit embarrassed that he'd won -- making light of it as "just a bump in the road" for the President. That's a far cry from his recent colorful snipings. But the Democrats, furious at this Republican ambush, unleashed a harsh volley, with Senator Robert Byrd saying Republicans would accept "billions for unemployment, not one cent for jobs" and calling them "guardians of gridlock." And George Stephanopoulos, voice of the White House, said that for Mr. Dole, "playing politics is a lot more important than putting people to work." As the dust cleared, though, maybe there was a lesson for Mr. Clinton on how to deal with those folks on Capitol Hill.
 
Greenspan Sees Low Inflation
 
If Alan Greenspan has anything to say about it -- and he has a lot to say about it -- there'll be no burst of inflation any time soon. In a speech to the Economic Club of New York, the Federal Reserve chairman said inflationary pressures were "difficult to imagine" with bank lending subdued and labor costs under control. And he vowed not to repeat the mistakes that led to high inflation in the late 70's. He clearly sees low inflation as crucial to a strong economy, saying that it has helped businesses focus on productivity, not raising prices -- and that the resulting jump in productivity could signal a lasting trend. Maybe in another year you'll be refinancing that mortgage yet again.
 
In the meantime, the economy took another stumble. Durable-goods orders -- a key barometer of industrial health -- fell a surprisingly large 3.7 percent in March, the biggest decline in 15 months.
 
$60 Million Gift for Columbia
 
John W. Kluge knows what minority youths sorely need: a good education. And he's putting a good chunk of his fortune where his heart is. Last week Mr. Kluge, chairman of Metromedia and one of the nation's richest people, gave Columbia University $60 million for minority scholarships. That will work out to yearly grants of $10,000 for 300 students. But what Mr. Kluge does not need is a campus building with his name on it. Columbia and other colleges have offered it, repeatedly, "but I'm not interested," he said. What he's interested in is minority scholarships, because, he said simply, "the need is there."
 
A Greener President
 
When the hard choices come, how much will Clinton stick up for the environment? Early signs weren't good, as the President backed away from a shift in Federal land policy and allowed a toxic waste incinerator in Ohio. But maybe a bit of Earth Day spirit got into him last week. Reversing two key Bush policy positions, Mr. Clinton said the United States would sign an international treaty protecting endangered species and would act to reduce global warming. Environmentalists, including Vice President Gore, cheered. "President Clinton has brought America back into step with the rest of the world on environmental protection," said Fred Krupp, executive director of the Environmental Defense Fund.
 
Law Firm Pays Its Keating Dues
 
In 1989, the Government paid $2.5 billion to mop up after Charles Keating and his pals at Lincoln Savings. Uncle Sam was not happy. The Government got Mr. Keating behind bars, and keeps trying to get some money back. Last week, Jones, Day, Reavis & Pogue, the giant law firm, agreed to chip in $51 million just before a trial was to begin to decide whether it should pay a lot more. Back in 1986, Jones, Day did some work for Lincoln -- and, a Government lawyer said, was told in "graphic and detailed terms" about Lincoln's shenanigans. It was a prime opportunity "to stop Mr. Keating in his tracks," he said.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
Fiat Says Yes, There's a Problem
 
Maybe a healing process is beginning in Italy. For the first time, Gianni Agnelli, Fiat's chairman, publicly acknowledged corporate corruption and urged investigators to get on with it. For over a year, the scandal has mushroomed, with more and more tales of bribes to politicians for contracts, and Fiat, the giant of Italian business, was at the heart of it. Mr. Agnelli's admission was seen as an attempt to head off further damage.
 
Eurotunnel's Coming, Someday
 
Some cynics, surely, think there will never really be a tunnel linking England and France -- believing England is destined to remain that sceptred isle, standing aloof from the rest of Europe. Cynics, take heart. Last week the planned opening of the delay-plagued Eurotunnel was delayed yet again. It was supposed to be Christmas, but now -- amid a dispute over $1 billion in costs -- it looks more like next year. So for a bit longer, that fortress built by nature is unscaled by engineers.
 
A Trade Issue of Clinton's Own
 
Bill Clinton has talked tough on trade, but until now there's been no true taste of Clinton action. There have been disputes on autos and computer chips, but those were holdovers from the Bush days. Last week, the first trade issue taken up by this Administration came to the fore, and the result was mixed. There was an accord with Europe on contracts for work on electric utilities, but Europeans will be barred from bidding on other contracts.
 
 
 
COMPANIES

 
I.B.M.'s Been Down So Long . . .
 
Investors have gotten so used to large-scale grim news from I.B.M. that they looked at last week's $285 million quarterly loss and said, well, it could have been worse -- and bid the stock up by $1.375, to $50.625. But the news was bad -- as the market soon realized, with the stock slipping to $47.75 by week's end -- because the fine print showed that I.B.M.'s mainframe business had serious, lasting problems. These big machines have always paid I.B.M.'s bills, and though companies still buy them, competitive pressure has pushed prices down 30 percent in a year -- and there's no end in sight. On the plus side, I.B.M. cut operating costs by a sharp 9 percent in the quarter, but Louis V. Gerstner Jr., the new chief executive, still has a huge task ahead.
 
Goodbye House, Goodbye Garden
 
Maybe home decorating, like housecleaning, is an endangered art as hassled multicareer families have less time to fuss about the nest. Maybe magazine advertising is not bouncing back all that quickly. Or maybe it's just that Conde Nast did not want to compete against itself. But whatever the reason, HG (born in 1901 as House & Garden) is no more. Conde Nast, which just bought HG's healthier rival, Architectural Digest, said last week that HG's July issue would be its last. The publisher's financial reasons were certainly sound, but many found it hard to see an institution die. "It's the end of an era," one designer said. And one shocked journalist added, "It was like the death of a friend."
 
Trade Center Tenant, at a Price
 
BankAmerica may have qualms about moving into the World Trade Center, but it wasn't admitting them last week when it signed a 15-year lease for eight floors. With improvements made since the February bombing, it is "the safest building in New York, and perhaps even in the country," the bank said. Pretty strong words. But then again, it was given some pretty strong incentives to sign that lease -- two years free rent, among other things. Fearing that other tenants might flee when their leases end, local officials badly wanted this new tenant -- and were willing to pay the price. "BankAmerica is sending an important message," Gov. Mario Cuomo said, seizing on the symbolism. "The World Trade Center is back."
 
McDonnell Clings to the C-17
 
This much is clear: McDonnell Douglas badly wants to keep making the C-17 cargo plane, and the Air Force badly wants the plane, to replace an outdated model. But then it gets murky. At a hearing last week, House members accused John F. McDonnell, the chairman, of conspiring with the Government to bail out his company. But Mr. McDonnell strongly denied any wrongdoing. Even the company's earnings were questioned. On the eve of the hearing, McDonnell had reported a strong comeback, but some on the House panel expressed doubt about its recovery.
 
A Five-and-Dime It's Not
 
What, exactly, is a store? A place to buy what you need and then quickly get on with your life? Get real. These days, "people are looking for fantasy and entertainment from retailing," a market researcher says. True, there are still those driven souls who dart into a department store for lipstick or a tie, but Takashimaya turns up its nose at them. "Jewelry and cosmetics on the main floor are tired concepts," said a merchandise manager for the Japanese retailer. So, out with tired concepts! Last week, Takashimaya opened a Fifth Avenue store whose first two floors are devoted to an art gallery and a soaring atrium. Will hurried New Yorkers make time for this? We'll see.
 
Look Who's Back: Sears
 
Six months ago, Sears, Roebuck posted its first loss since the Depression. It was smarting from an auto-repair scandal, its Allstate Insurance unit had taken a hurricane beating and its merchandising business was floundering. But last week those clouds vanished: Aided by a new vigor at Allstate and strength in retailing, Sears reported the highest first-quarter profit in its 106-year history. The stock, in the low 40's in October, closed the week at $53.50.

SECTION: Section 9; Page 5; Column 1; Styles of The Times

LENGTH: 2437 words

HEADLINE: A Stroke Of Genius

BYLINE: By NEAL KARLEN

 BODY:
WAYNE NEWTON'S unlikely enshrinement into the hallowed halls of hipness began with a Las Vegas-style existential crisis. Gazing into his bathroom mirror one fateful day during the winter of 1991, Mr. Newton refused to look below as the first half of his infamous pencil-thin mustache swirled down the drain. Was it too late, the singer fretted, to reconsider his decision to finally lose his Valentino-via-Vegas look?
"I stared at what was left of my mustache, and thought very hard about what it all meant," said the 51-year-old casino crooner, whose collected monikers over the decades include "Mr. Excitement," "the Midnight Idol," "King of the Strip" and, most often, "Mr. Las Vegas." 
 In the preceding days, Mr. Newton's closest friends had told him he was nuts to even think of shaving off his trademark. To the millions of fans who had made Mr. Newton the highest-paid nightclub singer ever, the mustache was as integral a part of his persona as Groucho Marx's greasepaint or Gabby Hayes's whiskers. Of course, to the cognoscenti who had long lampooned Mr. Newton as the ultimate ham-boned lounge lizard, his mustache had become a symbol of Las Vegas vulgarity itself, as unctuous an icon of Sin City as Liberace's candelabra or Sammy Davis Jr.'s medallions.
Staring in the mirror, Mr. Newton took final stock. "I said, 'If all I am is a mustache, then that's not enough. A mustache isn't a person, it doesn't have a soul.' " And so, with a steely grip Wayne Newton shaved off his remaining sliver of facial hair.
Two years later, that razor stroke reverberates as the beginning of an astonishing counterrevolution of perception wherein Mr. Newton, and the town he embodies, is suddenly hip. More young people are coming to Las Vegas than ever before: last year, according to the city's Convention and Visitors Authority, 31 percent of the city's 22 million visitors were under 40, and 14 percent were under 30.
And the new clientele aren't all coming from trailer parks, or why would Wolfgang Puck have just opened a Spago in Caesar's Palace? True these visitors aren't monolithic in their tastes: several Hollywood brat packs have led the charge to Las Vegas, accompanied by their polar opposites from the anti-rat-race worlds of alternative music and Generation X.
To be sure, part of Las Vegas's new appeal is based on the historic appreciation of fine pop cultural cheese by the baby boomers. Still, young people are putting their money where there irony is: there are enough Armanis and skinny sideburns in casino showrooms to indicate that Las Vegas no longer belongs just to the legions of blue-haired and mutton-chopped Americans who had been scaring off the style-conscious for decades.
Las Vegas's reputation has rebounded among even the most self-consciously cool chronicles. Not long after Mr. Newton shaved, Spy magazine toasted him with a laudatory feature; Spin, the glossy bible of alternative music, ran a lengthy appreciation, topped off with the sentence: "Wayne Newton is, for lack of a better word, God." He even made it onto a popular Zippy the Pinhead button, where the countercultural comic hero elliptically exclaims, "I'm under direct order from Wayne Newton!"
Mr. Newton, meantime, unbowed by decades of critical abuse or a recent bankruptcy, has remained pleasantly shocked at his change in status. "Suddenly the same things I was doing five years ago that were considered pure corn are now perceived to be in," Mr. Newton said at his home in Las Vegas. "I've even got teen-age fan clubs." He paused, and then laughed. "It's a wonderful satisfaction to finally be hip."
Las Vegas chic has spread beyond Nevada. Among the popular party schemes for the young sets in New York or Los Angeles this season are get-togethers based on Tom Jones themes. Mr. Jones, a 52-year-old Welshman, continues to thrill his new audiences at Bally's, his home base, with surreal-sounding renditions of Prince's "Purple Rain" and Junior Walker's "Shotgun."
Among Mr. Jones's most devoted young fans are Luke Perry and Jason Priestley, stars of "Beverly Hills 90210," who recently flew to Las Vegas to see their hero perform. "I heard the fellows were fans, so I said let's get together," Mr. Jones said.
Traditionally, Las Vegas has been where brilliant talents have landed after their gifts have corroded. Few recall with fondness Billie Holiday's gigs at the Dunes, a bloated Elvis Presley at the Hilton or Orson Welles aping himself at the Riviera. Now, even the most current rock acts can prosper on the Strip; last month, Soul Asylum appeared with Keith Richards at Bally's . . . albeit billed in neon below Tom Jones.
"There's not a whole lot of difference between a Las Vegas club crowd and a Seattle club crowd," said Lori Barbero, the dread-locked and tattooed drummer for Babes in Toyland, who recently came to town on a double bill with Faith No More.
Las Vegas square has also been reborn as 90's cool on records and in books. Today, compact disks of the late Louis Prima and Keely Smith, the ultimate Vegas lounge act, are suddenly popular among the young in Hollywood, while Dean Martin, the consummate smarmy Vegas crooner, was recently recast as a totem of hipness via the critically acclaimed biography "Dino," written by the rock-and-roll chronicler Nick Tosches.
"It used to be that you wouldn't be caught dead telling anybody that you were going to Las Vegas on vacation," said Dick Mammen, 42, who was recently dubbed "the hippest man in city hall" in Minneapolis.
Yet, when he left his government job as an adviser on inner-city affairs to set up his own public-interest consulting firm, Mr. Mammen said he had only one thought of where to celebrate his new life. Accompanied by a stack of Frank Sinatra tapes, he drove his 1969 Cadillac convertible to Las Vegas.
"It was a gas," Mr. Mammen said. "You used to go there and feel like an alien from another solar system. Now, you'll run into people who actually look like you."
Las Vegas's last bout with hipness ended in the winter of 1960. Around this time, Frank Sinatra had called upon his show business cronies to convene in Las Vegas for a "summit of cool" to coincide with the filming of "Oceans Eleven," the ultimate "rat pack" movie. John F. Kennedy, on the eve of the New Hampshire primary, flew into town to watch Sinatra, Dean Martin, Sammy Davis Jr., Peter Lawford and other assorted swingers cavort on stage at the Sands Hotel.
According to Nick Tosches's book "Dino," Peter Lawford told the author that after the show, a million dollars in cash was said to have been given to the Kennedy campaign in a leather satchel by a consortium of Las Vegas hoteliers. The next morning, according to "Dino" and several other books, Sinatra introduced the candidate to Judith Exner, who would reportedly serve as mistress to both President Kennedy and the Chicago Mafia boss Sam Giancana. This wasn't Camelot, and Las Vegas, for all intents and purposes, was over.
By decade's end, Sinatra had a new friend, Spiro T. Agnew, and Las Vegas was so square that in 1968 Jim Morrison, visiting the city, was arrested and charged with vagrancy for failing to identify himself to police. By the 1970's, the city was seen as a blight to spirit and soul. "The Strip was an idiot Disneyland of architectural parabolas, overloaded utility poles, celestial hamburger stands and gimcrackery fairy palaces," wrote John Gregory Dunne in "Las Vegas: Memoir of a Dark Season" (Random House, 1974).
THE popular conception of Las Vegas probably reached bottom in the 80's and was embodied in the film "Lost in America," Albert Brooks's 1985 comic fable of a prototypical Los Angeles yuppie who has dropped out to find his soul. "We don't want to stay in Las Vegas!" Brooks tells his wife when she asks to check into a casino hotel. "This represents everything we left behind."
But by 1991, the earth had moved. Steve Wynn, a casino owner, opened the stately Mirage, proving that Siegfried and Roy could be even better attractions for a casino than "Nudes on Ice." Barry Levinson filmed "Bugsy," a stylish hagiography of the psychotic gangster Benjamin (Bugsy) Siegal, who invented modern Las Vegas. And Mr. Newton shaved his mustache.
"Aging baby boomers have the money to travel -- and they're realizing that there are certain things in the United States that they simply have to see in their lifetimes," said Jim Kilby, professor of gaming studies at the University of Los Vegas. "If you don't see Mardi Gras, the Kentucky Derby or Las Vegas, you've lived an incomplete life."
The city at large has boomed as much as the Strip. According to the 1990 census, Las Vegas is the fastest-growing major city in the country. With the sprawl, however, have come urban problems ranging from street gangs to pollution to water shortages.
Nothing, though, is scaring away the weekend crowds. In the current recession, many visit for practical reasons. "Las Vegas is the cheapest vacation in the world," Professor Kilby said. "You can still get a room for $18."
And betting isn't even a necessity for many young visitors. Several months ago, Rob Bragin, 37, joined a pack of fellow Hollywood television writers in a pilgrimage to Las Vegas. "The lure isn't gambling," Mr. Bragin said. "I'll bet a dollar, then get bored. But for me, and a lot of writers I know, the point is trying to temporarily re-create that kind of rat-pack feeling where you walk into a casino wearing a shiny suit while your mental soundtrack is playing Frank Sinatra singing 'Summer Wind.' It's nostalgia for things we were too young to be aware of at the time."
For some members of the even younger Generation X, rejection of baby-boom nostalgia for the 60's is behind the new appeal. "The rat pack may have all been chauvinist pigs, but there's still something romantic about that Vegas-in-the-50's aura," said Maria Larson, 27, a Manhattan-based dealer of vintage movie posters, who has visited Las Vegas three times in the last few years. "I'd so much rather hear Dean Martin sing 'That's Amore' then Fleetwood Mac doing 'Don't Stop Thinking About Tomorrow.' "
A trip through the "new" Las Vegas should perhaps begin at the Graceland Wedding Chapel, situated not far from downtown's Glitter Gulch. Graceland has become one of the premier rock-and-roll marriage spots in the world. Taking the vows can cost as little as $45, and the Elvis impersonator who serves as a witness for each wedding is free.
Jon Bon Jovi began the parade of the famous to the chapel in 1989, when he married his high-school sweetheart outside on the steps. Last March, Phil Joanou, the director of the U2 concert film "Rattle and Hum," tied the knot in a ceremony that was rebroadcast from the stage every night of the band's last American tour. Last winter, three members of Def Leppard showed up at Graceland's door, one to get married and two to renew their vows. You don't have to be famous to get married at Graceland. Around 45 ceremonies are performed a week, a pace that seems to be frazzling Norm Jones, the Elvis impersonator in residence.
"I heard I was on MTV a couple weeks ago, but I haven't had time to watch," Mr. Jones said, escorting a newly wedded couple out the door as another pair arrived. "And Def Leppard asked me to play with them in Los Angeles on New Year's Eve, but things were so busy I couldn't get away."
Moving from camp to the visionary, the next stop is the Mirage, the 29-story, 3,000-room hotel-casino that Steve Wynn opened in 1989 in an attempt to do away with the sameness of the typical Las Vegas casino. At the Mirage, there is no garish neon outside, no shoebox layouts inside and no headdress-and-breast shows in the theater.
Off the casino, patrons can walk through a tropical rain forest stocked with 90-foot-high trees or admire almost two dozen white tigers kept behind glass in a roomy habitat. But the Mirage's best-known feature -- indeed the city's single most popular attraction -- is a throwback to old Las Vegas spectacles that sits in front of the hotel. There, Mr. Wynn built a 50-foot-high volcano that erupts every 15 minutes into a Gilligan's Island-style lagoon of grottos and waterfalls.
While the Mirage represents Las Vegas's future, the Strip's past can best be seen a block away at the recently shuttered Dunes. When it opened in 1955, the resort, topped by a 30-foot plexiglass sultan, was hailed as the world's most luxurious hotel. The hotel was, in fact, Las Vegas at its most vulgar: in 1957, the Dunes made history when it offered "Minsky's Goes to Paris," Las Vegas's first topless burlesque.
Last November, Mr. Wynn purchased the hotel and announced he planned to tear it down and build another project. The closed Dunes still stands, however, and by day, one can still make out the words on the darkened sign in front: "Las Vegas -- City of Change."
The most popular Las Vegas daytime attraction off the Strip is the Liberace Museum, a dizzying collection that includes every diamond-encrusted automobile, piano and hot-pants outfit used by "Mr. Showmanship." By night, the draw is the "Legends" show at the Imperial Palace, where the world's finest Neil Diamond impersonator gives way to a faux-Madonna who seems to dance even more fluidly than the original.
Among the most sought-after Las Vegas tickets for the self-consciously cool are those for high-profile boxing matches. For years, fans like Jack Nicholson, Sylvester Stallone, and Billy Crystal have come to the desert to watch the fights. Now, they have been joined ringside by a growing number of Hollywood's younger stars. "You have a group of young actors who aren't interested in boxing, but in the spectacle of a big championship match in Las Vegas," said Seth Abraham, president of HBO Sports. "It's sexy women, sexy jewelry, sexy entertainers, sexy names. Many of these younger people are voyeurs who want only to see -- and be seen."
The hottest ticket, week in and week out, remains Wayne Newton. His show at the Hilton retains all his favorite chestnuts, including "Foggy Mountain Breakdown" and "Mack the Knife." But also woven into the act are unexpected gems, ranging from a Sam Cooke medley to "Hard to Handle," the rhythm-and-blues classic that the Black Crowes turned into a big hit a few years ago.
After a recent show, Mr. Newton recalled once again his inspiration to shave his pencil-thin mustache, a decision he says he believes led directly to his current position as an icon of the Las Vegas arrivistes. "A convert," Mr. Newton said, shaking his head, "is the best audience you'll ever have."

HEADLINE: Conversations/Mark Winston Griffith;
Into the World of Banking Comes a Hip-Hop Credit Union

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
AS the president of the newest Federally chartered lending institution in New York City, Mark Winston Griffith cuts a striking figure across the gray and gritty blocks of central Brooklyn. Sporting natty dreadlocks and a loan officer's bright tie, the 30-year-old is a poet among community activists and an iconoclast among bankers.
"Bring the noise! We're 'bout to take it to ya face," he said concluding his speech at the April 17 opening of the Central Brooklyn Federal Credit Union in the Bedford Stuyvesant community. 
 In January Mr. Griffith was part of a cadre of young black community activists to be granted a Government charter for the credit union. It was the first such charter granted under the Administration of President Bill Clinton, who has proposed the creation of more than 100 similar community development banks in impoverished American neighborhoods. The new lending institution opens amid widespread acknowledgement that commercial banks have been unable, and often unwilling, to provide adequate services to poorer neighborhoods in New York and other cities.
The credit union's organizers -- all schooled in political activism and the legacy of a civil rights movement that they now consign to the scrapbook of an earlier generation -- makes it quite clear they intend do things differently. With a level gaze, Mr. Griffith calls his not-for-profit financial services venture "the world's first hip-hop credit union."
If Mr. Griffith's language is obscure to the banking establishment, the community development strategy he embraces -- using existing law and political muscle -- is less so. Within three months of its inception, the new Federally insured Brooklyn credit union has received deposits and other commitments of financial support from Republic National Bank, Chemical Bank, Bankers Trust Company, the Municipal Credit Union and others.
Nor is the Brooklyn venture unique. In a spurt of enterprise that experts say was a response to the riots in South-Central Los Angeles, credit unions set up solely to provide services in poor areas received Federal charters last year in Omaha, Denver and Los Angeles. Now, with the Clinton Administration's support, others are being planned.
 
A Credit Boomlet

 
 "Since the day after the election, we have all sensed a new atmosphere and things have greatly accelerated," said Clifford N. Rosenthal, executive director of the New York City-based National Federation of Community Development Credit Unions, which advises such institutions. He said he expects six new charters over the next six months, paving the way for credit unions in Camden, N.J., Washington and other cities.
Mr. Griffith's credit union has so far raised $600,000 in deposits, a paltry sum compared to most commercial banks. But it hopes to attract at least $5 million, much of it to be used for personal loans and small business financing in Brooklyn.
"No other bankers could pull off what we are doing," Mr. Griffith added. "Our success is predicated on living in the neighborhood, being known by the people and being an organic part of this community."
Mr. Griffith, a graduate of Brown University who received a master's degree in Nigerian poetry from the University of Ibadan in Nigeria in 1988, was born in Bedford Stuyvesant. He lives across the street from the credit union's temporary quarters in a brownstone owned by his parents.
His co-founder is the credit union's treasurer, Errol T. Louis, a 30-year-old Harlem native and Harvard graduate who received a master's in political science from Yale and whose doctoral dissertation is on the role of credit in urban development. Mr. Louis is also an associate director of Mr. Rosenthal's credit union group.
"People in the traditional banking community question our background, but I am convinced it has helped," said Mr. Griffith, a former member of Assemblyman Clarence Norman Jr.'s staff. "We do not represent business as usual, and we bring a certain freshness."
Both Mr. Griffith, whose mother is Jamaican-born, and Mr. Louis, whose grandparents emigrated from Trinidad, say their Caribbean ancestry has given them a greater understanding of the needs of the thousands of West Indian immigrants who have settled in Brooklyn since the mid-1970's.
Mr. Griffith and Mr. Louis began their efforts in 1991 after the failure of Freedom National Bank, New York City's largest minority-owned lender. A critical source of support has been the 1977 Community Reinvestment Act, which gives watchdog groups and others power to question the lending practices and service of commercial banks in poor neighborhoods. Under the law, which was strengthened in 1990, banks that fail to provide adequate service can be challenged when they seek regulatory approvals for mergers, new branches and other new business ventures. Most large lenders have responded by establishing new guidelines for loans and even hiring executives with political savvy in seeking out investments in economically depressed areas.
 
Penny on the Dollar
 Mr. Griffith and others first conducted a study comparing the amount of deposits large banks received from their neighborhood and the amount committed to the area in home loans. "For every dollar they took out of Bedford Stuyvesant and Crown Heights, they gave back one penny in home lending," Mr. Louis said.
Armed with the potentially damaging data, and using his close ties to other activists, Mr. Griffith said he began a campaign of arm twisting and polite entreaties that attracted the support of big banks. "In a way, I suppose, we were political opportunists," he said, adding that his negotiations with the large banks "have often been like straddling the fence. I've had to play the tough guy, but also show them that we are reasonable people who can deliver the goods."
A strong working relationship with commercial banks is likely to be crucial to any success the embryonic Brooklyn credit union will have. So far most of the deposits have come from the larger Manhattan-based lenders.
At this stage no loans have as yet been made. "We are making arrangements to extend our own reach," he said. "We will be able to vouch for people in our community, and we think the commercial banks will respond."
Amid that unusual blend of allegiances -- to the poor streets of central Brooklyn and the board rooms of Manhattan banks -- Mr. Griffith said he had adopted a set of priorities that might not have seemed practical to black activists of past generations. "I don't think there needs to be a distinction between political energy, black empowerment and economic development," said Mr. Griffith, who is also executive director of the Central Brooklyn Partnership, a neighborhood housing and social service agency.
But what does hip-hop have to do with it?
"There is a new generational consciousness," Mr. Griffith said, adding that the economic development strategy he has adopted in central Brooklyn is as far removed from the civil rights protests of the the 1960's as hip-hop music is from the rock-and-roll ethos.
"The civil rights movement has died, its spirit passed, and we have to move to a different form," he said.

HEADLINE: Does the World Still Recognize a Holocaust?

BYLINE: By JOHN DARNTON

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia

 BODY:
LADY THATCHER, in her scorching indictment of Western inaction over Bosnia and Herzegovina two weeks ago, said: "I never thought I'd see another holocaust in my life." And then to her fellow Tory, Prime Minister John Major, she gave the unkindest cut of all. During the Battle of Britain the country was overwhelmed and inadequately prepared, she said, but at least it had "a Prime Minister with a lion heart." The implication was unmistakable: Mr. Major is no Churchill -- he is Neville Chamberlain.
Not for half a century has the world witnessed events in Europe that have stirred such an agonizing echo of past horrors. The television footage of houses reduced to rubble, the bombed-out churches and mosques, the lined-up bodies and mass graves -- they all evoke the flickering black-and-white newsreels of World War II. The words "genocide," "massacre," "holocaust," "civilian bombing" and "ethnic cleansing" haunt everyday speech and stir up guilt-ridden memories like smoke rising from a crematorium. 
 For European leaders and now, especially, the Clinton Administration, the ever-worsening events in what once was Yugoslavia throw up difficult questions: When does dithering negotiation turn into appeasement? Is it finally time for intervention?
Last week the questions were thrown into the sharpest relief by a letter from 12 State Department officials to Secretary of State Warren Christopher, telling him that the course of diplomacy followed so far had failed and urging him to advocate the use of military force to save the Muslims of eastern Bosnia. The stakes were larger than Bosnia alone, the letter said, because failure to take military action there, it said, "would teach would-be conquerors and ethnic bigots throughout the world that their crimes will go unpunished."
Throughout the conflict, the most compelling argument for not getting involved in the defense of Bosnia against Serbian nationalists has been that outside meddling might only raise the general level of suffering and death. But just in the last two weeks, Western suffrance for the Serbian nationalists has been strained more than ever as they relentlessly hammered Srebrenica to the point of submission. And there now seems less reason than ever to hope that the way to contain the evil let loose in the Balkans is to let the conflict just play itself out. Last week, even as Serbian ethnic cleansing went unpunished in the east, Croats and Muslims who had been nominal allies fell upon each other in spasms of their own ethnic cleansing, rending villages where Croats and Muslims had long lived side by side.
By coincidence last week, Poland commemorated the 50th anniversary of the Warsaw ghetto uprising -- the insurrection against the Nazis by several hundred Jewish fighters that is the 20th century's most powerful example of heroic resistance against insurmountable odds. But it also carries a message of universal reproach, for during the uprising, which led to the razing of the ghetto and was a critical chapter in the extermination of Poland's Jews, the world stood by and did nothing. A parallel to ships filled with Jewish refugees searching for a harbor can be found today, when refugees from the fighting in Bosnia and Croatia are kept out of most European countries and form huge crowds outside embassies in Belgrade in hopeless quests for visas.
The point was made Thursday at the opening of the Holocaust Memorial Museum in Washington, when Elie Wiesel, the Nobel Prize-winning author and survivor of the Holocaust, stopped talking about events of 50 years ago during his speech and said to President Clinton: "And Mr. President, I cannot not tell you something. I have been in the former Yugoslavia last fall. I cannot sleep since what I have seen. As a Jew I am saying that. We must do something to stop the bloodshed in that country." An ironic footnote to the opening of the museum came when Mr. Wiesel and Simon Wiesenthal, the Nazi hunter, objected to an invitation to Franjo Tudjman, Croatia's President, pointing out that a 1988 book he wrote claimed that only 900,000 Jews, not six million, died in the Holocaust.
 
Grand Disillusionment
 Behind the guilt lies grand disillusionment, for the generations that grew up in the shadow of the Second World War came to terms with the concentration camps through an unspoken assumption that never again would evil of that magnitude be tolerated. Not war itself, which was perhaps unavoidable, but war waged ruthlessly against everyday civilians who are selected for slaughter solely on the basis of ethnicity or religion -- that would be ruled out of bounds for all time.
With the collapse of Communism, one hope was that the demise of superpower rivalry might allow foreign affairs to be conducted around a fulcrum of morality, with more focus on economic development, the conservation of resources and the discouragement of anti-democratic petty tyrants.
It has not worked out quite that way. In the matter of long-suppressed ethnic identities, it appears in retrospect, Communism acted as something of a hermetic seal. Once the seal was broken, acts of hatred and ethnic crimes from 40 years ago, when exploited by unscrupulous leaders, lose the distance of history and are experienced as if they happened yesterday.
Under Marshal Tito, the expression of ethnic sentiment in Yugoslavia was a crime. Memories of the ugly deeds of the Nazi state of Croatia, where thousands and thousands of Serbs perished in concentration camps, were suppressed. Mass graves were covered over by concrete. The recent opening of those graves by Serbs who carefully reburied the heaps of bone was not only an act of reverence for the dead. It also was a fanning of the flames of insecurity for Serbs who lived outside Serbia, in the Krajina area of Croatia.
Western diplomats based here agree that Serbs have every reason to recall their barbarous treatment at the hands of the Croatian Ustashe. They note that in the current conflict there is an ample record of atrocities on all sides -- Serbian, Muslim and Croatian. But they will also acknowledge that the prime mover of Yugoslavia's descent into chaos has been the engine of Serbian nationalism as driven by President Slobodan Milosevic. Its mission is to draw together the Serbs in other former republics of the now-defunct federation -- the "precani," meaning literally "the ones across the river."
 
Warnings
 The first alarm bells should have gone off six years ago when Mr. Milosevic took his now famous trip to Kosovo, the southern region that nurtured Serbian nationalism but where Albanians now constitute 90 percent of the population. Appearing before a crowd of thousands of Serbs, who were pushed back by police truncheons, he declared, "No one has the right to beat you!" The frenzied response taught him the power of the force at his disposal.
Several former ambassadors from European countries privately expressed frustration to Western journalists during the ensuing years. They said their cables to their home offices warning about the genie that Mr. Milosevic had freed from the bottle were being ignored. In 1991, the secession of Croatia and Slovenia precipitated the Serbian-Croatian war that turned, a year ago, into civil war in Bosnia. The Bosnian Serbs, supported by Serbia, now control about 70 percent of the territory.
The time for effective intervention, many people now argue, was in May or June of last year, when the Serbian siege of mostly Muslim Sarajevo was getting under way. It might have given pause to the Serbs before they felt the power of their own dominant position, before ethnic cleansing had advanced so drastically and while there still was a semblance of civil society in Sarajevo and cities like Mostar. Now, Mr. Milosevic is at the peak of his strength despite a trade embargo against Serbia that is almost a year old, a year of war in Bosnia and an on-again, off-again war with Croatia.
These days, with reports of atrocities continuing and nightly footage on international television of wounded and orphaned children, the pressure for some form of action to stop the slaughter is building. Once again, diplomats are contemplating the lesson of Chamberlain's umbrella: Move in quickly and stamp out the infection, because otherwise the pathology will spread exponentially.
 
Two Faces of the Facts of War
 FOR weeks now, the fate of Bosnia has seemed intertwined with the fate of one eastern town, Srebrenica. Perhaps 50,000 Muslims, including refugees and defenders, remain surrounded there by Serbs who had besieged and all but captured the town before a cease-fire was worked out by the United Nations. The truce put the town under U.N. protection to allow the disarming of the Muslims and some evacuations. At the climactic moment last weekend, when Srebrenica appeared on the brink of surrender following ferocious Serbian shelling, the newspaper readers of Sarajevo, the Bosnian capital, and Belgrade, Serbia's capital, were offered radically different versions of the events. In these excerpts, Tanjug refers to the Yugoslav news agency; Republika Srpska is the name Serb nationalists give to their self-proclaimed government in Bosnia; Karadzic is Radovan Karadzic, leader of the Bosnian Serbs; Milosevic is President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia, and Mladic is Gen. Ratko Mladic, commander of the Bosnian Serb forces, sometimes called Chetniks.
 
In Sarajevo
Tomorrow, a Canadian battalion serving with the United Nations Protection Force should enter Srebrenica as a result of negotiations between Lieut. Gen. Lars-Eric Wahlgren, commander of the U.N. force, and the war criminal Karadzic. A Golgotha continues for the citizens of Srebrenica . . . Zlatko Lagumdzija, the Deputy Prime Minister of Bosnia and Herzegovina, has told the world that Mladic's army, that is Milosevic's army, has to be stopped, that the only thing that the aggressor army understands is force, and that the only way it can be stopped is by confronting it with a greater force. . . . The aggressor forces continued their offensive at Srebrenica throughout the day yesterday with undiminished intensity, and the people of the town continued to give a heroic account of themselves in resisting the attempt by the more numerous and better-armed attackers to penetrate the town's outskirts. Besides their push across the front lines, the Chetniks continued to use their heavy artillery to shell the center of Srebrenica, massacring civilians. During the morning hours alone, the Chetnik artillery killed six people and injured 15, including several children. In Tuzla . . . local and foreign reporters were presented with a transcript of an intercepted radio-telephone conversation between war criminal Mladic and the Chetnik commanders in the area . . . in which he ordered them to press their attacks so as to enter Srebrenica before he began his negotiations on a cease-fire.
Oslobodjenje
PUB-DATE: April 17, 1993
 
In Belgrade
 In spite of the fact that the Muslim armed forces are facing a total military defeat, they again launched attacks this morning from various directions from the territory of Srebrenica. According to Tanjug reporting from this region, the Muslim units are using all their artillery and firing equipment. The Serbian sources say that Serbian defenders had tens of dead and wounded following attacks by Muslim forces which lasted for days. The army of the Republika Srpska was forced to respond strongly in a counterattack and it has reached strategically important peaks around Srebrenica. The Serbian lines are only about one kilometer by air from Srebrenica. Using the fact that the Serbian side is not undertaking any action against Srebrenica itself, the Muslim extremists continued to attack. During the morning the most severe attacks of the Muslims were launched on Ratkovic, Zeleni Jadar, Podravanje and Milici. According to Tanjug, the Serbian sources are reporting that Muslim soldiers have started surrendering arms yesterday. There were such individual cases in the region of Skelani, Bratunac, Derventa and Podravanje. The Muslim extremists are in a hopeless situation from the military point of view. They are still reluctant to surrender because they were the ones to destroy 56 Serbian villages near Srebrenica, Bratunac and Skelani and on several occasions have killed in a most brutal way more than 1,300 Serbs, mostly women, children and aged people.

LENGTH: 1089 words

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
The G.O.P. Can Win, But It Can't Gloat

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THERE is something President Clinton and Senate Republicans seem to agree on. Both say it's not all that important that the Republicans killed his economic stimulus bill last week.
From the President, it was normal enough to say, as he did Friday, that "Everything has been passed except the stimulus program, so I think we're doing fine." Anybody who loses likes to think it didn't matter all that much. 
 But the motivations were a little more complicated when Senator Alan Simpson of Wyoming, the deputy Republican leader, kissed off the event, saying that this defeat, "in the course of human events, is not but a flutter of a hummingbird wing near a honeysuckle."
Modesty was not his prime motive. Political tactics and realities mattered more. There were tactical reasons for him and other Republicans like the less poetic Bob Dole ("just a bump in the road for President Clinton") to play down their success.
First, they are dealing with a newly elected President whom the public wants to see succeed. They don't want to be seen as obstructing for the sake of obstruction. They went to great lengths to invent new definitions of "gridlock" and "filibuster" to avoid the public impression, as Thomas Mann of the Brookings Institution put it, that they were "politicians getting their kicks by denying Clinton a vote on his package."
Second, they didn't need to brag. Newspapers and television stations had already made a major event of their blocking action on the President's $19.5 billion proposal.
Finally, despite the difficulties Mr. Clinton faces on issues from homosexuals in the armed forces to tax credits for investments and a new energy tax, the Republicans don't expect to beat him often.
They won't always want to beat him, either. Mr. Dole and Mr. Simpson are eager to help pass aid to Russia, for example. And even when they want to fight, the Democrats will sometimes pick off a few Republicans and get the 60 votes it takes to end debate. So Republican leaders have little interest in dressing themselves up as suddenly invincible, and thereby making the defeats they foresee seem startling.
The unity they achieved not only stunned the White House, which had not expected an all-out assault this early. It also surprised the Senate Republicans, especially since some of the most vociferous opponents of compromise included moderates who sometimes vote with the Democrats, senators like John Chafee of Rhode Island and John C. Danforth of Missouri.
 
Distracted by the House
 The Administration had been worrying more about the House, a simpler body with real rules, but one that needs attention anyhow. The Administration never got around to cultivating malleable Republicans beforehand, and it let G.O.P. resentments build up over everything from consultation on health care to Senator Robert C. Byrd's parliamentary tactics on the floor.
Mr. Dole skillfully molded those irritations into unity. Republicans reassured one another that if there is one thing they all agree on, it is opposition to increasing the deficit. That opposition seems considerably stronger now that a Democrat is in the White House.
The Clinton Administration was "schizophrenic," as one highly placed Administration aide put it, in trying to pry Republicans away. It alternated between quiet, serious approaches and lumbering denunciations, apparently unaware that nothing makes a senator seem more important and independent than being attacked by a President.
But the slickest Congressional liaison effort imaginable might not have been enough to break up that Republican coalition once it was formed against the $19.5 billion package. Mr. Clinton's offer to drop it to $15.4 billion found no Republican takers.
Then Senator Mark O. Hatfield of Oregon, the senior Republican on the Appropriations Committee, could not get his colleagues to go along with an $8.7 billion proposal. They had more or less offered it when they left for spring break April 5, but when they returned after cheers from their constituents, they offered only a $6 billion plan, knowing the Democrats would not take it seriously.
In the end, only $4 billion, for extended unemployment benefits, survived.
Where can the Republicans take their opposition, and what can the Democrats do about it?
At one end of the spectrum there is the charge from House Democrats like Representative David Obey of Wisconsin that Republicans are trying "to keep as many dollars out of the economy as possible" and to "knock the sheen off Clinton" in order to see that the economy weakens by next year's elections.
And at the other end is the hope among some moderate Republican senators that after a month or so to cool off, a handful of Republicans can break ranks and let through a package of about $5 billion more for various obvious job-producing projects.
They may insist on its being "paid for," with compensating cuts in other programs. Even though such cuts weaken the stimulative effects of the spending, the Administration was willing to go along with some offsets last week and may accept more of them to get increased spending for summer youth jobs and accelerated highway spending.
Mr. Dole is likely to continue delaying most domestic measures on the floor for at least a day or two. He has done that for a couple of years, probing to see where Republicans seem ready for tough fights and where to back off. At the very least, delay diminishes the number of Democratic bills the Senate can consider.
But the spring legislative agenda is likely to offer fewer chances for all-out Republican filibusters. "We don't anticipate that our program is going to invite that kind of problem all the time," said Howard Paster, the chief White House lobbyist on Capitol Hill.
Legislation dealing with issues like education, apprenticeship and national service tends to attract some of the moderates who stood firm against the jobs bill. The Democratic senators who handle such measures, like Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, are accustomed to enlisting Republican allies before they take bills to the floor.
Moreover, Administration officials maintain that they are indeed alert to the need to seek out Republican help. If they weren't last month, they certainly have seen its importance demonstrated. Republicans sound hopeful. "He's going to need us and we're going to be there on things like Nafta and health care," said Mr. Chafee, referring to the North American Free Trade Agreement. "They haven't sought us out, but they will."
