SECTION: Section 4; Page 4; Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1248 words

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
The Nation's Capital Eagerly Awaits Urban Remedies

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE week before his inauguration, then President-elect Bill Clinton took a walk up Georgia Avenue, a stroll many saw as a symbolic outreach to the city of Washington and to its black population in particular.
The symbols have continued. Last week Janet Reno, the new head of the Justice Department, comforted students in a school in a Northwest Washington neighborhood plagued by a drive-by gunman. And Mr. Clinton named a native Washingtonian, Loretta Avent, as liaison to the local regional government council. 
 Mr. Clinton's attention to his urban neighorbhood bodes well for the District of Columbia, two-thirds of whose residents are black, and sends a signal that cities and urban affairs, largely neglected for the last 12 years, are once more a White House priority, if not yet the focus of fully defined policies.
The attention comes none too soon, in the view of many who have watched the urban agenda slip off the national scope during previous administrations. To them, the tensions in Los Angeles over the beating of Rodney G. King underscore the neglect that has turned American cities into powder kegs. Though tensions have been defused after the conviction last weekend of two of four Los Angeles police officers accused in the beating, they haven't been dispelled: a long list of pressing urban problems awaits Mr. Clinton.
Just how challenging getting to that agenda will be was illustrated last week when Senate Republicans killed Mr. Clinton's economic-stimulus package. The package contained a considerable amount of aid that would have benefited cities, including public works funds and money for summer jobs, and its defeat suggests how much more difficult it would be to get an urban legislative package through Congress even though a host of urban problems defines the wards abutting the seat of national power.
Prominent among the problems is crime, vividly illustrated most recently by the series of nighttime, drive-by shootings that left two people dead and terrorized Columbia Heights and surrounding neighborhoods before the arrest of a suspect last week. The shootings were another setback for a city struggling to rebuild an image damaged in recent years not only by social ills but by controversial administration under former Mayor Marion Barry (elected as a City Councilman last year in a political comeback following his 1990 drug conviction).
Yet its image notwithstanding, Washington is not particularly troubled in comparison with many cities. It is because the district offers examples of the problems plaguing many others -- but in relatively mild form, among a relatively small population of 700,000 people -- that it could make an ideal, easily observable testing ground for the Clinton urban policy makers who work and in many cases live there.
"The police department is per capita the largest in the nation," said Peter Reuter, an economist with the Rand Corporation who did a study on street drug dealers several years ago. "The criminal justice system by most standards operates relatively effectively. It's a fairly wealthy city. What is peculiar about it is the extraordinary homicide rate. It was moving along at about 200 a year and then suddenly, in the mid-80's it skyrocketed to around 450, and it hasn't gone down. And no one knows the reason."
 
An Urban Laboratory
 Even public schools in the District of Columbia, though not without problems, are not as severely troubled as perceptions suggest. Although President Clinton chose to send his daughter, Chelsea, to private school, city school students by many yardsticks match or exceed the national average in academic performance. And violence in schools is significantly lower than in most urban systems.
Washington nevertheless suffers from homelessness, crime, infant mortality, a declining middle class, a shrinking tax base, concentrations of low-income people, pollution, boarded-up public housing, a struggling public school system, job displacement and other ills. Washington is more than ever a city in which blacks and whites function after working hours in separate worlds, a pattern underscored by its housing, which shows it to be one of the 10 most residentially segregated cities in the nation. (The city's substantial numbers of affluent and middle-class blacks demonstrate, however, that this segregation does not always mean poverty.)
Even the longtime assumption that Washington was recession-proof in terms of jobs is proving erroneous. Despite the presence of the Federal government as a major employer, there is a growing disparity among its workers.
"It has all the problems of the new service economy and the split between highly paid people and poorly paid people," said Margaret M. Weir, an urban scholar with the Brookings Institution.
The fate of the District of Columbia has always seemed especially intertwined with national urban policy because it has long come under direct Federal oversight and responsibility.
The city, now governed by Mayor Sharon Pratt Kelly and a 13-member City Council, has the right to raise taxes, but still labors under restraints. Congress must approve its budget and can override any of the city's legislation. The city is often called "the last colony" because it is not independent and there has been a push for at least a decade for home rule.
 
Seeking Independence
 Many, including Eleanor Holmes Norton, the non-voting Representative for the District of Columbia, think this is the best time to pressure Congress for statehood and are heartened by Mr. Clinton's apparent interest.
"I am so encouraged by the extent to which the President appears to identify with the district that I've written asking him to make the district a city in which he tries out his considerable ideas and models for restoring the urban agenda," she said.
For now, urban policy in the Clinton Administration has taken a back seat to its focus on the economy as a whole. Mr. Clinton has no urban legislative package yet, nor has Henry Cisneros, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, unveiled his plans for enterprise zones to develop inner city businesses. The Administration has already, however, proposed making permanent a tax credit for private developers of low-income housing, a step long advocated by housing advocates. The law, introduced as a temporary measure in 1986, was used in overhauling Washington's Whitelaw Hotel into a home for 35 low-income families.
And within Mr. Clinton's five-year budget blueprint unveiled this month are the broad outlines of how the President intends to remedy urban woes: tax incentives for small and inner-city businesses and higher outlays for job training and employment programs, housing assistance, food stamps, nutrition programs, early education for poor children, childhood immunizations and the like.
Still, budgetary and other constraints are already apparent, for example at HUD, which has sought billions of dollars in new spending just to continue housing the families it is now assisting, not to mention the growing numbers of needy renters.
Nonetheless, many see Mr. Clinton's gestures toward Washington as a harbinger of good for all the nation's cities.
"Even in the most symbolic way, his interest shows that he has a concern for cities all over the country," said Ms. Weir of Brookings. "It's important to change the symbols and the rhetoric because the predominant images of cities in the last decade have been so negative."

HEADLINE: China's Crackdown on Births: A Stunning, and Harsh, Success

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, April 24

 BODY:
She should be taking her 2-month-old baby out around the village now, proudly nursing him and teaching him about life. Instead, her baby is buried under a mound of dirt, and Li Qiuliang spends her time lying in bed, emotionally crushed and physically crippled.
The baby died because under China's complex quota system for births, local family planning officials wanted Ms. Li to give birth in 1992 rather than 1993. So on Dec. 30, when she was seven months pregnant, they took her to an unsanitary first-aid station and ordered the doctor to induce early labor. 
 Ms. Li's family pleaded. The doctor protested. But the family planning workers insisted. The result: The baby died after nine hours, and 23-year-old Ms. Li is incapacitated.
 
Lowest Fertility Ever
 That episode in Hunan Province, described in a classified Government report and confirmed by the local authorities, is one outgrowth of a major nationwide crackdown by the Chinese family planning authorities. While the crackdown has been under way for two years, information about it is only now emerging as the authorities release population statistics showing a stunning decline in the birth rate.
The latest data suggest that through compulsory sterilization and other measures, China has lowered fertility to by far its lowest level ever here. The statistics for 1992 -- showing many fewer babies even than during the harsh crackdowns of the early 1980's -- amazed population experts, for the family planners achieved targets that they had not expected to reach until the year 2010.
 
Problem for Clinton
 Ms. Li's persecutors had a reason for going to such extremes to enforce population quotas: they were protecting themselves under a new "responsibility system" that the Government has introduced as the mechanism for the crackdown. Under this system, central leaders hold local officials personally responsible for reducing births in their jurisdictions, and punish them for failing to do so.
The evidence of a far-reaching crackdown presents a direct challenge to the Clinton Administration. President Reagan had cut off United States financing of the United Nations Population Fund because of concerns that its work was intertwined with a coercive family planning program in China, but President Clinton announced last month that he would end the boycott.
Now the new evidence of a crackdown is likely to embarrass Mr. Clinton as he tries to restore funds to the United Nations program. Moreover, criticisms in the United States about forced sterilization in China are likely in turn to inflame Chinese sensitivities and could create new tensions in Chinese-American relations.
To be sure, some Chinese -- particularly city-dwellers -- support a tough family planning policy. They say the drop in fertility is helping to produce a historic economic boom and a rise in the nation's education and health standards.
By restricting couples to one or two children each, they say, the Government is helping to lead China out of poverty and into a modern, industrialized future. They note that one reason why China's long-term development prospects may be better than Bangladesh's or Kenya's is that Beijing appears to have defused its population bomb.
Peng Peiyun, the 64-year-old minister of the State Family Planning Commission, acknowledged in a rare news conference on Wednesday that it was mainly Government efforts that had brought down the birth rate.
"Why did fertility drop so drastically?" asked Ms. Peng, who two years ago persuaded the Politburo to order the crackdown. "Above all because party and Government officials at all levels paid greater attention to family planning and adopted more effective measures."
The indications of a drop in fertility come in a raft of statistics announced by Ms. Peng, printed in the official Population News or disclosed by Chinese officials. Among the figures are these:
*The birth rate dropped to 18.2 per 1,000 population in 1992, down from 21.1 in 1990 and 23.33 in 1987.
*Based on last year's birth data, each Chinese woman can expect to have an average of 1.8 or 1.9 children in her lifetime -- about the same as in the United States or Britain. China's total fertility rate, as this statistic is known, was 2.3 in 1990 and had never before dipped below 2. In contrast, the average Indian woman has 4 children.
*Only 9.6 percent of all births in 1992 were third, fourth or subsequent children. In 1988, the figure was 15.4 percent.
*The proportion of couples of child-bearing age who are sterilized or use contraception rose to 83.4 percent in 1992, up from 71.1 percent in 1988.
"It's what would be called saturation contraception in any other country," said Judith Banister, a specialist on China's population at the United States Bureau of the Census. "You can't get much higher than that."
China already has 1.17 billion inhabitants, 22 percent of the world's population on 7 percent of its arable land. Even at present fertility levels, the Chinese population will continue to soar because the age structure is very young and many Chinese have yet to enter their child-bearing years.
Some experts believe China's population will peak at almost 1.9 billion in the first half of the next century before stabilizing and then gradually declining again.
 
The Methods
Sterilization Made Efficient
 To Chinese peasants, who account for nearly one person in five on the planet, almost nothing is so important as bearing children, particularly sons. Many peasant couples feel that they have failed in life's mission, that they have dishonored their ancestors, if they do not extend the male line.
In the early 1980's, there was a storm of international protest when it became clear that the local authorities sometimes dragged women to abortion clinics if they did not have permission to become pregnant. Interviews in a dozen provinces in the last few years suggest that such use of physical force is now less common.
Instead, the focus of the crackdown has shifted to the more efficient method of compulsory, organized sterilization, so that women do not have the option of becoming pregnant again.
Typically, local cadres swoop down on each village once or twice a year, taking all the women who have already had children to a nearby clinic. There they are fitted with IUD's or else undergo sterilization.
Some women manage to get pregnant again before they are sterilized; others flee the village on the day they are supposed to go to the clinic. When the authorities discover an unauthorized pregnancy, they normally apply a daily dose of threats and brow-beating.
Some women buckle and accept an abortion, while many others simply flee to a relative's village, returning only after the child is born. In such cases, fines equivalent to hundreds or even thousands of dollars -- per capita income in the countryside last year was $135 -- are imposed. Peasants in many different provinces say homes are routinely knocked down if the fine is not paid.
 
Worst-Case Abuse
Local Officials Get Carried Away
 The report about Ms. Li, who is crippled after the induced labor, is an example of how local officials became carried away in the current crackdown. The three-page account, classified "secret," describes how Ningxiang County decreed in September that women should normally be allowed to give birth only after reaching the age of 24.
The problem for the local authorities was that they had already given some women "pregnancy permits" even though they were under 24. Some of these women were pregnant. Nine of them -- including Ms. Li -- would not give birth until 1993, the first full year in which the new age limit took effect.
"Some district and township officials feared that they would be fined for not meeting the family planning targets, or would not receive their bonuses," the report declares.
So at the end of December the family planning officials formed an "early birth shock brigade" to round up all nine women so labor could be induced. When the team showed up at Ms. Li's home, her mother-in-law pleaded with the officials.
"My daughter-in-law's health isn't good, and she may not be able to get pregnant again," the report quotes the woman as saying. "So let her have one baby, someone to look after her and my son when they grow old. It doesn't matter if it's a boy or a girl. After it's born, she'll go get sterilized."
The officials rejected the plea. And at the first-aid station, when the doctor said Ms. Li was too frail to undergo induced labor, they swept his protests aside and ordered him to proceed. She bled severely, fell unconscious and almost died along with the baby.
Her family took her to the township clinic, which saved her life. Now she has returned home, but the report says she is crippled, without specifying the nature of her injuries.
The report deplores the actions of the local officials and calls for Ms. Li to be compensated for her medical expenses. But a county officer, reached by telephone, said that so far nothing had been done, except that the officials responsible for the "early birth shock brigade" have been summoned to a meeting and told not to induce labor in the future.
 
The Motivations
Insistence On Meeting Targets
 In retrospect, it is now possible to piece together how the crackdown came about. Interviews with Chinese and foreign specialists, and examination of materials published in China, indicate that Ms. Peng and other senior officials became increasingly concerned in the late 1980's that enforcement was growing lax and that China would miss its targets.
In early 1991, Ms. Peng convinced Prime Minister Li Peng and the Communist Party General Secretary, Jiang Zemin, that the matter was urgent. The standing committee of the Politburo, the highest decision-making body, unanimously resolved to tighten family planning work.
Most important, the new "responsibility system" galvanized provincial leaders to pass warnings all the way down the chain of command: family planning targets had to be met! Otherwise, those in charge of the area would be fined or even dismissed.
A result was a 25 percent surge in the number of people sterilized in 1991, to 12.5 million. The number declined in 1992 to 6.5 million, apparently because most women of child-bearing age already had been sterilized by then.
The scope of the crackdown became visible only after the State Family Planning Commission released data from a sample survey conducted in October. The data for 1992 startled almost everyone.
"We were very surprised by these numbers," said Sterling D. Scruggs, the China director of the United Nations Population Fund. "We didn't expect statistics approaching these levels for several more years."
Western diplomats said they believed that a crackdown was the only plausible explanation for the new statistics. They said Ms. Peng herself seems willing to take credit for the drop in the birth rate.
 
The Missing Girls
Some Newborns Seem to Vanish
 One prime concern among demographers is that hundreds of thousands of newborn Chinese girls seem to vanish from the statistics each year. Biology dictates that for every hundred female births there should be about 105 or 106 male births. But in 1989 for every 100 reported girl births, there were 113.8 births of boys.
That ratio implies that about 8 percent of newborn girls appear to have vanished from the statistics. In China that amounts to 900,000 missing girls each year.
Ms. Peng refused to release the sex ratio in 1992. An aide in charge of statistics, Zhang Erli, said the 1992 survey did not collect such information.
In fact, experts say the survey did gather the data and found a sex ratio of 118.5. But the sample size was small and the margin of error very high, so it is not clear how meaningful the difference is.
Zeng Yi, a leading Chinese demographer, said that the problem of the missing girls is very serious but that most of them are probably alive and never reported to the authorities. Parents who are allowed only one or two children may not want to use up their limited ration on a girl; instead they do not report the birth and try again.
A second factor, according to Mr. Zeng and many other experts, is the growing use of ultrasound equipment in Chinese hospitals. Peasants find out from the doctor -- usually with a small bribe -- whether a fetus is male or female. If it is female, they get an abortion and start all over.
A final factor, which Mr. Zeng argues is much rarer, is simply infanticide: on instructions from the parents, the midwife keeps a bucket of water beside her, and if a girl emerges, she drowns the baby immediately. It is reported as a stillbirth.
Mr. Zeng and other Chinese experts deplore all such practices. But ultrasound equipment is spreading rapidly, and so many specialists fear that the sex ratio is likely to become increasingly skewed.
Mr. Zeng cautioned that part of the apparent decline in fertility may simply be the result of under-reporting, particularly of girls. The figures were already adjusted upward by 7 percent to compensate for under-reporting, but Mr. Zeng believes that may not have been enough.
To some diplomats, what the new statistics underscore above all else is how little is known of what happens the Chinese countryside.
"We had almost no idea that this was going on," a Western diplomat said, shaking his head in perplexity. "Even those who follow these things just had no clue."

HEADLINE: Bagels Are Now Fast Food, And Purists Do a Slow Boil

BYLINE: By MOLLY O'NEILL

 BODY:
The bagel, that chubby, chewy staple of New York life, has rolled across the country. First, it took over the frozen-food counters of supermarkets, then made its way onto menus at McDonald's and Burger King. Now, it has started pushing aside muffin and croissant stores in malls everywhere.
"The fast-food industry is always looking for the next hamburger, and right now the smart money is riding on bagels," said Steven Finn, the president of Bruegger's Bagels, a chain of 65 bagel stores whose headquarters are in Burlington, Vt. 
 This proliferation should be good news to bagel junkies, who have bemoaned the scarcity of the chewy rolls west of the Hudson. Instead, they are incensed. In their eyes, the integrity of the bagel has been undermined.
 
'No Character'
 "Increasing numbers of bagels resemble dinner rolls," said Nach Waxman, owner of Kitchen Arts and Letters, a cookbook store in Manhattan. "It's an outrage. No crust, no character, no nothing."
Buoyed by its healthful, low-fat, high-carbohydrate nature, as well as its accessibility and relatively low cost, the bagel is poised for its own Horatio Alger story. While precise sales figures are difficult to calculate, Ron Wirtz, a researcher for the American Institute of Baking in Manhattan, Kan., estimates that Americans consumed fewer than a half-million bagels in 1962 but more than five million last year.
"The bagelry is your new pizzeria," said John DePalo, manager of Bagel Oasis, an old-fashioned bagel bakery in Queens. "We used to be one of the only games in town. Now there's a bagel shop in every neighborhood."
Some aficionados have come to accept the industrialization of the bagel, which was previously shaped by hand and boiled in a kettle before baking. "The reformulating that mass-marketing requires does toy with perfection," said Marilyn Bagel, author of "The Bagel Bible" (Globe Pequot, 1992), which she wrote with her husband, Tom Bagel. (Bagel is their real name.) But she added that the softer texture and diminished crust that is characteristic of mass-produced bagels must be weighed against the increasing accessibility of her favored bread.
Still, the sociological and economic factors that inspired the soaring popularity of bagels make her fear the future. Bagels, she whispered, could become a new Wonder bread.
George Rosenbaum, who analyzes food trends for the Leo J. Shapiro Company in Chicago, said her concern was well grounded. "A bagel is a doughnut with the sin removed," he said. "If you can become a doughnut, or a doughnut proxy in the fast-food market, you are no longer an ethnic food. You are as American as pizza."
Bagelites perish the thought. The object of their desire has long been called "a cement doughnut," and purists relish the characteristics that make this a well-earned title.
 
A Royal Thank-You
 It's believed that bagels were invented by a Jewish baker in Vienna in 1683. To thank King John III Sobieski of Poland for saving the city from Turkish invaders, the anonymous baker crafted a hard roll in the shape of a riding stirrup, in honor of the king's favorite hobby. The bread's original name was "bugel," from the German for stirrup.
After the bread spread to Jewish communities throughout Eastern Europe, its name evolved, but its formulation -- a thrifty and unembellished blend of yeast, malt syrup and flour -- remained unchanged for three centuries. After being brought to America by Jewish immigrants in the early 20th century, the recipe was fiercely safeguarded by Bagel Bakers Local 338, a union of 300 workers based in New York City. By limiting admission to sons of members, the union insured perpetuation of the time-honored technique -- and a perpetual shortage of the bread.
"My father ran a bakery in Brooklyn, but he never made a bagel because he couldn't get into the union, and they would have broken his legs if he made bagels without being in the union," said Michael Yoss, who owns Royal Bagel in Atlanta. Bagel Bakers Local 338, Mr. Yoss said, was to the floury, steamy world of bagels what Jimmy Hoffa's teamsters were to the road.
 
The Machine Age Dawns
 The closed shop, with its closely held bagel secrets, wasn't broken until the early 1960's, when Dan Thompson, the Canadian scion of a European bagel baker, introduced the Thompson Bagel Machine, which rolls and shapes bagels. This innovation reduced the dependence on union bagel makers -- the union is no longer active -- and paved the way for mass production.
"The machine rolls 200 to 400 dozen bagels an hour," Mr. Thompson said from the Los Angeles headquarters of the Thompson Bagel Machine Manufacturing Corporation. "You used to have two guys hand-shaping and boiling and baking who could turn out maybe 120 bagels an hour. With the machine and now the new ovens, I have one baker putting out 400 bagels an hour."
Officials in the industry agree that Lender's Bagels, a bakery opened in 1927 by a Polish immigrant, Harry Lender, in New Haven, turned "bagel" into a household word. In 1962, he began using the Thompson machine and getting his packaged, frozen rolls into grocery stores nationwide. The proliferation of the machine paralleled the slow spread of bagel savvy.
 
How Much Is That . . . ?
 In fact, as late as 1974, when Mr. Yoss first put a sign in his Atlanta window advertising bagels, "people would come by to talk about dogs," he said, because "They thought we were opening a beagle kennel."
Mr. Thompson estimates that there are 200,000 of his machines in operation. Other companies have introduced ovens that steam and bake the bagels, eliminating, in many bakeries, the traditional boiling kettle. Although the steam ovens are more efficient, they are the nadir of Old Bagledom.
"Steam! Industrial Steam!" Mr. Waxman, the New York bookstore owner, said. "That's what's making all these soft bagels. Mushy! No crust! Nothing more than dinner rolls!"
But others say industrial innovations have improved bagels. "The cement doughnut was extremely chewy and dense," said Mr. Wirtz of the baking institute. "But it was limited. All you could do was eat it.
"The softer bagels are more versatile. You can make sandwiches out of them, little pizzas, even slice them and bake them to eat like taco chips."
In the trade, he said, the softer, steamed bagel is called a California-style or sandwich bagel -- and it is a runaway success.
But no American success story would be complete without pathos and nostalgia. Like the affluent parent recounting his childhood trek through snow to school, the typical Old Bagelite recalls the halcyon era of cement blocks, embellished with nothing more than a "shmeer" of cream cheese.
 
Symbolic of Society
 To these traditionalists, the softness of modern bagels is a metaphor for modern society. California bagels, they say, are not merely emblematic of fading connoisseurship, but also represent a significant and worrisome shift in political and economic life that should be redressed legally.
The demise of the traditional-bagel way of life has been furthered by additional ingredients that make the counters of slick, new bagel shops resemble those of Ben & Jerry's. Spot Bagel in Seattle offers blueberry swirls. The Bagel and Bagel shops in the Kansas City area cannot bake enough whole-wheat honey bagels. Raisin and cinnamon bagels, egg bagels. Even cheddar cheese bagels are becoming common.
But Mr. Waxman said innocent citizens should be protected. "This kind of perversity," he proclaimed, "should be prohibited by law."

HEADLINE: White House Memo;
Amid Setbacks, Clinton Team Seeks to Shake Off the Blues

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN with MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 24

 BODY:
At the White House meeting on Tuesday, the chief of staff tried to cheer up the Clinton team. Sure, President Clinton was having some problems, Thomas F. (Mack) McLarty 3d told the group, but Ronald Reagan's poll ratings also dropped after his first few months in office and it was only when he got shot that his popularity soared.
"Ah, Mack, what are you suggesting here?" deadpanned Rahm Emanuel, the political director, as the room broke up in laughter. "Things aren't that bad." 
 Black humor and a hint of paranoia were the fashion at the White House this week, as the President and his staff tried to pull themselves out of their first big slump. Seared by criticism about his judgment and political savvy in dealing with his economic stimulus package, Congress, Bosnia, the Branch Davidians and the gay march in Washington this weekend, the President summoned his top staff members for a "jam session" on Friday to evaluate where the Administration is headed, and he held a news conference in which he acknowledged he had "misgauged" some things.
"I hope that I can learn something," Mr. Clinton added. "I've just been here 90 days."
 
Low Approval Ratings
 Indeed, the young, energetic team that so relentlessly controlled the agenda during the Presidential campaign has lost focus on its central economic message. The laser is looking more like a strobe light, and youthful idealism is looking more like inexperience.
His job approval ratings, just under 50 percent in several national polls, are worse than any other modern President's at this point in a Presidency.
By the end of the week, George Stephanopoulos, the White House communications director, had a battered look about him and a bristling tone.
Asked why the Administration seemed a little wobbly lately, he replied: "On the campaign trail, you can just change the subject. But you can't just change the subject as President. You can't wish Bosnia away. You can't wish Boris Yeltsin's troubles away. You can't wish David Koresh away. You can't just ignore them and change the subject."
Others in the West Wing were taking more of a this-too-will-pass attitude. Mark D. Gearan, the deputy chief of staff, said with a smile that he knew that the White House had done a poor sales job on the stimulus package when a sympathetic Congressman began talking to him about "the stimulation package."
But while the Washington chatterers are chattering about how the Clinton team has lost its focus, in a way, the President himself -- with his master strokes and miscalculations, his good days and bad -- may actually be coming into focus.
 
Comparison With Bush
 Unlike Mr. Bush, who began his Presidency with the politics of minimalism and few stated goals, Mr. Clinton is trying to lasso the moon. And unlike George Bush, whose personality was more straightforward and transparent, Bill Clinton offers a complicated, contradictory portrait, vexing at times to allies and foes alike.
Although the Clinton team came into office saying it intended to emulate the concentrated, hard sell that Ronald Reagan used on his economic plan, some top officials now privately admit they are falling into the Jimmy Carter syndrome of a laundry-list Presidency.
"We're trying to do too much at once," worried one of the President's closest friends in the Government. "We've laid the intellectual framework for all sorts of major initiatives -- national service, welfare reform, campaign finance, the budget, health care -- but we don't quite have the political strategy to implement them. When you have so much out there, it makes it easy for the Republicans to define it as just more Democratic spend-spend-spend."
Edward J. Rollins, who worked on selling President Reagan's tax cut, agreed: "Clinton is a good communicator but he's all over the map."
 
Undisciplined Style
 While Mr. Clinton intellectually understands the virtue of a clear, simple agenda, he cannot contain himself, aides say. He has an undisciplined personal style, a desire to please all sides, a mind stuffed with 30 years of policy ideas he wants to try, and a party full of clamoring interest groups who think that this is their moment.
"I think there is a tension in Clinton between the student of Presidential power and the student of policy," said Michael J. Sandel, a Harvard University political theorist. "As a student of the Presidency, he knows he should keep it simple, but as a student of policy he can't. The risk is that he knows too much. Reagan did not have that problem. For Reagan, a thematic Presidency was easy because he did not know very much. All he had were broad themes on three-by-five cards. Clinton has a CD-ROM in his head."
There is still a sense that the American people really want Mr. Clinton to succeed and support his basic direction on the economy and health care, although the polls also reflect a slight erosion of trust.
"The guy in the street is hearing about an energy tax, a regressive tax, a value added tax, some taxes they've never even heard of before and don't understand," said Senator Alan K. Simpson, Republican of Wyoming.
 
'Blips' and 'Bumps'
 Although White House officials did their best to diminish recent miscalculations, referring to the defeat of the stimulus package by rejuvenated Republicans and the disaster with the Branch Davidians as "blips" and "bumps," these events have offered a glimpse into the President's contradictory impulses and operating style.
For instance, Mr. Clinton has managed to get his biggest domestic and foreign policy initiatives through Congress in record time: a $1.5 trillion budget outline with unprecedented deficit cuts and unprecedented new aid for Russia. But at the same time he bungled his $15 billion jobs bill and has been casting about elsewhere for a single success in foreign policy.
His aides present him as a master of detail and student of history. Yet, in the Branch Davidian affair, he ignored the first lesson learned by his idol, John F. Kennedy, who felt he had made a mistake in leaving the Bay of Pigs attack on Cuba in 1961 to the experts. Mr. Clinton devoted only 15 minutes on the phone to Attorney General Janet Reno's suggestion that they use tear gas to force the Branch Davidians out of their compound near Waco, Tex. He never explored the details of the plan or other options, entrusting the decision to an Attorney General in office only six weeks and an Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigations whom many believe he would like to force out.
While Mr. Clinton has shown boldness in tackling budget deficits and health care, issues sidestepped by a succession of Presidents, he has also shown flashes of his campaign problem of ducking responsibility for his words and actions.
 
Decision to Break Silence
 Mr. Clinton was silent for almost a day as Ms. Reno was left to answer to the public, uttering the phrase made famous by a Democratic President: "The buck stops here." Only after an internal debate did the President come out and take responsibility.
Even now, though, White House officials insist that Mr. Clinton made no mistake, that polls show the American people supported his decision and that it is simply a problem of perception by opinion elites.
"Fundamentally, we are not as cynical as you think," Mr. Stephanopoulos said. "The President was not ducking anything. He was letting Janet Reno do her job."
In reality, though, while the White House painted anyone who questioned the President's handling of the Branch Davidians as cynical, it was pure political calculus that motivated aides to advise Mr. Clinton not to go on camera for 24 hours.
Whatever their wider resonance, such incidents nevertheless have the potential to reinforce certain character doubts about the President with key constituencies. Like President Bush, Mr. Clinton came into office with question marks about his ability to be tough in a crisis. Mr. Bush dispelled such doubts with his showdown with Saddam Hussein. But Mr. Clinton has yet to erase them, particularly with his own Pentagon.
 
Military Emotions
 Last Tuesday, there was a goodbye party at the Pentagon for Lieut. Gen. Martin L. Brandtner, the popular director of operations for the Joint Chiefs of Staff. All the Pentagon's top brass turned out, as well as former Defense Secretary Dick Cheney.
After introducing everyone on the dais, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Lieut. Gen. Colin L. Powell, turned to Mr. Cheney, who was sitting in the front row, and said with a twinkle in his eye, "Welcome back, boss."
With that, the audience of military officers and Pentagon employees erupted with applause that went on and on. As one Pentagon official recalled, the reception for Mr. Cheney was both "touching and telling, like striking a match to dry tinder."
In some ways Mr. Clinton is a victim of his own political skills. His ability to charm and connect with people is so potent that they come away feeling that he sees the world just as they do. But, as one aide put it, "they don't always hear the fine print" (which is sometimes hard to find). Then when Mr. Clinton strikes the inevitable political bargain, people feel betrayed.
 
What's in the Fine Print
 It was striking that after Mr. Clinton met with leaders of gay and lesbian organizations at the White House nine days ago, they emerged from the meeting glowing. But many of those who got only a second-hand report felt that Mr. Clinton was backing away from his support for the organizations' goals and should have at least stayed in Washington on Sunday for the gay march.
As David Mixner, a Los Angeles consultant and longtime Clinton friend, told the Sacramento News and Review: "He has wonderful instincts, but we've seen that he must be constantly pressured."
White House officials are privately fuming that the interest groups that had helped to elect Mr. Clinton will not practice more patience.
"The gays are crazy to go after him now," a Presidential aide said. "They should just sit back and let him get his feet on the ground and work quietly with him."
 
Problem With Idealism
 Such is the fate of any politician who infuses his campaign with starry idealism. After President Kennedy's first year, James Reston, the New York Times columnist, wrote that the magic was gone. The sense of "great perspectives ahead," he said, were "outdistanced by events; not that there is no momentum but that it is not fast enough to keep up with the pace of history at home and abroad."
Now it is the teen-ager who once shook President Kennedy's hand who wrestles with that balance between pragmatism and idealism.
The conservatives have already begun their Cassandra chorus, warning that the President is just "a baby-boomer version of George Bush," as one puts it, who has been willing to compromise on any principle and goal. But those who work with Mr. Clinton every day say he is inspiring because, while he will cut deals where he has to, or disappoint constituencies when he needs to, he has his eye on the prize.
"The real test is that at the core of everything he does, he is pushing a really pervasive set of changes that are embodied in the budget," said Bruce Babbitt, the Interior Secretary.
Mr. Babbitt found himself publicly undermined when the President decided to cut a deal with Western senators on grazing and mining fees to win their votes for the budget. But Mr. Babbitt now says it was merely a tactical change.
"The President hasn't put any gag on me," he said. "After I was on the floor and took that pounding, he said: 'Look, dust yourself off, get back up and keep after it. We will still get it done.' "

HEADLINE: U.S. Is Asked to Control Prices of Drugs It Develops

BYLINE: By GINA KOLATA

 BODY:
With health costs continuing to soar, some economists and health-care experts think the Government should try to restrain prices on a costly group of drugs over which it has some nominal authority. These are drugs developed by Federal researchers but marketed by pharmaceutical companies.
These experts argue that the companies, in marketing drugs the Government discovers, should be required to charge no more than a "fair" price, as called for in contracts they sign. And they say that when the Government pays for research on drugs owned by private companies, the price of the drugs should reflect the public's investment. A thorny issue, however, is who should determine what a fair price is and how. 
 Dr. Alan Garber, an economist and internist at Stanford University, said the public paid twice when drugs were developed with generous help from the Federal Government. It paid first for research and development, he noted, and then again to buy the drugs.
Representative Henry A. Waxman, the California Democrat who heads a House health subcommittee, is planning hearings on the issue soon. Donna E. Shalala, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, is preparing a policy statement.
 
Treatment at $300,000 Yearly
 Critics of the current policy complain, for example, that Ceredase, a drug used to treat a rare inherited disorder, Gaucher's disease, which causes anemia and severe bone pain, can cost $300,000 a year. Yet the drug was discovered and developed by Federal scientists and academic researchers supported by Federal grants before it was turned over to a small Boston company, Genzyme, to market.
Genzyme said the high cost reflected the expense of making the drug, which is extracted from human placenta.
Another drug, levamisole, which was marketed for years to cure sheep of worm infestations, has turned out to be a stunning success in treating colon cancer. The studies that determined its effectiveness against cancer were conducted entirely by Government scientists.
But Johnson & Johnson, which markets both versions of the drug, charges a hundred times as much for the human version as it does for the identical drug for sheep. The drug costs cancer patients an average of $1,200 a year.
Johnson & Johnson points to the extra cost of training doctors to use levamisole as a reason for the higher price for the human version.
 
Companies See Justification
 Representatives of major drug companies were unanimous in asserting that the present system for setting drug prices was necessary to cover the high costs of research on new drugs and of training doctors in their use. The companies say that if the Federal Government controlled the prices of the drug it paid to develop valuable drugs might never come to market and others might be delayed.
The National Institutes of Health, in accord with its mission to discover new therapies and speed them to the market, invites pharmaceutical companies to market the drugs. The agency awards exclusive licenses for the drugs based on criteria like the company's manufacturing ability and speed of delivery. The price the company will charge is not considered.
The agency also invests heavily in developing drugs already owned by pharmaceutical companies. The system provides strong incentives for the companies to bring important new drugs to the market but few incentives to hold down the prices.
"Everyone feels these prices are just too high," Dr. Bernadine Healy, director of the National Institutes of Health, said in a recent interview. "That's an appropriate response. But then you have to step back and say, 'What can we do about it without wrecking a very important system?' The U.S. pharmaceutical industry is the envy of the world."
 
A Doctor's Outrage
 In the case of levamisole, Dr. Charles Moertel, a cancer researcher at the Mayo Clinic, protested that the drug's development "was paid for just about in full by the American taxpayer." Dr. Moertel said he was outraged when he was told by a scientist working with a Johnson & Johnson affiliate that the drug would be marketed in Europe at a price "considerably lower than in the U.S."
"It just infuriated me," said Dr. Moertel, who argues that the Government should control prices of the drugs it helps develop. "It is so unfair. To put this burden on American cancer patients when our country paid the bill in full for development and to give Europe a bargain just sent me up a tree."
Robert Kniffen, a spokesman for Johnson & Johnson, said that the company deserved credit for discovering the drug and that the price of the human version had to include the cost of training doctors in its use.
Dr. Moertel and other critics dismiss the training costs as advertising and promotion.
 
U.S. Hand in Important Drugs
 According to a study by James Love of the Center for the Study of Responsive Law, a public interest group founded by the consumer advocate Ralph Nader, the majority of what the Food and Drug Administration deemed the most important and innovative drugs coming to the market in 1990 and 1991 were developed with substantial help from the National Institutes of Health.
The study also found that 34 of 37 cancer drugs that have come on the market since 1955, when the National Cancer Institute began its intensive search for such drugs, were developed with significant Federal financing.
Dr. John Beary, who is senior vice president for science and technology at the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association, said most of the drugs that Mr. Love cited were for treating AIDS and cancer, for which the Government has special programs to develop drugs, and rare diseases.
Drugs that benefit only a small number of patients are less important to drug companies, Dr. Beary said. For that reason, companies and the public "expect a lot of Government interest and a lot of Government support" for those drugs, he said.
 
Fair-Price Clause a Reaction
 Since 1989, the National Institutes of Health has inserted a clause in its contracts with pharmaceutical companies that requires them to charge a "fair" price for the drugs they develop with the Government. This clause, Dr. Healy said, was a reaction to outrage on the part of the institute's scientists at the price of AZT, the primary drug for combatting AIDS, which was discovered at the National Cancer Institute.
Burroughs Wellcome, which marketed the drug, initially set its price at about $10,000 a year per patient. The recommended dose of AZT has since been reduced, as has its price, so that it now cost a patient about $3,000 a year.
It is this fair-price clause that some health experts are suggesting the Government enforce to reduce drug prices. But Dr. Healy said the National Institutes of Health had no way to ascertain whether a price was fair and no way to enforce a fair price even if it knew what one was. Dr. Healy, who is leaving as director of the health institutes on June 1, said the agency, in view of its mission, was not even the appropriate one to enforce fair pricing.
Other Government experts agree. Dr. Michael Gluck, a senior analysts at the Office of Technology Assessment, said his agency had concluded that the National Institutes of Health "had neither the legal authority nor any true procedure or perhaps even the incentive to implement that policy as it needs to be implemented."
But an advocate of Government enforcement of the fair-price concept, Peter S. Arno, a health economist at Albert Einstein College of Medicine in the Bronx, said he had a possible solution. He said companies that enter into cooperative agreements with the Federal Government should be required to open their books, allowing economists to decide whether the price of the drugs was fair.
"A monopoly is not a gift," he said. "It is a social privilege. We confer it for the sole aim of stimulating innovation. But if the innovation is by Government scientists and paid for by the taxpayer dollars, where's the drug company's innovation?"
 
Better Investment Return
 A different approach suggested by some health-care experts, among them Dr. Gluck, is to drop the notion of a fair price and focus on having the Government get a better return on its investment in drugs.
Instead of handing out licenses to market its drugs, the health institutes could, for example, hold an auction or charge higher royalties. Although the Federal Government can ask for royalties when it grants licenses to drug companies, it has received very little from such royalties, according to a report by the General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress.
From 1981 until 1990, for example, the Government collected $26 million in royalties, of which $22.6 million was from two licenses. These were for the test for detecting antibodies to the virus that causes AIDS and the hepatitis B vaccine. In 1990, the health institutes collected $5.84 million from its patents, which was less than four-tenths of 1 percent of the amount it spent on research and development by its own scientists.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 30; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1771 words

HEADLINE: As U.S. Policy Makers Debate, States Move Ahead on Health Care Overhaul

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 24

 BODY:
The governors and legislatures of the 50 states are not waiting for the Clinton Administration to find a fresh approach to health care.
Squeezed between rising demands for care and soaring costs, and fearful that Congress will act too slowly or wrongheadedly on whatever the President finally recommends next month, states are determined to go ahead on their own to improve matters. 
 "The health care crisis out in the states is so pressing that we can't wait any longer to see what the Federal Government is going to do, if anything," said Casper R. Taylor Jr., the leading advocate for an overhaul of the health care system in the Maryland Legislature, where he is a delegate. "A lot of individuals can't afford care. The cost of providing care to workers is breaking some of our businesses. Other state needs are being neglected because of the health care budget. The heat is on."
Like President Clinton, the states intend to insure a minimum level of coverage for all and to halt the steep climb in medical costs. But there is no unanimity on how to reach the goal and no guarantee that every state program will mesh with the package that eventually emerges from Congress.
 
Variety of Approaches
 The President has indicated he favors a mix of price competition and regulation. The states are taking varied, piecemeal approaches that in many cases are in the trial stage. Some have proposed programs but have not yet arranged financing for them. A number of states are trying to expand coverage to the poor and children and to control doctor and hospital fees. Others are trying to regulate insurance costs, mandate benefits, limit malpractice suits and revamp Medicaid.
Still others are pushing preventive care, eliminating duplication and unnecessary procedures and are seeking ways to slash administrative costs.
Hawaii has already made insurance available to almost all its residents. Several other states, including Minnesota, Oregon, Vermont and, most recently, Florida have enacted varying programs intended to provide universal coverage. And just Friday, the Washington State Legislature approved a plan that would phase in basic coverage for all residents by 1997.
Several states, most recently Maryland, have enacted insurance regulations intended to end discrimination against the aged and those who are chronically ill. Several other states, with Maryland again being the latest, have also adopted rules intended to hold down doctor fees and limit malpractice suits.
 
Success in Maryland
 Maryland successfully put caps on hospital costs a decade ago, and several other states are now trying to impose similar caps.
Many states are trying various strategies to hold down Medicaid costs, the most burdensome medical load. Tennessee recently proposed hiring private contractors to run its program.
New York has been a leader in state efforts to hold down administrative costs, developing a standard, simplified claim form.
For the most part, states are driven by their need to control health care budgets, which are rising 15 percent to 20 percent annually, mostly reflecting their share of ballooning Medicaid costs.
On average, one of every five tax dollars collected by state governments goes for health care, as against one in seven dollars at the national level.
The states know they risk being undercut by Clinton health care initiatives and mandates. But they hope the Administration will be flexible and let many of their efforts stand.
 
State Must Take Action
 Still, state officials say they have no intention of halting their efforts and waiting for action by the President. They contend that they must do something now or face bankruptcy, since unlike the Federal Government, states must have balanced budgets.
"We just can't wait," Gov. Lawton Chiles of Florida declared recently.
Besides, state officials add, the harder that states push for change, the more influence they are likely to have on the Federal debate and the more likely they will be able to meet new Federal mandates on schedule.
The Clinton Administration has not tried to discourage innovation, and in fact, officials say they are taking a close look at state programs as possible models for a national overhaul. They are also studying the political alignments in the states, hoping to prepare for the battle on Capitol Hill.
"There's a lot to look at, and we're looking," said John Hart, a White House aide who specializes in state-Federal relations, especially health care issues.
 
Support for Managed Care
 The National Governors' Association, whose support could be important to Mr. Clinton, recently endorsed the managed-competition concept of health care that the President frequently mentions. Under this concept, the Government would help individuals and businesses in a particular area form a single health care purchasing pool that would buy fixed packages of benefits from networks of doctors and hospitals in the area.
But whether or not managed competition ends up as one of the main components of Mr. Clinton's plan, state officials say they should be given great flexibility and extra Federal money to meet new Federal mandates. In the past, they say, Washington has been too restrictive and too parsimonious in dealing with the states on health care, particularly when it comes to highly expensive plans, like Medicaid, in which the states are responsible for part of the cost but the Federal Government sets the standards and rules.
Gov. Carroll A. Campbell Jr. of South Carolina, the vice chairman of the governors' association, emphasized the need for flexibility and Federal-state cooperation during the group's annual winter meeting a few weeks ago. The meeting was dominated by health care and featured a talk on the subject by President Clinton, who promised flexibility.
 
Ex-Governor as President
 "I'm going to do everything I can to work with you," Mr. Clinton said, adding that as a former Governor he was aware that the health care crisis was "threatening to bankrupt many of you."
Congressional leaders have also called for flexibility. "We do need comprehensive reform, but that should not be an impediment to state action," Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, said when he addressed the governors shortly before the President spoke.
And many states are pushing ahead on their own.
Maryland's new package, passed early this month, contains provisions to slow rising doctor fees and insurance premiums. It also includes reins on malpractice suits and controls on insurers who cancel policies of the seriously ill or flatly deny them coverage.
A week before the Maryland plan was enacted, Florida adopted a sweeping health plan intended to guarantee care for all Floridians, mainly through managed competition.
"We would like to be able to chart the way for the Federal Government," Governor Chiles said.
But like officials in Maryland and in most other states that have recently enacted health care programs, Mr. Chiles was unable to say when his plan might take full effect. Nor was he able to put a dollar figure on the savings expected from it, though he said the plan would eventually free up money for other state social programs.
"We've got to stop the spiraling increases, and then we'll talk about savings," Mr. Chiles said when the plan passed.
At least a dozen other legislatures are working on health care proposals, and more and more governors are speaking out.
 
Burden of Medicaid
 In Tennessee, Gov. Ned McWherter said the burden of helping to pay for Medicaid and of meeting all Federal mandates had become too onerous, a common complaint by states. Mr. McWherter wants to stop taking part in the program and, with the help of Federal support, to contract out care of the poor to monitored private groups of doctors and hospitals.
In New York, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has suggested that his legislature consider capping doctor fees and setting up regional health care networks in which community leaders, hospitals and doctors would work together to control costs, a variation of managed competition.
"We must do all that we can for ourselves while we await something better from Washington," Mr. Cuomo said. Besides, he suggested, such action might influence the debate in Washington.
Although many state health care programs are new or have not yet been started, some have been around long enough to be judged.
Among the notable successes is Maryland's decade-old effort to slow increases in hospital costs. A specially drawn package of regulations and caps has cut the annual rise in the state to less than half the rise nationwide.
In Hawaii, the first state to mandate universal access to health care and to back it up with money and regulation, 98 percent of the people are covered, compared with 85 percent nationally.
But there have been failures, too.
A few years ago, Massachusetts passed a broad "pay or play" plan that required employers to pay into a fund to provide insurance for their workers if they did not arrange their own health-insurance plan for their workers. The state also guaranteed coverage for the unemployed and others in need.
But the plan stalled after Massachusetts was hard hit by the recession. The startup date, initially set for 1992, was moved back to 1995, and state officials have not ruled out a further postponement.
Among state initiatives now being started after considerable delays, the Oregon plan is among the most interesting. It guarantees coverage for every citizen but, at the same time, limits the type of coverage offered, a kind of rationing many states have ducked thus far, though many health care experts believe rationing is inevitable.
Initially, Federal health care officials blocked the Oregon plan, saying the rationing would violate laws that protect the rights of disabled people.
After the Clinton Administration took office, Federal officials relented, raising hopes in state capitals of a significant change in Washington. "We believe the Federal Government must give the states the flexibility to solve their local problems," the Secretary of Health and Human Services, Donna E. Shalala, said in allowing Oregon to proceed.
All in all, in one form or another in recent years, states have tried to deal with almost every health care issue that Mr. Clinton has expressed concern about.
"There's hardly anything that at least one state hasn't tried or is getting ready to try," said Trish Riley, the executive director of the National Academy for State Health Policy, a nonprofit study group in Portland, Me.

HEADLINE: Hunt's Fall Can't Hurt Alabama Politics' Reputation

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MONTGOMERY, Ala., April 23

 BODY:
Politicians seem to be held in low esteem everywhere these days, but things may have hit rock bottom here.
In a state with crushing problems of poverty and education, the felony conviction and removal from office of Gov. Guy Hunt this week is seen less as an outrage and more as yet another indication of how government here has routinely failed its citizens. 
 The most common reaction seems to be speculation about how many other officials could be vulnerable if held to the same legal standards that were used to convict Mr. Hunt of converting $200,000 in money raised for his inauguration for his own use.
"You know how in Alabama they say, 'Thank God for Mississippi' and in Mississippi they say, 'Thank God for Alabama?' " said Phil Norton, who owns the Farmers Market Cafe here, referring to each state's ability to save the other from monopolizing the bottom of various national rankings. "I don't know if we can say that anymore."
 
'This One Just Got Caught'
 One of his customers, Sammy Mobley, a carpet installer, added: "There's two kinds of politicians in Alabama: the caught and the uncaught. This one just got caught."
Mr. Hunt's removal from office brought calls for new ethics and campaign standards for the state, and some believe the trauma could help revitalize state government. But almost no one believes that will be an easy task in a state still waiting for someone, anyone, to move it outside the shadow of George C. Wallace, who dominated the state's politics for a quarter century.
"This is the only Deep South state yet to elect a New South Governor, either Democrat or Republican," said Bill Barnard, a history professor at the University of Alabama. "There used to be a hope, a false hope as it turned out, that if we just could get through the turmoil of the 1960's, just get on the other side of racial change, that a brighter day for Alabama politics was at hand. It just didn't happen."
It was not always that way. Fifty years ago, Alabama produced some of the most savvy and progressive politicians in America, including Hugo L. Black, a Senator until he became a Supreme Court Justice in 1937.
 
The Wallace Factor
 But the political fallout from the battles over segregation hit harder and lasted longer in Alabama than anywhere in the South. From the time he was elected to his first term as Governor in 1962 to the time he ended his fourth in 1987, Mr. Wallace dominated Alabama politics so completely that no one could emerge from his shadow. Most experts say they believe his quarter-century of primacy stunted the state's political development.
Some say Mr. Hunt artificially extended the process when he was elected to succeed Mr. Wallace in 1986. A farmer and lay Primitive Baptist preacher with a high school education, Mr. Hunt was nominated as a Republican sacrificial lamb but became Governor after a fratricidal Democratic primary in which the winner was removed from the ballot by the courts. Mr. Hunt went on to win re-election in 1990 and supporters say his low-key, pro-business approach has been good for Alabama's economy.
But his critics say Mr. Hunt has been an ineffectual Governor who has dealt with none of the state's main problems. Those include a tax code that is widely seen as in need of drastic revision to alleviate inequities, an educational system that is being forced by a sweeping state court ruling this month to upgrade the state's schools and how they are financed, and a system of campaign financing so lax that a major element of the Governor's defense was that everyone else uses campaign money for personal use.
Alabama ranks 44th nationally in per capita income and 47th in the percentage of residents who have graduated from high school.
 
Poilitics and Race
 In addition, the state's racial politics are among the most combative in the country. "In the State of Alabama, it is very seldom that the white politicians will do things on their own initiative to eliminate racial discrimination," said State Representative Alvin Holmes, who is black. "In 99.9 percent of the cases, if something is done, it is ordered by the Federal courts or the Federal Government."
Looming over it all is a political system with a racially divided, philosophically neutered Democratic Party and a Republican Party still struggling to establish itself. Only two Republican candidates have been elected to statewide office since Reconstruction: Senator Jeremiah Denton, who won a single term in 1980, and Mr. Hunt.
"No one has been saying, for example, that if Guy Hunt were found guilty that education reform is down the drain, or if he is exonerated that we'll get tax reform on the table again," said Natalie Davis, a political science professor at Birmingham Southern College. "It's not that kind of politics here. It's just about who's winning and who's losing. It's a football game."
But some see some positive developments. Professor Barnard said the state's economy had become less dependent on industries like mining or timber, which has given corporate interests far more reason to care about education and economic development than in the past.
"You have increasingly, especially from the banking and financial community, business leaders with a stake in the economic and social well being of the state in a way the timber barons never did, the absentee-owned steel mills never did," Professor Barnard said. "And you're getting some leadership willing to work really for the first time with the leaders of the education forces."
 
Like Father, Like Son?
 But there is much doubt whether the new Governor, Jim Folsom Jr., the amiable, conciliatory son of a former two-time Governor and populist firebrand, James E. (Big Jim) Folsom, can be the the dynamic force the state needs. And some see the return of one of the state's storied names to the Governor's office as a reminder that in Alabama politics, everything can change and nothing can change at the same time.
"I think if they'd been on the other Governors like they got on Hunt, they'd have got all of them," said Sam Perry, who works for a local utility company, as he ate lunch at Charlie's Restaurant here.
And Phyllis Smith, a waitress, recalling Big Jim Folsom's two terms, from 1947 to 1951, then from 1955 to 1959, said: "You know what Folsom, his daddy, said: that the first time he did things by the book, and if he got back in there, he was going to get all he could out of it. This one will probably be the same way."

Phil Norton, owner of a cafe in Montgomery, Ala., said of each state's ability to save the other from being lowest in national rankings. "I don't know if we can say that anymore." (Alan S. Weiner for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Guido Carli, Economist, 79, Dies; His Firm Hand Led Italy's Growth

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
Guido Carli, for decades Italy's foremost economic leader and an influential figure in international finance, died in Spoleto on Friday. He was 79.
Official news reports said he died on the way to the hospital after a heart attack. 
 Mr. Carli guided his country's economic recovery after Italy's in World War II, and became a cornerstone of stability for revolving-door governments. Twice he was credited with rescuing the nation from financial ruin.
 
A Strong Leader
 His leadership continued in recent years as Western European nations linked their economies and the Soviet bloc disintegrated. Mr. Carli sometimes outspokenly criticized the United States for a failure of leadership, as he did when oil prices soared in the 1970's. But he also defended the United States when other Europeans tried to limit American investment as a threat to their autonomy.
 Mr. Carli, who was born in Brescia and educated at the University of Padua, was the son of an economics professor. A friend of the family (who later became Pope Paul VI) won Mr. Carli a job at a state holding company. There he interned under two men who later headed Banca d'Italia, the central bank, and he succeeded them in that post.
In 1944, at the age of 30, he represented Italy at the Bretton Woods Conference, which planned post-war reconstruction by the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank. He joined the I.M.F. managing board in 1947.
 
Two Rescue Operations
 During his term as governor of the central bank, from 1960 to 1975, Mr. Carli exercised strong influence on the Treasury Ministry, on Government planning, on the budget and on the stock market. When Italy's economy faltered in 1964, he was credited with reviving it through emergency actions, including a mission to Washington that netted $1.2 billion in aid.
A decade later, he defied pessimistic experts by arranging a similar rescue of the economy through budgetary austerity, a reduction in inflation and an expansion of foreign trade, a package he called shock treatment.
In 1983 Mr. Carli, a Christian Democrat, was elected to the Senate. He served as Treasury Minister from 1989 until last year. Since then he worked as a consultant.
Mr. Carli is survived by a son, Andrea.

HEADLINE: POLITICAL NOTES;
When Is a Fact Not a Fact? When It's a Statistic.

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
The Democratic mayoral primary is still five months off, but accusations -- accompanied by statistical jousting -- are already flying up. Mayor David N. Dinkins and his chief Democratic opponent, City Council President Andrew J. Stein, squared off last week on a point that Mr. Stein has been pressing for months: his contention that the Mayor has cut more than $700 million from the city's schools over the last four years.
Mr. Stein has argued often that Mr. Dinkins has let down the city's students, and perhaps even imperiled the city's future, by underfinancing the school system. "This administration has cut more than $700 million from the Board of Education," Mr. Stein said at a Democratic candidates forum last week in Brooklyn. "That's a fact." 
 But the Mayor insisted that it is not. He maintained that, even in the midst of the worst recession in a generation, he had made sure that the city's contribution to the Board of Education's budget "has increased each year that I have been Mayor."
Who is right? As is often true in politics, each candidate has a legitimate statistical basis for his claim.
According to financial data provided by the Mayor's press secretary, Leland T. Jones, the city's contribution to the school board increased each year from 1989 to 1992, and is tentatively set to go up again this year. In 1989, the city gave the schools $2.98 billion; by 1992, $3.42 billion.
Mr. Stein is so adamant on the point that, after going to his car at the end of the candidates' meeting, he returned to a cluster of reporters outside the House of the Lord Pentecostal Church in downtown Brooklyn, where the forum was held, to reiterate his claim. He said, in response to a question, that the Mayor had reduced, in actual dollars, the city's contributions to the schools each year.
But Mr. Stein's aides said the next day that the Council President had meant to say that the Mayor had reduced the city's contribution each year from the amounts it had planned to give to the school board in the city budgets approved each June. These cuts were part of a broad effort by the Dinkins administration to trim costs in virtually all city agencies.
The city's cuts against its own plans -- which amounted to $777 million in the last three years -- caused the Board of Education to slash programs, including reducing supplies and the numbers of guidance counselors, said Susan Wiviott, an assistant to Mr. Stein. "What they've cut is program money," Ms. Wiviott said.
 
Awaiting Cuomo's Nod
 Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has yet to speak about whom he will recommend as the next chairman of New York's Democratic Party, but names have started to emerge from his aides and political associates.
Mentioned most consistently is Al Gordon, a longtime Cuomo aide who is currently the Governor's director of legislative and intergovernmental affairs. Mr. Gordon has been involved in most of Mr. Cuomo's campaigns and served as the director of the Dukakis campaign in New York in 1988.
Other possibilities include Judith Hope, the former first vice chairwoman of the state party, Secretary of State Gail S. Shaffer, and Edward Szczesniak, the Democratic chairman of Onondaga County, which includes Syracuse.
The Democratic State Committee plans to meet on May 15 to ratify Mr. Cuomo's selection. The new chairman will succeed John A. Marino, who is joining a Manhattan investment firm.
The Cuomo aides said the Governor could also choose someone not being mentioned prominently at this time. And they said his decision would depend largely on whether he chooses someone to serve simultaneously as chairman and executive director, as Mr. Marino did, or he divides the tasks between two people.
 
Joining in the March
 The march may be in Washington, but so will be many New York City voters.
Several political figures from the city say they will take part in today's demonstration for equal rights for gay Americans, which is expected to draw 300,000 people to the nation's capital from the New York area.
Mayor David N. Dinkins and his likely challenger in the Democratic mayoral primary, City Council President Andrew J. Stein, say they will attend, as will Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman and Ruth W. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President.
They will be joined by Assemblywoman Deborah J. Glick of Manhattan, the Legislature's only openly gay member, and Councilman Thomas K. Duane, who is also gay.
Rudolph W. Giuliani, Mr. Dinkins's likely Republican opponent, is staying in New York City to raise money for his campaign, his aides said.
 
Hitting the Screen, by Mail
 The race for the Republican gubernatorial nomination in New Jersey has been run with the kind of stealth and scramble for strategic advantage that once marked the cold war.
It began with a build-up of press releases delivered by hand, mail or fax machine from each of the three major candidates: Christine Todd Whitman, Cary Edwards and James Wallwork. The fight has moved to community-access cable television channels and to the radio airwaves, where the candidates have pounded one another and Gov. Jim Florio, a Democrat.
All of this is leading toward a blitz in the final weeks before the June 8 primary, when expensive television ads will air on New York City and Philadelphia stations because there is no single television outlet that covers all of New Jersey.
Late last week, Mr. Edwards introduced an intermediate weapon that he hopes will help him overtake Mrs. Whitman in the polls: his campaign began mailing videotapes to registered Republicans across the state. The cover of the tape shows a harsh visage of Mr. Florio, with the caption, "Retire this guy: only one Republican can (Hint: Cary Edwards)."
On Friday, the chief political strategist for the Edwards campaign, J. Brian Smith, gave journalists in Trenton a preview of the 9-minute, 29 second video. It opens with a string of attacks on Florio policies on taxes, crime and education, then touts Mr. Edwards's virtues before ending with a scene showing Mrs. Whitman with a tennis racquet under one arm and luggage on the other.
Mr. Wallwork is ignored.
Mr. Smith declined to say exactly how many videotapes were being mailed. But he said the number was more than the 100,000 videos Mr. Edwards sent out four years ago when he finished second in the race for the nomination.
