HEADLINE: A Dealer in Art and, Some Say, a Dealer in Secret Police Data

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, April 24

 BODY:
Roy E. Bullock has recently become one of the best-known collectors in the Bay area, but it is not his Japanese wood block prints that has attracted attention. Rather, the collection that is raising curiosity and anger is his data base of 12,000 people and 500 organizations, including some culled from confidential police files.
Like any careful collector, Mr. Bullock sorted and labeled what he had, dividing his world into categories: "ANC" for supporters of the African National Congress in South Africa, "Skins" for right-wing extremists like skinheads and neo-Nazis, and "Arabs" for critics of Israel. The rest fell under two headings: "Pinkos" for liberals and "Right" for conservatives. 
 Then, critics say, he began to spread his collection around. Law-enforcement investigators here say he sold and traded the names and other information to police agencies, the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith and at least one foreign government.
The collection, which Mr. Bullock acknowledges he has been compiling for more than 30 years, has drawn accusations of domestic spying and invasions of privacy.
 
Lawsuit and Investigation
 Although no criminal charges have been filed, his activities are the subject of a civil lawsuit and are being investigated by the District Attorney's office here, which says the Anti-Defamation League has people like Mr. Bullock in cities around the country who have close ties with some law-enforcement officials.
Barbara S. Wahl, a lawyer for the league, says that the group does have a network of "researchers" and that they do have close ties to law-enforcement agencies in many cases. "But the A.D.L. does not run a spy ring nationwide," she said.
As reports of Mr. Bullock and his intelligence-gathering emerged in news accounts over the past four months, they began to raise eyebrows in largely liberal San Francisco. And when a flood of documents supporting government search warrants became public two weeks ago, the case began to evoke cries of outrage.
Part of the District Attorney's investigation involves Mr. Bullock's relationship with Thomas Gerard, a former police inspector here who has been accused by plaintiffs in the lawsuit of tapping into law-enforcement and government computers and feeding the information to Mr. Bullock.
Exactly what Mr. Bullock, 58, does do to support himself is hazy. He is often described as an art dealer, and he says most of that part of his life involves Japanese prints. He calls himself a researcher, but the evidence available in public documents indicates that his steadiest work seems to be on contract to the Anti-Defamation League, collecting information about people.
 
Trading and Selling Information
 He has admitted in court papers and in an interview that he is not a passive information gatherer, having infiltrated racist groups, tapped into telephone message systems and paid informers. In addition, according to public documents, he has traded information with law-enforcement officers, who gave him motor vehicle records and criminal rap sheets. And he says that for four years he sold some of his information to a man calling himself "Louie," who he said was an agent for the South African Government.
There is nothing illegal about collecting information that is in public records, which is what makes up most of Mr. Bullock's data. But the District Attorney's investigation is aimed at finding out how far Mr. Bullock and Mr. Gerard went beyond that, including whether they used police authority to obtain the names of postal box owners.
The investigation began in December, when the District Attorney's office began looking into Mr. Gerard's use of official information. A short time before that, Mr. Gerard retired from the police force and moved to the Philippines. The authorities are now trying to find him for questioning.
"The heart of this investigation is the violation of privacy and individuals' rights to exercise First Amendment freedoms," said District Attorney Arlo Smith. "People should feel free to go to assemblages without the fear that their license numbers will be taken down in the parking lot and classified information about them given out to private individuals."
 
'Massive Spying' Charged
 Mr. Smith said the investigators are trying to determine if there had been violations of California's laws on privacy, eavesdropping and disclosure of confidential records.
The civil lawsuit was filed April 14 by 19 people who have been publicly critical of Israel and South Africa. It is a class action, on behalf of everyone affected by the gathering of such information, and it charges Mr. Bullock, Mr. Gerard, the Anti-Defamation League and the head of the league's San Francisco office with violating the plaintiffs' privacy.
The suit also says a "massive spying operation" was run to discredit people and cause them "loss of reputation, jobs or economic benefit."
"If I thought this was just about finding out who the skinheads were, I wouldn't object," said Paul N. (Pete) McCloskey Jr., a former Republican Congressman from California who is representing the plaintiffs, including his wife, Helen.
Another plaintiff, Yigal Arens, the son of former Defense Minister Moshe Arens of Israel, said, "I've never done anything more than sometimes in public, sometimes in private, said what I think."
The case has caused confusion for some liberals because the Anti-Defamation League, an organization they believed was keeping tabs on racist or violent groups, has now been accused of spying on them.
 
'Outraged' by Pinko Listin
 "If it were the White Ayran Resistance and the Klan they were spying on, I probably wouldn't get upset about it," said Anne Poirier, who is involved with groups supporting anti-apartheid efforts in South Africa and is a plaintiff in the lawsuit. "But because it was about me, I care. I'm outraged that I'm on the Pinko list."
The Anti-Defamation League was founded 80 years ago to gather information about anti-Semitic groups. Since then it has thrown a wider net, opposing all forms of hate groups.
Melvin Salberg, the league's national chairman, flew here from New York on April 15 to defend the group. "We have been in the trenches fighting for civil rights," he said in an interview. "We have it as our mission to find out what racist groups are doing and saying so we can properly combat them."
Mr. Bullock said in an interview that he had not done anything wrong. His motivation, he said, has been a "repellent interest in hate groups, religious bigots, assorted kooks and radicals," an interest he said he developed in high school.
Although the laws have changed in the past 40 years to restrict spying by law-enforcement agencies on citizens, Mr. Bullock's methods have remained the same throughout his career. He said he had infiltrated organizations by passing himself off for months at a time as a white supremacist or as a sympathizer to Arab causes.
Despite the lawsuit and investigation, Mr. Bullock aggressively defends his activities. "I feel I have rendered a service to fight bigotry in every form," he said. "I'm very proud of what I've done."

HEADLINE: EIGHT TONS OF AID SAILS OFF TO CUBA

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KEY WEST, Fla., April 24

 BODY:
In an effort to ease the worsening shortages of food and other necessities in Cuba, the first of a dozen boats set out for Havana today loaded with eight tons of vitamins, food and hospital supplies.
Food rationing and the resulting nutritional problems have become severe in Cuba since the collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991 and the loss of $5 billion in annual Soviet subsidies. Early this month, the Cuban Health Ministry announced that there was an epidemic of a blinding eye disease caused, in part, by the lack of Vitamin B in the daily Cuban diet. 
 The flotilla shipment includes 32 boxes of Vitamin B complex pills.
"They are our neighbors down there," said the flotilla organizer, John J. Young of Key West, who calls his group Basta, which is Spanish for "enough." "What we're concerned about is getting medicines and as much as we can down there."
 
9 to 12 Boats to Go to Cuba
 Still, the gesture has divided this small resort island 90 miles from Cuba, with some Cuban-Americans saying the shipment will fall into the hands of President Fidel Castro.
Depending on the weather, 9 to 12 boats are expected to make the trip this weekend. Mr. Young said the group planned to arrive in Cuba by Sunday afternoon. A ceremony is planned for Monday at Havana Children's Hospital for the donation of the over-the-counter drugs, bed linens, reading glasses and other items.
The Commerce Department granted the license for the shipment on the condition that the goods be given to a group other than the Cuban Government. Mr. Young said the shipment would go to the Cuban Red Cross, the Ecumenical Council and the Baptist Convention.
But with the Cuban Government organizing the transport of the aid once it arrives in Cuba, some Cuban-Americans have their doubts.
"I worry that that help will go to the Cuban Government," said Alfredo Aguero of Key West, who formed a protest group called Basta de Basta, or Enough of Enough.
On April 10, Basta de Basta organized a motorcade of about 50 cars that drove through Key West with signs and flags protesting any aid to Cuba. The protesters said the aid would go to the Cuban Army, Cuban political leaders or foreign tourists.
 
Debate Over Aid to Cuba
 On Thursday, a small fire was set at the warehouse where the supplies were stored, but Mr. Young said they were not damaged. Mr. Aguero said his group had nothing to do with the fire.
The flotilla has underscored a growing debate among South Florida's Cuban-Americans, who are divided on whether they should send help to their former countrymen or stand behind the hard-line position that no aid be given while Mr. Castro is in power.
"I think 99 percent of the Cuban community agrees with aid to Cuba," said Mr. Aguero, who works at a local transit home where all Cuban refugees to the Florida Keys are processed. But, he added, "everyone who comes from Cuba, including doctors, says it goes to the Government."
Agents from the United States Customs Service checked some of the boxes as they were being loaded onto boats today to confirm their contents. Treasury Department officials from Washington were also there to remind captains and crew members that they are not permitted to spend any American dollars while in Cuba.
 
Helping the Children
 So the group will not have to spend any money, Mr. Young said the Cuban Government has promised not to charge a fee for docking at Marina Hemingway, a tourist compound a few miles west of downtown Havana.
For the boat owners, the reasons for going to Cuba are simple. "I'd like to see kids get the humanitarian thing," said H. T. Pontin, a 70-year-old retired tugboat captain, who lives near Key West on Ramrod Key. His 53-foot sailboat is one of the largest in the fleet sailing to Cuba, which includes vessels as small as 24 feet and as large as 72 feet.
"The two countries are playing their own ball game, and I'm just a boater in the middle," Mr. Pontin added.
A Key West writer, John Leslie, who oversaw the storage of the goods for Basta, had more political goals. "The more openness we can get going, the greater the chance that the embargo can be lifted," Mr. Leslie said. "Once the embargo is lifted, Castro is gone."

HEADLINE: PAKISTAN IS FACING TERRORIST LISTING

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 24

 BODY:
Aware that the step could shatter what was once a close relationship, the Clinton Administration is debating whether to add Pakistan to its official list of nations that support terrorism.
The proposed declaration has stirred deep misgivings within the State Department and in Congress because of the danger of a backlash of anti-American feeling in another Islamic country and because the alleged offenses mainly involve support for separatist guerrillas in the disputed Kashmir region. 
 But senior Clinton Administration officials say that Federal law will give them no other option unless Pakistan can present evidence that it has severed its ties to separatist groups that employ terrorism as a weapon.
"If circumstances don't change, it's going to happen," a senior State Department official said, speaking on condition of anonymity. The Director of Central Intelligence, R. James Woolsey, warned separately this week that Pakistan was "on the brink" of the designation, which would mean heavy costs for the country's economy.
 
A Spur to Fundamentalists
 But several other United States officials in both Washington and Islamabad say that such a decision would be counterproductive and perhaps unjust. It would strengthen the hand of Islamic fundamentalists in the region and would punish Pakistan for backing guerrilla action in neighboring Kashmir that is sometimes more comparable to ethnic strife than a clear-cut example of terrorism.
Direct economic and military aid to Pakistan was suspended in 1990 in retaliation for its development of nuclear weapons. If it is judged to be supporting terrorism, Pakistan would face an automatic halt to the indirect American assistance it has continued to receive as well as new barriers to trade between the two countries. The United States assists Pakistan through the Peace Corps, the Export-Import Bank and development organizations.
Officials from both countries say the step would all but end the decades-long cooperation between the United States and Pakistan, which reached its height during a 14-year campaign by Muslim guerrillas to unseat a Communist regime in Afghanistan.
Secretary of State Warren Christopher warned a special Pakistani envoy this month that the United States expected Pakistan to take specific "action" to cut its ties to groups that engage in terrorism. Yet some American officials say the debate on Pakistan's status has raised questions about whether the criteria used in assessing terrorism remain appropriate as ethnic violence spreads to an increasing number of countries.
 
No Room to Differentiate
 The countries placed on the terrorist list have usually been regarded by Washington as outcasts, for example Iran, Libya and Iraq, whose main offense was said to be support for attacks on American targets or on American allies.
If Pakistan is added to the group, the United States would primarily be punishing the country for its backing of Kashmiri separatists who use terrorism as well as more conventional tactics of protest in their rebellion against India's central Government.
The law passed by Congress in 1979 to require punishment of nations supporting terrorism allows no room for differentiation among them. But the circumstances of Pakistan's actions and the potential consequences of its punishment have caused some American officials in both Washington and Islamabad to question whether it truly meets the terrorist test.
"They are not blowing up planes, or seizing half the Cabinet like North Korea did in Burma, or seizing American hostages, or giving refuge to Abu Nidal," the mastermind of a Palestinian terrorist group, said a senior American official in Islamabad who opposes Pakistan's designation as a terrorist state. "What they are involved in is what we did in Afghanistan," said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity.
But Mr. Woolsey, who backs a strict approach, told Congress this week that not only Kashmiris but Sikh secessionists had "found safe haven and other support" in Pakistan.
 
Arms Flow Called Stemmed
 In a recent interview, a very senior Pakistani intelligence official contended that Islamabad had stemmed the flow of arms and guerrillas into Kashmir directly in response to American threats.
With the Clinton Administration is skeptical about such claims, Pakistan has also sought to call Washington's attention to the Islamic radicals inside the country who are intent on making the schism with the United States permanent. Adding Islamabad to the terrorist list would "throw Pakistan into the hands of mullahs and clergy," Malik Zahoor Ahmad, a Pakistani diplomat in Washington, warned in an interview this week.
He also repeated Pakistan's contention that the United States is overlooking the support India has given to Tamil separatists, who have used terrorism in their violent campaign for independence in northeastern Sri Lanka.
The most recent State Department list of state supporters of terrorism, issued in January, includes Cuba, North Korea and Syria as well as Iran, Libya and Iraq. Although the law allows the department to amend that list at any time, Administration officials said they hoped to reach a decision by June about Pakistan and the Sudan, which is also facing a threat of American sanctions.

HEADLINE: President Sees Many Gains in His First 100 Days

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 24

 BODY:
President Clinton awarded himself high grades today for his first 100 days in office, saying in his weekly radio address that he had changed the nation's direction, tackled the budget deficit and helped small businesses and struggling families with children.
Mr. Clinton spent much of today meeting with Senate Democrats at a weekend retreat, as he taped the speech on Friday. The President and the senators are trying to figure out how to regroup after Senate Republicans defeated his jobs bill this week. 
 Facing an onslaught of Republican criticism that his first 100 days have gone sour, Mr. Clinton devoted much of his radio address to putting a positive spin on his record.
He noted that Congress had approved the broad outlines of his economic program. He added that he had taken steps to make more credit available to small businesses and farms, provide more Federal aid to working families with children and set up programs to help people who had lost their jobs because of cuts in the military.
 
'Good News Lately'
 Mr. Clinton expressed pride that the stock market was at an all-time high and that long-term interest rates were very low. "There's been some good news lately," he said. "After about 100 days as President, we've begun to change the direction of America."
In a rebuttal, the House minority leader, Robert H. Michel of Illinois, agreed that Mr. Clinton had changed the direction of America, but toward higher taxes. Mr. Michel's speech was part of a stepped-up Republican strategy to hammer Mr. Clinton over his proposals to raise taxes, through a new energy tax, higher taxes on Social Security benefits and a possible value-added tax.
"The President himself has said one of his top priorities is creating jobs," Mr. Michel said. "But higher taxes don't create jobs. They kill jobs."
In his radio address, the President lashed out at Senate Republicans for their filibuster that blocked his package to stimulate the economy.
"A lot of those people think they've scored a victory by killing a chance to put nearly half-a-million Americans to work," he said. "I don't think that's much of a victory. I think that's letting the American people down."
After the President arrived with his family in Williamsburg, Va., the White House announced that he had signed into law the one part of his package that he had salvaged: $4 billion in extended unemployment compensation benefits to about 1.9 million people without jobs. The Senate approved the measure on Wednesday.
The closed session with senators was described by White House and legislative aides as a strategy session on promoting the agenda of the President and the senators.
The President spent much of the morning visiting Jamestown, the nearby historic settlement, with his daughter, Chelsea; his mother, Virginia Kelley, and her husband, Dick Kelley. He was also accompanied by his mother-in-law, Dorothy Rodham, whose husband died April 7.
While they were sightseeing, Hillary Rodham Clinton was busy speaking with the Democratic senators about the Administration's plans for health-care reform.

HEADLINE: Celebrities Join Ohio Congressman in a Fast

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 24

 BODY:
Representative Tony P. Hall, who is nearing the end of his third week of a protest fast, was joined Friday by 40 celebrities around the country in an effort to raise awareness of hunger and to protest a House decision to abolish the Select Committee on Hunger.
Mr. Hall, a Democrat from Dayton, Ohio, began fasting on April 5 after the House voted to cut its budget by eliminating the hunger committee, which he led, as well as special committees on aging, children and narcotics. 
 "It's not some kind of crazy guy who's fasting trying to get his way," the actor Jeff Bridges said Friday, from his home in Montana. "This is a well-respected Congressman. I wanted to help him sound the horn and get the message out."
Mr. Bridges said he helped organize the one-day celebrity fast in hope that people would pay attention to the 35,000 people who die of starvation in the world each day. He is also hoping to get the attention of members of Congress.
"I hope this will put some fire under their tails and they will find a way to replace the committee now that it's gone," Mr. Bridges said.
Since beginning his fast, Mr. Hall has lost about 20 pounds. The Congressman, who said he is drinking only water, said he would break the fast early next week, after Agriculture Secretary Mike Espy announces a plan to coordinate the work of Federal agencies that handle programs to combat hunger.
Mr. Hall said the fast had given him empathy for the famine victims he had seen in Somalia, Ethiopia and elsewhere. "I know how they go days without food," said Mr. Hall, who has continued his work schedule, "but how do they walk? I walk a block and I am winded."
William Stanton, the senior adviser for external affairs at the World Bank, said Mr. Hall's fast had inspired officials of the development bank to promise a series of worldwide "hunger summits," beginning with a symposium in the United States this fall. The bank spends about $1 billion a year on nutrition programs, he said.
But Linda Elswick of the World Sustainable Agriculture Association said famine-relief groups had mixed views about World Bank programs.
She said some groups complained that developing nations had been encouraged to grow crops for export rather than crops that feed local people. Others complained that the money went to local governments but did not reach the people that needed it the most, she said.
Mr. Hall's fast has inspired one-day fasts on college campuses around the country, as well as the celebrity fast, which the actress Valerie Harper helped Mr. Bridges organize.
The actors who said they would take part included Brooke Adams, Steve Allen, Beau Bridges, Gary Busey, Michael Cole, Bruce Davison, Shelley Fabares, Andy Garcia, Cynthia Geary, Scott Glenn, Deidre Hall, Harry Hamlin, Mel Harris, Michael Jeter, Carol Kane, Perry King, Stepfanie Kramer, Michael Learned, Jayne Meadows, Rob Morrow, Edward James Olmos, Susan Ruttan, Susan Sarandon, Connie Stevens, McLean Stevenson, Brenda Vaccaro, Lindsay Wagner, Lesley Ann Warren and Sam Waterston.
Others who announced fasts on Friday included the former astronaut Buzz Aldrin, the musicians Graham Nash, Mary Travers and Peter Yarrow and such personalities as Phyllis Diller, Dick Gregory, Casey Kasem, Cassandra Peterson and Olden Polynice.

HEADLINE: POLITICAL MEMO;
Stephen A. Douglas's Style Tips and Other Errors

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, April 24

 BODY:
Though it has been only a week since the official start of the gubernatorial races, there has been more than time enough for political truisms to be driven home to candidates in both parties.
Lesson No. 1: Do Not Give Up Your Day Job. 
 If you are going to run for governor, it's wise to make sure that you: a) are wealthy enough to need no job; b) have the proper political and business connections, so that finding another line of work is of no concern, or c) make it a part-time mission.
This was supposed to be the year that John Budzash bought a boat -- a sleek $10,000 speedboat paid for with a $4,000 down payment from his Federal income-tax return and a small monthly note that his post office salary would comfortably cover.
But instead of going boating this summer, Mr. Budzash, 42 years old, decided to run for governor, challenging the incumbent, Jim Florio, for the Democratic Party's nomination.
 
New Haircut, No Mustache
 To gear up for the race, Mr. Budzash quit his $32,000-a-year job as a letter carrier, switched his party registration from Republican to Democrat two days before the filing deadline, had his hair professionally cut for the first time in 20 years (he had been cutting his own hair, he said) and shaved the mustache he had worn for half his life. (Someone on his grass-roots campaign staff had told him about a theory that facial hair was a negative for candidates.)
Democratic Party leaders have charged that Mr. Budzash, who was propelled into New Jersey politics as an antitax maverick in 1990, has the covert financial and political backing of Republicans and/or the National Rifle Association, which has vowed to defeat Governor Florio over the state's ban on semiautomatic weapons. Mr. Budzash denies such ties and said he quit his mail job with no other prospect except to be Governor.
And now he will have no spot on the ballot either, after a successful Democratic challenge to his candidacy petitions. On Friday, Secretary of State Daniel J. Dalton, who is a Florio appointee and confidant, upheld a ruling by an administrative law judge that his petitions were flawed.
 
Soldiering On, but No NavyXx
 Unbowed, Mr. Budzash pledges to soldier on, campaigning for write-in votes, although he conceded, even before he was tossed off the ballot, that the economics were shaky. "Now that I don't have a job, my income-tax refund has got to help me live for the next few months and no boat!" he said. "And on top of that, I have to sell my Corvette."
Lesson No. 2: If Possible, Avoid Sharing the Stage With Children or Animal Acts.
It was once de rigueur for politicians to kiss babies. But unlike party underlings and campaign staff members, children cannot be counted on to toe the line.
Consider the carefully staged re-election announcement by Governor Florio, which was made at a community center in Edison April 13.
Just before the announcement, Mr. Florio posed for a campaign videotape in a side room with his wife, Lucinda, in the midst of a roomful of children wearing T-shirts with the message: "Florio for Governor."
 
Fidgeting and Yawning
 The children then trooped into the auditorium and sat behind Mr. Florio. They were intended to provide visual and symbolic background as he defended controversial policies of his first term, including a $2.8 billion tax increase, as good and necessary for the future of New Jersey.
But Mr. Florio quickly found that he was competing for the attention of the press and television cameras with the fidgeting, yawning and otherwise distracted children who were not captivated by his message -- hardly the image he had envisioned.
Lesson No. 3: Be Punctual!
Very few politicians adhere to this rule. But for those who try, it is important to learn that it applies to both sides of the hour hand.
This has best been demonstrated by J. Patrick Gilligan, a candidate for the Republican nomination whose entire campaign has consisted of infrequent, one-page messages, written in arching longhand and sent via a fax machine at the American Stock Exchange, where he is a consultant.
 
Accidentally Too Early
 "My failure to keep a 9:30 A.M. press conference on March 24th at the time I entered my petition for the Republican nomination for Governor of New Jersey was not an intentional affront to the press," Mr. Gilligan said in a message that arrived, via fax, more than three weeks after the events. "It was an accident."
"I arrived early by chance, went through the procedure and finished shortly after 9:15 A.M," he said. "Seeing no press, I mistakenly assumed they were not interested and left. I should have waited and I apologize to whomever I offended."
Lesson No. 4: You Can Be Too Rich.
From the earliest days, Federal and state leaders were generally learned, landed and loaded.
But Christine Todd Whitman, a candidate for the Republican gubernatorial nomination, has found her campaign bedeviled by a wealth of embarrassments over her wealth.
The latest blows landed last week when Ms. Whitman and her husband, John, disclosed that they had an estimated income of $3.7 million in 1992. Ms. Whitman said she and her husband, a financial consultant, had paid $1,028,569 in Federal taxes and $255,000 to the state.
 
Those Immigrants Again
 The financial information she provided revived past controversies, particularly her admission that she had hired illegal immigrants and had not paid their taxes, a problem she shared with Cary Edwards, another Republican gubernatorial candidate.
Another problem arose over a much more trifling amount: $1. It was reported this week that on her state tax return for 1991, Ms. Whitman, who has qualified for the maximum $1.6 million in state matching funds for the primary election, checked "no" on the section of the form that asked if the taxpayer wanted to divert $1 of their tax dollars for the election fund.
A campaign spokesman, Joe Justin, explained to The Asbury Park Press that the Whitmans felt that their contributions of money and time for political causes more than made up for the checkoff.

"And on top of that, I have to sell my Corvette," he said. Mr. Budzash stood outside his house in Howell Township, N.J. (Kevin P. Coughlin for The New York Times)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Biography

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (92%); 

STATE: NEW JERSEY, USA (92%); 

CITY: TRENTON, NJ, USA (79%);

HEADLINE: Waste Management, American Style

 BODY:
To the Editor:
To suggest we can aim at recycling and reusing up to 72 percent of our packaging strikes me as unrealistic. 
 Today, we are recycling about 21 percent of our waste, but for a host of economic, technical and practical reasons, we're never going to approach 70 percent. The practical upper limit for recycling in the United States is probably about one-third of our trash. This is a ceiling, not a near-term target. A good recycling range for most communities is more like 20 to 30 percent.
Why can't we achieve higher rates? We have already reached high recycling rates for the more valuable, easy-to-collect items. For example, we're recycling 65 percent of aluminum cans, nearly 60 percent of cardboard boxes and 50 percent of newspapers.
To think we can triple our current rate by relying on things that are expensive to collect or have no market value is naive.
We need to stop trying to convince ourselves that recycling is the only way to deal with trash. Rather, we should encourage communities to tailor integrated waste management programs to their own local circumstances. The unique mix of source reduction, recycling, incineration for energy production, and landfilling that makes the most sense in each local situation is the best way to handle our trash.
 
J. WINSTON PORTER
Sterling, Va., April 13
 
The author is an environmental consultant.

HEADLINE: A Vote for Investment Professionals

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"At Tax Time, Thoughts of I.R.A.'s" (Mutual Funds, April 11) spoke to the point that much of the I.R.A. money flows into exactly the wrong places, because "most people do not understand the real risk of investing for several decades: inflation." It then proceeds to extol the virtues of 18 "no loads" with five-year track records "that reflect a controlled level of risk." Investor needs are neatly categorized by age. What if these needs were addressed individually by an investment professional who could help select an appropriate fund or funds that may carry a sales charge, or "load"? Is it possible that this advice might indeed put money in the right places? 
 Several growth and income funds with outstanding 30-year records are available through investment professionals. Clearly, investors who held such funds during this period enjoyed substantial investment success and do understand the risk of inflation. Do you really suppose they say to themselves today, "If only we hadn't paid that sales charge?"
 
BRUCE M. ROCKWELL
Detroit, April 12
 
The author is senior vice president of the First of Michigan Corporation.

HEADLINE: Bob Dole Versus Political Reform

 BODY:
First Bob Dole, the Senate minority leader, strangled the President's economic stimulus plan. Now the Dark Prince of Gridlock has pledged to give the same killing treatment to Mr. Clinton's long-promised campaign finance reform package. So sure of his antipathy is Mr. Dole that he has not even bothered to wait for its unveiling, which could happen any day now. If you're dead set against cleaning up politics, there's really no need to read the legislation.
But well-meaning Republicans and the Democrats should not let Mr. Dole's pre-emptive hostility deny serious political reform to the American people. To do so is to taunt an electorate already angry over the mortgaging of their democracy to wealthy influence peddlers. They want a better, freer Congress. This is a fight Mr. Clinton can win -- if he will stiffen his resolve and use his communication skills to show up Mr. Dole's rhetoric for what it really is: shilling for a corrupt status quo. 
 In a positive development, both chambers now seem poised to take up the campaign finance issue before Hillary Rodham Clinton's task force delivers its proposal and health care reform takes center stage. This means that House Speaker Tom Foley, who seemed bent on deferring the issue until the summer or even beyond, has listened to the voters.
The lingering question is whether the plan Mr. Clinton and Democratic leaders have been crafting in protracted negotiations will be one worth fighting for. That's still unanswerable, and that's where Mr. Clinton must use the weight of his office to whip resistant legislators into line. Here are some clear tests that he can apply:
Does the plan, strengthening the bill vetoed last year by President Bush, contain adequate public funds to break incumbents' dependence on special-interest money and allow challengers to wage competitive races? Does it sufficiently curb the political action committees, or PAC's, which now dominate in Congressional fund raising?
Does it shut down the evasive system that pumps soft money through the Democratic and Republican national committees? Has the bundling loophole, which permits special interests to magnify their clout by aggregating checks, been shut tight?
To Mr. Dole, it seems, these details are unimportant. He's ready to brand any bill that contains public financing and spending limits as an incumbent-protection scheme, a new form of welfare for politicians. And some Democrats, loath to see that line carried in an opponent's 30-second spot, are clearly scared.
But, in fact, there's no way to reduce the role of special interests and help Congressional challengers without a public financing system. A new Wall Street Journal/NBC poll suggests Americans are willing to support the idea, if the money comes from eliminating the tax deduction for lobbying -- the transfer favored by Mr. Clinton.
As for incumbent protection, nothing beats the current system. In 1992 senators running for re-election raised an average of $4.8 million for their campaigns -- nearly triple the average raised by challengers. Mr. Dole, who accepted $8 million in taxpayer money in his two failed Presidential campaigns, surely knows all this. But his determination to thwart the public will -- and the public interest -- on this issue is strong.
Mr. Dole is said to be putting heat on three Republican Senators -- Dave Durenberger of Minnesota, James Jeffords of Vermont and John McCain of Arizona. Each voted for public financing legislation in 1990, 1991 and 1992 and for overriding the Bush veto. Mr. Dole wants them to abandon their principles and join in killing whatever plan Mr. Clinton and the Senate majority leader, George Mitchell, serve up.
In assessing his first 100 days on Friday, Mr. Clinton gave himself high marks on campaign reform. He hasn't really earned them yet, but he can by breaking the Congressional gridlock on raising the ethical standards of American politics.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Clinton As Carter?

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB

 BODY:
From Washington and around the world, the grumbling has begun about President Clinton's leadership, his ability to wield power and his willingness to do what's necessary to prevail.
To combat this, he has to gain control quickly of two keystone issues, mastering Congress on the budget and mustering Europeans behind a plan for bold action on Bosnia. Otherwise, his Administration risks becoming what it fears most -- a repeat of the Carter Administration. 
 Much of the grumbling is politically motivated, premature and unfair. But it does contain a growing kernel of truth.
Tellingly, the criticisms come not just from Republicans and attack journalists, but from Democrats who desperately want him to succeed.
In the last weeks, friends and foes alike have been taking the measure of the man in the White House and are finding him wanting. Most troubling is that he's losing control of the budget, the carefully crafted economic plan he set before Congress to wide acclaim barely two months ago.
Bob Dole, the Republican leader in the Senate, savaged the President's grab-bag economic stimulus package. Mr. Clinton struck back, arguing that the package was critical. Mr. Dole held fast. The President offered a quick compromise. Mr. Dole dug in. Within days, Mr. Clinton caved.
In the game of power perceptions, Mr. Clinton's collapse cost him dearly. Either he shouldn't have made the issue a test case, or he should have cracked heads to make sure he had the votes to win.
Now the President must regroup and refocus on what was most applauded and needed in the budget -- the energy taxes, the higher taxes on the rich and deficit reduction. And he has to push the budget through Congress before midsummer, before the even bigger battle that looms over health care reform.
Mr. Clinton's ability to do this is absolutely essential to his international power. What foreign leaders admired most about him two months ago was his courage in tackling America's massive debts and his seeming capacity to command Congressional and popular support. They know, as Mr. Clinton knows, that America's power abroad rests on America's economic good health.
But the President's standing abroad also hinges on his handling of the Bosnian crisis. Most of the fault for this situation rests on the Europeans. They would not stand up to Serb aggression at the outset.
Now the Europeans want it both ways on Bosnia. They want to avoid military intervention, and they want U.S. leadership to quell the crisis. Foolishly, Mr. Clinton tried for months to dodge hard decisions about force and follow Europe's cynical policy of feeding the Muslims while doing nothing to prevent their slaughter.
It makes no sense, however, to endlessly berate the hapless Europeans. They know they can't lead, and Americans know they can't lead. Their leaders haven't got the political strength or the military power.
To make matters worse, Mr. Clinton seemed to lose control of his own Administration on Bosnia. Defense Secretary Aspin talked publicly about using force. Secretary of State Christopher publicly ruled it out. Madeleine Albright, the U.N. envoy, sent Mr. Clinton a private letter calling for the use of force. Twelve Balkan experts in the State Department did as much, and leaked it to the press.
Finally, on Friday, Mr. Clinton showed signs of stepping up to the challenge. Now he must unite his own team and then NATO behind realistic and understandable objectives: not bringing the Serbs to their knees military, which would require a massive land war, or even forcing them to make concessions at the negotiating table, which they won't do. But raising the costs of genocide to the Serbs and giving the Muslims a better chance to defend themselves. These goals can be met by using NATO air power and by arming the Muslims, and would call for minimal ground troops to guard safe havens.
If Mr. Clinton will lead in this direction, Europe will follow. The path leads not to another Vietnam, but to a fighting chance for the victims of genocide and to the reassertion of basic Western values.
The Clinton Presidency is on the line in Bosnia and Congress. With Mr. Clinton's formidable political skills and dazzling mind, he must know that he cannot afford to appear weak, that he must take clear stands and risks -- and lead.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Conflict in the Balkans;
Serbs Again Reject Vance-Owen Peace Proposals

BYLINE: By JOHN DARNTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 24

 BODY:
Courting the risk of allied air strikes and virtually assuring that new international sanctions will descend on Yugoslavia on Monday, the leader of the Bosnian Serbs said today that a proposal to link Serbian enclaves in Bosnia with a demilitarized corridor was not acceptable.
 After meeting for three hours with Lord Owen, who is trying to mediate an end to the Bosnian war, the Serbian leader, Radovan Karadzic, said the latest version of the peace plan "is absolutely anti-Serb" and "didn't meet a single Serbian need." 
Western diplomats said more talks could be held on Sunday, when Lord Owen is to return from an overnight trip to Zagreb, Croatia.
 He is also supposed to meet again with Slobodan Milosevic, the President of Serbia, who is widely assumed to call the shots for the Serbs in Bosnia. The ability of the Serbs in Bosnia to continue their battle for territory depends on the Serbian-dominated Yugoslav federation of Serbia and Montenegro.
 
Among the Dandelions
 With the United Nations deadline for acceptance of the plan creeping closer, diplomats could not rule out an 11th-hour move by the Bosnian Serbs to wrest some final concessions that would lead them to a grudging acceptance of the peace plan.
 But most thought that was unlikely, given the vehemence of Dr. Karadzic's rejection, and they viewed his stand as a critical step toward deeper international involvement.
 The meeting today took place in a villa on the outskirts of Belgrade, a pale yellow stucco house with drawn shades and an overgrown lawn resplendent with yellow dandelions. As the talks wore on, more and more maps -- ever larger --were sent for and delivered.
 But when Lord Owen left, he pushed through a mob of reporters, his face drawn. Asked if any progress had been made, he responded with a curt no.
 
Plugging Loopholes
 The rejection means that sanctions mandating the seizure of all Yugoslavia's assets abroad and prohibiting the transshipment of goods across Yugoslavia will automatically come into effect on Monday. These steps are expected to plug major loopholes in a trade embargo imposed a year ago that is already choking the Yugoslav economy.
 At the same time, the intransigence of the Serbs will test the patience of the Clinton Administration, which is under growing pressure to take military action to end "ethnic cleansing" and to support the Muslim-led Bosnian Government.
 President Clinton said on Friday that he was giving serious consideration to air strikes against Serbian positions, adding that he expected that European allies would join Washington in such an action.
 The foreign ministers of the European Community met in Denmark today to weigh military action. For Britain and France, which both have troops with the United Nations peacekeeping forces in Bosnia, a decision to bomb Serbs could expose their soldiers to retaliation.
 Any decision on military strikes could also be complicated by the long siege of Srebrenica. Under a cease-fire agreement, Muslim defenders surrendered some weapons to United Nations troops there, or slipped through the encircling Serbian lines. Now all that is protecting a desperate and hungry civilian population of some 30,000 Muslims from attack by Serbian artillery is a lightly armed 145-member United Nations force from Canada.
 
The Offer of a Corridor
 The five-day mission to the region by Lord Owen, the European Community mediator, had the air of a last-ditch attempt to win approval of the peace plan that he devised with Cyrus R. Vance, who was the United Nations mediator. The plan would carve Bosnia into 10 semiautonomous provinces virtually parceled out among Muslims, Croats and Serbs.
 The Croats and Muslims have signed the agreement. In an effort to overcome the objections of the Serbs, Lord Owen has proposed a 6-mile-wide, 50-mile-long corridor patrolled by United Nations forces that would link the Serbian area around Banja Luka in northwestern Bosnia with the Serbian province in the east, which borders the republic of Serbia in Yugoslavia.
 The corridor, while not under Serbian sovereignty, would at least provide a transit link, as the Berlin corridor linked the city to West Germany during the cold war, Lord Owen said.
 Dr. Karadzic rejected both the corridor and the historical analogy.
 "The German corridor went through Germany," he said, "but that is not the case here," meaning that the Bosnian corridor would traverse territory held by Croats. Without a more solid corridor under their own jurisdiction, the Serbs living in the northwestern Bosnia would flee in terror, he suggested.
 
'We Should Be Separated'
 "We asked Lord Owen, where are we going to put 500,000 Serbs who would run away?" Dr. Karadzic told reporters. He said that he took the threat of Western air strikes very seriously, but that he had no alternative to rejecting the proposal.
 Insisting that Serbs, Croats and Muslims had been fighting for centuries, he castigated the West for pressing a plan that would force them to live in the same country. "Why are you pushing us together, like a dog and a cat in the same box?" he asked. "We can't live together. We should be separated to be good neighbors."
 This statement pointed toward the resolution preferred by the Bosnian Serbs. They want to sit down with the Croats and perhaps the Muslims and simply cut the country into three parts.
 The Serbs, who control about 70 percent of Bosnia, would be in a dominant bargaining position. They would most likely try to arrange a trade with the Croats that would give the Serbs their corridor in exchange for a more consolidated Croatian area around Mostar and other towns in the southwest.
 
'Greater Serbia'
 The Serbs have other objections to the Vance-Owen map. They feel it deprives them of major industrial areas and power stations. They also want more territory around Trebinje in the south and in the northwest.
 The self-styled parliament of the Bosnian Serbs is meeting today and Sunday in Bijeljina, in northeastern Bosnia, to reconsider the Vance-Owen plan, which Dr. Karadzic said he would present without recommending acceptance or rejection. The parliament, which is even more militant than he is, already turned it down on April 2.
 The parliament voted to establish an assembly between Serbs in Croatia and Serbs in western Bosnia, a step that Croats and Muslims are bound to regard as a provocative move toward creation of a "greater Serbia."

HEADLINE: Conflict in the Balkans;
Weighing Strikes in Bosnia, U.S. Warns of Wider War

BYLINE: By STEPHEN ENGELBERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 24

 BODY:
As President Clinton weighs military action in Bosnia and Herzegovina, the danger of the war spreading elsewhere in the Balkans is emerging as a dominant issue in the deliberations, Administration officials say.
 The C.I.A. has told the White House that any spillover of the fighting in Bosnia could ignite a regional war that might ultimately bring in Greece and Turkey, both NATO members, against each other. 
Although both the Clinton and Bush Administrations have warned Serbia in recent months that any signs of aggression beyond Bosnia's borders would bring an immediate, military response, a number of senior United States officials now say those warnings have been undermined by the West's inaction on the civil war in Bosnia.
 In a recent letter to the White House, the United States delegate to the United Nations, Madeleine K. Albright, argued that air strikes in Bosnia were needed both to save civilian lives and to convince Serbia's President, Slobodan Milosevic, that the West is serious in its warnings against pushing the conflict beyond its current borders, Administration officials said.
 Washington warned Mr. Milosevic this year against driving ethnic Albanians from Kosovo, a province of Serbia in which Serbs are a small minority. Clinton Administration officials have since expanded what one called a "red line" to include any move by Serbs against Macedonia, one of the new countries that emerged from the disintegration of the former Yugoslavia.
 "Probably Milosevic doesn't believe it," one senior Adminstration official said. "I worry about that. I'm afraid we don't have a great deal of credibility on Kosovo because of what we've shown on Bosnia. And there is already a lot of Serb pressure on Macedonia."
 Macedonia's representative in Washington, Ljubica Z. Acevska, said few in the Balkan region were taking the American pledge to protect her country seriously. "After Bosnia, it is a sham," she said.
 Many Administration officials believe that military action against Bosnian Serbs would deter the federal Serbian-led Yugoslav Government in Belgrade from undertaking or financing Serbian nationalist military campaigns elsewhere. On the other hand, officials believe that if the West does not act now -- after President Clinton's public acknowledgement that he is considering air strikes --Serbian nationalists will be further emboldened.
 President Clinton and his top aides frequently invoke American interests in discussing the possibility of a wider Balkan war. Appearing before a House Committee in March, Secretary of State Warren Christopher said a Serbian move toward Kosovo or Macedonia could even set off a world war.
 "We fear that if the Serbian influence extends into either of these areas, it will bring into the fray other countries in that region -- Albania, Greece, Turkey -- and from there, on it could extend very broadly," he said.
 "So the stakes for the United States, are to prevent the broadening of that conflict to bring in our NATO allies, and to bring vast sections of Europe, and perhaps as happened before, broadening into a world war."
 Although 1.7 million ethnic Albanians live in Kosovo, forming an overwhelmingly majority, the territory is also prized by Serbian nationalists as the site of the Serbs' apocalyptic last stand against Turkish invaders in 1389.
 Mr. Milosevic, a former Communist, began his career as a nationalist firebrand in 1987 with a speech in Kosovo in which he decried what he contended was mistreatment of local Serbs by ethnic Albanians. Belgrade has since transformed the province into a virtual police state with huge contingents of Serbian police officers and army troops there to keep order.
 The Albanians in Kosovo have so far generally refrained from violent resistance, although clashes broke out between Serbian security forces and Albanians in December 1992. The skirmishes led led Bush Administration officials to worry that Mr. Milosevic was setting the stage for a new round of "ethnic cleansing," according to a former Bush Administration official.
 
A C.I.A. Scenario
 The C.I.A. has warned that Albania's military is poised to respond if ethnic Albanians are pushed across the border into Albania. On Dec. 15, President Bush's Director of Central Intelligence, Robert M. Gates, said in a speech that the fighting in Bosnia "has the frightening potential to spread."
 Mr. Gates said that the C.I.A. told President Bush in private briefings that any Serbian move in Kosovo would destabilize Macedonia, which has a large Albanian minority.
 Bulgaria, Greece, and Serbia, all of which have at various times asserted territorial claims to Macedonia, would seize parts of that country as the violence increased, according to a possible scenario suggested by the C.I.A.
 Turkey and perhaps other Muslim nations might then jump in to support Muslim Albania, such thinking goes, while Orthodox Greece would ally itself with the Orthodox Serbs.
 Mr. Bush's warning was delivered on Christmas Day, and Pentagon planners drew up an extensive list of targets -- from key military bases to communications links -- that would be hit if the Serbs did not comply The former Bush Administration official said the United States planned on organizing passage of a resolution by the United Nations Security Council authorizing such action.
 When Mr. Clinton took office, he endorsed Mr. Bush's warning on Kosovo but decided to rely on economic sanctions and diplomatic pressure to end the war in Bosnia.

HEADLINE: 54 Rms Pk Vu

BYLINE: By Kenneth T. Jackson; Kenneth T. Jackson, the Barzun Professor of History at Columbia University, is the author of "Crabgrass Frontier: The Suburbanization of the United States."

 BODY:

NEW YORK, NEW YORK
How the Apartment House Transformed
the Life of the City (1869-1930).
By Elizabeth Hawes.
Illustrated. 285 pp. New York:
Alfred A. Knopf. $30. 
 COMPARED with other American cities, New York thrives at its center. Its citizens complain of crime, dirt and taxes, but the fact is that Manhattan, with its bustling sidewalks, efficient public transportation, crowded stores and, most important, its substantial middle- and upper-income population, is unusual in the United States. The rest of the nation is relentlessly suburban, and its dominant urban model is that of a doughnut -- a depressed central city with little vitality surrounded by hundreds of square miles of shopping malls, office parks and subdivisions.
How did Manhattan come to be so different, so European, so un-American? Elizabeth Hawes, formerly a staff member at The New Yorker, suggests that high-rise living, a once-novel idea, may be responsible for the singularity of the Hudson River metropolis. Before 1869, she argues in "New York, New York: How the Apartment House Transformed the Life of the City (1869-1930)," all respectable residents, in New York as elsewhere, lived in private, single-family houses.
Although bourgeois Parisians had been living on "shelves" since the days of the ancien regime, any American household of even modest aspirations considered a multifamily building to be sexually racy, a "stage set for adultery." After all, busybodies could not monitor the comings and goings of visitors when private entrance ways did not front on the street. Before the Civil War, the word "tenement" described any dwelling that housed three or more families, and the term "apartment building" was unknown.
Change began when the first upper-income apartment building in the United States was built in 1869 by the architect Richard Morris Hunt for Rutherford Stuyvesant, one of the most respected men in New York. Offering residents the security and convenience of a full-time concierge, the Stuyvesant Apartments at 142 East 18th Street overcame the risque image of the "French flat" and attracted couples of impeccable social standing. General Custer's widow moved there after her husband fell at the Little Bighorn.
The Stuyvesant's success encouraged others. In 1884, the most lavish residential structure yet seen was put up on a corner of 72d Street and Central Park West. Known as the Dakota because it was so far from the center of things that one wag said it might as well be in the Dakota Territory, it was richly ornamented and featured separate servants' entrances, service stairways and service elevators.
In the last two decades of the 19th century, even as the private mansions of the Vanderbilts and the Villards continued to march uptown, new apartment buildings were transforming the public perception of high-rise living. William Dean Howells, according to Ms. Hawes, had particular significance, not only because the author's move from Boston to Manhattan helped make New York the intellectual capital of the United States, but also because his choice of an apartment, not a house, typified a larger residential shift.
The great boom in apartment-house construction came after the turn of the century, spurred by the opening of the subway in 1904. Focusing on the Upper East and Upper West Sides, where new buildings sprang up like wildflowers, "New York, New York" gives special attention to the biggest of the residential behemoths, places like the Ansonia, the Apthorp and the Belnord. Technically, many were apartment hotels but, whatever the name, by 1929 they had transformed New York.
Indeed, by the onset of the Great Depression, Ms. Hawes estimates, 98 percent of affluent Manhattanites lived in apartment buildings, some of them so elegant that they rivaled the private palaces that once held sway on upper Fifth Avenue and on Riverside Drive. Mrs. E. F. Hutton's apartment at 1107 Fifth Avenue, for example, had 54 rooms.
Written for a general rather than an academic audience, "New York, New York" does not break new scholarly ground, and students of architectural and social history will find little that is not already accessible in Andrew Alpern's "Apartments for the Affluent" (1975); Elizabeth Cromley's "Alone Together: A History of New York's Early Apartments" (1990); or Richard Plunz's "History of Housing in New York City" (1990). Moreover, Ms. Hawes, by focusing on Manhattan, neglects the middle class in favor of the wealthy, and ordinary apartment buildings in favor of famous ones. But she is an engaging stylist, and her vivid prose and the book's excellent illustrations escort the reader into the lavish interiors of New York's grand residences and help us to understand "the conversion of the rich." With economy and grace, "New York, New York" explains how, in a short period of feverish activity, the nation's metropolis assumed its modern shape.

HEADLINE: THEATER;
At the Shubert, 'Will Rogers Follies'

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN

 BODY:
JUST a week ago, a musical about the showman Mike Todd opened in New York, making a gasping attempt to live up to a reassuring but ultimately misleading title: "Ain't Broadway Grand."
About to enter its third year on Broadway, a block away from the doddering new show, which had a Connecticut tryout last year, "The Will Rogers Follies" delivers the elaborate production numbers, the feel-good songs and the sentimentalized biographical outline that "Ain't Broadway Grand" vaguely promised. 
 Now the "Follies" can be seen at its near best, in the national touring edition, with the original star, Keith Carradine, at the Shubert all week, and it's proving a point about the dearth but not the death of musical comedy.
Once the norm, the lighthearted American song and dance show -- rooted in traditional family entertainment values, Broadway style, with a brassy big time Broadway score -- comes around in the post rock-and-roll age perhaps every decade or so. Before "Will Rogers Follies" (1991), the last such exemplar of extravagance, pizazz and frivolity was "La Cage Aux Folles" (1983).
More throwback than innovation, "Will Rogers Follies" is blessed with the ingenuity of Tommy Tune's direction and choreography to celebrate Broadway's past with witty, teasing references to and variations on dance steps, many his own, that epitomize the Broadway musical.
Given the largesse and extraordinary detail of Willa Kim's shimmering costumes, one wonders whether the real Ziegfeld shows had as much esthetic intricacy. Perhaps the Ziegfeld shows had outrageous headgear and more flamboyant accessories, but it's hard to imagine outdoing the taste and bounty of Ms. Kim's creations on this scale. And Tony Walton's set designs invent the chic open interior space to match the wide open spaces that were Will Rogers's birthright. Realistically, who is going to dream up a show that looks as sumptuous as this one, down to the deep red sequined curtain and splendid staircase glowingly lit by Jules Fisher.
One of the delights of catching a current musical passing through has to do with the contagion of adrenaline that flows through a company on the move, ever readjusting to new audiences, in contrast to the routine, the rote performances, that all too often set in during a lengthy static run.
It's cheering that Mr. Carradine has chosen to tour in the super part that finally defines him as a stage star. He is handed a spectacularly built-up entrance ("Howdy") and he rates the treatment, right on to his last curtain chat with the crowd, and an irresistible country interpretation of "Never Met a Man I Didn't Like," the Cy Coleman-Betty Comden-Adolph Green anthem that's guaranteed to make us forget all exceptions to the title, for a few minutes of benevolent escape.
Mr. Carradine's closest support, Dee Hoty, is encumbered as Betty Blake (Mrs. Will Rogers), a role not only as vapid as Mrs. P. T. Barnum in another musical about a big star and his dutifully submissive wife, but bigger. Leigh Zimmerman propels the show from number to number and from scene to scene as Ziegfeld's favorite, more with mechanical competence than performing flair. For other diversions, a roper and a dog act are really neat and germane, personal taste aside.
In its single, shallow dimension, the conceit of Peter Stone's book -- Rogers's life is presented "in revue" -- works as novelty, with Wiley Post, the pilot on the plane crash that killed him and Rogers in Alaska in 1935, seated in the box, urging Will: "Let's go flying." Characters step out with coy asides to the audience, as when Will's father says: "I don't get to be lovable till somewhere in Act II."
For all that, the rise of Will Rogers, from featured act in the St. Louis World's Fair Wild West Show to the biggest star of stage, talking pictures, radio and newspapers -- and a stab at Presidential candidacy in 1928, is cheerily chronicled. He was the Oklahoma Philosopher, the Droll Cowboy, the Sagebrush Sage, the Lariat King (as in "Poet Lariat") and America's Favorite Humorist. And we hear a fair dollop of apothegms: "A man makes a living by what he gets; he makes a life by what he gives."
In one jolting number, "Presents for Mrs. Rogers," a triple threat triumph for director, choreographer and costume designer, a promenade of glitter -- Ms. Kim at her showiest -- is abruptly halted by the announcement of the Depression: "a general economic collapse." The bejeweled new Ziegfeld girls are suddenly draped in burlap. Mr. Carradine's calming address (at President Hoover's request) about homelessness, unemployment and unjust distribution of wealth -- house lights up -- catches an audience off guard. It's 1931: an intrusion of conscience, in Rogers's very words, after the shakedown of the previous scene.
After such an infusion of social consciousness, an upbeat finale is actually more deserved than contrived. So here it is: Broadway showmanship at its most warming. Truly grand it is, giving momentary credence to the stock starry-eyed definition of musical comedy: the two most glorious words in the English language.
"The Will Rogers Follies" at the Shubert Theater, 247 College Street, New Haven; 624-1825. Remaining performances today and next Sunday at 2 and 7, Tuesday through Friday at 8, Saturday at 2 and 8.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The new Ziegfeld girls in touring company of "The Will Rogers Follies" in New Haven. (Martha Swope)

HEADLINE: The View From: Mansfield;
With the Loss of an Anchor, a Mall Looks for a Life Preserver

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
THE announcement that the 104-year-old Sage-Allen Department Store chain would be closing all its stores over the next several weeks will probably have its greatest impact at the East Brook Mall in Mansfield.
The mall already has several empty storefronts, and the closing of the 37,000-square-foot Sage-Allen store, which occupies about 15 percent of the mall's space, will create one of the highest vacancy rates in a Connecticut mall. 
 While the loss of one of the mall's two largest tenants (the other is Caldor) could force other smaller tenants out of business, there is also the possibility that a new tenant could reinvigorate the nearly 20-year-old mall, which has not fared well against the opening of regional malls within a 40-minute drive.
"It's going to do us a lot of harm," predicted Frank Prague, owner of two shoe stores in the mall and who also owns shops in 30 others. "We're going to lose a lot of traffic that the other stores depend on. The mall managers had better get that place rented."
But Mark A. Silvares, who opened his Hot Tees Custom Airbrushing shop on March 20, after the closing announcement, questioned how many customers a store like Sage-Allen was bringing in.
"A lot of the big stores aren't adapting to the economic time," Mr. Silvares said. "Even their best sales, with 20 or 30 percent off their regular prices, are no bargain. People are going to K-Mart and the other discounters."
"If we get one of those discounters in here, Sage-Allen's closing could actually help the mall," Mr. Silvares said. "They get the right tenant in there, and they'll bring a lot of new business in."
 
'Short-Term Negative Effect'
 Others, like Kevin M. Tubridy, who runs Tubridy's women's shop in the mall, are taking a wait-and-see attitude. He estimated that perhaps one in five of the customers at the mall come in to visit Sage-Allen and often stop by other stores while they are at East Brook. "It's going to have a short-term negative effect -- we'd be foolish not to acknowledge that," Mr. Tubridy said. "But if they can get a stronger tenant in there, it will benefit the rest of the mall in the long run."
Town officials in Mansfield, where the East Brook Mall has been one of the major taxpayers since its opening in the mid-1970's, have expressed their concern.
Gregory J. Padick, the town planner, said he had started working with the Windham Regional Planning Agency to develop a network of sidewalks, bikeways and bus stops that would serve nearby residents.
"We're talking about making it more accessible to the people who use the mall now, by making it easier for them to get there," Mr. Padick said. "I don't think these plans will bring any new customers to the mall."
Mr. Padick and others say it is important to take a realistic look at the mall. Because it draws from a shopping population of about 70,000 people in northeastern Connecticut, it will never attract a retailer like Bloomingdale's, which wants a draw of at least 250,000.
"We don't view ourselves as a regional mall," said Elizabeth Fourar-Laidi, director of marketing for the mall, which is managed by Landau and Heyman Inc. of Chicago. "We fill a particular need in this community, providing one-stop shopping close to home."
She said the mall was negotiating with several potential tenants for the space, a process that started months ago, when it was clear the chain was in financial trouble. She said she was hopeful of filling the Sage-Allen store before the Christmas shopping season.
 
Opportunity in New Tenant
 "Everyone's a little sad about the fact that Sage-Allen has been here since the mall opened, and now it's closing," Ms. Fourar-Laidi said. "But we also see it as an opportunity to bring in someone new and exciting."
She said that the closing at least came at a time when there were signs of an economic turnaround in the state; if Sage-Allen had pulled out three years ago the store might still be empty.
Sage-Allen, which employs 1,653 people at its eight stores in Connecticut and Massachusetts, is a subsidiary of Sage-Dey Inc., based in Syracuse, N.Y., which has been in bankruptcy since November.
The Connecticut stores to be closed are mostly at malls. Besides East Brook, there are Sage-Allen stores at the Buckland Hills Mall in Manchester, Farmington Valley Mall in Simsbury and Avon, the Hawley Lane Mall in Trumbull, and the Westfarms Mall in Farmington. There are free-standing stores in Old Saybrook and Wethersfield.
Allan R. Travis, a spokesman for Sage-Dey Inc., said all the closings were scheduled for early next month. The company has hired a broker to find substitute tenants for the stores it will be leaving.
"Once the liquidation process is complete, the buildings would be immediately available for new occupants," Mr. Travis said. "The process is going smoothly. We're negotiating with other stores that might be interested in their space, but nothing is at a point where we can talk about it."
 
In Business Since 1889
 Sage-Allen opened in Connecticut in 1889 in Hartford, selling soft goods like clothing, hosiery and linens. Top managers bought out the company from Sage-Allen Corp. in December 1987 with financing from GE Capital, an arm of General Electric Inc. In 1989 GE Capital provided additional funds to expand the store, then a year later it helped Sage-Allen hire a management team that set up the merger with the Addison-Dey chain.
In documents filed with the bankruptcy court, the department store chain determined that liquidation of the Sage-Allen stores was its best hope to pay off $48 million in debt to nearly 800 creditors.
The closings came as a bit of a surprise since Sage-Dey listed $54.2 million in assets on its bankruptcy papers and had originally said it would sell off the former Addison-Dey chain of department stores chain in upstate New York so it could keep the more financially healthy Sage-Allen stores open.
Anthony B. Zehnder, a spokesman for GE Capital, said the company did what it could.
"We worked with and supported Sage management in their attempt to find a way Sage could survive," Mr. Zehnder said. "Those efforts didn't work," so GE Capital helped Sage-Dey work out a plan that provided for maximum payout to employees and creditors, he said.
Retailing experts tend to agree with Mr. Zehnder that it would have been difficult, and expensive, to save Sage-Allen.
"What happened to Sage-Allen was years in coming," said Mary Ellen K. Brigham, a professor of marketing at the University of Connecticut School of Business Administration.
Sage-Allen was classified as a "junior department store," because it carried no hard lines, like furniture or large appliances. Those types of stores were strong from the 1950's to the 1970's in smaller community shopping centers, she said. While most other junior department stores grew up, Sage-Allen never abandoned its approach, she noted, thus, "Sage-Allen really didn't bring in any new customers, and that's where their troubles began."
Four or five years ago Sage-Allen tried to change its appeal, but it was too late, Dr. Brigham said. Also, Sage-Allen's technology was outdated. Modern retailing operations are computerized for quickest turnover of stock, and purchasing and warehousing are controlled tightly. Sage-Allen still did a lot of its record-keeping on paper.
 
Competitors Too Close for Profit
 It also hurts that East Brook is nestled between Buckland Hills and the Crystal Mall, each a short drive away, Dr. Brigham said, and that a new Wal-Mart store is coming into neighboring Windham.
"A place like East Brook is going to really have to be creative to get someone to take that real estate," Dr. Brigham said. "As far as a big department store going in there, it's not going to happen."
The mall managers would do better looking for a discount shop or general merchandiser like a Filene's Basement, a Marshall's, or a T. J. Maxx, she said. At Vernon's Tri-City Mall, Sage-Allen left during a retrenchment three years ago, and T. J. Maxx took over, she said, and now that mall is doing better than ever.
Clearly, the East Brook Mall could use a boost. Shoppers entering from the south must walk by a dark, empty restaurant that has a warning of a sheriff's tax seizure posted in foreboding black block letters on the window. Inside, four other stores are closed, including the Fleet Bank office that closed in November 1991.
 
Only One Restaurant Left
 There is only one concourse shop, where there were several in the mid-1980's boom time. And there is only one restaurant left, a pizza parlor, where shoppers only a few years ago had their choice of three.
Mr. Prague, who runs the two shoe stores at East Brook, said many of the newer tenants were single-shop operations, which rely heavily on the advertising budgets of the anchor tenants to draw customers.
"There are merchants in here who are right on the brink," Mr. Prague said. "They're not going to last that long."
Others were not so pessimistic. Darryl J. Lowen, manager of the General Nutrition Center in the mall, which opened last year, said Sage-Allen's dwindling customer base hurt everyone.
"Someone's going to come in who's going to appeal to a wider customer base," Mr. Lowen said. "I'm not all that upset at this point. The only thing I'm concerned about are the Sage-Allen employees. But for the other shops, it won't be long before we're recovered."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Shoppers, top, at the Sage-Allen Department Store that will soon be closing at the East Brook Mall in Mansfield. The mall has several empty stores, center. (Photographs by Steve Miller for The New York Times)
