HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Newspapers Redefining Themselves

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GLABERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, April 25

 BODY:
The publishers of the nation's major newspapers are meeting here today and this is some of what they are talking about: selling advertising in telephone books and using new technology to supply soap opera updates.
Many publishers have found that they cannot make as much money as they were accustomed to making the old-fashioned way, so across the country they are entering businesses that are sometimes so far from the traditional that they barely involve news -- or even, for that matter, paper. 
 Newspapers are supplying marketing services, helping race tracks and pizza delivery companies, for example, select readers who might be interested in a wagering afternoon or a pie with anchovies. Newspapers are direct-delivery agencies that compete with the post office, they are sellers of faxes, sources of personal-computer data, printers of special-interest magazines and publishers of telephone books that compete for advertising with the listings by the phone company.
Nearly a third of all major newspapers are now "audiotext" suppliers, letting telephone callers dial up not only news and weather, but also classified ads read by a computerized voice, stock-market information, loan rates, race results, lottery numbers and soap opera updates. (Press "1" to find out how Mimi's pregnancy is going and whether Lee declared her love for Terry).
"We are at the beginning of a time when the newspaper as it is historically viewed will take on a broader role," said Cathleen Black, the president of the Newspaper Association of America, the publishers' trade organization, which is holding its annual convention here. "It doesn't only have to be a traditional newspaper as we know it."
The new newspaper ventures began largely when advertising plummeted during the recession. Though most newspapers now say business is better, there is general agreement that some types of advertising are probably gone forever. Without changes, many in the industry say, newspapers will never return to the profit levels of the mid-1980's.
Few of the new ventures are big money makers yet, but most offer promise. Many of the 465 newspaper audiotext systems in operation work, for example, by encouraging readers to make free telephone calls to listen to recorded messages that follow 15-second paid commercials. The Washington Post says its three-year-old Post Haste telephone system getss 800,000 calls a month.
 
Loss of Focus?
 As newspapers adapt to the new enterprises, they are changing sharply as commercial and journalistic institutions. In the process, some in the industry fear, newspaper people risk losing track of a once-popular notion that advertising was merely the means to the end of disseminating information, not the end itself.
The flood of new ventures, some of the critics say, has created a dangerous shift in priorities at many newspapers. Instead of gathering information only because it might interest readers, many newspapers now gather information, like Government records and data on reader preferences, with the hope of reselling it.
"It is dangerous to the kind of public-interest journalism we are obliged to practice if we accept the protection of the First Amendment," said Bill Kovach, the curator of the Nieman Foundation for journalists at Harvard University. "There is the risk that the news decisions are made on the value of the information for resale, rather than on the value of the information to the reader."
But many publishers say the objective is not merely to return to what were unusually high financial returns of the 1980's. They say long-term trends indicate that many newspapers must fight to keep their business niches or they will wither.
For years there have been steady signs of declining reader interest in many newspapers, although there are some that continually increase their circulation despite business trends. Also, because of such changes as the demise of big retailers and the growth of new advertising vehicles like cable television and direct mail, many newspaper advertisers have simply vanished.
Some publishers say many of their new businesses, like selling marketing information about readers and local residents, are needed to enhance demand for advertising. "The demand is dropping -- demand for basic, plain-vanilla newspaper advertising," said W. Stacey Cowles, publisher of The Spokesman-Review in Spokane, Wash. "We're not selling space anymore. We're really trying to find marketing solutions for our customers."
 
Newspaper as Marketer
 For the last decade or so large media conglomerates have been investing in new media services and exploring new ways of selling information.
The Spokesman-Review, owned by Mr. Cowles's family, recently helped a local store turn premium dog food into a hot item with a marketing scheme that newspaper executives say is likely to become popular.
Northwest Feed wanted to sell dog food. From a computer, Mr. Cowles's staff produced information gleaned from a reader survey that identified 10,000 Spokesman-Review readers who were dog lovers.
The dog-loving newspaper subscribers then received letters alerting them to watch for newspaper ads with coupons and get-your-pet-photographed offers. Northwest Feed told Mr. Cowles that it won 600 new customers and was persuaded that The Spokesman-Review knew how to tap its market.
Across the country, Pizza Hut has been especially active in using such newspaper marketing programs.
Newspaper executives say they hope to increase revenues. But many say that even if the new ventures only produce modest profits in the short run, newspapers cannot afford not to start them.
If newspapers allow other businesses, like telephone companies or national marketing companies, to erode their position as the primary supplier of information to communities, they say, newspapers could lose their special place forever.
"I'm going to be No. 1 in my city in providing information, so nobody else can come in and take this away from me," said Tim Gallagher, editor of The Albuquerque Tribune.
For the last three years, Mr. Gallagher's newspaper, like about a dozen others in the country, has been supplying what it calls an "electronic supplement to the newspaper" -- a data service accesssible by personal computer that gives readers access to volumes of information not printed in the newspaper.
In addition to full texts of news wire services purchased by the newspaper, Electronic Tribune subscribers can read old restaurant and movie reviews, drunken-driving court records and information on local landlord-tenant disputes.
 
New Alliances With Old Rivals
 The new business climate is prompting newspaper people to shelve old rivalries and stretch old rules. For example, in a once unthinkable practice, some newspapers are now forging alliances with their old television and radio enemies.
The Sarasota Herald-Tribune, owned by The New York Times Company, has a new pact with the local ABC television station under which the newspaper supplies the station with some of its following day's articles. When the station uses the news, it advises viewers to pick up the next day's Herald-Tribune for a fuller account.
In an arrangement that was opposed by some journalists, Milwaukee newspaper readers this winter received added coverage of professional hockey and indoor soccer. The Milwaukee Journal and Sentinel, its spokesman, Bob Dye, said, promised half a page a week of new coverage for each of those sports after the two local professional teams complained about lack of coverage.
The newspaper, Mr. Dye said, promised to add that coverage if the two teams would each buy a half-page of advertising every week. "To be an independent successful publisher," Mr. Dye said, "you need advertising. But we're not succumbing to advertiser pressure."
 
Building Good Will
 To be sure, many of the new ventures offer newspapers opportunities to polish their images. In Evansville, Ind., The Courier is proud of Schnucks' Homework Hotline, which uses the newspaper's audiotext system to give parents the chance to check by telephone on their children's homework assignments. Schnucks, "the friendliest stores in town and your food for thought," paid for the audiotext message and every teacher in town now has a voice mailbox on The Courier's system to report on class assignments.
The Courier also ran a marketing and advertising campaign for a local race track. The campaign included instant race results on The Courier's telephone system and traditional newspaper advertising. In addition, people the newspaper's data base identified as interested in racing received on their doorsteps packages of reduced-admission coupons and promotional material.
When asked, The Courier's editor and president, Thomas W. Tuley, said he had never considered whether such close public identification of the newspaper with its advertisers might erode the newspaper's independent voice. He said the new services were not much different from the simpler display advertising that newspapers have always carried.
But Mr. Tuley said it was clear that the long-term trends showed business growth to be nearly impossible for newspapers that refused to change.
"As a business, if you're not growing, you're going backward," Mr. Tuley said. "Do you keep taking steps backward? And if you do, when do you go out of business?"

HEADLINE: Perot Urges Calls to Clinton Denouncing Economic Plans

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, April 25

 BODY:
In a technique reminiscent of President Ronald Reagan in the first months of his Administration, Ross Perot issued an appeal tonight for Americans to flood the White House and Congress with telephone messages opposing President Clinton's policies on taxes, health care and military cuts.
Mr. Perot made his appeal at the conclusion of a 30-minute appearance he bought on NBC. 
 He provided the telephone numbers for the White House and Congress, and said, "You've got to keep calling until you get through because this is really important."
Mr. Reagan, in selling his first budget against a Democratic majority in the House, went on national television with charts and a pointer, and urged Americans to flood their representatives and senators with telephone calls and telegrams. The tactic was effective, and Mr. Reagan got his way.
 
Complaints of Spending
 Intensifying the harshness of his attack on the Clinton Administration, Mr. Perot accused the President of misleading voters. He cited spending increases in Mr. Clinton's budget that the Administration estimates will raise the Federal debt by $900 billion, to $5 trillion, by 1996; the mentions of a new national tax, the value-added tax, as one way of paying for a revised health-care system, and the proposed jobs-creation program, which Mr. Perot estimated would cost taxpayers $89,000 for each new job.
Mr. Perot was the only speaker on the prerecorded program. An NBC spokesman said tonight he could not find out how much the network charged for the 30 minutes, but a half-hour that Mr. Perot bought on NBC on March 21 cost $500,000.
Mr. Perot appealed to viewers to contribute $15 to his organization, United We Stand America, and said,, "The money is spent on programs like this."
 
Wants Debt Reduced
 Reprising themes from his Presidential campaign last year, Mr. Perot made sweeping assertions about Americans' desire to curb Government spending and cut the Federal deficit. "The problem is not going away," he said. "It's getting worse."
He declared that most Americans would accept higher taxes only if the money were committed to reducing the Federal debt, which exceeded $4 trillion last year and which, he said, continues to rise by $1 billion a day.
He derided Mr. Clinton's economic plans, saying the Administration did not know how it could pare the military budget by 20 percent. "They just pulled the number out of the air and now they're trying to put it together in a rational way," he said. "That's not the way you do business, folks."
He said the Clinton White House, like the Administrations of Mr. Reagan and George Bush in the previous 12 years, was bending to the demands of foreign and domestic lobbyists "and other special interests who paid for their last campaigns."

HEADLINE: STRICTLY BUSINESS;
Barnes & Noble Superstore Prompts Volumes of Worry

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN

 BODY:
Not for nothing did the writer and Nobel laureate Isaac Bashevis Singer spend most of his life on the Upper West Side. From Lincoln Center in the south to Columbia University in the north, the neighborhood has long crackled with the passions, ideas, disagreements and noises defining the intellectual life of America's largest city.
From the perspective of one of the nation's top booksellers, the message emerging from all this cacophony could not be more distinct. 
 "The Upper West Side is clearly one of the best markets for books in all of America," said Leonard Riggio, chief executive of Barnes & Noble Bookstores, which on Friday will open a block-long, architecturally striking store offering 225,000 books, free gift-wrapping and an espresso bar, on Broadway between 82d and 83d Streets, in the heart of the neighborhood. "I have never been more excited about a store opening."
 
Other Booksellers Scrambling
 Not everyone shares his enthusiasm. Owners, workers and some customers of Shakespeare & Company, the idiosyncratically sprawling bookstore a block away, are seething, and other neighborhood book merchants are scrambling for retaliatory strategies. And residents feel torn between their loyalty to the existing neighborhood stores and excitement over Barnes & Noble's immense selection and steep discounts.
"I hope that Shakespeare doesn't close," said Jeanette Rausch, a city economic development official who lives nearby and loves to browse for books. "But I'll probably end up going there less."
What is happening on the Upper West Side is part of a sea change in the way Americans sell and buy books. In less than two years, Barnes & Noble and the Kmart Corporation, operating through its Waldenbooks and Borders chains, have salted the nation with what are called "superstores," bringing to books the same revolution Toys "R" Us and The Home Depot have brought to other segments of the retail business.
Mr. Riggio says the effect will be to raise sagging national literacy levels within a decade. "People who are predisposed to buying books will buy more books in a greatly expanded book space," he said. "These stores create the idea of the importance of books, of possessing books."
But skeptics predict that such stores will force hundreds of independent bookstores out of business, giving Americans fewer choices and leaving publishers at the mercy of a few very large buyers.
"It would be disingenuous to say there is not a lot of anxiety out there," said Charles Robinson, the owner of an independent bookstore in Bellingham, Wash., and president of the American Booksellers Association, whose members include both Barnes & Noble and Shakespeare.
It is difficult to predict how such a megastore will fare in the singular environs of the Upper West Side. The giant Zabar's at 80th and Broadway, a fiercely independent purveyor of gustatory temptation, does a booming business year-in and year-out. But Kiddie City Toys, a block away at 79th Street, died early this year despite the seeming advantage of being located in an area bustling with young children.
The 32,000-square-foot Barnes & Noble store at 2289 Broadway is one of 135 so-called superstores that the company has opened in the last two years as part of a careful strategy of offering amenities to encourage more customers to linger, and thus increase the chances of making a sale.
The store will carry 1,500 magazines and newspapers, offer a children's theater and be decorated in gold leaf wallpaper. Gift-wrapping will be free, and customers will be welcome to lounge all day in Shaker-style furniture, even as they sip cappuccino and peruse $100 art books. Titles will be discounted at least 10 percent and some as much as 80 percent.
Despite its size, the Broadway store will still be smaller than Barnes & Noble's flagship store on Fifth Avenue at 18th Street, the world's largest bookstore at 154,250 square feet.
 
A Direct Challenge
 To the people at Shakespeare & Company, so named for the legendary Paris book emporium whose owner first published James Joyce's "Ulysses," those kinds of amenities are a direct challenge to their store's existence. Although Shakespeare has over the years spread into adjoining and overhead spaces, growing from perhaps 800 square feet to nearly 6,000 square feet in 12 years of existence, its owners fear the new superstore will be too big and too dominant. It is, they say, entirely different from the two small Barnes & Noble shops that long competed nearby, the nearest of which is across the street from the new store and will now close.
"The big monster bully store is here to knock us out," said David Wetter, Shakespeare's mass market buyer. "On a gut level, I want them to go away and leave us alone."
Some customers feel the same way. "I can't imagine that I would not come to Shakespeare anymore," said Katie Fraser, a graduate student in comparative literature at City University of New York. "They have more of the unusual things that I would be looking for, like literary criticism and poetry journals."
But others in the neighborhood welcome the new store. "I'm happy," said Ronald Bario, a special education instructor at a junior high nearby. "More books, more intellectuality."
Ernest Fernandez, a computer designer who likes books on life in other galaxies, said: "I spend a fortune in bookstores. This is fabulous."
 
Trend Toward Giant Stores
 Experts say the growth of what Mr. Riggio calls "complete and unabridged" stores is part of a nationwide trend away from conventional shopping malls and toward giant stores that offer huge selection and discount prices.
The result, said Bill Kurland, one of two brothers who owns Shakespeare, is "the Wal-Marting of America," the phenomenon of chain-store culture and values that he says has spread to "even the streets of New York."
Other bookstores in the neighborhood are also watching the new store and making plans to respond. At the elegant Endicott Booksellers at 4500 Columbus Avenue, between 81st and 82d Streets, Encarnita Quinlan, the owner, said she viewed the newcomer with "trepidation" and was prepared to expand, eliminate or strengthen whole departments.
"I see why a person would walk a block for a $10 discount," she said.
At Eeyore's Books for Children at 2212 Broadway, between 78th and 79th Streets, a special 25 percent-off sale will be offered on all books to coincide with Barnes & Noble's opening. But the owner, Joel Framm, said he doubts a chain store can match his meticulous service, which occasionally includes advising customers against particular purchases. "Buyers of children's books will suffer," he said.
By contrast, Gryphon Bookshop at 2246 Broadway, between 80th and 81st Streets, which specializes in antiquarian titles, welcomes the Barnes & Noble superstore. Tony DePauw, the day manager, said, "It will make this even more of a book neighborhood."
 
Asking for Suggestions
 Shakespeare itself is responding by encouraging its sometimes brusque clerks to be friendlier, something some customers say is overdue. "It's sort of big and impersonal and they don't do much to warm it up," said Alan Brinkley, a Columbia history professor who said he had spent upward of $1,000 there.
Indeed, Ruth Liebmann, a Shakespeare manager, has been asking customers what the store can do to improve. One was still smarting over the time a clerk corrected his pronunciation of Proust five years ago, while another suggested additions to "the Mom table," made up of books suitable as gifts to mothers.
"They're Upper West Siders and they all have dislikes," Ms. Liebmann said with a smile.
Barnes & Noble is attacking the neighborhood with near-abandon. Area authors and poets have been invited to read months into the future. Peter, Paul and Mary, Tom Paxton and others have been booked to perform free concerts. Events are being set up with such local cultural institutions as Symphony Space.
The question hanging over all the anxiety is whether the superstore can coexist with its neighbors. "It remains to be seen how much the market will be expanded, and when there will be a shakeout," said Mr. Robinson, the booksellers president. "Shakespeare may find it difficult to draw the same traffic."
For his part, Mr. Riggio says studies show that 70 percent of the business generated in superstores, even those with close neighbors, is new. "The size itself creates sales," he said.
His point seems at least partly supported by the experience of several major independent stores in other parts of the country. The Tattered Cover in Denver, a 40,000-square-foot bookstore than began in a single room 17 years ago, has seen its sales increase despite being surrounded by five Barnes & Noble superstores.
"Would our sales have gone up even more if they weren't there?" asked Pat Gunckel, general manager. "We don't know, but we're not hurting."

HEADLINE: A Fare Card For Transit Is Lagging

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON

 BODY:
Installing computerized fare boxes in New York City's buses at the same time that computerized turnstiles were being put into subway stations once seemed like a good idea to transit officials. But it is no longer a feasible one.
Metrocard, the plastic fare-card system that is expected to replace tokens, is still scheduled to debut in a few subway stations in December and to be operating in 69 stations by the time it is formally introduced next March. 
 But putting automated fare collection equipment aboard the city's 3,450 buses will not be completed until late 1995, according to a report by the Transit Authority that was released last week. That is a full year later than was predicted in January.
 
New Fare Box Needed
 The principal snag, officials said, is the need to redesign, retest and retool a new fare box. Flaws were found in the design and the reliability of a sample fare box tested on the Bx55 line in the South Bronx between October and January, and a new prototype is being built by the Cubic Corporation, the San Diego-based company that is also making the turnstiles.
"There are some fairly substantial design changes that we need," said Charles J. Broshaus Jr., senior vice president for operations support. "That's going to take time."
The new model will require a rider to insert the fare card into a slot in the box, where it will be ingested, read electronically and expelled. Originally, planners favored a model with an open slot through which a rider would swipe the card, like some supermarket credit-card readers.
The new machines are scheduled to be tested in the summer of 1994. Some bus depots and buses will be equipped to use Metrocard by April 1995, according to the current schedule, and installation will be completed by the end of that year.
 
Delay in Discounts
 That could be accelerated by up to nine months, Mr. Broshaus said, if the Transit Authority decides to begin ordering parts for the fare boxes before all of the necessary modifications are known, on the assumption that any changes would be minor. That would entail some financial risk for the agency, however, if it were later determined that major changes were again needed.
The disparity between Metrocard's starting dates for the subway and buses, Mr. Broshaus conceded, means a delay in conveniently granting discounts to riders who transfer between systems. Many now pay two fares, or $2.50 each way, to get to or from work, something officials have said they hope to eliminate through use of the Metrocard.
The additional work needed to solve the glitch in the fare boxes, and other problems, such as delays in deliveries, is expected to cost $20.7 million, the Transit Authority report said.
Even with that, Mr. Broshaus said, the overall cost of installing the system by 1997 is now estimated to be $660 million, or $30 million less than was budgeted. Most of the saving is due to lower-than-expected inflation, he said.
But one of the most sensitive issues connected to Metrocard -- how much it will cost riders -- is yet to be resolved.
One possibility is for a Metrocard to allow an unlimited number of rides for a single price, like a weekly or monthly pass. Another configuration would be a stored value card, with a set price, and charges deducted as each trip is taken. A variation would allow Metrocard users to pay different fares during peak and off-peak hours.
A survey on possible pricing schemes is scheduled to be completed in June. The results will be presented to the board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the Transit Authority's parent organization, which could adopt any or all of the possibilities, officials said.
Another unpredictable factor in Metrocard pricing is the possibility of a fare increase in 1995, when the automated fare system is partially operating. Earlier this month, New York State leaders agreed to preserve the $1.25 fare in 1993 and 1994, but left open the possibility of an increase in 1995.

HEADLINE: No Quick Gain From Stronger Yen

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration is proclaiming the dollar's latest plunge against the yen as a windfall for America -- one that should finally shrink the nation's painful trade deficit with Japan. "The stronger yen is the best single thing that could have happened to the trade deficit," a senior Administration official said last week.
But improvement is not likely to come quickly, even though a stronger yen pushes up the price of Japanese goods sold in United States while enabling American products to be sold for less in Japan. Indeed, the yen might have to stay strong for two years or more, many experts say, to have much impact on American-Japanese trade. The reason is that both American and Japanese companies are resisting any adjustment in prices to reflect the changing values of their currencies. 
 Cooper Industries, for example, exports spark plugs and crankshafts to Japan, but as with many American companies, Cooper says it will not cut the yen prices of its products.
Robert Cizik, chairman of Cooper as well as the National Association of Manufacturers, explains why Cooper will not act, and therefore why a change in the trade deficit will be slow to be realized.
"Japanese companies don't change relationships with their suppliers that fast," he said. "And these currency changes are temporary. You may get aberrations from time to time, as we are getting now. But the customer relationship has to be based on quality and delivery, as well as price."
But the stronger yen and weaker dollar certainly give American companies a pricing advantage in their competition with the Japanese, if the companies want to use it. In two months, the dollar has fallen 11 percent against the yen, to 110 yen to the dollar, compared with 124 in February. At 110, the level is the lowest since World War II. That means that an American-made spark plug sold in Japan for 124 yen now brings the manufacturer $1.11, rather than the $1 collected in February. That leaves room to cut the yen price, which could increase sales in Japan.
The Japanese, conversely, must raise dollar prices in the United States to collect the same number of yen once the dollars are exchanged for the Japanese currency.
 
Some Raising Prices
 A few companies, including Honda and Nissan, announced price increases this month. Honda, for example, added $100 to $450 to the sticker prices of its various models, most of them assembled in the United States with some parts made in Japan. And in Tempe, Ariz., Mother Board Warehouse Inc., which distributes computer components, raised the price of memory chips from Japan by 10 percent, to $40 to $45 apiece.
"Any computer with Japanese memory chips -- and that is many computers -- is likely to go up in price," said Alan Gifford, Mother Board's sales manager.
But most Japanese companies, including the giant Matsushita Electric Corporation, say they are reluctant to raise prices, fearful that higher prices might reduce sales. At Matsushita, whose Panasonic VCR's and video cameras are exported to the United States, James Reilly, a corporate spokesman, said, "If the current trend continues in the yen-dollar exchange rate, price hikes on some products might be inevitable, but there are no plans for such hikes yet."
 
Counting on Yen's Strength
 Nevertheless, the Clinton Administration is counting on the yen's strength to shrink a trade deficit with Japan that rose to $50 billion last year from $44.3 billion in 1991 -- mostly because of a spurt in Japanese imports. Administration officials even cite a trade theory that says that for every 1 percent increase in the value of the yen, Japan's trade deficit will eventually decline by $5 billion.
The Boeing Company's transactions with Japan tend to support this theory. Boeing prices the planes it sells to Japan in dollars, not yen. So now the fall in the value of the dollar means that the Japanese can spend less in yen to buy the dollars to buy the planes.
"We sell planes under long-term negotiated contracts, and we don't expect any impact on prices from the latest currency changes," said Paul Binder, a Boeing spokesman. Boeing, the nation's single biggest exporter, sold the Japanese $2.5 billion in commercial airliners last year, or 5 percent of total American exports to Japan in 1992. The shipments to Japan will be similarly large this year -- and less costly to the Japanese in yen, which could encourage them to buy more planes.
But Clinton Administration officials say that the exchange rate advantage is not sufficient by itself to solve the United States trade deficit and that political pressure needs to be used to open Japan to specific American products and to try to get Japan to change rules that are barriers to trade and foreign investment. Talks on these subjects are scheduled for July, Administration officials said.
The Japanese Government, also concerned about the American trade deficit, waited until last week before it finally reacted to the rising value of the yen. The Bank of Japan bought big quantities of dollars in an attempt to strengthen the dollar's value, and a bank official criticized the Clinton Administration for encouraging the appreciation of the yen. But some Japanese find a silver lining in the yen's rise.
"The stronger yen will not solve the trade gap with Japan, but it may reduce the public pressure" on the Clinton Administration to take action to open the Japanese market, said Michiharu Maeda, a vice president of Adi-Ichi Life International Inc., an insurance company with an investment office in New York.
 
Japanese Investing Less
 The yen's appreciation has come almost by chance since Mr. Clinton took office, and involves several factors. With the Tokyo stock market rising again, Americans and Europeans have been buying yen to buy Japanese stocks, a process that bolsters the yen. The Japanese, on the other hand, are no longer offsetting this process by buying dollars in huge quantities to invest in United States Treasury securities, in new factories and in real estate in the United States.
Also driving up the yen is the Japanese Government's recent announcement that it will spend more than $100 billion on public works and other projects to stimulate the economy. That has created the expectation that Japan's economy will grow more robustly and that Japanese interest rates will rise to control inflation.
The higher rates, in turn, make yen investments more attractive. And "that is happening just as our economy appears to have weakened, putting downward pressure on interest rates in the United States, and making American investments less attractive," said Henry Kaufman, an economic consultant.
In the late 1970's and again in the late 1980's, the dollar fell sharply against the yen. But each time, the dollar also declined against the German mark and against other European currencies. That brought the danger of rising inflation, partly from price increases for goods imported from Europe and Japan. To avoid inflation and strengthen the dollar, the Federal Reserve Board raised interest rates, which as a side effect, slowed the American economy.
 
'Orderly Rise' Seen
 While Japanese imports totaled $96.9 billion last year, that is not a large enough part of the huge American economy to have much impact on the inflation rate. With only the yen involved, the Administration seems willing to sit tight.
"We are not facing a generalized rapid decline of the dollar, but an orderly rise in the yen against not only the dollar but every major currency," said C. Fred Bergsten, director of the Institute for International Economics. "That is a huge difference from what happened to the dollar in the 70's and 80's."
Some economists, among them Martin Feldstein of Harvard University, argue that a strong enough yen will by itself correct the trade deficit with Japan -- once the dollar drops to 100 yen or less. But others, like Mr. Bergsten, say that as the dollar has fallen in value, Japanese companies have found ways to cut costs and improve efficiency, thus avoiding major price increases for exported products. One method has been to shift some labor-intensive production to low-wage Asian countries.
American exports did double in the late 1980's, as the dollar fell in value against the yen. But partly as a result of the efficiencies achieved by the Japanese, imports from Japan also rose sharply -- and the trade deficit, which was $43.5 billion in 1985, was still roughly at that level when the decade closed.

HEADLINE: Review/Theater: Blood Brothers;
Separated at Birth, Mainly by Social Class

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH

 BODY:
Hardened New York theatergoers who expect British musicals to hit town powered by big bucks, Technicolor spectacle and deafening amplification may be taken aback by "Blood Brothers," the latest West End export to reach Broadway. "Blood Brothers" opens with a tableau of its title characters laid out as corpses. The eveninglong flashback to follow unfolds largely in the dank brick welfare housing of depressed northern England. The offstage band is small and tinny enough to hold forth in a garage. There is not much dancing, or, for that matter, much to dance about.
Which is just how Willy Russell, the author of the show's book, music and lyrics, wants it. First produced in London in 1983, "Blood Brothers" is a Thatcher-era attack on the British class system that wears its austerity on its sleeve, bourgeois frills be damned. Mr. Russell, the Liverpool-born author of "Educating Rita" and "Shirley Valentine," would rather be sincere than slick. His musical has the rough-hewn proletarian flavor of British dramas of the angry-man era of the late 1950's and early 60's, and that authentic chips-with-everything spirit has been transferred to the snug Music Box Theater without any infusions of Broadway glitz. 
 Whether the appealing, pungent atmosphere will carry less class-conscious Americans through the musical's nearly three hours is another question. "West Side Story" this is not. Easy as it is to like "Blood Brothers" on egalitarian principle, it is rousing theater only in spurts. Mr. Russell milks a melodramatic tale peopled with agitprop characters exclusively for didactic ends. His score is tuneful (and impressive coming from an essentially amateur composer) but spread thin. One song, typically, has four reprises, and even so the evening seems to have too little music and too much talk.
At center stage is a heroine like Mr. Russell's Rita and Shirley: a woman ground down by economic deprivation and men. Mrs. Johnstone (Stephanie Lawrence), as she is called, is a single mother of nine who decides to give up one of her new twin babies to a wealthy woman (Barbara Walsh) for whom she cleans house. The boys, who later become best friends without learning that they're brothers, grow up on separate social tracks that eventually lead to a tragic reckoning seemingly inspired by "Carousel."
But not before the author pounds in his deterministic conviction that nurture always wins out over nature, that the rich brother (Mark Michael Hutchinson) is inevitably bound for success while his impoverished counterpart (Con O'Neill) is destined for the skids. Such is the rigidity of the show's simplistic ideological scheme that the rich mother is barren and her husband (Ivar Brogger) asexual while the poor folks all radiate fecundity and erotic swagger.
As indulgently directed by Bill Kenwright and Bob Tomson, "Blood Brothers" seems to be pitched at audiences with time on their hands, tourists perhaps. Mr. Russell makes each plot point several times, with the utilitarian dialogue, songs and doom-laden narrator (Warwick Evans) all chiming in. (Should anyone's mind wander, the most portentous lines are italicized by drum beats, growling synthesizer chords and lurid lighting cues.) Both acts come to dead halts for completely excisable sequences of child's play that seem to exist only to jolly up British matinee audiences eternally nostalgic for "Oliver!" In Act I, the neighborhood children, cloyingly played by adult actors portraying 7-year-olds as if they were toddlers, act out attenuated games with cap pistols and slingshots. In Act II, the same lengthy attention is devoted to the now teen-age characters' first fumbling forays into puppy love.
The scenes that actually advance Mr. Russell's plot are more often enlivened by his music, which recalls both old-time Liverpudlian rock and American country, than by the banal lyrics about bright new days and long Sunday afternoons. (An opening-number simile about Marilyn Monroe is pushed into inanity by overuse by evening's end.) The performers, British and American alike, all sing and act forcefully, even when, like Ms. Walsh, they must animate the most abject caricatures. Mr. Evans's prophet-of-doom turn as the narrator boasts an insinuating Macheath quality, and Mr. O'Neill and Mr. Hutchinson bond as sympathetic brothers once they are allowed to play roughly their own age. Jan Graveson is a fine Shirley Valentine-in-waiting as the feisty young woman who loves them both.
Ms. Lawrence played the sad mother for two years in the 1988 West End revival of "Blood Brothers," which is still running. She lacks the touchingly frayed warmth that the pop singer Barbara Dickson brought to the original production. But she is a clarion belter in the West End manner of Elaine Paige, and her saintly, bone-weary survivor's smile is the very soul of a musical that reveres underdogs as unequivocally as its splashier London competitor canonizes cats.

HEADLINE: Essay;
1st Quarter Report

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The White House press office provided, at taxpayer expense, a handy-dandy guide to the first 100 days of the Clinton Administration, while the President went to Boston to press his 100-days defense on the nation's newspaper publishers.
I refuse to be so manipulated by an arbitrary number; instead, here is my "take," as with-it pundits say, on the first of the 16 quarters of Mr. Clinton's term. 
 1. The Fraud That Didn't Fly. With audacity and flair, the new President persuaded a majority of the public to accept higher taxes to reduce the deficit -- and then, in a classic bait-and-switch, proceeded to apply the anticipated new taxes to more spending.
"Double-cross!" shouted those of us who half-believed his promises of being a new-kind Democrat who would reform welfare and not further burden the middle class. His Election-Day conversion to liberal economics went down well with editorialists delighted with the unexpected plan to redistribute wealth, but in time reality dawned on sold-out centrists: not only was the deficit not to be cut in half, but even more new taxes were to be demanded for a huge health-care subsidy.
The Senate minority found itself representing majority opinion in the nation, which enabled reunited Republicans to block spending that would deepen the deficit. After the first big budget battle was won by filibuster, Ross Perot came galloping on the field last weekend to shoot the liberal wounded.
The leftward lurch of the new President's economic proposal was a historic miscalculation; Clinton, who thinks it was merely a mistake in tactics, still doesn't get it: Americans are prepared to sacrifice for the next generation by reducing the deficit, not for this generation by continuing it.
2. He Goes Home With the Partner What Brung Him. On the issue of abortion, which caused so many defections in Republican ranks, Clinton moved with alacrity to deliver on all his promises. He remembered, too, how homosexuals fervently supported his candidacy, and has done all that can reasonably be expected to associate himself with their causes.
Loyalty has its costs. Feminist leaders have short memories; homosexual activists focus on the shortcomings of those in power; and the desire to accommodate Friends of Bill and Hillary has led to delays in making appointments -- even the Justice Department's Criminal Division remains headless.
3. The Comeback Kid Rides Again. Clinton showed in his first quarter an ability to get up off the floor: his sobriquet may be The Great Recoverer.
His first formal news conference was a flop; not having done his homework, he was both overconfident and uncertain. But his second was much improved, notwithstanding his throat trouble, with a memorable passage about "real debates over ideas" and his wish to "open the floodgates for debating these ideas." That moving justification for experimentation should have been his answer to Mary McGrory's softball about his assessment of the 100 days, instead of the laundry list he memorized.
He quickly recovered, too, from having gone A.W.O.L. after the Waco disaster. His Attorney General de jure, having acquiesced in the wrong judgment, became St. Janet overnight by saying "The buck ends on my desk" when of course it ends on the President's.
Anybody with political savvy could have told him that the best way to get people to say "It wasn't really your fault" is to insist gallantly, "I take full responsibility." The most important job his wife has is to spot and stop his tendency to flinch from responsibility; Hillary failed him this time.
4. Awesome Burden Time. Clinton marshaled allied support for Boris Yeltsin, which George Bush failed to do, but he matched his predecessor in dithering about the Serbian rape of Bosnia. That handwringing about military "compellance" (sometimes spelled "compellence" on the analogy of "deterrence") is to end this week, after the sweeping Yeltsin referendum victory -- if the Serbs don't blink.
Then we will see if Clinton acts incrementally or resolutely. He will have to choose between apologizing for having to take a painful, limited action, or forthrightly calling a free people to a moral cause. The way he rallies compatriots to costly world leadership, and not the way he got his sea legs in the White House, will be the first true measure of his young Presidency.

HEADLINE: A Value-Added Tax;
It Could Pay for a Health-Care Plan And Then Some, but the Hurdles Are High

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 19

 BODY:
The value-added tax being considered by the Clinton Administration faces challenges beyond the political ones. It would also be difficult to set up, expensive to administer and hard to make equitable, because it would hit poor Americans hardest.
But, boy, what a revenue raiser. 
 The vast sums that such a consumption tax -- akin to a national sales tax -- would rake in make it alluring to an Administration that is scrounging for revenues for its health-care plan, which the President's aides say could cost $30 billion to $90 billion a year.
Two weeks ago, the Administration acknowledged that it was considering a value-added tax, and since then many political analysts have said it would face an uphill battle in Congress if it was included as a revenue-raising measure in the President's health-care plan.
According to the Congressional Budget Office, a 5 percent value-added tax would, if placed on all goods and services, raise more than $100 billion a year. At that level, such a tax not only would handily underwrite the Administration's health plan but would also be a potent tool to cut the budget deficit. A small increase in the tax, to 6 percent from 5 percent, could cut the deficit by an additional $20 billion to $25 billion a year.
Any of the many revenue options being considered to pay for the health plan are bound to meet resistance. But a value-added tax would have to surmount one more sizable hurdle: Many Democrats fault such a tax as regressive, hitting high-income households more lightly than other Americans as a percentage of income.
Because the poor spend such a high percentage of their income on basic consumption, the 20 percent of households with the lowest income would pay three times as high a percentage of their income in a value-added tax as the richest fifth of Americans, according to a study by the Congressional Budget Office. Households in the lowest 20 percent would pay 4.8 percent of their income in a 5 percent value-added tax, while those in the highest quintile would pay 1.5 percent.
"The biggest opponents of a consumption tax are the left wing and the right wing -- the left yells it is regressive, and the right yells that it is a money tree for Big Government," said David A. Berenson, national director of tax policy at Ernst & Young.
Most economists, however, like a value-added tax, saying it would help tilt the economy away from its consumption binge and toward increased saving and investment. This, they say, should ultimately raise the nation's long-term growth rate.
A value-added tax is imposed on businesses at each step in the production process according to how much value each business adds to the product. One thing that attracts politicians and economists to the tax is that it is largely invisible; consumers pay it, but often do not see it, because it is usually incorporated quietly into the final retail price rather than tacked on visibly at the end like a sales tax.
Beyond the politics are some nuts-and-bolts difficulties.
Some Administration officials have talked of raising about $30 billion a year from a value-added tax. But because the tax would cost so much to administer and comply with -- perhaps more than $8 billion a year -- some economists say the Administration should not bother unless it plans to reap considerably more than $30 billion from it.
 
High Administrative Costs
 The Congressional Budget Office estimates that it would cost the Government $750 million to $1.5 billion a year to administer the tax and that it would cost businesses $4 billion to $7 billion a year to pay the accountants and clerks needed for the additional paperwork.
"It's not worth thinking about a value-added tax at 1, 2 or 3 percent," said Rudolph Penner, a former director of the Congressional Budget Office and now director of economic studies at K.P.M.G. Peat Marwick. "In light of the Administration's costs, you should think of at least 6, 7 or 8 percent."
Deputy Treasury Secretary Roger Altman acknowledged recently that it could take two to three years to get a value-added tax up and running.
Eugene Steuerle, a senior fellow at the Urban Institute, said the delays would come on many fronts: "It requires new tax forms; it requires development of a new tax staff. You'd have to train new I.R.S. personnel. You'd have to set up new computers at the nation's banks and businesses. You'd have to hire new people to handle them."
 
Less Paperwork in Japan
 Some advocates of a value-added tax are backing the version adopted in Japan, which requires less paperwork than the version now used in Europe. In Europe, businesses pay the tax based on each transaction; in Japan, a business pays on the yearly total of its transactions -- on the difference between the value of its inputs, including raw materials and machinery, and its total sales.
The United States is the only major industrial nation that does not have a value-added tax. Most Western European nations adopted the tax more than two decades ago because it is a big revenue raiser and because they saw it as a straightforward way to replace a welter of confusing and overlapping business transaction taxes. In France, the standard value-added tax is 18.6 percent, in Britain 17.5 percent and in Germany 15 percent.
Many European officials say the value-added tax is preferable to the sales taxes common at state and local levels in the United States because it is harder to evade. Retailers often avoid paying sales taxes by under estimating their receipts. It is less easy to evade a value-added tax, however, because at each step of the production chain there are two companies keeping scrupulous records of each transaction -- the company that having finished its processes passed the product on and the company that received it.
One reason the United States has balked at a value-added tax is that state and local governments worry that it would interfere with their sales taxes. Some economists suggest that a value-added tax could replace state and local sales taxes and the Federal Government could share its value-added revenues with states, as is done in Germany.
Despite Europe's social democratic traditions, there are few complaints among Europeans that the value-added tax is unfair to the less well off. The reason: European governments embrace the tax to finance generous social programs, including government-supported health care and high levels of unemployment compensation.
According to Mr. Steuerle, if the Federal Government adopts a value-added tax to finance a health-care plan that insures the 37 million Americans without coverage, that might defuse protests that the tax is regressive.
"The value-added tax is usually thought of as mildly regressive," he said. "You can solve that problem by how you distribute the benefits. Then the net impact will be progressive."
To make their value-added taxes less regressive, several European countries established a higher value-added tax on luxury goods, like furs. And many nations have exempted certain basics like food, housing and medical care from the tax.
According to the Congressional Budget Office, if Washington were to exempt these three basics, a 5 percent value-added tax would collect about $60 billion a year -- or about half as much as with those three items included.
Eager to keep compliance simple, many economists assert that using such exemptions and differing rates greatly multiplies the paperwork and headaches for companies seeking to comply. Nonetheless, many European leaders see such exemptions as politically necessary.
"I'd argue that there are better ways to make a VAT fairer," Mr. Penner said. "You can increase food stamps or use a bigger earned-income tax credit."

HEADLINE: Economy Aids a Compromise Over Developing Forest Land

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TUXEDO, N.Y.

 BODY:
Here on a spread as vast as all of Manhattan, a Swedish insurance company wants to build a utopian city for 35,000 inhabitants and 20,000 workers, a complex that would dwarf all but a few towns between New York City and Albany.
That vision for Sterling Forest, a privately held woodland 40 miles north of New York City, is diametrically different from one preservationists have long had for the thousands of rugged acres of hemlock and white cedar that are home to black bears, coyotes, bobcats, foxes and timber rattlesnake.
 
A Deal Is Under Way
 Both visions, however, are running up against the sour economic reality of the 90's. In the 1980's, developers could dream of projects on a mighty scale, and preservationists could plan Arcadias for hiking and fishing and the protection of wildlife. But the 1990's, with a sputtering economy that impoverishes both landlords and public park preservers, is forcing a new approach: compromise. 
 State officials, speaking on the condition of anonymity, say a deal for under $50 million may soon be struck to make most of the Sterling Forest part of the Palisades Interstate Park System. It would leave the developer perhaps a quarter of Sterling Forest's 17,500 acres for housing and office buildings. The deal, now in negotiation, would require tapping pools of Federal and state money in an arrangement as intricate as a leveraged buyout.
"We continue to have discussions with representatives of the corporation for a possible acquisition of a portion of the property," was all Robert Binnewies, executive director of the Palisades Interstate Park System, was willing to say.
Publicly, the developer, the Sterling Forest Corporation, which is controlled by a consortium led by Trygg-Hansa SPP Group, the largest insurance company in Scandinavia, has said it would sell the entire property -- for $150 million or more.
Robert E. Thomson, chairman of the forest corporation, says that his company has been losing $2 million a year through taxes and maintenance, and it needs to exploit the property or bail out.
"The only exit strategy is to begin to develop it," he said. "There's no other way to get out of the property."
Some critics see his price tag as a kind of blackmail and accuse the company of brandishing development as a way of manipulating a top-dollar sale. Others say Mr. Thomson is simply bargaining in public. But these critics express hope that the more difficult economic outlook will prompt the corporation to grab a sure offer.
For one thing, the office market in the suburbs and beyond is generally glutted, so prospects for still another glistening business center are hardly rosy. Similarly, the housing market is flat. And while the full-scale Sterling Forest project still faces formidable legal hurdles, area towns apparently would welcome modest development. All that suggests the company would be satisfied with half a loaf.
John Humbach, head of the Sterling Forest Coalition, a corps of environmental and other groups fighting the development, said the public needed to understand the importance of preserving Sterling as a forest.
"As we look forward to the year 2050, when the megalopolis will have expanded through Orange County and beyond, people will be grateful to us for preserving a green oasis like Sterling Forest, just like people of New York City are grateful for Central Park," he said.
 
Hamlets and Clusters
 The developer's master plan foresees five hamlets that would sprawl like an archipelago through the forest, with separate clusters of housing and office buildings to minimize destruction of timber. Condominium apartments and homes would be built over 25 to 30 years and range in price from $100,000 to $600,000.
Energy-saving jitneys would carry residents to their jobs within the forest. And there would be amenities galore: three shopping centers, three golf courses, a 250-room conference center and a Main Street hub with its own theater and library.
The fate of Sterling Forest has galvanized the passions of this town as well as Warwick and Monroe, the other towns that embrace the forest.
Supporters of a large development argue that Orange County already has enough green space, with Harriman and Bear Mountain State Parks on its southeastern border. What the county really needs, they say, is more taxpayers and more jobs.
 
Supporters Welcome Business
 Rosalie Gaudiello, owner of the Market Basket, a grocery in Greenwood Lake just west of the forest, left the hurly-burly of New York City 21 years ago. But she thinks the area has become too sleepy and needs an infusion of businesses that would hold youngsters after they grow up.
"There's nothing here for the kids," she said. "My daughter went to school in Bergen County and she's not coming back."
Tuxedo, a once posh town that lent its name to the formal evening suit after a local plutocrat wore a prototype in 1886, also needs new growth, said Annette Dorozynski, its supervisor. Tuxedo may be a picture postcard place for New Yorkers, she says, but its population has dwindled to 3,069, stores have closed, and jobs have been lost with plant closings by the International Business Machines Corporation, the Ford Motor Company and International Nickel.
The town does not get enough taxes to support services for its aging population. Yet Ms. Dorozynski worries that the scale of the proposed development would clog the roads and strain the police and firefighting forces, so she would support a somewhat more modest complex.
"You're going to pay now or pay later," she said. "If you don't want progress, the infrastructure is still going to decay, so you're going to have to pay for it anyway, with a smaller tax base."
The Palisades Interstate Park Commission, which oversees 23 parks in New Jersey and New York, and the Regional Plan Association, a nonprofit planning group that has monitored the forest for decades, treasure Sterling as a crucial link in a verdant corridor running from the Hudson River to the Delaware River.
Many species need the unbroken swath of wilderness for their migrations. The forest's streams also supply the drinking water for two million residents of northern New Jersey. The forest hugs the Appalachian Trail and has eight lakes.
The Palisades Commission has pressed for a deftly mapped purchase that would protect the flow of clean water, expand trails for hikers, yet allow scaled-back development.
Sterling Forest is not virgin land. Hidden among its trees are the ruins of 19th-century smelters, miners' shacks and railroad cuts that testify to a once-thriving iron industry. The property was purchased in 1895 by the Harriman family, whose wealth stemmed from railroads. The family sold it in 1953 for $750,000 to a real-estate developer that set up the Sterling Forest Corporation.
 
Cashing In on an Asset
 Large chunks of the forest have already been turned into homes for 250 families and offices for 2,000 workers. But the forest has barely been developed, benefiting the insurance affiliate only as a holding against which policies can be written.
Yet Mr. Thomson, the forest corporation's chairman, maintains that the spread of suburbs beyond Westchester and Rockland Counties and the rapid growth of Orange County may make the forest prime for profitable development.
"This is a unique property," Mr. Thomson said. "There aren't a lot of 17,000-acre properties essentially intact this close to New York City."
Mr. Thomson, a genial and witty Californian, has been working to disarm his opponents rather than wear them down. He boasts that, unlike other developers, his company has not tried "to do it in secret and cram it down the community's throat."
 
Opponents and Skeptics
 The Sterling Corporation has already received approval of the project's concept from the towns of Tuxedo and Warwick. An assessment of the development's environmental impact must also be completed. The corporation hopes to get full approval from all three towns sometime next year to break ground.
Mr. Thomson has promised that 75 percent of the property will be kept as green space and a habitat for animal life. Opponents contend that green space will be so fragmented that the forest will essentially lose its value as a habitat.
Mr. Thomson has also pledged that the property will not increase the tax burden of town residents. But many are skeptical. They predict that the costs of schools, police, sewer and other services for 35,000 people will exceed the increase in revenue.
 
The Bottom Line
 Ron Nowak, editor of the Greenwood Lake News, argues that the development will double the number of students at the Greenwood Lake Union District schools without creating enough taxable housing to pay for them. He also worries that a school system that now has only 1,272 students will become impersonal.
"This is the kind of system where every kid is known," he said. "Nobody falls through the cracks."
The only compromise between these positions would require a purchase. Louis Heimbach, a former county executive of Orange County who is second in command to Mr. Thomson, says the company has been willing to consider a buyout, but has not seen one to its liking.
"Our response to the people who want to keep it green is, 'Show us your money!' " he said.

HEADLINE: CLINTON SAYS U.S. MUST HARDEN LINE TOWARD THE SERBS

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 26

 BODY:
Only hours after the Bosnian Serbs once again rejected peace proposals, President Clinton said today that it was clear that the United States and its allies needed "a stronger policy" in the Balkans and promised to decide on a new course of action within the next few days.
A senior American official said the most likely strategy would be a program of limited bombing, intended to produce a cease-fire in place and a new round of negotiations. With European nations insisting upon American leadership, both Britain and France indicated over the weekend that they would probably prefer bombing to any of the other military options under study. 
 "The President wants a definable objective, not just a spasm of bombing, and a limitation of scope," the American official said. "We are prepared to lead, but not to act alone."
 
A Round of Consultations
 Mr. Clinton signed an order today aligning the United States with new, tougher United Nations sanctions that were scheduled to go into effect against Serbia at midnight, but neither the American Government nor its principal allies think they are likely to end the fighting in Bosnia and Herzegovina or the "ethnic cleansing" that many have described as near-genocide.
A second American official said a decision would follow talks between Mr. Clinton and Congressional leaders and possibly one more full-dress meeting with his foreign-policy advisers. Its broad outlines would then be disclosed, the official said, speaking like his colleague on condition of anonymity, but details would be withheld pending negotiations with key allies such as Britain and France. Warren Christopher, the Secretary of State, is expected to fly to Europe for those talks as soon as Mr. Clinton reaches his decision.
The President said last week that he would take no action unilaterally.
 
U.S. Public Divided
 Officials involved in the discussions of Bosnian policy warned that Mr. Clinton had made no final decision yet, and that because all the possible policies had evident disadvantages, he might yet avoid air strikes. One of the President's advisers said that "this is an absolute brute, this issue, with no answer that leaps off the page, and we've all changed our minds a lot."
Another adviser insisted that lifting the embargo on arms sales to the Muslims, though unpopular with the Europeans, remained under active consideration as an alternative to bombing.
Lord Owen, the European Community's peace negotiator, said in Belgrade today that "confrontation is now inevitable" between Europe and the Bosnian Serbs. The Serbs will be punished "economically, politically, and if they continue, in my view, militarily within the context of the U.N. Charter," he said.
Although there is little public pressure for action -- most recent polls show American voters equally divided between favoring and opposing military intervention -- other forces are pushing Mr. Clinton toward a decision.
Prominent senators of both parties, members of his own Administration and influential journalistic commentators are all clamoring for action, as are such figures as Elie Wiesel, the Holocaust survivor who won the Nobel Peace Prize. Former Secretary of State George P. Shultz called today for "a very large, sustained air- and sea-based attack" on Serbian positions.
The Russian elections, a potential complicating factor, are over, and the European countries made it plain this weekend that they would move only with reluctance and only under substantial United States pressure.
"The President had hoped the Europeans might go first, which would have given him some cover," a European diplomat said. "But it's going to have to be the other way around."
In London, Foreign Office officials stressed that Britain's overall goals in the Balkans remained unchanged: continued pressure on the Serbian leaders, including a blockade to enforce economic sanctions, to force them to accept either the peace plan devised by Lord Owen and Cyrus R. Vance or some other agreement. But the officials hinted strongly that they were inclined to go along with Mr. Clinton in his search for a policy with more force behind it.
 
No British 'Blank Check'
 "We have not signed a blank check," one British official said, "but I can say that any proposal that is put to us will be considered."
At a meeting of European Community foreign ministers in Denmark over the weekend, Douglas Hurd, the British Foreign Secretary, made relatively favorable comments about air strikes, even though the ministers failed to reach agreement on a new policy. He emphasized, however, that in the event of bombing some method would have to be worked out to protect United Nations troops engaged in the effort to deliver relief supplies to besieged Muslim towns in eastern Bosnia.
Alain Juppe, the French Foreign Minister, ruled out a partial lifting on the United Nations arms embargo on all factions in the Balkan fighting to allow the Bosnian Muslims to close the gap on the better-armed Serbs. Mr. Juppe argued that such a policy would only widen the slaughter, but he said that France was ready to discuss what he termed "selective air strikes."
It is not clear how extensive the air strikes would be if that is what Mr. Clinton and the allied leaders agree upon. They could be concentrated on battlefield targets, such as ammunition dumps, the artillery emplacements from which the Serbs have rained fire on Bosnian towns and cities and the vulnerable mountain bridges which they need for resupply.
 
An Attack on Belgrade?
 Some, like Mr. Shultz, have advocated bombing targets in or near Belgrade, on the ground that such attacks would prompt the Serbian Government to bring pressure on the Bosnian Serbs. But several Administration planners said that was not likely, at least at the moment.
Mr. Clinton, who has been speaking with increasing bluntness about Bosnia in recent days in a throwback to his tough language during the 1992 election campaign, discussed the situation with reporters this afternoon during a White House ceremony to honor the University of Arkansas track team.
"It is now, I think, clear that the United States and its allies need to move forward with a stronger policy in Bosnia and I will be announcing the course that I hope we can take in the next several days," he said. "I think the time has come to focus on that problem and what it means for the United States and the rest of the world as well as for the people that are suffering there."

HEADLINE: Old Peril of Abandoned Mines Stirs Calls for Action in West

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: COPPERTON, Utah, April 24

 BODY:
For decades, the West tolerated dangerous abandoned mines and piles of toxic mine wastes as necessary, if ugly, byproducts of an industry that provided thousands of jobs and billions of dollars for the region's economy.
But momentum is gathering in state capitals, in Washington and in mining communities like this one for new safeguards. Across the region, attention is focusing on new evidence of water pollution from mine wastes containing lead, arsenic and cyanide. There has also been concern over the number of people killed by falls into abandoned mines -- 73 from the late 1970's through 1991, by the Department of Interior's count. 
 This month, Gov. Bruce King of New Mexico signed the toughest mine-cleanup law in the country. It establishes a fund for cleaning up abandoned mines and sets new land-reclamation standards for those still in operation.
And here in Utah, the Kennecott Corporation is working with the state and the Federal Government on the largest voluntary project ever undertaken in the United States to clean up and entomb toxic dirt from lead-processing operations.
 
After the Ore Was Gone
 By any measure, such efforts are long overdue, said state officials and executives of Kennecott. Thousands of mines where gold, silver, lead, copper and other hard rock minerals were clawed from the earth were abandoned after their ore gave out. Many were left surrounded by tons of pulverized rock laced with toxic materials.
When it rains or snows, the water mixes with those materials, forming acidic solutions that have polluted, by some estimates, 10,000 miles of streams in the West. The abandoned mines and wastes, including residues from mineral-processing plants, represent another staggering environmental cost from industrial development in the United States.
Mine wastes now cover at least two million acres of private and public land -- roughly two-thirds the area of Connecticut -- according to studies by the Western Governors Association, two Federal agencies, Congress and the National Academy of Sciences.
The piles of waste, some with humps like great beasts, lie sprawled across the land. Not only does the runoff from these piles ruin streams and kill the fish in them, it also taints underground supplies of drinking water, according to the state and Federal studies.
The states estimate there are at least 500,000 abandoned mines in the West. In Utah, where three people died in falls at abandoned mines in 1985 and scores have been injured, state officials say filling in and sealing 17,000 abandoned mines will cost at least $174 million.
But the state can find only about $1 million to spend on the problem each year from state and Federal funds. "It's a pittance for a public health and environmental issue that affects every part of this state," said Mary Ann Wright, director of Utah's Abandoned Mine Reclamation Program.
Over all, estimates of the cost for stabilizing the toxic wastes from mining and ore-processing, repairing the damage to streams and aquifers and closing abandoned mines across the West ranges from $20 billion to more than $70 billion, according to various public and private studies. Those estimates put the problem in the same category as toxic-waste and radioactive cleanups now under way on military installations, nuclear-weapons plants and abandoned chemical dumps.
The Federal Government alone will spend $10 billion this fiscal year to clean up the latter wastes, more than a quarter of all Federal spending on environmental protection, while total Federal and state spending on mine-related cleanups will total less than $250 million.
 
An Array of Proposals
 Next month, Senator John Glenn of Ohio, the chairman of the Senate Committee on Governmental Affairs, is to hold a hearing on mining in preparation for legislation to address toxic pollution on Federal land. Other members of the Senate and the House have put forward an array of proposals to establish environmental controls on mining.
The White House this month said it would support Congressional efforts to increase environmental safeguards at mines on Federal land, which represent about a third of the hard-rock mining industry. "This is an industry granted special favors that must end," said Representative George Miller, Democrat of California and chairman of the House Natural Resources Committee.
But Mr. Miller and other House Democrats have questioned the White House's commitment in light of the removal last month from President Clinton's budget of a measure that would have required a 12.5 percent royalty on all hard-rock minerals mined on Federal land. Some of the royalties would have been used to set up a fund for cleaning up mine sites on Federal land.
The message that Congress and the White House may be ready to challenge the mining industry has not been lost on industry leaders. "There is a general consensus that mine wastes are a huge problem, and we better recognize that the only way to deal with it is with a collaborative program between Government and the industry," said G. Frank Joklik, the president and chief executive officer of Kennecott, which is based in Salt Lake City.
 
Some Surprising Results
 No other state in the West has tried more approaches than Utah, and some of the results have been unexpected. In Park City, high in the Wasatch Range 75 miles east of here, the Environmental Protection Agency proposed to dig up a neighborhood that was built on lead and arsenic wastes from processing mills. The agency justified the proposal on the basis of the risk to children from eating lead-contaminated dirt.
After medical studies showed that the Park City children had lower levels of lead in their blood than the average American child, citizens rejected the E.P.A. plan. They chose a much less costly approach to safeguard their families. Their yards were covered with clean dirt, and they established a rule barring families in the neighborhood from planting vegetable gardens.
Across the Wasatch Valley, the town of Midvale is trying another approach under the Federal Superfund program, which is generally used to clean up abandoned chemical dumps. A lead-processing mill that operated at the center of town for most of this century poured 13 million tons of lead and arsenic wastes onto a 270-acre field along the Jordan River during its lifetime.
 
A $300 Million Pile
 The cost of cleaning up this enormous pile could easily exceed $300 million if the state gets its way and has the pile moved. Neither the state, the Federal Government, nor the mill's former owners want to pay for it, said Daniel Symonik, a toxicologist and manager of the State Division of Environmental Response and Remediation. "The Superfund law is not designed to get things done," he said.
Rob Walline, the top mining-waste expert at the E.P.A., agrees. "Superfund is not well suited to deal with mine wastes," he said by telephone from his office in Denver. "The costs are just too high. A new approach is needed."
The missed deadlines, lawsuits, community anger and regulatory deadlock that have accompanied the Midvale project are a constant reminder to the executives of Kennecott, who can see the yellowed pile of mine wastes across the valley from the flank of their open-pit copper mine here.
On the east face of the Oquirrh Range 15 miles southwest of Salt Lake City, Kennecott produces 15 percent of the nation's copper from a hole where a mountain once stood. Almost 90 years after the company began digging here, Kennecott executives said they are out to prove that a newer approach to mine reclamation, involving collaboration with Government instead of litigation, can be successful.
In one phase of the project, millions of tons of lead and arsenic wastes are being picked up and moved into new, clay-lined repositories the company built on its property below the copper mine. In another phase, the company emptied a waste-water reservoir and scraped from the bottom millions more tons of sediments contaminated with toxic metals. Those wastes, too, are heading for the repositories.
 
Into an Aquifer
 The reservoir was the principal source of toxic metals that had seeped into an underground aquifer and contaminated the drinking water source used by thousands of residents along the Wasatch Front. The state and the company are negotiating how to halt the spread of the contaminants in the aquifer and determining whether other steps are needed to clean up the water.
Mr. Joklik and other top Kennecott executives said the project -- estimated by Kennecott at $150 million, even though state officials predict it will be considerably more -- was motivated primarily by a desire to avoid arguments with regulators that would cost the company even more money and sap the energy of the company's leaders.
"Why tie up management's time with trying to deal with all these wastes within a government bureaucracy?" said Gregory H. Boyce, the company's chief spokesman.
