HEADLINE: Stocks Drop Again on Economic Concerns

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
The stock market demonstrated a determined descent yesterday, having shambled downward last week, closing lower for the sixth consecutive trading session with barely a flicker of upward movement. All major indexes were down, and the only major gaining stocks were gold-mining companies, although less so than on Friday.
The market opened the week by largely ignoring good news about Boris N. Yeltsin's apparent victory in Sunday's Russian referendum, which would aid Germany and thus European economies. Investors paid more attention to bad news about the American economy. The National Association of Realtors said sales of existing single-family homes dropped 2.9 percent in March, nearly triple the 1 percent decline expected by analysts. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average closed down 15.40 points, to 3,398.37. In midmorning trading, it briefly swerved upward 12 points, then dived 26 points shortly before 3 P.M., then recovered somewhat.
Four Dow stocks -- Allied Signal, J. P. Morgan, General Electric and Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing -- accounted for most of the drop. Allied Signal, a diversified manufacturing company, lost 2 5/8, to 63 5/8. Tending to lift the Dow was Aluminum Company of America, which closed up 1 1/2, to 65 3/8.
The Dow Jones transportation average closed down 37.47 points, to 1,580.55, posting its fifth decline in six trading days. UAL, United Airlines' parent, closed down 4 7/8, to 139 3/8, and accounted for nearly 8 points in the transport average's decline.
Big Board volume totaled 283.3 million shares, compared with Friday's volume of 259.8 million shares. Decliners outnumbered gainers by about 2 to 1. The New York Stock Exchange composite index closed down 1.94 points, to 239.91. The Standard & Poor's 500 dropped 3.49 points, to 433.54. The Nasdaq composite index dropped 12.54 points, to 645.87.
Many major stocks were down on continuing anxiety about the economy. Bank shares, led by those of Citicorp and BankAmerica, and insurance companies, led by American International Group, were bid down on expectations that persistently low interest rates would hurt earnings.
Citicorp closed down 1 7/8, to 25 7/8, on heavy volume of 4.45 million shares; BankAmerica ended down 2 7/8, to 44 1/4, also on heavy volume of 4.18 million shares. Barron's, the business magazine, and analysts have questioned whether bank earnings, generally good, have peaked.
 Shares of Intel, already battered by prospective sales of a tiny rival's cheaper copy of Intel's microchip, were hammered again by word of a new and cheaper chip from Motorola, a more formidable competitor. Intel closed down 5 1/4, to 87 3/8, on volume of 11.6 million shares, the heaviest of the day.
Gold stocks were the striking exception among market performers for the second consecutive session, although there appeared to be some profit taking in the group. Traders followed the lead of the well-known investors George Soros and Sir James Goldsmith. Mr. Soros bought a 10 percent stake in Newmont Mining from Sir James for $400 million. Sir James reportedly used proceeds from that sale to purchase options to buy gold bullion, analysts said. Newmont shares rose 1, to $46 7/8.
Homestake Mining was the most actively traded stock on the Big Board, with 3.2 million shares, but it closed down 1/4 point, to 15 3/4, despite trading higher during the day.

HEADLINE: A.T.& T. In a Deal In Japan

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 26

 BODY:
After years of trans-Pacific trade frictions over telephone equipment, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced today that it had tentatively agreed to sell a dozen of its most advanced central office telephone switches to Japan's main telephone company.
The deal is the first instance of A.T.& T.'s selling telecommunications equipment to the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Company, which is the world's largest local telephone company and is two-thirds owned by the Japanese Government. Today's transaction came after years of pressure applied by the United States to get N.T.T. to break its traditional reliance on Japanese suppliers.
 
Under Washington's Eye
 In recent weeks, American officials had let N.T.T. and the Japanese Government know that they were closely watching the talks. 
 For separate reasons, American and Japanese Government and corporate officials played down the politics of today's announcement, which was also made by N.T.T. in Tokyo.
Randall L. Tobias, A.T.& T.'s vice chairman, contended that today's decision showed that A.T.& T. manufactured a competitive product. But he also said that officials at the State Department and other agencies "have certainly been helpful to us in engineering, as nearly as they could, a level playing field."
 
A Japanese View
 Seiichiro Noboru, the economics minister at the Japanese Embassy here, said that today's deal had "absolutely nothing to do with political pressure because N.T.T. has been continuously increasing its purchases since the early 1980's."
The Government has a long record of making concessions at politically opportune times, and this may not signal a broader opening of the Japanese market. Japanese imports of American telecommunications equipment dropped sharply last year, to $555 million from $699 million in 1991.
Anne Luzzatto, the press secretary for Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, declined to comment.
Today's announcement happened to coincide with increased activity in the Clinton Administration's review of whether to classify imported mini-vans and sport-utility vehicles as trucks instead of cars, a move that would raise import tariffs on them to 25 percent from 2.5 percent, helping to protect Detroit auto makers.
At a National Economic Council meeting on Friday of deputy Cabinet secretaries, Roger Altman, the Deputy Treasury Secretary, presented a Treasury Department review of the advantages and disadvantages of such a move, a Treasury official who insisted on anonymity said.
President Clinton said at a news conference on March 23 that the Bush Administration's decision to classify the vehicles as cars was "a $300-million-a-year freebie to the Japanese for no apparent reason," a reference to the difference in what the two tariff rates would yield in annual revenues to the Government.
A possible compromise under discussion in the Administration and the auto industry would have the Treasury reclassify the mini-vans and sport-utility vehicles as trucks and then lower the truck tariff to 8.5 percent from 25 percent.
Mr. Tobias said that today's telephone switching equipment announcement had been in preparation for weeks and that the timing was not determined by politics.
N.T.T.'s purchasing practices have been the subject of trade squabbles since the Carter Administration, when the Japanese company's chairmen then, Tokuji Akikusa, made a comment that his company might "open procurement to the U.S. for buckets, rags, mops and miscellaneous office supplies."
The latest American-Japan agreement, in December, required that N.T.T. hold open and competitive bidding for its electrical power and construction contracts.
A.T.& T. and Nippon refused to discuss the value of today's deal. But Gregory Mesniaeff, an analyst at Northern Business Information, a New York consulting company, estimated that it was worth about $40 million, including installation.
"It's a notable achievement," he said. "Until recently, the whole N.T.T. market was off limits to anyone except Fujitsu and NEC."
Today's agreement is tentative because N.T.T. has insisted that it must make sure the programming is compatible with the Japanese telephone network.

HEADLINE: Panel Gives California Hope on Keeping Bases

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OAKLAND, Calif., April 26

 BODY:
The chairman of the Presidential commission that will determine the fate of scores of military bases has told state officials that bases elsewhere in the nation may be reviewed in the coming weeks as possible replacements for some in Northern California that are scheduled to be closed.
The possibility of expanding the scope of the commission's review was raised by the panel's chairman, James A. Courter, during a four-day visit to Northern California that included visits to eight military bases in the region and two days of public hearings here. 
 Mr. Courter's tentative offer is still subject to the approval of five members of the eight-member Defense Base Closure and Realignment Commission. But it was considered a small victory for lawmakers, leaders of community groups and military experts here, who brought thick reports, colorful pie charts and aerial photos in their 11th-hour plea to save local bases and the tens of thousands of jobs they provide.
 
'Very Sympathetic'
 Since saving jobs is not the mandate of the commission, however, the most effective pitches here were those that challenged the data and analysis used by the Department of Defense in recommending that certain bases be closed and others saved based on military preparedness.
In at least two cases -- the Alameda Naval Air Station and the McClellan Air Force Base in Sacramento -- Mr. Courter said he was "very sympathetic, without pledging on a Bible," to suggestions that their military preparedness be measured against that of other bases that might be better candidates for closing.
"That logic is compelling to me," Mr. Courter said after hearing detailed challenges to the Pentagon analysis by groups representing the bases in Alameda, a naval enclave on the other side of the Oakland estuary, and Sacramento, where two other bases are already in the midst of closing as a result of earlier military cutbacks.
In the case of Alameda, the alternative would be Everett Naval Station in Washington State, a base now under construction that has no housing, hospital or piers for nuclear carriers, as the Alameda station does. In the case of McClellan, the alternatives would be Ogden Air Force Base in Utah, Tinker Air Force Base in Oklahoma, Kelly Air Force Base in Texas or Robbins Air Force Base in Georgia, none of which would require the costly environmental cleanup necessary before the Sacramento base can be developed for nonmilitary uses.
Considering other bases, Mr. Courter said, would require a commission vote, which could come as early as next week, when the panel convenes again in Charleston, S.C., for further hearings, the third of nine such sessions nationwide.
The base-closing commission, which was set up to insulate Congress from angry constituents on such decisions, can alter the Pentagon's list by adding or subtracting bases. The panel must submit its final recommendations to President Clinton by July 1. Mr. Clinton, and then Congress, would have to approve or reject the entire package.
Dozens of witnesses, including Representative Ronald V. Dellums, the Oakland Democrat who is the new chairman of the House Armed Services Committee and a longtime advocate of sharply reduced military spending, testified on behalf of keeping the Alameda station open.
Mr. Dellums did not make an economic argument for keeping the station open at a time when the state remains in an economic slump. Instead, he stressed the failings of the new base in Everett and the costs of making it the equivalent to Alameda.
"It will take hundreds of millions of dollars to replicate the situation we already have," Mr. Dellums said. "I am not a Ph.D. in mathematics, but the economics of that escapes me."
 
Piers for Nuclear Carriers
 Adm. Bob Foley, a former commander of the Pacific fleet and a one-time Assistant Secretary of Energy, testified that the three berths in Alameda for nuclear carriers would be difficult, if not impossible, to duplicate elsewhere. He said permits for such operations were extremely difficult to obtain.
Admiral Foley noted that the Navy's statistical comparison of bases had awarded more points to Everett for its gymnasium than to Alameda for its piers for nuclear carriers.
Witnesses supporting McClellan drew laughter from members of the base commission when they said the Sacramento base was downgraded because it was not near an aquarium. But it was testimony about McClellan's contaminated ground water and soil that elicited the most concern.
Gov. Pete Wilson testified that cleaning up McClellan would cost $3 million to $10 million. And Sacramento officials said they doubted if any developer would be interested in the toxic site or if any bank would be willing to loan money toward McClellan's purchase.
"There is no future for this facility," said Representative Vic Fazio, Democrat from the Sacramento area.
Harry C. McPherson, a member of the commission, said of McClellan: "You're filthy. Nobody can touch you with a 10-foot pole, or a 10-billion-foot pole. That's a pretty good argument to have to stay in business."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Ronald V. Dellums, right, chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, confers with an aide, H. Lee Haltermann, at a meeting of the military base-closing commission in Oakland, Calif. (Susan Spann for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Struggle to Survive in Town That Steel Forgot

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALIQUIPPA, Pa.

 BODY:
Molten metal still flows in a handful of buildings on the seven-mile stretch of the Ohio River bank here where a sprawling Jones & Laughlin steel complex once employed as many as 17,000 workers. But if the nation had a hospital for communities, this struggling town 25 miles northwest of Pittsburgh would have been sent to intensive care.
The LTV Corporation, which bought Jones & Laughlin in 1968, has only 600 employees here now. They work in a tin mill that coats steel made elsewhere. Farther north, in a former LTV building, a machine maintenance and repair concern shares space with a small steel finishing company. Then there is J & L Structural Inc., a private concern that in 1987 acquired an LTV mill that makes 14-inch steel bars used primarily in mobile home construction, and a dock facility for shipping and receiving goods by water. It employs about 130 people. 
 Added up, though, the activity is a meager down payment on future prosperity of a town that was built by paternalistic steel barons earlier this century and has been dependent on the industry ever since. Most of the steelmaking operations have been carefully demolished. What remains are vast stretches of vacant, bulldozed land ringed by barbed-wire fences and No Trespassing signs.
The Aliquippa experience is a stark contrast to that of Kamaishi, Japan, a steel town that lost its leading industry when the Nippon Steel Corporation gradually shut its steelmaking operations there. Eager to preserve its lifetime-employment policy, Nippon created almost any new business it could for the jobless workers.
Aliquippa is only one of many American towns that were blasted by the contraction of the steel industry. There are about 167,000 workers in the industry today, down from a peak of 650,000 in 1953.
Many communities that depend on auto makers and military contractors have faced similar pressures. A few communities are equally dependent on military bases that are scheduled to close in the coming decade.
Occasionally, American companies that have left the communities they dominated economically have been willing and able to provide substantial transition assistance. More typically, though, the abandoned communities and various government bodies have been left to do the best they can with limited corporate support.
Hard-pressed steelmakers in particular have had little to offer towns like Aliquippa when they pulled out. Indeed, some like LTV have ended up in bankruptcy court where they sought to duck pension obligations and other support that workers had assumed would be theirs even in the event of shutdowns.
"It's not just LTV, although once Jones & Laughlin sold to them we became nothing more than a blip on a Texas computer," said Sylvester Greco, a longtime downtown merchant, referring to LTV's corporate headquarters in Dallas. "There was so many things that went wrong that I don't know where to begin."
Franklin Avenue, the main shopping street of the town during its heyday in the 1950's and 1960's, looks even more forlorn than the weed-pocked expanses where open-hearth furnaces once flamed. About 30 stores, including Mr. Greco's cheerful shop that sells bridal and women's clothing, survive in a shopping district that once had almost 300. Most storefronts are boarded up, empty or given over to social service agencies. There are gaps where entire buildings have been torn down but not replaced.
The woes of downtown Aliquippa are not entirely the fault of its shrinking steel industry. It has also been victimized by a migration to the suburbs of wage-earning families and the merchants who serve them. The population fell by 20 percent during the 1970's even though employment at the mill held relatively steady at more than 10,000.
"Aliquippa has been ghettoized," said Simon Simoni, a lawyer here for 35 years. "All that's left around here are the aged and those on welfare."
Many steelworkers retired to live on part-time handyman work and pensions after the layoffs. Union officials said that others had found jobs as baggage handlers and bus drivers at Pittsburgh's airport, as security guards at shopping malls, and in a variety of other service tasks that pay far less than the mill.
 
Surviving on Lower Wages
 Donald Maretti, who was laid off in 1984 after 19 1/2 years, just six months short of his pension, had a series of jobs that advanced him to the position of director of housekeeping at the Beaver Valley Mall about a 15-minute drive north of Aliquippa.
"I could have done anything when I came out of the Marines," Mr. Maretti said. "I chose the mill. I don't blame the Government, the company or the union for what happened."
Few of the workers have landed jobs that pay as well as the mill once did. "The pension plan is relatively liberal and helps a lot of people survive on lower wages," said Peter Eritano, the staff representative of the United Steelworkers International for Western Pennsylvania and the former head of the Aliquippa local.
A patchwork of training programs and social services provided by LTV, the union, churches and government agencies also cushioned the crash. Federally financed education benefits for workers who lost their jobs in industries like steel that suffered from imports helped some Aliquippans, as did extended unemployment benefits for those in training programs. An LTV-financed union program helped those without high school degrees get their diplomas.
 
Lack of Skills Training
 "The trouble is that there's not enough training to really upgrade people's skills and not enough high-tech jobs available even if they get the training," Mr. Eritano said. "The United States lags way, way behind other industrial countries in providing new opportunities for workers where plants are shut down."
Local development agencies and politicians have worked hard to recruit other major employers, but the effort has been futile. Indeed, it took millions of dollars of state loans, concessionary contracts from the unions and discounted utility rates simply to arrange the management buyout that saved the bar mill.
"And thank God for the Westinghouse Credit Corporation," said Howell A. Breedlove Jr., the chief executive of the business that bought LTV's 14-inch bar mill and the dock facility in 1987. "They loaned us about $8 million. None of the local banks would touch us."
Mr. Breedlove said LTV had also helped J & L Structural by lobbying the union to accept the new contract and by executing a "supportive" arrangement for dealing with the web of utilities, railroads, and roads at the site.
LTV officials said the decisions about shutdowns had been made from Cleveland, the headquarters of the LTV Steel Corporation, not Dallas, where the parent is based, and that it had taken a number of steps to cushion the blow. Those included continuing to pay property taxes for five years beyond its obligations and financing a union-run job search and career development center.
 
Union Is Not Critical
 LTV also spent more than $50 million to tear down buildings and clean up the site in an effort with local officials to attract new businesses.
"Aliquippa was the flagship," said Mark Tomasch, an LTV spokesman in Cleveland. "We put off closing it for years and when we did, it was an emotional blow for the company."
Union officials said that whatever its faults, LTV should not be criticized for its handling of the shutdowns.
Several organizations have been formed to revitalize the town's industrial and commercial base. The most ambitious has been the Aliquippa Alliance for Unity and Development, which has been addressing social and economic concerns since 1984. Its business incubator, a former bank building, currently is home to entrepeneurs offering services like landscaping, videotaping of weddings, greeting cards for the military market and computer-aided design.
One project backed by the alliance is an outdoor arts pageant scheduled for next month. It is aimed at celebrating the town's potential. "The more I talked to people, the more I realized there's a grieving for the past," said M. Michele Illuminato, the art show's organizer. "They miss their jobs and life style, of course, but they also miss the bonds of community that have been broken with so many people moving away."

HEADLINE: U.S. Congress, Glad Yeltsin Won, Ponders Aid

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 26

 BODY:
President Boris N. Yeltsin's victory in the referendum on Sunday produced expressions of relief today from the White House, the State Department and Congressional supporters of the proposed $1.8 billion aid package for Russia, which would have been killed by a vote of no confidence.
"This is a very, very good day, not only for the people of Russia, but for the people of the United States and all the people of the world," President Clinton said today during a ceremony in the East Room of the White House where he greeted members the University of Arkansas track team. 
 The President, who spoke by telephone with Mr. Yeltsin this afternoon to congratulate him, also praised the voters who backed Mr. Yeltsin and his policies despite economic privations. "I think the reaffirmation of his policies really is a tribute to the farsightedness of the Russian people," he said.
 
Now, How Can U.S. Help?
 Approval of Mr. Yeltsin and his program gives an added boost for Mr. Clinton's proposal to aid Russia.
"If the vote had gone the other way, no matter how much political theory we could argue -- for supporting the democratic process and the economic benefits -- it would have been an almost insurmountable obstacle," said Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont and chairman of the Appropriation Committee's Subcommittee on Foreign Operations.
Still, with the air thick with talk of tax increases, budget deficits and cuts in Government programs, foreign aid faces formidable obstacles.
"I think it eventually can be put through," said Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House majority leader. "But there are tactical and substantive questions."
The aid package, announced earlier this month by Secretary of State Warren Christopher during a meeting in Tokyo of foreign and finance ministers from seven major industrial nations, is in addition to $1.6 billion that was offered to Mr. Yeltsin during his summit meeting with President Clinton in Vancouver, British Columbia. The first $1.6 billion has already been authorized.
The additional sum is made up of $1.3 billion in direct aid and $500 million to be funneled through international agencies. In putting up the $500 million, the United States challenged other industrial nations to match or exceed that amount.
The President, who also spoke today to former President Richard M. Nixon on how best to proceed with Russia, used his photo opportunity with the track team to make his sales pitch for aid, tying support economic changes in Russia with America's long-term economic interests.
"They are a huge country with vast natural resources, with enormous opportunities for Americans to create jobs and to earn income and to reap the benefits of trade," he said.
 
A Litmus Test
 Backers of the aid say that failure to win Congressional approval would not only embarrass the Administration but also signal that Washington is not serious about supporting economic change.
Representative David R. Obey, Democrat of Wisconsin and chairman of the Appropriations Subcommittee on Foreign Operations, which will be asked to approve any aid package, said: "This is the foreign policy issue. This is the issue that defines whether we're going to live up to our responsibilities to protect our own interests."
But so far the Administration has not said how it will raise $1.8 billion.
It could seek an emergency addition to the 1993 budget, a tactic that was used for the President's economic-stimulus package, which was blocked in the Senate.
The President could also try to amend the 1994 aid budget, which he has already submitted. That would mean cutting spending, probably from the Defense Department or aid programs. But the Administration is talking about spending more for things like refugee assistance, population control and economic development.
 
Domestic Intersections
 Mr. Obey and others say domestic politics, including the failure of President Clinton's economic proposals, complicates getting approval for aid to Russia. Republican lawmakers say that if the Administration tries to declare the aid an emergency addition to the 1993 budget, which would add to the deficit, it would suffer the same fate as the stimulus package.
On the other hand, Democratic liberals, especially those representing urban areas, say it is difficult to sell constituents on aiding Russia when Congress has refused to help the cities. Some Democrats also plan to make that point to embarrass Republicans, like Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, who killed the economic package but who support aid to Russia.
"Why is it easier to help stimulate the Russian economy than it is the United States economy?" asked Representative Nancy Pelosi, Democrat of California. "My belief is that the Russian aid package is not as popular as they may have thought."

HEADLINE: Polo Returns to the Lawns of Long Island;
After Decades of Decline, the Sport Is Regaining Prominence

BYLINE: By PETER MARKS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERICHO, L.I.

 BODY:
Grab your mallets and your hip flasks. Have the groom saddle the ponies and tell the valet to chill the champagne. There is jolly sporting news, at long last, for Long Island's smart set:
Polo is back.
It isn't quite what it was from the 1920's to the 40's, when the gilded clans of the Gold Coast, the Whitneys and the Guests, the Hitchcocks and the Phippses, played matches in their own lavish backyards, when the Duchess of Windsor or the Maharajah of Jaipur might pop in to present a sterling silver loving cup or knock the ball around for a chukker or two on one of the Island's 50 polo fields.
 
U.S. Open in Polo Land
 Nevertheless, after decades of decline, during which polo clubhouses were bulldozed for expressways and fields subdivided for housing developments, the sport is being played again on vast, lush lawns from Old Westbury to the Hamptons. Strings of polo ponies are being put through their paces in paddocks along Long Island's North Shore. Membership in the Meadowbrook Club, the Island's premier polo club, has risen from 14 to 42 in three years, placing it near its goal of 50 and among the 10 largest in the country. Two new polo clubs have been established on the Island in the last few years. 
 And, in the most significant symbol of the sport's revival here, the organization that governs polo in the United States has selected Nassau County as the site of next year's United States Open, bringing the tournament back to Long Island for the first time in 40 years.
While the United States Polo Association's decision is unlikely to cause a stampede to local stores for bamboo polo mallets -- there are only about 4,000 active players in the nation -- local polo aficionados are ecstatic. They say the return of the Open, which will be played here in both 1994 and 1995, is what Long Island polo needs to build interest.
"I'm just so thrilled about it; it's just overwhelming," declared Albert V. Bianco, a Brooklyn-born developer who keeps 25 polo ponies on his 55-acre spread in Old Brookville. Mr. Bianco, president of the Meadowbrook Polo Club -- which is based here and bills itself as the oldest polo club in the nation -- is polo's No. 1 booster in these parts. Polo has become such a major part of his life that he has integrated it into his business, offering free club memberships to buyers of homes in an Old Westbury subdivision he is developing named Polo Estates.
Polo -- with its image as a tony pursuit of British royals and American industrialists who sound faintly British -- does not, of course, have the drawing power of hockey, tennis or even tractor-pulling. Opens held in Indio, Calif., and Lexington, Ky., in recent years drew only a few thousand spectators. Even so, Nassau County officials who have never swung a mallet are describing the tournament's return as a major coup.
 
'Tourism Revenue' for Nassau
 "The fact that the Open is coming here demonstrates, in the minds of many, that Nassau County can compete with other geographic areas in attracting such sporting activities," observed Thomas S. Gulotta, the Nassau County Executive, whose office supplied a helicopter to take the association's representatives on a tour of polo fields in Bethpage State Park and elsewhere to persuade them to select Nassau over sites in four other states.
Mr. Gulotta, who says he has been riding horses in amateur rodeos since he was 4, predicted that polo fever will bring the crowds to the monthlong Open in September 1994, and that the event will generate $6 million in "tourism revenue" each year. "We are anticipating up to 20,000 spectators," he said.
Still, officials acknowledge, the networks are not exactly lining up for the broadcast rights. Polo's peak predated the era of television. In the first three decades of this century, Mr. Bianco said, polo was a huge spectator sport on Long Island, where many of the game's greatest players, like Tommy Hitchcock and Alan Corey, got their start. In 1928, a three-day series of matches between the United States and Argentina, held on the original fields of what was then known as the Meadow Brook Club, attracted more than 100,000 people. Between 1916 and 1953, 28 of the 31 United States Opens were held at Meadow Brook, which was then in nearby Westbury.
"It was the heyday of polo when it was held on Long Island," said Allan Scherer, the executive director of the polo association.
 
Will Rogers and Harriman
 At first glance, polo may look like croquet on horseback, but it actually has more in common with such hardscrabble sports as hockey and soccer.
A match, played by two four-person teams on a field 300 yards long and 160 yards wide, is divided into six periods, or chukkers. Between each chukker, the players change horses, which are ridden at speeds of up to 35 miles an hour. Players, in helmets and knee pads, use the bamboo mallets, or sticks, to hit the wood or plastic ball into the opposing team's goal.
Will Rogers, who lived on Long Island when he appeared in New York with the Ziegfeld Follies, played at Meadow Brook, as did W. Averell Harriman, the former New York Governor, who was a formidable polo talent. The matches would pit rich men on horses against rich men on horses, and the matches were intense and tiring and dangerous, much as they are today. Mr. Bianco, who at 66 still plays, broke his wrist in a fall from his horse a few years ago.
"Genteel people can be rough," said Charles Leonard, 73, a retired stockbroker who grew up in Jericho and played in one of the last Opens held at Meadow Brook in the early 1950's. His younger brother, Hazard, was killed during a polo match in Aiken, S.C., in 1952.
 
Muscled Off the Island
 It was during the 1950's that polo was muscled off the island, its playing fields -- each requiring nearly 10 acres -- coveted as prime residential and office space. In 1954, the land under the Meadow Brook Club was taken by the state for a highway. The club's name lived on in the plans of Long Island commuters: the state called the new road the Meadowbrook Parkway.
A few diehards continued to play polo as the club moved to Jericho. But to many, the demise of the old club represented the passing of a way of life on Long Island. Membership declined as many of the old North Shore estates were broken up or sold off, and the younger generation turned to other distractions, like golf.
But now, even in the face of a slow economy, polo is muscling back, largely as a result of Mr. Bianco's energy and salesmanship. Having taken control of the Meadowbrook Club in 1984 -- the two words were combined during a 1961 reorganization -- Mr. Bianco has slowly tried to rebuild membership by developing new fields and training programs.
The polo fields remain the playground of the well-heeled: polo ponies, bred mostly in the western United States, start at $4,500 to $7,000 and go up to $200,000. And, Mr. Bianco says, you must have at least two. Full membership in the club, which employs a full-time polo pro, costs $4,300 a year for a season that runs from May to October.
There are, of course, other polo meccas. There are clubs from Greenwich, Conn., to San Antonio to Santa Barbara, Calif. And though polo got its start in the United States in the Northeast, Palm Beach, Fla., is considered by many to be the nation's premier polo spot.
"But there is no club in the world that has the heritage of Meadowbrook," said Mr. Bianco.

HEADLINE: I.M.F. Warns of Sluggish '93 Growth

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 26

 BODY:
The world economy will experience sluggish growth for the third straight year and could suffer a new slowdown if the major industrial nations fail to take stronger steps to bolster growth, the International Monetary Fund said today in an economic forecast.
The I.M.F. said the United States economy would grow by 3.2 percent this year and next, but it predicted a dismal year of economic stagnation in Europe and unusually slow growth in Japan. 
 "The recovery of global economic activity after the 1991 downturn remains hesitant and uneven," the I.M.F said in its semiannual forecast, the World Economic Outlook.
The report said the Clinton Administration should have done considerably more to cut the budget deficit, saying its plan to reduce the deficit by $140 billion by 1998 -- to around $200 billion, or roughly 3 percent of the nation's gross domestic product -- was inadequate.
 
Would Lower Rates
 I.M.F. officials said deeper cuts in the deficit would help lower interest rates in the United States and abroad and make more money available for private investment.
Perhaps the biggest negative was the forecast that the economies of former Soviet republics would again shrink, by a painful 11.8 percent this year, after having shrunk 18.5 percent last year. But the report said that if the former Soviet lands succeeded in controlling inflation and creating basic market economies, they could experience "an economic turnaround as early as the middle of the decade."
The I.M.F. said sluggishness was fueling trade tensions as worries about high unemployment mounted. Emphasizing the importance of economic cooperation, it suggested further interest rate cuts in Germany and Japan as well as additional budgetary stimulation by Japan.
"If the industrial countries do not seize the opportunity for effective action," the forecast said, "a further deterioration of the economic climate and rising tensions over trade might be difficult to avoid."
In an unusually pointed statement for an I.M.F. official, Michael Mussa, the fund's research director, said at a news conference today that it would be good for the American economy and for economies generally if the United States were to cut its budget deficit by almost twice as much as the Clinton Administration has sought.
Mr. Mussa noted that many economists said it was unsatisfactory when the Reagan Administration pushed the budget deficit up to 3 percent of gross domestic product, saying that having a similar budget deficit now is also unsatisfactory.
"Further measures will therefore be necessary," the I.M.F. report said, although it noted that the President had already made a "considerable effort."
A Treasury official responded by saying that President Clinton's "deficit reduction package was the largest ever put forward by an American administration." He added that the Administration believed that deeper deficit cuts would have endangered economic growth.
The report forecast that Germany's economy would do miserably this year -- shrinking by 1.3 percent -- while European economies over all would fail to grow. The forecast did see Britain slowly pulling itself out of its long recession.
For Japan, the I.M.F. forecast puny growth of 1.3 percent this year, the same as last year. With inflation low and the yen near a high against the dollar, the report said Japan had room to lower its interest rates further.
The I.M.F. forecast that over all, economies would grow by 2.2 percent this year, up from 1.8 percent last year. This year's forecast is a big reduction from the fund's prediction of 3.6 percent, made in October.
Although it emphasized that there were risks that could slow growth, like increasing trade tensions and shaky business confidence, the I.M.F. forecast that the world economy would improve next year, growing at 3.4 percent.
The brightest spot in the report was a forecast that developing nations' economies would grow by a robust 5.1 percent this year, led by stunning growth of 6.7 percent in the emerging countries of Asia.
In much of its report, the I.M.F. sought to sound the alarm about rising trade tensions and growing protectionism, saying, "The significant benefits from free trade now seem threatened."
It said that the failure to conclude the current round of negotiations aimed at creating more liberal world trade rules was adding to this tension. It also criticized industrial nations for imposing trade penalties on others and for adopting managed-trade agreements.
"They run the risk of triggering a spiral of retaliation and counter-retaliation, severely harming business confidence and prospects for recovery," the report said.

HEADLINE: Ho Chi Minh City Journal;
The Smiles for Americans, and Other Paradoxes

BYLINE: By HENRY KAMM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HO CHI MINH CITY, Vietnam

 BODY:
The contradictions of Vietnam are evident everywhere, as the Communist Government tries to combine a free-market economy with rigid, one-party rule.
But they are most palpable in this city, which has been Communist for 18 years. Ho Chi Minh City, the former Saigon, has made rapid progress in the 1990's to undo the dour monotony imposed since 1975 by the stern party bureaucrats from the North, who came down to show their brothers the virtues of Marxism-Leninism. 
 It is not only that the restaurants today are more elegant than the best of the pre-Communist era. It is also that those who go there to dine and be seen do so with the self-assurance that only a very full wallet confers.
 
American Entrepreneurs Dine
 It is also that among the diners there are American business people whose main offices may be in Singapore, Kuala Lumpur or Hong Kong, in observance of the American embargo on trading with Vietnam, but much of whose business is done here.
Moreover, one may find among the guests men who for many years have been in the shadows because of supposed political unreliability. They include people active in politics under the old Saigon Government, as well as southern revolutionaries who fell into oblivion for resenting the North's dominance after 1975 or individualists difficult to incorporate into any authoritarian system.
The city also offers the sight of sailors from the first Communist country, whose ships no longer bring Soviet aid but serve as tramp freighters for cargoes from thriving Asian countries, stealing into the rear of shops on Nguyen Hue Street, bustling once more, to sell satchels full of contraband caviar for a pittance.
The Soviet Union was the country without which Vietnam might not have survived the enmity of the United States first and China later, and the reward for its extensive aid in war and peace is barely disguised scorn for the poverty of the few Russians still seen here.
The eagerness to welcome Americans in Vietnam, North and South, is one of the few things in which official pronouncements coincide with public opinion.
"We never felt bitterness toward the Americans," said Nguyen Tu Chi, a 67-year-old Hanoi anthropologist, combat soldier in the struggle against the French, and Communist Party member since 1946. "Maybe we have passed through too many wars. One gets used to it."
Visible as are the paradoxes of this city, they are equally strong in Hanoi. There, however, they strike the ear more than the eye. The lovely city of lakes, ringed by buildings of old Vietnamese, Chinese and French-colonial architecture, sadly run down, has changed little.
The paradoxes lie in the verbal gymnastics with which Government and party officials of the old school cling to justifications for an ideology that few others still believe.
While the ideology continues to be proclaimed and taught, throughout the North temples forced by the ideologists to be neglected for decades are being restored by villagers with their own hands and their limited money.
The face and voice of Pham Van Ngoc, an elderly carpenter in Xa Dong Tien, near Haiphong, trembled with modest pride as he showed the handsome dragons that he had copied in cement from another temple to decorate the classical roof of the village shrine. On an ordinary day, the restored temple was crowded with villagers praying, lighting joss sticks and bringing offerings of food.
At the opposite end of the widened ideological range, Vu Huu Ngoan, deputy director of the Institute of Marxism-Leninism, and a senior colleague, Dao Duy Quat, took pains to assure a visitor that the demise of their sister institutes in Europe, along with the parties that trained their functionaries there, had served only to reinforce them in their faith.
"I don't believe the doctrine has collapsed," Mr. Ngoan said. "On the contrary, the collapse of those countries proves that the principles are right and they applied them wrongly."
But because of the declining standing of Marx and Lenin, some of whose ideas they said had proved erroneous, the institute last May took out a kind of dialectical insurance. Mr. Ngoan said the name of Ho Chi Minh was added to the school's title.
"Maybe their own gods are no ideological giants, but they are their own," a Russian diplomat said.
Tran Cong Man, an amiable retired major general and journalist, who often serves as informal party spokesman, conceded that there was an ideological crisis. But all the old ideas of the class struggle still apply, he added. "There must be state enterprises," he said. "If we don't control them, we don't control the situation."
"In our experience, it isn't too necessary to have many parties," he said. "We want to have more and more democracy every day under the rule of one party."
There was real pain in the voice of General Man, an old Communist, when he said two of the highest socialist ideals -- free education and free medical care -- had proved luxuries that Vietnam could no longer afford. Parents now pay fees for their children from secondary school on, and doctors and medicines must be paid for.
Prof. Vu Van Tao, assistant to the Education Minister, said, "Today, free education is utopian in Vietnam."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Ho Chi Minh City, the former Saigon, has made rapid progress in the 1990's to undo the dour monotony imposed in Vietnam since 1975. Those who dine in Ho Chi Minh City's elegant restaurants, like these guests at a wedding party, display a wealth and extravagance previously unknown. (Robert Maas/Sipa Press)
 
Map of Vietnam showing location of Ho Chi Minh City.

HEADLINE: Coke Plans to Buy 30% Stake In Mexican Soft Drink Unit

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, April 26

 BODY:
The Coca-Cola Company announced today that it would spend $195 million to buy a 30 percent stake in the soft drink operation of Fomento Economico Mexicano S.A., the Monterrey-based company that holds Coke's biggest foreign franchise.
The move raises Coca-Cola's stakes in what has become one of the most important theaters of its global struggle with Pepsi-Cola International. Mexico's per-capita cola consumption is second only to that of the United States, and the nation's thirst is expected to grow for years, with or without ratification of the North American Free Trade Agreement. 
 The proposed sale values the soft-drink arm of Femsa, as the Mexican company is known, at $650 million, or 15.8 times the division's 1992 earnings. The figure is considerably less than some beverage industry analysts had forecast, and the price of Femsa shares fell nearly 4 percent today to close at $3.86 on Mexico City's Bolsa de Valores.
Last month, Pepsi International announced that it would spend $115 million on equity stakes in its franchises in Monterrey, Guadalajara, Mexico City's suburbs and other parts of the country. Pepsi said it would spend another $635 million to expand its operations around Mexico over the next five years.
"To a large degree, this is a defensive move by Coca-Cola," said Carlos Laboy, an analyst at James Capel Inc. in New York. "But it's a good way to counter Pepsi's moves and it's a good way for Coca-Cola to acquire greater management control over its largest franchise in the world."
In a first rejoinder last week, Coca-Cola announced that its "system" would spend $3 billion in Mexico over the next five years. Half of the amount is to go into advertising and promotions, while the other half is to be invested in the renovation and expansion of Coca-Cola's bottling and distribution operations and the building of eight new plants.
By borrowing new money and selling shares, Femsa Refrescos S.A., as the soft-drink unit is called, will contribute a third of the money for improvements. Femsa's general director, Othon Ruiz Montemayor, said the soft drink unit would spend the money to build a "megaplant" in the Mexico City valley and a bottling plant in the southern state of Oaxaca, and to upgrade its distribution network, warehouses and other bottling plants.
Industry analysts said they expected Coca-Cola's investment in the Femsa subsidiary, the company's first equity stake in a Latin American bottler, to quickly turn the franchise into an even more important cog in Coke's operations in the region.
Officials of the two companies said Femsa Refrescos would be reconstituted as a debt-free company -- a factor that seemed to account in part for the unexpectedly low multiple of earnings reflected in the sale.
 
Latin American Foothold
 They said that in addition to spending $500 million over the next five years to modernize and expand production and distribution capacities, the unit might also buy or take over franchises in other parts of Mexico and elsewhere in Latin America.
The soft drink unit is to get a separate listing on stock exchanges in Mexico and abroad. Femsa officials said they would soon offer as much as 19 percent of their share in the subsidiary for public sale; Coca-Cola's chairman, Roberto C. Goizueta, left open the possibility that Coke might try to increase its stake, but its executive vice president, John Hunter, said later that Coke had no such plans.
Under the sale arrangement, Coke is to have four seats on the board of the soft drink unit. Femsa gets five seats, including that of the chairman.
 Industry analysts have voiced concern, echoed privately by some Coca-Cola Company officials, that the conglomerate that owns 51 percent of Femsa, Valores Industriales S.A., or Visa, has not been focusing sufficiently on soft drinks. In October 1991, Visa's management led the purchase from the Government of the second-biggest bank in Mexico, Bancomer S.A., and used Femsa to borrow $610 for the deal. Visa has also been hunting for strategic partners for its other ventures in beer, packaging and convenience stores.
 
Market Share Claims
 Pepsi has been moving aggressively in Mexico, where it is believed to command about a quarter of all cola sales and slightly more than 20 percent of the entire market for soft drinks. (The competitors' claims of market share conflict, and there is no independent public estimate.)
The country's biggest Pepsi bottler, Grupo Embotelladora de Mexico S.A., or Gemex, stole away some of Femsa's market share in the Mexico City valley last year by producing a returnable 1.5-liter product more quickly and promoting it more heavily. Femsa has since won back the 55 percent share of the region's cola market that it previously enjoyed, but has had to scramble to keep up with Gemex's innovations in distribution and sales tactics.
 
 
No Call to Arms
 Coke and Femsa officials announced the sale at a Mexico City news conference at which they all seemed to be trying hard to sound as nondefensive as possible. Sitting behind a row of open Coke bottles -- from which none of them drank -- they scrupulously avoided terms like "Pepsi" and "war."
Referring obliquely to "all the recent noise made by some of our competitors," Mr. Goizueta said, "We sell more than twice as much as they do."
 
Battle Intensifies
 But neither he nor other company executives seemed to challenge the notion of many industry analysts that Femsa and Coca-Cola will have to fight harder and differently to keep their huge share of the market.
"Generally in Mexico, the advertising hasn't been nearly so competitive a process and the focus has been on distribution," said Timothy C. Davis, a Latin America analyst at Lazard Freres & Company in New York. "But as the distribution networks develop, the market will become more like the United States, where the major soft-drink producers battle over points of market share."
In comparison with most of the rest of the world, Mexico is already a cola seller's bonanza. According to Coke, only the average American (who drank 296 eight-ounce servings) was able to outdrink the average Mexican (who consumed 275 servings) last year when it came to Coke, Fanta, Sprite and other soft drinks produced by the company.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Selloffs by Italy Reduced To Olive Oil and Gelati

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ROME, April 26

 BODY:
Amid the political upheaval in Italy, the Government is trying to sell some huge, state-owned companies including an ice cream maker and the producer of the best-selling olive oil exported to the United States.
The aims of the intended sales are to unravel decades of state involvement in the economy, reduce a $100 billion budget deficit and also take aim at the $1.2 trillion national debt. 
 Timed from 1992 to 1995, the sales of Government stakes in banks, food-processing companies, engineering firms, and energy and insurance enterprises were supposed to raise more than $25 billion, making the project the largest divestiture of state assets in continental Europe.
Thus far, though, nothing has been sold, and critics are suggesting that the plan was overly ambitious. The only transactions in a relatively advanced stage involve two food-retailing divisions owned by Societa Meridionale Finanziaria S.p.A., known as SME. That, in turn, is 62 percent owned by a giant state holding company, Istituto per la Ricostruzione Industriale, or IRI.
The two divisions are Italgel and Cirio-Bertolli-Derica. What makes them attractive to potential buyers is both their profitability and their market position. Italgel is No. 2 in the Italian ice cream market with a 30 percent share, and No. 2 among all frozen foods with 18 percent.
 
A Big Name in Tomatoes
 In addition, Cirio-Bertolli-Derica leads the processed tomato-products market with a 27 percent share and is Italy's top canned-food producer with 22 percent. Their brand names, including Cirio canned foods and Bertolli olive oil -- also a market leader -- are household words in Italy. And Bertolli is the leading imported olive oil in the United States, with 24 percent of the market, a company spokesman said.
"The interest in buying into these companies is basically twofold," a food-industry analyst who spoke in return for anonymity said. For Italian companies, it offers a way of expanding their share of the market. For outsiders, it offers a point of entry into a very big market.
Italian news reports last week said 12 corporations, nine of them Italian, had survived a selection process to enter bids. Five bid for Italgel and the others for Cirio-Bertolli-Derica. They included some of the country's food giants, including Ferruzzi, Barilla and Parmalat. The foreign bidders were said to include Nestle, Unilever, Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. of Britain and the BSN Group of France.
The names of the bidders, however, have not been formally announced by the American merchant banker Wasserstein, Perella & Company, which is handling the deal. Details of the bids were not immediately known.
The auction has had its uneven stretches. Workers at SME headquarters in Naples occupied the premises for nearly three months this year until managers agreed that whatever happened to the company its headquarters would remain in Naples.
 
Touched by Scandal
 Nor has SME escaped the vast national bribery scandal. Its managing director, Mario Artali, was jailed for a time, and then freed this month to face questioning about the illicit financing of political parties that forms a main strand of the scandal.
Beyond this pending sale, the privatization program has mostly generated debate. Conservative opponents of the process forced the suspension of a decree that would have created a separate privatization ministry. And opposition is mounting to the next, far more controversial sale of a 67 percent stake in Credito Italiano, the country's sixth-largest bank.
"Possibly, it was done in too much of a hurry," said Enzo Berlanda, the head of Italy's stockbrokers' confederation, "because when we talk about a bank, we are talking about money, assets and the danger of foreigners taking over."
Treasury Minister Piero Barucci said recently that the Government planned to shed its majority stake in energy companies, acknowledging that details needed to be worked out. In the meantime, Italy is facing the prospect of a new Government and a protracted political crisis over electoral reform.
The privatization program was not squarely in the public eye this past week because of a national referendum on the reforms, in which Italians voted overwhelmingly to scrap much of the system that has prevailed since World War II. If changes on that scale come to pass in the electoral system, and thus in the way the country is run, privatization will assume even greater importance as the economic underpinning of what some hope will be a political revolution.
There are further pressures on Italy to privatize. European Community rules on competition make it impossible for the state to continue financing money-losing industrial albatrosses. The giants of state ownership, IRI and the energy conglomerate ENI, need to revitalize subsidiaries and pay off debts. And Italy is committed to reducing its deficit to meet European Community standards.
Rome's ability to continue drawing on a $10 billion community loan, granted in part to offset the costs of trying to defend the lira during the currency crisis last September, depends on meeting tighter fiscal-management targets.

HEADLINE: For Bellamy, Asserting Fiscal and Electoral Credentials for Comptroller

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, April 26

 BODY:
Carol Bellamy, a leading candidate for state comptroller, spent more than an hour at a legislative hearing today telling lawmakers her views on auditing, pension investments and debt reform. She even impressed legislators by knowing that P.U.C., an actuarial method used to calculate pension contributions, stands for projected unit credit.
But the most important part of Ms. Bellamy's presentation today may have been the chart she handed out showing how many votes she won in each of New York's 62 counties in 1990. 
 Ms. Bellamy, a Democrat, narrowly lost that race for state comptroller to Edward V. Regan, the Republican incumbent who plans to retire on Friday. And for all Ms. Bellamy's mastery of the subject matter, it may be her potential to win a statewide election in 1994 that most interests the Democratic legislators charged with choosing Mr. Regan's successor.
In fact, none of the six candidates seeking to succeed Mr. Regan seems to believe that the policy issues discussed in a two-day series of hearings that began today will have much to do with whom the Legislature selects. The most critical issue, they say, will be who wins the endorsement of Assembly Speaker Saul Weprin, who presumably will have the political power to swing the election.
 
Political Realities
 Ms. Bellamy seemed to acknowledge those political realities in her testimony today. After briefly discussing the issues, she said: "I am the only candidate who has demonstrated public support for the office of state comptroller. In 1990, running against a three-term incumbent, almost 2 million voters, or 49 percent of the electorate, voted for me. From Niagara Falls to Montauk, those votes were cast by tens of thousands of your constituents in every single Senate and Assembly district across the state."
The Speaker, a Queens Democrat, did not attend today's hearing. But he has said he probably will announce an endorsement after the hearings conclude. Among other things, Mr. Weprin wants to make sure that none of the candidates commits a political or policy faux pas, according to his colleagues. None of the four who appeared today seemed to do so today.
When the state comptroller leaves office in the middle of a term, New York's Constitution gives the Legislature, sitting as a whole, the responsibility to fill the position.
Democrats hold 127 of the Legislature's 211 seats, so if they keep a united front they can insure the election of a fellow Democrat. And because Mr. Weprin is the leader of 101 of the 127 Democrats, he is considered the kingmaker.
 
Significant Fiscal Powers
 The comptroller's job is coveted partly because it carries significant fiscal powers, including investing a $56 billion pension fund, auditing state agencies and local governments and critiquing the state's debt and budget practices. But it also is one of only six statewide elective offices and is considered a potential springboard to higher office.
The Republicans are boycotting this week's hearings in protest over the Democrats' control of the election, notwithstanding that it was a Republican, Mr. Regan, who put them in this fix.
Almost since Mr. Regan announced his plans in February to retire, lawyers for the Republican-controlled Senate have been devising legal and parliamentary maneuvers to block the election of a Democrat. The Senate Republicans plan to pass a bill on Wednesday that would require a nonbinding public referendum before the Legislature could choose a candidate.
Senate aides said they would also favor allowing Mr. Regan's deputy to run the comptroller's office until a successor is elected popularly in 1994. And they said the Senate simply may refuse to convene the joint legislative session needed for a vote, a move likely to inspire a long court fight.
"We're trying to draw attention to the fact that this is not an open and public process and that people are being excluded," said John E. McArdle, a spokesman for the Senate Republicans.
The candidates who appeared at today's hearing with Ms. Bellamy, who is a managing director of Bear, Stearns & Company and a former New York City Council President, were Assemblyman Joseph R. Lentol of Brooklyn, Assemblyman Robin Schimminger of Kenmore and Joel A. Giambra, the Buffalo City Comptroller.
The other candidates, H. Carl McCall, the president of the New York City Board of Education, and Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx Borough President, are scheduled to appear on Tuesday. Mr. McCall and Ms. Bellamy are considered by many in Albany to be the leading contenders.
At today's hearing, Mr. Lentol and Mr. Schimminger stressed their legislative service, with Mr. Schimminger telling his colleagues that the Legislature is "likely to find the very best person to serve in that vacated office within its own ranks." Mr. Giambra emphasized that he was "the only one that has been elected to the office of comptroller."
On the issues, Ms. Bellamy said she would use the clout of New York State's pension fund to influence the management of the corporations it invests in but would not seek to micromanage them.
She said she would not invest pension money in banks that "red line" disadvantaged neighborhoods. And on economic as well as social grounds, she said she would seek to divest the state of investments in companies doing business with South Africa, even without legislation mandating that she do so.
 
Some Tough Questioning
 Ms. Bellamy faced some antagonistic questioning from McCall supporters on the panel.
Assemblyman Arthur O. Eve of Buffalo said he found it "a little offensive" that Ms. Bellamy said she plans to run for comptroller in 1994 regardless of whether she wins the interim appointment.
Assemblyman Clarence Norman Jr. of Brooklyn asked how she would handle the potential conflict of using Bear, Stearns to underwrite state bond issues. And Senator Howard C. Nolan Jr. of Albany pointed out that while she almost won her 1990 campaign, she failed to defeat what he termed a vulnerable incumbent.

HEADLINE: Frank Vanderlip, Philanthropist And Investment Banker, at 86

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON

 BODY:
Frank Arthur Vanderlip Jr., a New York investment banker and philanthropist, died on Friday at the John Douglas French Center for Alzheimer's disease in Los Alamitos, Calif. He was 86 and lived in Somers, N.Y., and on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.
The cause was cancer, said Henrik N. Vanderlip, a nephew. 
 Mr. Vanderlip was born in Scarborough, N.Y. His father was a financier, president of National City Bank of New York, now Citibank, and Assistant Secretary of the Treasury under President William McKinley. He attended the Scarborough School, founded by his parents, and Phillips Exeter Academy, before graduating in economics and architecture from Harvard in 1930.
Mr. Vanderlip became well known as a fund raiser and organizer of charity balls, for causes that included mental health and the fight against cancer.
 
Active in Civic Affairs
 He was a past president of the Cancer Care volunteers for the National Cancer Foundation, and director and treasurer of the American Opera Society. Over the years he also served as a member of the executive council of the International Young Men's Christian Association, chairman of the Committee on Mental Health Needs of New York City, and a council member of the National Municipal League.
He and his second wife, Dr. Neva Eileen McGrath, built the Beechwood Theater for the Scarborough School on the former family estate, Beechwood, in Scarborough.
In World War II, he was commissioned into the Army and rose to the rank of lieutenant colonel while serving in Australia, New Zealand, Africa and Europe. His commendations included the Outstanding Civilian Service Medal of the Armed Forces and the French Legion of Honor.
In business he headed family-controlled investment and real-estate concerns, like the Palos Verdes Corporation in southern California. He also held directorships in various corporations.
Mr. Vanderlip's wife died a year ago. He is survived by a brother, John, of Rancho Palos Verdes, and 12 nieces and nephews.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Gold Up $6.30 in New York; Highest Price in 9 Months

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: LONDON, April 26

 BODY:
Gold surged to its highest price in six months here today and reached a nine-month high in New York on reports that the British financier Sir James Goldsmith had stepped into the market and executed a major purchase.
Sir James reportedly bought the gold after George Soros, a Wall Street investor and fund manager, bought a 10 percent stake in the Newmont Mining Corporation from Sir James for $400 million. 
 The metal climbed more than $5 in London to $349.25 an ounce, its highest since Oct. 9, and then moved higher on the Commodity Exchange in New York to end at $352.80, up $6.30 from Friday's close. That was the highest settlement for spot deliveries since July 31.
The buying also spilled over into silver, lifting the price by 11.1 cents, to $4.065 an ounce in New York trading.
 
Other Markets mixed
In other commodity markets, coffee prices soared and grain and energy prices were mixed.
Gold had been in the doldrums for several years but a surge of buying was reported last week on worries about inflation and the clouded outlook for economic reform in Russia.
One dealer cited the worldwide lowering of interest rates, which threatens to fan the flames of inflation.
"The policy seems to be -- stimulate regrowth at any cost," he said. "Governments appear to be ignoring the inflation risk and that is good for gold."
But analysts had mixed views on how much higher the market could go.
"The market has work to do around $350," one dealer said. "We could see gold trading at $360 an ounce eventually, but I think we'll see the market back at $345 before then."
Coffee prices rallied when a large trading house snapped up deliveries at the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange.
Coffee prices have declined since representatives for growers and consumers were unable to come to any agreement on re-establishing a quota system that would lift the market.
But Dean Witter Reynolds, the large trading house, took delivery of a substantial supply.
"That indicates there's a final destination for the coffee," said one analyst of Dean Witter's move.
Grain prices ended mixed in Chicago, where buying in the soybean complex was balanced against worries over Russia's purchasing plans.
Oil trading was quiet, with June crude oil down 4 cents at $20.30 a barrel.

HEADLINE: U.S. Chides Europe Bank On Spending

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, April 26

 BODY:
The United States chastised the head of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development today for lavish spending of taxpayer money, but said it would continue to support the institution's efforts to promote the development of capitalism in Eastern Europe.
The United States is the largest financial backer of the European Bank, which was set up by Western governments two years ago to promote private enterprise in the former Soviet bloc. 
 The bank and its president, Jacques Attali, have come under criticism in recent weeks for spending $83 million on a new headquarters in London and hundreds of thousands of dollars on private jet flights for Mr. Attali. The spending has come under particular criticism because of the slow pace of lending by the bank, which has so far lent or invested only about $240 million in the formerly Communist nations.
 
U.S. Official Speaks
 Speaking at a meeting here of the bank's board, Roger Altman, the Deputy United States Treasury Secretary and the nation's top representative at the meeting, said the Clinton Administration "expects institutions to which we have entrusted public money to use the money wisely."
Mr. Altman said the United States, which has committed $350 million in capital to the bank over five years, had asked Mr. Attali for a review of the management and budget process, with an eye toward tightening controls over internal spending.
"We are sure that Mr. Attali and the bank understand the importance of taking organizational steps to deal with these problems," Mr. Altman said.
Mr. Altman was only one of several officials at the meeting who expressed unhappiness.
Viktor Geraschenko, the chairman of the Russian central bank, said he was disappointed with the level of lending to his nation, saying it had amounted to only $7.5 million so far.
"I believe this is a paltry sum and in no way comparable with the predicted participation of the European Bank or with the promises of the bank's management," he said.
 
Mistakes Admitted
 Mr. Attali, who has admitted making mistakes in overseeing the bank's spending, told the meeting that he expected the pace of lending to increase.
Mr. Altman said that despite the Clinton Administration's unhappiness with Mr. Attali's management, the United States agreed that the bank should be an important part of the West's efforts in the region. He said the United States would like to see the bank re-emphasize lending to private enterprise rather than the financing of public projects like telephone networks.
Mr. Altman said that ultimately the United States wanted to see the bank meet the commitment in its charter to devote 60 percent of its funds to the private sector, up from about 50 percent now, but that he was flexible about how quickly that should happen.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Mostly Heads Lower But Gains Against the Yen

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar declined broadly against European currencies yesterday as worries over economic weakness in the United States helped persuade traders to buy British pounds and German marks.
The dollar advanced only against the yen, as world leaders continued to tone down their recent support for a stronger Japanese currency. 
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 110.05 yen, up 0.15 yen from Friday's close. In late New York trading, the dollar was worth 110.60 yen, up from 110.50 late Friday.
Most of the currency buying, though, focused on German marks and British pounds after President Boris N. Yeltsin's apparent victory in the weekend referendum in Russia.
"This is one of the more positive results of this referendum that the market was looking for," said Lisa Finstrom, a currency analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. "It's still an uncertain situation, but not as bad as people had feared."
Economic data from Britain drew attention to the pound. In the latest positive statistic, the Government yesterday proclaimed the end of the nation's longest postwar recession, saying that the economy grew modestly in the year's first quarter after more than two years of decline.
In western Germany, several states reported inflation increases of more than 4 percent, which helped underscore sentiment that the German central bank would not deviate from its policy of making only gradual reductions in interest rates.
This encouraged sales of dollars, since investment generally flows to currencies where interest rates are higher.
Also contributing to the dollar's retreat were further worries about the economy in the United States. Friday's news of a disappointing decline in March durable-goods orders was followed yesterday by a real estate trade group's report that sales of previously owned homes dropped 2.9 percent in March, the third straight month of declines..
In London, the British pound rose to $1.5903, from $1.5745 late Friday. By late afternoon in New York, the pound fetched $1.5840, up from $1.5747 late Friday.

HEADLINE: Executive Dip In Confidence

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 26

 BODY:
Manufacturing businesses' confidence slipped in April for the second consecutive month, partly because of uncertainty about the Clinton Administration's plans, Cahners Economics Inc. said today.
"All signs are that the recent retrenchment in business confidence merely reflects a cooling-off period for the industrial sector, rather than a reversal," Cahners said after surveying about 400 business executives. Its findings cover businesses in four areas sensitive to economic cycles, computers, construction, consumer goods and general manufacturing. 
 The Cahners business confidence index, which had risen for four straight months until March, fell to 66.3 in April from 67.8 in March and 68.9 in February.
Only 59 percent of the executives surveyed said business conditions were good or excellent, down from 62 percent in March. The portion of executives who expected improvement slipped to 71 percent in April from 79 percent in March.
The survey found that business executives want deficit reduction to be the top priority for the Administration, with 55 percent saying that should be the case. Twenty-nine percent of the executives said job creation through an economic revitalization program should be Government's top priority.

HEADLINE: Resales Off For Houses

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 26

 BODY:
Sales of previously owned houses dropped 2.9 percent in March, the third straight month of declines caused by severe weather, a real estate trade group said today. Sales fell in every region except the Midwest.
"Sellers and buyers lost a week in March" because of bad weather, said William S. Chee, president of the National Association of Realtors. But he added that sales appeared to have picked up since then. 
 The group said sales of previously owned houses totaled 3.36 million at a seasonally adjusted annual rate in March, down from 3.46 million a month earlier.
The revised 8.5 percent drop in sales in February was even steeper than the initial estimate of 6.1 percent. Sales fell 6.4 percent in January after rising 4.7 percent in the final month of 1992.
Mr. Chee said the severe blizzard in March brought housing activity to a virtual standstill for several days in the South and Northeast. But he said anecdotal evidence suggested sales had resumed. "Buyers are continuing to take advantage of low mortgage rates," he said.
The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation reported that the national average commitment rate for 30-year conventional fixed-rate mortgages was 7.5 percent in March, down from 7.68 percent the previous month.
The median price of a house in the United States in March was $106,000, up 2.3 percent from February. The median means that half of the houses cost more and half cost less.

HEADLINE: Reviews/ Television;
Real People With Babies On the Way

BYLINE: By JOHN J. O'CONNOR

 BODY:
In the often hazy reality of prime-time entertainment, few events are exploited more adroitly than the birth of a baby. Ratings sagging? Get yourself a pregnancy. From Lucy to Murphy, the ploy seems fail-safe, although, as the subsequent sag in "Murphy Brown" may indicate, not necessarily conducive to long-range survival.
Homing in on the obvious, an hourlong ABC special called "We're Expecting," tonight at 10, follows three couples as each goes through the special experience of having a first child. Reading Louis H. Gorfain's script, Connie Selleca is the warmly reassuring host, promising a journey that will be "wondrous, exhausting, exhilarating." 
 Pushing the consumerism button, the show also looks long and affectionately at "the business of birthing," which, in addition to fees for special classes, involves buying clothes, toys and furniture. Says one expectant mother looking at a very expensive brass-plated crib, "This is gorgeous!" Says the salesman quickly, "An excellent choice," adding ever so smoothly that "you only have your first baby once."
The couples chosen for this exercise are pleasant people, one and all, some coping better than others. The best off economically, a black couple, have the most worrying pregnancy complications. The second husband and wife fret about job and housing problems. The third pair goes into somewhat refreshing reverse: he has morning sickness and is gaining weight, while she is worried because she's feeling so well, relieved only when she finally hears the embryo's heartbeat.
But "We're Expecting" can't resist jerking everybody's leash. As the mother-to-be hears the heartbeat, Ms. Selleca murmurs: "Listen hard. Hear your miracle!" Now, as an exploding world population attests, there is nothing miraculous about having a child. The biological process is normally straightforward. There is nothing supernatural about it. It can be a wonderfully gratifying experience or, as in the instance of AIDS babies, it can be heartbreaking.
But prime time usually insists on nonstop gushing. Children born into television series are obviously going to grow up to become Shirley Temple or Macaulay Culkin, not Amy Fisher or Joey Buttafuoco. Too often, young viewers can get the idea that having a baby is something like getting another doll. Perhaps, no matter what pessimistic evidence to the contrary, cockeyed optimism should prevail. Ms. Selleca certainly remains unruffled. "It's all you could ever expect," she concludes, "and much, much more." Especially if the ratings are good.
 
We're Expecting
ABC, tonight at 10.
(Channel 7 in New York.)

Written by Louis H. Gorfain; directed by Charles A. Bangert and Hank O'Karma; Casey Schwartz, co-producer; Mr. O'Karma, producer; Mr. Bangert and Mr. Gorfain, executive producers. Connie Sellecca, host. A New Screen Concepts Production.
