HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
Imagining the Electric-Car Future

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 22

 BODY:
Research and development for electric vehicles have mainly concentrated on batteries, power controllers, motors and other vehicle parts. But what about the infrastructure in which the vehicles will function?
One visionary sees battery-recharging stations being combined with other commercial establishments -- Charg-'n'-Shop might do brisk business at a shopping mall, or Charg-'n'-Eat at an Interstate highway exit.
 
Sketching the Future
 Such visions of the future have come tumbling forth in an unusual design competition here that has as much in common with architecture as engineering. Some 130 teams of planners, thinkers and dreamers have submitted their ideas in poster-board form for a contest with the theme "The Electric Vehicle and the American Community." Their sketches offered ideas for new products, new services and whole new industries. 
 The electric-car future is not far off. California has adopted rules demanding mass sales of electric cars, beginning in 1998, and depending on the outcome of courtroom appeals by the auto companies, the same may hold true in New York, Massachusetts and other big Eastern states.
Beyond such basic questions as what the car will look like, there are broader uncertainties. Would electric vehicles be charged at the owner's house, at a service station, or while the car was parked at work? The electric may be the perfect urban vehicle, but how would a city dweller who does not have a garage or driveway charge up a car? If cars could be charged as they ran, through magnetic fields from under-road metal plates, how would drivers be billed?
"There are very real unanswered questions," said Steven G. Cecil, the manager of the competition, which was sponsored primarily by the Edison Electric Institute, a utility trade association; the General Motors Corporation and the Energy Department. "The engineering types have their own tradition of predicting what the future will look like. We're trying to place ourselves in that tradition."
 
Panel of Specialists
 So beneath an age-darkened oil portrait of Thomas Edison, a seven-member panel drawn from specialists in energy, the environment, engineering and architecture completed judging the entries today; the dozen or so winners, who will split $100,000 in prizes, will be announced on May 10. The contest sponsors are not planning to execute any of the designs; the intent was simply to stimulate thinking.
The judges assessed each entry without knowing whose work they were viewing. A reporter was invited to observe on condition that the judges not be quoted by name in their frank assessments of specific submissions.
Several entries proposed the popularization of electric vehicles through regulatory means. A plan for Keene, N.H., for example, called for giving zoning benefits to buildings that offer recharging, or other accommodations for electric vehicles, or in which 25 percent of the employees drive electrics. Such buildings would be entitled to a "density bonus" of two extra stories.
 
A New Kind of Shopping
 This same entry, made by the Charg-'n'-Eat folks, also depicted a store called Battery Exchange -- placed next to a Kmart in a flourish of authenticity.
An entry from Sacramento, Calif., foresaw a different adaptation of commerce: Mom & Pop's Fruit & Battery Farm, a roadside stand set against a backdrop of windmills and farm fields.
There were metropolitan images, too. A Philadelphia proposal predicted expensive homes on the median strips of major highways, once the noise of internal combustion engines had faded to memory. It also included a sketch of a vandal-resistant curbside recharging unit for use in neighborhoods without driveways.
Though not bothering with such details as how a resident would insure that someone else did not park in his space, the entry did take care to predict what the cars will look like. One was an electric reproduction of the '57 Chevy, produced by Fonda (the future parent company of Ford and Honda). Another was the Chrysler '09 Elvis. (That's '09 as in 2009, and no, the King wasn't behind the wheel -- he was merely the design on the hood.)
But the car companies have miles to go before worrying about such cosmetics. So far, the auto manufacturers have not settled on a common design for the electrical plug, an essential standard if all electric vehicles will be able to recharge at any station.
"This field is changing so much, that if I were a manufacturer I would be very hard pressed to make a commitment to build," said Paul MacCready, the chairman of Aerovironment Inc., the company that designed the Impact, a zippy two-seater electric prototype, for General Motors.
The true value of the competition, Mr. MacCready said, was "edging people to think about transportation, rather than cars." In recent decades, he said, gasoline-powered cars have "developed our civilization." Now, with some advance planning, he said, perhaps people could regain the initiative, and could plan the civilization and the vehicles to match.
Many designs called for supplanting the gasoline-powered car with the electric through inducements, like preferential parking for electric vehicles. A proposal for Cambridge, Mass., sketched the partial redevelopment of the Alewife stop on the Boston subway system.
The Alewife stop is currently the site of a huge elevated parking garage. The proposal was to drape it with photovoltaic cells, to provide electricity for recharging cars while their owners took the subway into Boston. The design also called for a day-care center and a supermarket to be added to the complex, to reduce the demand for travel.
That design also addressed, if only broadly, the problem of rapid recharging. If a car is to be recharged in five minutes or so, the demand for current is enormous.
To go 100 miles or so between charges, for example, G.M.'s Impact carries about 14 kilowatt-hours of electricity in its 900 pounds of batteries. If those batteries could be charged in five minutes -- itself a challenge, given the state of battery technology today -- they would need to draw well over 100 kilowatts. That is about the same amount of electricity that a small office building draws, pointed out another judge, James J. MacKenzie, senior associate of the World Resources Institute, an environmental group.
 
Spinning a Solution
 The solution in the Cambridge design was to store energy in a flywheel, whose spinning would be converted back to electricity when needed.
Another competitor, though, sketched a filling station with three different charging outlets -- standard, rapid and economy -- a parallel to the differing grades of gasolines sold today.
Another proposed a system of plates buried in the streets that could transmit energy to similar plates mounted on cars.
"How would the owner get billed?" one judge asked another. "Scanners, fiber optics, something," said the other.
Let the engineers iron out the details.

HEADLINE: Consumer Optimism Improves

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
To the surprise of many economists, consumers became slightly less pessimistic in April for the first time this year.
The Conference Board, a New York-based business organization, reported yesterday that its closely followed consumer confidence index bounced up to 67.7 in April, from 63.2 in March, regaining nearly a third of its 15-point drop since December, when post-election euphoria peaked. 
 The upturn cheered stock investors. Retailers track the survey because consumers' spirits -- just like income, inflation or interest rates -- can affect their willingness to spend. The mail survey includes 5,000 families around the country, and yesterday's report covers responses gathered during the first three weeks of April.
 
Two Gloomy Regions
 Confidence brightened a bit this month in six out of nine regions of the country, according to the Conference Board, though not in the mid-Atlantic region, which includes New York. The mid-Atlantic and the West Coast remain the the gloomiest regions. Consumers are most optimistic in parts of the country where the economy has held up pretty well, namely, the mountain states, the upper Midwest and the South.
Americans all over the country are still extraordinarily worried about the weak job market. According to the April survey, 15.5 percent of consumers, only a bit more than 14.9 percent a month earlier, think that jobs will be more abundant by Labor Day. A larger 22.1 percent believe that jobs will actually become scarcer. As recently as January the job optimists outnumbered the pessimists.
Not surprisingly, consumers say they do not have big spending plans. Just 6 percent say they are going to buy a car within the next six months, 3 percent plan to buy a house and 27 percent expect to buy a big-ticket appliance, about the same proportions as a year earlier.
Nonetheless, the Conference Board survey shows that consumers' perceptions of current business conditions are more positive than they have been since last summer. That observation squares with recent weekly readings from a ABC/Money magazine consumer poll that portrays consumers as relatively more sanguine about their current financial situation than about the economy's future prospects.
Spending does not always follow the ups and downs of consumers' spirits, but this month retailers and car dealers are reporting that consumers are also buying more. Car sales have turned more solid in the last few weeks, for example. In the first 20 days of April, auto sales averaged 6.6 million at an annual rate, compared with an annual rate of 6.3 million in March.
And chain-store sales also seem to have bounced back from their mid-March funk, the Johnson Redbook Service, a weekly survey of about 25 national retail chains, reported yesterday. For the first three weeks of the month, sales have been 9.3 percent higher than a year earlier and, seasonally adjusted, are up 2.3 percent from March.
"Sales have been pretty good," Steven Marotta, analyst at the Johnson Redbook Service. "We haven't seen numbers like these since Christmas."
For example, at the Century City Shopping Center and Market Place in Los Angeles, sales have picked up in the last 10 days or so, especially for spring clothes, toys, furniture and consumer electronics. "The weather's been beautiful," Linda Smith Frost, the center's marketing director, said. "And there was a collective sigh of relief after the Rodney King trial verdict."
But the slightly better mood does not mean that consumers will soon be spending as freely as last summer and fall.
For one thing, confidence is still relatively weak. During the boom of the 1980's, readings of 100 or more on the Conference Board's index were typical. "The April reading is encouraging," said Jason Bram, an economist at the Conference Board, "but it's too moderate a gain to signal the start of an enduring upward trend."
 
 
Other Reasons
 Besides, there are other reasons for thinking that consumers will not be the economy's main engine of growth this year.
"The consumer still suffers from the same litany of problems that have kept spending weak for several years," Bruce Steinberg, an economist at Merrill Lynch, said. "Job growth is still sluggish. Wages are rising slowly. And the debt burden is still heavy."

HEADLINE: Company That Shut Factory Has Returned From Mexico

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: STONINGTON, Conn., April 27

 BODY:
In 1989, Quality Coils closed its factory here and moved production to Juarez, Mexico, in search of cheaper labor. Now, the company has returned, saying that decision actually cost it money.
"What we learned down in Mexico is that the up-front wages might look a lot less expensive," the company's president, Keith A. Gibson, said. "What we found is that the Connecticut worker is by far more productive." 
 By returning to Stonington, he said, the company hopes to save $150,000 a year despite the higher wages and insurance costs for workers here.
The company's announcement comes less than two weeks after the state's largest employer, Pratt & Whitney, threatened to close two plants in Connecticut, saying its costs here were $6 to $8 an hour more per employee than at its plants in Maine and Georgia.
State officials were quick to seize on the experience of Quality Coils as a reason for manufacturers to stay in Connecticut.
 
'The Bottom Line'
 "The fact is worker productivity goes right to the bottom line," the State Economic Development Commissioner, Joseph J. McGee, said. "Let this be a warning to other small manufacturers to look very closely before moving out of Connecticut."
Quality Coils, which is based in Bristol, Conn., reopened its Stonington plant, near the Rhode Island border, in February.
The company makes electromagnetic coils for refrigeration equipment, motors, relays and signaling devices, and it employs 200 people, with its overall sales reaching $9.6 million in 1992. The plant in Stonington has 18 workers, but that number is expected to reach close to 40 once all its equipment has arrived from Mexico.
Wages in Mexico average $5.38 an hour, including benefits, Mr. Gibson said, compared with $10 an hour here. But he said it takes one Connectciut worker to do the work of three employees in Mexico.
Mr. Gibson said Quality Coils expects to receive $50,000 to $60,000 from the state for the relocation costs.
"We have agreed to help in some undefined way to offset the cost of this move," acknowledged Joseph M. Cohen, a spokesman for the State Economic Development Department. "So far, it's a verbal commitment only."
That assistance, Mr. Cohen added, is not likely to include any tax incentives.
 
Projections Questioned
 Speaking at a ribbon-cutting ceremony here today, Mr. McGee challenged Pratt & Whitney's estimates of the added costs of manufacturing in Connecticut.
He said Pratt & Whitney was guilty of poor management and that its projections failed to address the issue of worker productivity.
"There is no question we've got to improve on things like workers compensation and energy costs," Mr. McGee said. But he said Connecticut's skilled work force is 20 percent more productive than the national average.
A number of businesses that moved to Southern states seeking cheaper labor, Mr. McGee said, have returned.
"We're trying to make a point here to those who answered the siren call of the South," he said. "We are focusing on wage productivity -- whether unskilled workers can be as productive as skilled workers."

HEADLINE: Hartford Assembly Saves A 5 Deposit on Bottles

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, April 27

 BODY:
Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr.'s plan to replace Connecticut's 5-cent bottle deposit with a 5-cent-a-bottle tax was killed today by the General Assembly's Appropriations Committee, which voted to continue paying for environmental protection through existing taxes.
The committee's 28-to-20 vote on the budget today was the Legislature's first formal response to Mr. Weicker's spending plan for the next two years. Committee leaders said they believed their plan retains Mr. Weicker's priorities, especially for education, and also keeps the budget at his $8.6 billion figure for the year that begins on July 1. 
 But there were changes beyond the bottle-deposit measure. The committee also scrapped the Governor's proposal to evict from welfare people deemed employable. The committee's compromise was to reduce the benefits of such recipients, but not cut them off entirely.
 
Raiding Casino Fund
 The committee also raided the $100 million-a-year fund created earlier this year by the Mashantucket Pequot Indian tribe after Mr. Weicker agreed to permit slot machines at the tribe's casino in Ledyard.
The fund is at the center of the hottest debate in the Legislature, over casino gambling, and some municipalities -- the fund's main beneficiaries -- had feared the money would become a political trading card. But the committee removed only $15 million, leaving $85 million for grants to towns.
Some members questioned just how secure even that money would be as a bill legalizing casinos for Bridgeport and Hartford moves toward a vote later in the session. Under the Governor's agreement with the Pequots, payments to the fund dry up immediately if any other casinos were legalized by the Legislature.
 
An Unbalanced Budget?
 Some legislators wondered whether the budget would suddenly be out of balance if the Pequot money dried up in the aftermath of a casino vote.
"I'm not sure we can tell you today," said the committee's co-chairman, Senator Joseph H. Harper Jr. Mr. Harper said the two theories being analyzed were that the tribe would be obligated to pay until competing casinos were in operation, or that the agreement would become void immediately upon the approval of casinos.
Mr. Harper called the overall plan a "conservative" budget, under which state spending would grow 6.9 percent for the year, compared with Mr. Weicker's budget growth of 7.2 percent. It was the first budget prepared under a new law mandating an annual cap on the growth of state spending, and the first under a two-year budget law also intended to allow greater control over spending. The preliminary budget for the year beginning July 1, 1994 was set at $9 billion.
Mr. Weicker had argued in proposing his budget that recycling is so established in the state that the 13-year-old deposit law is no longer necessary. The extra nickel that residents are used to paying per bottle for beer, soda and other drinks, totaling $65 million a year altogether, could be better applied for state parks and other uses, Mr. Weicker said.
 
Bottle Deposits Popular
 But the plan came under immediate fire from some environmental groups, who said bottle deposits were among the most popular conservation measures. Concerns were also raised about people who survive in part by scavenging bottles and cans to return for their deposits.
"What you want to do is draw the general public into an activity and this does it," said Paula Carrell, state program director for the Sierra Club.
As part of an overhaul of the welfare system, Mr. Weicker had proposed that any person considered employable be taken off general-assistance welfare on July 1, the beginning of the fiscal year. His aides estimated that perhaps 22,000 people now receiving help would be cut off on that date.
The committee's modified plan defines employable more narrowly, to include about 13,500 people. Some categories of drug users, for example, who would have been deemed employable under the Governor's plan, would instead be deemed unemployable and eligible for treatment programs. People considered employable, however, would see their benefits cut from $314 a month to $285.
 
Prescription Subsidies
 The committee also modified, but kept largely intact, the Governor's plan to reduce state subsidies for drug prescriptions for the elderly, a program called Connpace. The committee's budget would institute a 50 percent co-payment program for prescriptions and impose tighter limits on who can qualify for the assistance. But the committee's budget rejected Mr. Weicker's idea of assessing an annual application fee.
More than 20 amendments proposed by Republicans on the Democratic-controlled committee were rejected on largely party-line votes. Most of the amendments proposed deeper spending cuts, or tax cuts for businesses and residents.
The House's ranking minority member, Representative Reginald L. Jones, a Republican from Darien, said he thought that many of the defeated ideas would re-emerge when the budget came up for a vote in the House of Representatives, probably next month.

HEADLINE: Nashville Sets Unusual Deal To Acquire Route of USAir

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT

 BODY:
In Nashville, the best defense is a good offense.
That is the message, at least, of an agreement by the city to pay USAir $5 million for an air route between Charlotte, N.C., and London, move the American end to Nashville and let American Airlines operate the route. 
 Confused? So is American Airlines, which says it learned of Nashville's plan over the weekend. "This has never been done before," Tim Smith, a spokesman, said. "We don't know how that works."
 
Will Government Approve?
 Neither, for that matter, does the Department of Transportation, which noted that only airlines could buy the rights to fly a route. Under the Nashville Airport Authority's deal, which is contingent on Government approval, the city would not actually own the route.
Perhaps more interesting than whether the deal is ultimately approved is why it is being attempted.
The deal stems from USAir's recently approved alliance with British Airways, which calls for USAir to dispose of three routes to London, from Philadelphia, Baltimore and Charlotte. Most of the major carriers have clamored for the routes, saying they should get the routes free and be permitted to move them to their hub airports.
Nashville, one of the cities threatened by the contraction of the airline industry, is fighting its own battle. As the major carriers look to reduce some of their costly operations, American Airlines is frowning on unprofitable hub operations at Nashville. It plans to shrink operations in the city, where it operates 127 daily flights and employs roughly 3,000 people.
Pointing to economic ripple effects, Nashville officials contend that moving the London route to Tennessee would inject an additional $250 million annually into the state.
Industry analysts expect similar bidding efforts by other airport groups. In a sense, the airport officials are simply extending a long tradition of competing with other states for businesses.
"They're scrambling to maintain a competitive advantage," said Kenneth P. Quinn, counsel to the aviation practice of Mercer Management Consulting.
Nashville's aggressive stance is not new. City officials have tried for three years to win a London route, and have visited England to drum up support.
"Nashville is rising to the occasion," said Mr. Smith of American Airlines. "In hindsight, we shouldn't be surprised."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
New York State's Outlook Improves

 BODY:
The borrowing prospects for New York State, which is expected to sell about $850 million of tax-and-revenue anticipation notes in competitive bidding today, continues to brighten.
The Standard & Poor's Corporation on Monday revised to stable from negative the outlook on the state's $5.1 billion of general obligation debt. 
 As a result, the ratings on debt issued by the New York State Dormitory Authority is also viewed as stable. Yesterday, S.& P. assigned a BBB+ rating to a planned $1.2 billion revenue bond issue for the State University of New York through the dormitory agency. That issue is expected to be priced this week.
While the rating on the state's $5.1 billion of general obligation debt remains A-, the revision by S.& P. indicates a potential upgrading over several years. Rating upgrades allow issuers to borrow at lower rates.
The revision of the state's rating outlook, S.& P. said, was because of positive financial trends over the last two years, including operating surpluses, the timely passage of a budget for two consecutive years and a budget based on realistic economic and revenue estimates. S.& P. said it had assigned its highest short-term rating of SP-1+ to today's $850 million competitive offering.
Last week, Moody's Investors Service Inc. rated the issue MIG-1, its highest rating and the best rating for short-term debt for the state since 1990. Moody's warned that the rating involved a small amount of debt and was not a general endorsement.

HEADLINE: Looking a Gift Painting in the Dollar Sign;
Paterson Examines Its Legacy of Art: How Much It's Worth and How to Restore It

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PATERSON, N.J., April 21

 BODY:
During the first half of the century, industrialists and business leaders filled the Danforth Library here with gifts of books and works of art. But as important industries left the city and its economy declined, so did appreciation for its cultural treasures.
Much of the art, including statues, bronzes, rare furniture and more than 60 paintings, is now in storage and, like the building itself, in need of maintenance and repair. But while a makeover is planned for the 88-year-old library, an acrimonious debate is growing over the art -- what it is worth, who should care for it and even where it is. 
 At least twice the city has tried to raise money by selling paintings from the library collection. Public outrage stopped one sale in the 1970's. In 1982 it took a lawsuit filed by a dozen citizens to save a painting titled "In the Park" by William Merritt Chase that has been appraised at $500,000 to $1 million. The painting was one of 26 donated in 1926 by Jennie Tuttle Hobart, the widow of Garret A. Hobart, who served as William McKinley's Vice President from 1897 until Mr. Hobart's death in 1899.
"Part of the reason we sued was that we felt if that painting was sold the whole collection might go," said Howard Sterling, now a member of the library's art committee. Publicity led to display of the painting in a retrospective on Chase's work at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. And the attention caused the city to take a new look at the art.
"What's happening in Paterson is not unique," Mr. Sterling said. "What is going on is that a lot of people who collected art around the turn of the century began giving it to public institutions in the 1920's, and people are just now beginning to take notice of things they just considered decorations gathering dust. In many cases folks don't know what their collections are worth or how to maintain them."
A couple of years ago a library official went looking for 28 19th-century American and European paintings donated to the library by Ralph P. Ross, a textile manufacturer.
Several paintings were found in a vault, some of them torn and deteriorating from dampness, said Dominic A. DiNardo, a member of the library's board. "Nobody will say who put them there," he said.
A former Paterson resident who wants to establish a museum to house the city's art claims more than two dozen pieces donated by Mr. Ross are missing. Nick Sunday, a magazine writer and graphic artist who lives in nearby Prospect Park, has sent a list of the items that he claims are missing to the State Attorney General, Robert J. Del Tufo, who forwarded Mr. Sunday's complaint to the Passaic County Prosecutor. In the last few days Mayor William J. Pascrell has asked the library for an accounting of each piece of art. He also estimated the cost of restoring the paintings at $50,000 and pledged to find the money.
Norma Harrison, president of the board since January, has said the library can account for all of the objects listed in Mr. Sunday's complaint.
In addition, Ms. Harrison says, the library has asked the city and council, which must approve its budget request, for $12,000 for a part-time curator to examine the paintings, appraise their value and determine which ones are worth restoring and which are too damaged to repair. "We also hope a curator will help us attract grants, interpret the art and develop a curriculum for the schools in Paterson and elsewhere," she said.
Mr. Sunday has also taken on another Paterson institution, the Hamilton Club, a businessmen's group founded in the late 1800's, in defense of another group of paintings.
He has persuaded Sotheby's auction house in New York to delay the sale of 19 paintings that he contends were once owned by Mr. Ross. "He was very firm about what he wanted done with his paintings," Mr. Sunday said of the city's best-known philanthropist. "He wanted them to be available for the young people of the city."
Mr. Sunday says the paintings were part of a collection of 50 works that Mr. Ross gave to the local chamber of commerce in the 1930's, specifying that if the chamber ever wanted to dispose of them they should go to the city's two high schools and the library.
In the early 1950's, he said, the chamber moved out of its quarters in the Fabian Building, and Mr. Ross took 25 of the paintings to the library and 25 to the Hamilton Club, the businessmen's club. Some of these paintings were taken to Sotheby's late last year by Hamilton Club Associates, a limited partnership that had obtained them from the club, Mr. Sunday said.
Walter Hunziker Jr., the president of the Hamilton Club, said discussions are under way to clear up questions about ownership of the paintings, whose history, he said, is "very confused, nothing is clear." But he said the story about their being given to the chamber of commerce and earmarked for the schools "is made up out of whole cloth and supposition."
Mr. Sunday has set up a nonprofit museum named for Jennie Tuttle Hobart to protect the city's art collection from future attempts to sell it off. But the museum exists only on paper so far.
Last year Mr. Sunday and his fledging museum won a $10,000 grant from the New Jersey Committee for the Humanities to make a catalogue of the library's art collection, but the award was rescinded when the library board said it would not cooperate with the project.
"It was a total surprise," said Mr. Sterling, who was on the library committee in 1991 when Mr. Sunday served as a member for a few months.
"He quickly decided we weren't capable and wanted us to turn over the library's collection to him," he said.
He said it was regrettable that Mr. Sunday's relations with the library soured. "He was absolutely right when he said many pieces of art are at a critical stage, need attention and will deteriorate faster if we don't do something," he said. "But we are not at the stage where we will absolutely lose some of the art."
"I have this idea that some think crazy, that somewhere down the road the city will be restored to economic vitality, and that benefactors and resources will be found to restore the collection and appropriately display it."

GRAPHIC: Photo: A bitter dispute has erupted over what to do with the numerous works of art at the Danforth Library in Paterson, N.J. Evelyn Forbes, left, and Tonya Nothern, students, studied near statues in the library. (G. Paul Burnett/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
New Head For A.T.& T. Products Unit

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS

 BODY:
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company has gone outside its ranks and named Carl S. Ledbetter Jr., a mathematician, computer executive and self-described gadget junkie, to head its $2 billion consumer products operations.
Mr. Ledbetter, 43, has been a corporate vice president at Sun Microsystems Inc. since 1991. He previously held senior posts at the Control Data Corporation and the International Business Machines Corporation. 
 In his new job as president of A.T.& T Consumer Products, he will take over the unit that controls 400 retail phone stores and manufactures and markets household products, including cordless telephones, answering machines and A.T.& T.'s new line of videophones.
During the next few years, the subsidiary is expected to play a central role in marketing hand-held computing devices that read handwriting and transmit data over the air.
"The computer and communications industries are coming together," Mr. Ledbetter said. "We're talking about a time when voice messaging and multimedia are all part of the enterprise of communication."
As both an engineer and a marketing man, Mr. Ledbetter headed a division at Sun Microsystems that makes networking products to link personal computers with more powerful work stations. A man who keeps no fewer than four personal computers at home, he said the emerging family of wireless communication devices should be a huge growth business.
Although A.T.& T. refuses to disclose sales in the consumer product business, it contends that it is the biggest supplier of cordless telephones in the United States. Marion Boucher, a telecommunications analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, estimated that the unit generates about $2 billion in sales and said the business has grown comfortably in the last few years.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Euro Disney Needs to Raise Funds in Face of Loss

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, April 27

 BODY:
Faced by a persistent European recession and a mixed response to its attractions, Euro Disney said today that it would incur a substantial loss for the current fiscal year and would need to raise more money to shore up its finances.
A statement from Euro Disney, which is 49 percent owned by the Walt Disney Company, said the concern had a net loss of 1.08 billion francs ($203 million) for the six months that ended March 31. 
 "Anticipated losses and the expenditures required for the company's ongoing capital investment program will have an adverse effect on its cash and financial positions," the company said. "To address this situation, Euro Disney and the Walt Disney Company are exploring potential sources of financing for Euro Disney."
The company did not indicate the amount it would seek to raise or the means of financing it would use.
 
 
Investment Program
 The new funds would be used to pay down some debt and to finance an ambitious program of investments, including the construction of new park attractions to cut long lines and add variety, company officials said.
Complaints about the lines and the admission fees have marred the park's first year. There have also been difficulties related to cultural differences between the United States and Europe: for example, many Europeans do not like the fact that wine and beer are not available to accompany meals in the theme park.
But analysts said they were troubled by the news that Euro Disney needed more capital when the company's stock had already been battered by lower-than-expected attendance at both the theme park and the six company-owned hotels surrounding it.
"It is odd and disturbing that Euro Disney says it wants to raise new financing but gives no details," said Andrew Hunter, a leisure analyst at Hoare Gavett in London. "The company is probably going to need a substantial amount, perhaps several billion francs, but it may have to put in a better performance before it can raise the money."
Euro Disney, which has faced persistent problems since it opened its theme park amid great hoopla just over a year ago, has debts of 20.3 billion francs ($3.8 billion).
Although attendance in the first year of operation, at 10.3 million, was not much below the company's target of 11 million, spending by visitors has not been as high as had been hoped and occupancy of hotels has fallen far short of expectations. For the most recent fiscal first half, occupancy averaged 37 percent.
 
 
Real Estate Slump
 "Overall results were significantly affected by low hotel occupancy during the period," the company said. A company spokesman, Jean-Jacques Roulmann, said Euro Disney had hoped to sell some of the hotels but had been hampered by the slump in the French real estate market.
Mr. Hunter said he now estimated that Euro Disney would make a small profit during the six summer months, giving a loss for the full fiscal year of about $176 million.
Euro Disney's stock fell 2.8 percent today to 77 francs, or $14.50, on news of its first-half loss. When the park opened, the shares traded at more than double this price. In the United States today, shares of the Walt Disney Company closed at $40.875, down 12.5 cents, after dipping lower earlier in the day.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Mobil's Profit Is Buoyed by Global Sales

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES

 BODY:
In contrast to many other oil companies, the Mobil Corporation reported today that its European and Asian refining and marketing operations were profitable despite the sluggish global economy, helping Mobil post first-quarter net income of $490 million, compared with a loss of $319 million a year earlier.
Revenues were virtually unchanged from the period a year earlier at $15 billion. Japan and Australia were especially strong markets for Mobil, the nation's second-largest oil company, analysts said. 
 Michael Mayer, an analyst at Wertheim Schroeder Inc., said the big surprise in Mobil's report was a plunge in spending on worldwide exploration and production, to $53 million, from $169 million in the first quarter of 1992. Over all, Mobil's capital budget fell to $815 million, from $905 million a year earlier.
 
Remaining Expenditures
 After Mobil officials said spending for worldwide exploration and production had not been reduced, some analysts concluded that spending would be higher than anticipated for the remainder of the year, and earnings lower. That expectation helped push down the price of Mobil's shares in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
Still, Mobil's net income of $1.19 a share exceeded the consensus of Wall Street analysts, which had put earnings at $1 a share.
 
Higher Prices
 Mobil, which is based in Fairfax, Va., benefited from higher prices for natural gas and crude oil in the United States as well as lower costs from job cuts, mainly in United States operations.
The company received an average of $2 for each 1,000 cubic feet of domestic natural gas produced in the quarter, compared with $1.48 in the first quarter last year. Mobil's average price for domestic crude sold to refineries rose to $14.70 a barrel from $13.69. The higher prices and lower expenses contributed to operating income of $117 million for the domestic exploration and production unit in the quarter, compared with $19 million in the period a year earlier. The foreign exploration unit earned $316 million, compared with $213 million.

HEADLINE: Income Grew By 3.9% in 1992

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 27

 BODY:
Americans' personal income rebounded across much of the country last year, the Government said today.
The Commerce Department said incomes per person last year grew 3.9 percent nationally, to $19,841, a clear advance over the 2.4 percent increase in 1991. The 1991 report, the worst in 30 years, was used by President Clinton in his attacks on the economic record of then-President George Bush. Income growth was so slow that it lagged behind inflation for the first time in nine years. 
 Bu, last year income growth was faster than the 3.2 percent inflation rate. Forty-four states and the District of Columbia shared in the improvement. The six states with a deceleration in growth were Montana, Hawaii, Louisiana, South Dakota, Wyoming and Texas.
Regionally, the far West had the worst income growth last year, only 2.6 percent. It was pulled down by military spending cuts. The best growth came in the Plains states, 5.4 percent, and Great Lakes states, 4.6 percent.
New England and the Mid-Atlantic states, which had been hardest hit by the recession, had better-than-average growth, 4.4 percent and 4.3 percent respectively.
Incomes grew 3.9 percent in both the Rocky Mountain states and the Southeast. They grew 3.7 percent in the Southwest.

HEADLINE: Employment Costs Up 3.5%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 27

 BODY:
Wages, salaries and benefits paid to American workers increased a moderate 3.5 percent in the 12 months that ended on March 31, according to a report released today.
The Labor Department's Employment Cost Index showed that wages and salaries edged up just 2.7 percent and failed to keep up with a 3.1 percent increase in consumer prices. On the other hand, the value of employee benefits, including health care, rose 5.4 percent. 
 The index is considered a good gauge of wage inflation pressures. Evelina Tainer, head of Prime Economic Consulting in Chicago, called the gauge "a picture of subdued employment costs." Because employment costs are usually passed on to consumers, the stability should translate into a relatively stable price environment, Ms. Tainer said.
In a second report, the Labor Department said collective bargaining agreements for workers in the first quarter of 1993 provide for annual wage gains averaging 3.1 percent.
The pacts replaced contracts, which had generally been negotiated in 1989 and 1990, providing for 3.9 percent average annual gains.
The employment cost report showed that compensation growth slowed slightly from the 4 percent gain for the 12 months ended on March 31, 1992. Compensation had risen 3.5 percent during the 12 months ended Dec. 31 and Sept. 30. The 3.5 percent increases were the smallest since the department began the index in 1982.

HEADLINE: As Haute Cools, Paris Chefs Revitalize The Bistro

BYLINE: By MARIAN BURROS

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
DINNER under $40, created by three-star French chefs.
Non-smoking sections in restaurants. 
 Smiling faces, welcoming hands.
Can this be Paris?
For Americans who, in the last 15 or 20 years, sort of fell out of love with France and French food, Paris in 1993 is a revelation.
You want to speak in broken French? They'll answer you in French. You want to speak English? They'll speak English.
You look lost? They'll ask if they can guide you.
And if you want to eat high on the hog at moderate prices, no problem. The city's two- and three-star chefs are eager to oblige.
Bistromania has struck the city where it all began. What follows may sound familiar to those who have observed the fate of American restaurants since the late 80's.
Michel Rostang, whose eponymous restaurant has two stars, was the first to start the trend toward lower prices, in 1987. Now, everyone is doing it -- not once, but two, three and even four times.
Early this year, Mr. Rostang opened his fourth Bistrot d'a Cote, so named because the first was actually beside his two-star restaurant. Today, Guy Savoy and Jacques Cagna, whose restaurants bear their names; Gerard Boyer at Les Crayeres in Reims, and Marc Meneau at L'Esperance in Vezelay, about 120 miles southeast of Paris, have opened bistros. In February, Joel Robuchon of the three-star Jamin joined the parade, more or less.
There are a lot of reasons why these chefs, whose starred restaurants charge at least $100 a person for dinner, are either spreading the wealth or diluting their image, depending on your point of view.
Most of them have to do with money. The French, like Americans and most of the rest of the Western world, have been in the grip of a recession.
"The first bistro I opened was not an economic necessity," said Guy Savoy as he sat late one evening at his two-star restaurant in the 17th arrondissement, on the northwestern edge of the city. "Now it is an economic necessity for several reasons. There is a crisis in Paris.
"Absolutely, the regular clients come less often to Guy Savoy. I'm noticing more and more a lot of birthday cakes. This place is for special occasions."
Mr. Savoy's view of what is happening in Paris is shared by his colleagues.
"The crisis makes it unfashionable to spend money," Mr. Cagna said, sipping coffee at his two-star restaurant near the Luxembourg Gardens. "The only ones who are spending are from Taiwan and Hong Kong. And a Russian who bought a $1,500 Chateau d'Yquem."
The popularity of bistros is not just about money. The rhythm of life has changed.
"People don't have time anymore to take a month vacation," Mr. Savoy said. "They take a week. They have less time to relax. Everything is getting shorter. They have less time to eat, and they want to relax more when they eat. People want places to eat that are less formal. Society has changed."
Finally, even in Paris. Patricia Wells, an American who has lived in Paris for years and is the author of "The Food Lover's Guide to France" (1987) and the newly revised "Food Lover's Guide to Paris," both from Workman Publishing, sees the same phenomenon.
"France is much more casual than it was," she said. "France fought it for a long time."
And most of the two- and three-star restaurants have felt the effects. "I got into Guy Savoy by calling one day ahead," Ms. Wells said. "I used to have to reserve 10 days ahead."
Now, even Mr. Robuchon, widely considered the most important chef in France, has succumbed to the bistro concept in terms of price and style of food, but not in the rustic surroundings. His drop-dead-chic Relais du Parc in the new Hotel le Parc Victor Hugo, in the 16th arrondissement, doesn't look much like a bistro, but it serves bistro-style food at bistro prices. It is owned by the hotel, but the chef was trained by Mr. Robuchon and uses his recipes. Later this year, Mr. Robuchon is to move Jamin, which is also in the 16th, along the Bois de Boulogne, to the building next to the hotel, which it also owns.
The two- and three-star restaurants did not feel the economic downturn at first, Mr. Rostang said. "We thought it was the gulf war. In 1992, we did the same business as '91, but '93 is a little bit less, maybe 3 percent."
The bistros have picked up the slack. They are not subsidizing their owners' temples of haute cuisine, but they are making a lot more money. "I absolutely did not know how much money could be made in a bistro," Mr. Savoy said. "A bistro returns 10 times more on the investment than a restaurant like this," he said, referring to his two-star dining room.
"Maybe when I'm 65 I will have six rotisseries and no Jacques Cagna," said Mr. Cagna, whose two rotisserie-bistros are making a lot of money. "If I do, I will become a businessman, but I want to be both a chef and a businessman. I need Jacques Cagna because this is my life."
Of the chefs interviewed, only Gerard Boyer at Les Crayeres, his three-star country-house hotel, said business had not decreased. But, he said, "clients who used to come 10 times a year, now come six."
He and his wife, Elyane, opened their first bistro in 1989. "My original idea was to have other clients at the bistro, but finally it is the same clients," he said.
Sitting in the fin-de-siecle garden room, recently added to the hotel, Mr. Boyer says he thinks the French are now interested in plainer cooking.
"Good chefs want to open bistros because clients want restaurants to go to for simple food," he said. "It is important to have bistros with our quality food."
That's stretching a point. Mr. Rostang has a more clear-eyed view. "It's not the same house," he said. "It's not the same service. The ambiance is very casual. No one would ever say that about his or anyone else's two- or three-star.
Much of the food in the bistros and bistrolike places is very good; some is plebeian. After all, these starred chefs are not doing the cooking themselves. They oversee the operations; they go by often and spend time there; they plan the menus and provide the recipes, and in many instances, whoever buys the food for the top-quality restaurant buys the food for the bistros as well.
Certain standards are never lowered. The products are always fresh. But no truffles, no foie gras, no lobster. And these chefs who strive for perfection cannot always let go. "It is not usual to make the ice cream, the bread and smoked salmon at a place like this," Mr. Cagna said, "but it is the habit of perfectionism. I cannot buy food made elsewhere."
Cooking bistro food requires more skill than cooking in a two-star, Mr. Rostang said. "It is very easy to make a very good dinner with truffles. It is more difficult when you have only potatoes."
But it is possible to find a superb piece of salmon topped with sesame seeds and polenta mixed with vegetables and cheese at Mr. Rostang's bistros; a fine cod with capers on a bed of cabbage and an excellent apple tart at Mr. Savoy's places; a zesty dish not unlike a caponata but made with tiny mushrooms instead of eggplant at Mr. Robuchon's sort-of-bistro; a beautifully dressed salad with buttery goat cheese at Mr. Boyer's bistros and a vacherin with mocha ice cream and caramel sauce at Mr. Cagna's rotisserie-bistros, a dessert for which you will happily breach your caloric boundaries.
And today, Americans can eat these dishes in a relatively smoke-free environment. All of the bistros visited had some sort of non-smoking section in response to a new law. It is here that most of the Americans were eating. Unwittingly, the French have found a way to separate the Americans from the natives.
Not long ago, many restaurants in France would refuse reservations to Americans after their "quota" had been filled. A few still do. "Fou," Mr. Boyer said of the practice. "Americans who travel in France know more about food and wine than French people who do not go to these restaurants. The American clientele is important."
The French are nothing if not practical. "Without foreigners, two out of three two- and three-star restaurants would be closed," Mr. Cagna said.
But still. The French cannot resist the last word. "After so many years of Julia Child, Americans have improved their taste," he said. "Fifteen or 20 years ago, I would say Americans have no taste. Now they know how to eat."

HEADLINE: What the Check Doesn't Tell About the Price of a Meal

BYLINE: By FLORENCE FABRICANT

 BODY:
IF dining out in the 1980's was mostly about big plates with small portions, in the 1990's the focus is on value. And when every dollar counts, it helps to know what you are buying. What costs are hidden under that slab of sirloin or among the strands of fettuccine?
Whether it's steak or pasta, paying for a meal in a restaurant involves much more than merely purchasing ingredients that have been cooked and arranged on a dish. Cooks have to grill the steak or boil the pasta, waiters have to serve it, and they all must be paid. 
 The customer also absorbs the cost of the linens and their laundering and occupies a chair and table in a location for which rent, taxes, insurance and other expenses must be paid. Are there candles on the table? They have to be replaced constantly. Some restaurants spend as much as $100,000 a year on flowers alone. Most fast-food chains may not provide tablecloths and flowers but they do have hefty advertising budgets.
From city to city restaurant prices are affected by variables like taxes, garbage removal and what the competition is charging, to name only a few. Comparing prices is more easily done with a restaurant group like the Palm, which has 12 restaurants in 10 cities, all but one of which have the same menu. Some of the ingredients for all 12 are purchased by the company's headquarters in Washington, and some are even shipped across the country.
A visitor to New York from Chicago who has a steak dinner at the Palm, either in that legendary former speak-easy's original sawdust-strewn location at 837 Second Avenue, near 45th Street, or across the street at Palm Too at 840 Second Avenue, will discover that the shrimp cocktail is $12 instead of the $7.50 it goes for in the Chicago branch. The filet mignon is $27, not $22.
"People are very price-conscious in Chicago, and our manager there knows what we have to charge to stay competitive," said Bruce Bozzi, the co-owner of the Palm Management Corporation. In the restaurant industry, the first consideration in setting prices is what the traffic will bear.
To keep prices in line in Chicago, the Palm puts four jumbo shrimp in the shrimp cocktail instead of the five served in New York, Los Angeles, Miami and East Hampton, L.I. And even though wholesale prices for shrimp and most of the other ingredients are the same in Chicago as they are in New York, the restaurant charges less per shrimp in Chicago because many of the other expenses there are lower than they are in New York.
New York is the most expensive restaurant city in the country, not only for the Palm, but also on an average basis. According to the Zagat Survey, a series of restaurant guides for 19 cities in which restaurants are rated by consumers, the average cost of a dinner in New York is $32.48, compared with $20.97 in Chicago.
Along with the cost of ingredients, which restaurants figure at roughly one-third of expenses, labor is the other big outlay for a restaurant.
"Our labor costs are highest in New York," Mr. Bozzi said. "We figure labor at around $8 per customer. That's nearly double what we pay in some other cities. Utilities are also high. It costs us $7,000 a month for garbage removal for the two restaurants. There are assorted other expenses in New York, like an annual compressor fee to run the refrigerators and air-conditioning, which we do not have in other cities."
For the Palm, each city presents its own set of circumstances that affect the right-hand column on the menu.
Some New Yorkers might not flinch at being charged $16 for broiled chicken. Elsewhere, even $12 might seem outrageous. At the Palm in Dallas the chicken is $10.50.
But New York's lobster price, $55 for four and a half pounds, is the lowest, on a per-pound basis, of any Palm, thanks to volume. The New York Palms each sell about 85 lobsters a day, twice as many as in any other city, mainly because, by tradition, they have no menus, and many customers think all the two restaurants serve is steak and lobster.
"Some of the old-time waiters just say, 'How many steaks, how many lobsters here?' so people don't realize we serve other dishes," Mr. Bozzi said.
The veal chop in Dallas is the cheaper rib cut instead of the loin served elsewhere, because that's what the Palm in Dallas has found that its customers prefer.
In some cities, like Philadelphia, Mr. Bozzi said, portions are smaller to keep the prices competitive.
In Manhattan, he said, the Palms' prices are a trifle lower than for other steak houses nearby.
"A customer has to put up with certain conditions we can't correct, like cramped quarters with no bar where they can wait," he said.
Factored into the price of steak at the Palm in Los Angeles is the cost of shipping the meat by air from New York, where it is dry-aged. In Miami the prices are fairly high because the Palm there does not serve lunch -- the location wouldn't sustain it -- so the total expense of running the restaurant must be absorbed during the evening.
Even though prices are lower at lunch than at dinner, restaurants can often make a better profit at noontime. The actual cost of the food people tend to eat at lunch these days, like salads and pasta, is less, but at the same time, the markup on these items is usually higher than for, say, lamb chops.
The sale of food accounts for about 80 percent of a restaurant's income nationwide. And the more costly the ingredients, as a percentage of the price on the menu, the lower the profit the restaurant makes. At the same time, when prime boneless sirloin is simply grilled instead of being dressed up with elaborate sauces, lower labor costs can offset the price of the raw materials.
Larry Levy, the chairman of Levy Restaurants, which has 22 varied restaurants in Chicago and four other cities, said value was the key element.
"You set prices by what things are worth -- what they cost is secondary," Mr. Levy said. "The atmosphere and the style of service are very important. A person getting something to eat at a ball park or a mid-price restaurant has a different set of expectations than someone going for dinner at Spiaggia."
Spiaggia is Levy's elegant Italian restaurant on Chicago's glittering Miracle Mile. It has higher prices than the company's other restaurants nearby because a larger staff is needed to maintain the quality of the food and the service, and also because the replacement cost of china and glassware is higher, and the linens and flowers are more expensive.
These days most restaurant owners are scrambling to find ways to cover their expenses without raising menu prices. In clinging to his very European, and to many, outmoded, $2.50 cover charge, Sirio Maccioni, the owner of Le Cirque in Manhattan, said: "I don't want to prevent people from coming in here to have just a salad before the theater or a creme brulee after, but maintaining a table costs a certain amount. The cover charge generates enough to pay for laundering the linens."
With a couple of stiff drinks before lunch or dinner no longer the fashion, the amount of high-profit alcohol that restaurants sell has plummeted. Enter the costly cup of espresso or cappuccino, marked up as much 10 times cost, or the bottle of mineral water that costs $1 and is priced at $6. Whether it's the Palm or the local pizzeria, prices in a successful restaurant have to cover expenses and return a profit.
Last year, restaurant prices rose an average of 2 percent nationwide, the lowest increase recorded by the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics since 1964. The wholesale cost of food declined by about 1.5 percent, but other expenses have escalated. Labor costs increased by 4.6 percent and are expected to rise 4.8 percent this year.
"The best way to keep prices as low as possible is to try to lower costs," Mr. Levy said. "In the 1970's and 80's when expenses went up we could pass it along to the customer. Today, like any good entrepreneur, you have to try to be more efficient."
Since the start of the recession, many restaurants have learned to adopt a leaner, more efficient management style.
"The customer has less money to spend," Mr. Levy said. "But we've managed to increase volume so we're not making less profit now."
Wendy Webster, the manager of media relations for the National Restaurant Association in Washington, said that after prices rose by 3.4 percent nationally in 1991, the association had projected they would climb by nearly 4 percent in 1992. "Boy were we wrong," she said. "There is a tremendous amount of consumer resistance to menu price increases."

HEADLINE: Review/Television;
Patriots Trying to Repair A Broken Northern Ireland

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
Northern Ireland may not be at the top of many vacation itineraries these days, but in the minds of Glen Barr and Paddy Doherty, their city of Londonderry, rich in history and beauty, could be a grand tourist attraction. "Sons of Derry" conveys their vision. Unfortunately, few of their compatriots are in so accommodating a mood.
Glen and Paddy, as they are called in tonight's likable documentary, produced by two New York University professors, Terence Moran and Marcia Rock, are builders. Paddy has plans for rebuilding the mostly Roman Catholic inner city, with a view to attracting visitors. Glen is renovating buildings in the largely Protestant, upscale Waterside area, in hopes of keeping young couples from leaving. And both are trying to break down the religious, economic and political walls that keep the people of Northern Ireland divided. 
 "Sons of Derry" offers a quick but cogent account of three centuries of sectarian strife, which is still being nourished by parades, slogans and outbursts of assault and retribution. "Nobody owns the history," says Paddy, who dreams of "all those Americans coming over to find their heritage." Glen calls for a Bill of Rights modeled on the American Constitution, which he credits to Ulster Presbyterians like his forebears.
Adding to the age-old suspicion and animosity is high unemployment, twice as high for Catholics as for Protestants. Whatever their differences of heritage and affiliation, Glen and Paddy would rather concentrate on how much they have in common, notably their affection for Londonderry and their practical approach to problems. Both are teaching trades to young people and incidentally giving them an opportunity to meet one another in the flesh instead of in the demonologies of the paramilitary bands of both sides.
Tonight's program is too honest to raise expectations of peace and prosperity in their time, but what hope there is for Northern Ireland surely lies in people like Glen and Paddy, who are staking their lives on a livable future in the exasperating land they both cherish. There are glimmers of hope in the arrival of new businesses, but the old hates still run strong. As the narrator says, the stones of their much battered city "can be barriers or foundations."
It's Irish night on WNYC-TV. At 8 P.M., "McSorley's New York" offers a froth of social history served up by the owners and patrons of the city's oldest continuing saloon. A bitterer brew is on tap at 8:30 P.M. in "No Irish Need Apply," an account of the welcome Irish immigrants received from New York City in the 1860's.
 
Sons of Derry
PBS, tonight
(In New York, Channel 31 at 9)
 
Written by Terence Moran and Marcia Rock. Ms. Rock, producer, director and editor; Mr. Moran, executive producer. A Derry Video production.

HEADLINE: Daughters Already at Work, and Succeeding

 BODY:
Sandra Goeken Martis was never encouraged to go into any one of her father's start-up businesses: not MCI Communications, the computer network for the FTD floral service, Airfone or In-Flight Phone. Not that that stopped her.
"In the early days, I would have said he was the most sexist, male chauvinistic pig in the country," said Ms. Martis, 35, who charitably chalks it up to her father's desire to protect her from the unkind business world. 
 Recruited by one of her father's companies, the BTC Corporation, a telecommunications concern, she moved up largely because investors coaxed Mr. Goeken to make better use of his ambitious daughter's talents. "It was only after he saw how when the chips were down, I was always there to pick them up, that he changed his tune," said Ms. Martis, who calls her father Jack to avoid ruffling feathers.
Today, she runs the international half of In-Flight Phone while her father handles the domestic end -- and can barely contain his pride. "Over the years she's proved herself," Mr. Goeken said. "She's does things I wouldn't trust anyone else with."
 
ALEXANDRA LEBANTHAL AND JIM LEBENTHAL
 Alexandra Lebenthal, 29, the heir apparent to the municipal bond house by the same name in downtown Manhattan, has been accompanying her father, Jim, to work since she was 5.
 Her grandmother, Sayra, paid her 25 cents to reinforce the pages in binder notebooks. At age 11, Alexandra and her classmates pitched in at the peak of New York City's financial crisis to help her father figure out how many of the city's bonds were held by individuals.
"If the bonds were not honored, many people's life savings would be wiped out," said Jim Lebenthal, who is 64.
Though she initially considered becoming an actress, Alexandra, who has an older sister and a younger brother, said she was always most interested in the family business. Still is. "I was the only sibling who paid attention at the dinner table when the business was discussed and who worked at Lebenthal during the summers," Alexandra Lebenthal said.
After being graduated from Princeton University in 1986 with a degree in history, she joined Kidder, Peabody's municipal bond department.
 She moved to Lebenthal in 1988 -- a development her father considers quite fitting. Not only was the business started by her 94-year-old grandmother, but half of the sales force is women, unusual on Wall Street. Jim Lebenthal envisions a day when his middle child will be the Lebenthal in Lebenthal & Company.

HEADLINE: Cut New York's Un-Welcome Tax

 BODY:
The tax on an average hotel room in New York City is a staggering 21.25 percent. That's double the average for other big cities and, obviously, a crippling disadvantage for the Big Apple. Bills pending in the State Legislature would cut the tax to 16.25 percent. It would still be the nation's highest, but a lot more sensible than it is now.
An overnight stay in New York averages $113 and change -- plus tax. For that average room, the tax would be about $24. For a $200-plus room in one of mid-Manhattan's upscale hotels, the tax for just one night approaches $50! Might that make a tourist or a convention planner think twice about New York versus, say, New Orleans, where the tax is 11 percent? Of course it would, and does. 
 Statistical proof of lost business is hard to nail down, because one high tax isn't all that might discourage trips to New York. While the bright lights and bustle are a constant lure, for example, the crime, grime and high prices are not.
In any case, New York doesn't need another disincentive; the Convention and Visitors Bureau says that since 1990, when the state tax took effect, the city has lost 64 conventions with 228,000 participants who would have spent $133 million. However you add it, common sense says a tax this high is poor strategy for a city with a huge stake in people coming to do business or see the sights.
Politicians are partial to hotel occupancy taxes because the people who pay the tax are from somewhere else. But prohibitive hotel taxes can lengthen unemployment lines for the politicians' constituents whose jobs depend on out-of-towners.
New York City's hotel tax is actually six taxes, starting with the statewide 4 percent sales tax on goods and services, and the city's 4.25 percent on top of that. In 1980 the city imposed its first specific hotel tax -- $2 a night on rooms costing $40 or more. In 1986 it added a 5 percent occupancy tax on all rooms, and in 1990 another 1 percent. Finally, in 1990, the state enacted a 5 percent tax on rooms at $100 or more, for a total of 21.25 percent. Supposedly this last 5 percent was a statewide tax, but Albany knew it targeted New York City. Rolling back the state's last 5 percent grab would give New York a tax only a bit higher than its principal competitors for convention business. Chicago, Atlanta, Dallas and Houston charge 13 to 15 percent.
Like other distortive taxes, this one may cost more revenue than it produces by tamping down economic activity. The hotel industry and city officials insist that the state's 5 percent tax is a net loser, since the loss in income tax revenue because of reduced hotel traffic may be greater than what the tax brings in.
Clearly a tax exceeding 20 percent pushes the final cost of a room too high, but the hotels need one word of caution. Given their vigorous campaign to lower the tax, their credibility is on the line. Repeal of the state tax would only boost business if hotels hold their rates steady and let visitors have the benefit of the tax cut. The city's innkeepers have made a sound case for tax relief; their half of the bargain must be price restraint.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Foreign Investment, Key to New York City's Growth

 BODY:
To the Editor:
With unemployment and business activity still a serious problem in New York City, questions have been raised as to why Mayor David N. Dinkins has over the past several months chosen to lead missions to Europe and Japan. 
 The answer quite simply is that foreign investment in New York City still ranks as one of the most important growth factors in the city's economy. Rather than being questioned, these overseas trips, which the New York City Partnership/New York Chamber of Commerce and Industry have helped organize, should be applauded.
The reality for New York City is that the 2,500 foreign-based companies in the city, which employ 200,000 people, are critical to our economic future. Foreign companies account for 7 percent of all private-sector jobs in the city. Between 1978 and 1991, foreign companies accounted for $60 billion worth of direct investment in businesses and property here. Add upwards of $3.5 billion a year spent by foreign visitors and one begins to see the importance of paying attention to our overseas neighbors.
The single largest source of foreign investment in New York City -- and also nationwide -- comes from Britain. British investments in New York are widely dispersed across various industries, with the majority of manufacturing interest split between publishing and chemicals. Indeed, Britain has 47 separate investments in publishing firms alone. France, Germany, the Netherlands and Italy also figure prominently.
Thus it made great sense for New York leaders to re-establish ties with European investors. The city's delegation made 280 business contacts in three European countries, with 26 firms now in serious negotiations toward a New York City presence.
Japanese investors have established the largest number of wholesale trading firms in New York City. Japan ranks second to Britain in the total number of financial-industry investments. Japanese also are active in manufacturing and transport service industries and have been the source of the largest number of real-property investments in the city.
In the case of this year's Japan trip, the Mayor and the business community followed a time-honored rule of commerce: Support a customer encountering a difficult period. Japan, like America, is slowly emerging from a recession, with exports, wages and profits in serious decline and overseas investments being questioned. This made it all the more important for the Mayor and his delegation to reassure Japanese executives of the value of investments in New York City.
I have learned in my travels over the years that there is no substitute for face-to-face meetings between economic partners. Just as the Mayor and New York business leaders have visited their counterparts overseas, so, too, should we welcome similar missions to New York from other countries. The mayors and governors of other cities and states have been conducting outreach and economic missions for decades. Foreign investors wishing to locate in the United States have ample choices. And the battle to attract foreign employers remains a fiercely competitive one.
The bottom line for the city is that foreign investment represents one of a very few areas where the prospects for economic growth are most promising.
 
DAVID ROCKEFELLER
New York, April 19, 1993

HEADLINE: Foreign Investment, Key to New York City's Growth;
Unlocking Japan Trade

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In his Op-Ed article "It's Clinton's Turn to Bargain With Japan" (April 15), Clyde Prestowitz identifies the composition of trade between the United States and Japan as the area of most concern in U.S.-Japan trade relations. He suggests that the best way to address this concern is for Japan to adhere to prior agreements to purchase more auto parts from U.S. firms. 
 This is the prescription for managed trade, and we think that's wrong. A recent project by the Wednesday Group (a Republican caucus in the House of Representatives, of which we are members) shows that efforts to increase market shares of American firms in Japan will fail until we resolve the basic problem in U.S.-Japan trade: the lack of foreign direct investment in Japan.
The evidence is strong that foreign direct investment increases a nation's level of imports. This is because as multinational corporations expand abroad they continue to purchase supplies from the firms they relied on at home. Since 1957, in fact, 65 percent of all American-manufactured exports have consisted of shipments from American parent firms to their majority-owned subsidiaries abroad. To the extent that American firms have "underinvested" in Japan, they lose a crucial export base, and a crucial entry into the world's second-largest market.
American firms are underinvested in Japan. U.S. firms hold the majority of all foreign direct investment in Japan, but its overall levels are much lower in Japan than in any other advanced nation. All foreign companies combined hold less than $25 billion in direct investment in Japan. By comparison, the U.S. hosts more than $150 billion of Japanese direct investment alone. The U.S., Britain and Germany all invest abroad between 1 and 2.2 times what they host in foreign direct investment. Japan invests abroad more than 20 times what it hosts. This glaring lack of direct investment means foreign firms are deprived of their most important base for selling finished products in the Japanese market.
One reason for this gross investment imbalance between Japan and the rest of the world is the stringent entry process that prevented most foreign direct investment until about 1980. Since the liberalization of the process, the Japanese Government's land and fiscal policies have encouraged a staggering run-up in real-estate prices. It was this "bubble" in land values that allowed Japanese firms to invest so heavily abroad during the 1980's. Furthermore, the high land prices caused by the "bubble" are the most important barrier to the increased investment of American firms in Japan.
The Clinton Administration seems preoccupied with tired old ideas like exchange rates and stimulus packages, or policies that will only hurt us in the long run -- like managed trade. The first issue it should address is the lack of American direct investment in Japan.
 
RICK LAZIO
JIM KOLBE
Washington, April 19, 1993
The writers are Representatives from New York and Arizona respectively.
