HEADLINE: 10 Years After a Scathing Report, Schools Show Uneven Progress

BYLINE: By WILLIAM CELIS 3d, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 27

 BODY:
If ever the work of a blue-ribbon panel seemed destined to gather dust, it was "A Nation at Risk," the 65-page report of the National Commission on Excellence in Education, released at the White House 10 years ago this week.
The panel was appointed by Education Secretary Terrel H. Bell, whose department President Ronald Reagan wanted to abolish. Mr. Reagan's initial endorsement of the report was lukewarm. And with the economy fitfully recovering from recession, there seemed little prospect that the public would want to spend more money on education. 
 But the grim language of the report -- which warned of "a rising tide of mediocrity that threatens our very future as a nation and as a people" -- caught the imagination of educators, lawmakers and governors. It set off a wave of efforts to improve schools that in one way or another has touched just about every public school system in every state.
In interviews this month, people involved in this loose, nationwide campaign have offered a mixed assessment of its results. While many schools have embraced some of the study's recommendations -- longer school years, tougher curriculums and stronger teacher training programs -- the effort has produced only minimal gains in achievement.
"Schools have been responding diligently over the last 10 years," said Mr. Bell, now an education consultant in Salt Lake City. "But the results have been disappointing. The problems have been deeper and tougher than we thought, and they go beyond the school doors."
 
More Schooling, Mixed Results
 "A Nation at Risk" has driven an effort to improve schools that has lasted much longer than a previous push begun in 1957, when a nationwide alarm was touched off by the Soviet Union's launching of its Sputnik satellite.
Forty-two states since 1983 have toughened high school graduation requirements, a third have strengthened teacher certification programs, and teacher salaries have jumped 22 percent over the rate of inflation, rising from $22,000 to a national average of $36,000.
But student scores on the Scholastic Assessment Test (formerly the Scholastic Aptitude Test) and other benchmarks, while no longer falling as they did in the 1980's, have not shown a significant turnaround in the 1990's.
The woeful results in some areas, however, have masked what educators call significant gains elsewhere. Twenty-seven percent of high schools, according to one study, have toughened their curriculums and are assigning more homework, two recommendations from "A Nation At Risk."
At Pershing High School in Detroit, for instance, math and science requirements have been doubled to 2 years in each subject. Emeral Crosby, the principal, says the report prodded the stiffer requirements.
"The report did have an impact," said Mr. Crosby, one of the 18 members of the commission. "A lot of kids at Pershing who wouldn't have taken advanced math or science courses a decade ago are enrolled in those classes now."
In addition, 40 percent of schools have lengthened their school years, according to a study by the Educational Testing Service, an education research firm. And 70 percent of high schools -- double the number 10 years ago -- have adopted policies that keeps failing students out of extracurricular activities. Forty-seven states have introduced improved testing programs for students, while 39 states have introduced some form of teacher evaluation, according to a study by the Education Commission of the States.
 
Little Attention For City Schools
 Some educators suggest that it is still too early to gauge the movement's success. Others say the effort has been hobbled by the increase of single-parent families, the rising numbers of children living in poverty and the gap between money available to rich schools and to poor ones.
And city schools have been shortchanged by the movement, experts say, even though they enroll 13.5 percent of the nation's 42.5 million public school students and 40 percent of the nation's black, Hispanic and poor children.
"By and large, the reform movement has totally bypassed the cities," said Michael Casserly, executive director of the Council of Great City Schools, which represents the 43 largest urban school districts. "Cities have become so isolated racially, culturally and economically. And unfortunately most of the national leadership has either had an enormous sense of indifference or an overt hostility to the cities."
Although the dropout rate of black students has declined steadily over the last decade, the hemorrhaging continues: in 1991, 13.6 percent of blacks aged 16 to 24 were dropouts, nearly double that of whites in the same age group, while the Hispanic rate remained stubbornly high at 35.3 percent.
The negligible progress made by urban schools reflects what many educators concede are intractable problems that do not quickly respond to current solutions. For example, school-based management, in which central school departments give more control to teachers and parents, has had an uneven run in Chicago and in other cities.
As a result, urban schools have been forced to assemble their own programs to meet statewide requirements that were devised without taking into account the special problems of the inner cities. In Philadelphia, the University of Pennsylvania began a drop-out prevention plan for the city's schools, creating small enclaves of students within large high schools. More counseling and smaller class sizes also have been introduced in high schools that take part in the program.
Administrators like Joseph A. Fernandez, the departing Chancellor of the New York City Public Schools, is widely credited with pioneering some of the changes. When he was superintendent of the Dade County Public Schools, for example, Mr. Fernandez was among the urban administrators who recognized a need for better coordination of the delivery of services to students, not just in education but in health care and other social services.
"By and large, the improvement you have seen in urban schools is a creation of their own effort," said Mr. Casserly.
 
Recession Takes a Toll
 The recent recession forced states to cut budgets so severely that all schools have been dealing with a double burden: lower state aid and voters opposed to higher taxes. The district in Kalkaska, Mich., for instance, closed schools in March, two months early, because it ran out of money after voters rejected a tax increase. Other school systems have laid off teachers and eliminated extracurricular activities to conserve dwindling reserves.
"The competing resources for dollars is so dramatic now that I believe there has been an erosion of education dollars," said Katherine Keough, head of Xavier University's education department. "Health care, welfare, unemployment, jobs, infrastructure all are concrete and more visible. What goes on in the school is more difficult to identify." And thus, school finance experts say, more difficult to sell to voters deciding on tax increases.
Nonetheless, more spending overall has been poured into education, despite the recession. New Jersey, Nebraska and Oklahoma, for instance, have recently pushed through significant education spending bills, sometimes in the face of stiff voter opposition.
And the movement has attracted what many educators say is an unparalleled level of support from corporate America, which has lobbied for education legislation in statehouses, lobbied for strong job-skills programs and donated space for school buildings and equipment to ailing school systems.
 
The Future Of a Movement
 But progress is spotty, said Keith Geiger, president of the National Education Association, the teachers union. "We see a lot of good things, but I still think we haven't found ways to translate these successes to all schools, all teachers, all kids," he said.
That has started to change slowly as the campaign enters its second decade. Early childhood education and health-care and drop-out prevention programs are more and more being fused into so-called one-stop shopping schools, particularly in inner-city schools.
As part of the coordinated effort -- increasingly orchestrated by the Federal Government -- Head Start and Chapter 1, a program intended to help poor students reach grade level in reading and math are scheduled to receive more money in President Clinton's budget for fiscal year 1994.
The Administration's education legislation, unveiled last week, also seeks to tie together the unconnected efforts by offering national standards and assessment guidelines for schools -- the first time any Federal legislation has tried to do that.
"What has happened over time is that the analysis has gotten better," said Ernest L. Boyer, president of the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching. "Right now we are talking about the connection to health care and early childhood education."
But, he added, "Time is running out and, in the coming decade, our reform efforts simply must become more focused and more effective."

HEADLINE: Experts to Review Clinton Health Plan

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 27

 BODY:
President Clinton has named 47 doctors, nurses and other medical experts to assess his plan to revamp the nation's health care system before he sends it to Congress this spring.
 The White House did not announce formation of the panel until Monday, but a member of the group said today that members held their first meeting two weeks ago. 
Doctors and other practitioners say Mr. Clinton has relied excessively on economists and academic theorists in developing his health policy. The appointment of outside reviewers may help the Administration overcome such doubts.
 Some doctors, at the American Medical Association and medical specialty groups, suggested today that members of the panel were predisposed to support Mr. Clinton's plan. But White House officials and members of the review group rejected that idea.
 
Osteopath Heads Panel
 Dr. Stephen C. Gleason, an osteopathic physician from Des Moines who was active in Mr. Clinton's 1992 campaign, is chairman of the new panel, known as the health professionals review group. Osteopathic medicine takes a holistic approach to care of patients, emphasizing the body's ability to heal itself.
 Dr. Arnold S. Relman, a former editor of The New England Journal of Medicine, is a member of the review panel. He has harshly criticized the commercialization of medicine and has advocated strict limits on doctors' ownership of laboratories and other medical businesses.
 Pat Ford-Roegner, a former political director of the American Nurses Association, is vice chairwoman of the review panel. She has also worked at the Service Employees International Union, where she was responsible for health care and nursing issues.
 The vice chairman is Dr. Irwin E. Redlener, president of the Children's Health Fund, a foundation that supports mobile clinics for children in New York, New Jersey, West Virginia, Mississippi, Florida and Texas.
 Dr. Redlener was chairman of the National Health Leadership Council, a group of 300 health professionals who supported Mr. Clinton's campaign last year. He said he worked briefly in March for Hillary Rodham Clinton's Task Force on National Health Care Reform.
 
'Independent Group'
 But Dr. Redlener insisted that the review panel would not "rubber-stamp" Mr. Clinton's proposals. "This is an extremely independent group," he said.
 Dr. Redlener said the panel held its first meeting two weeks ago and was supposed to complete its work this week, but that it might hold another meeting in mid-May.
 The American Medical Association and 26 other groups, representing psychiatrists, surgeons, pathologists and other specialists, outlined their concerns in a letter to Dr. Gleason. They called for changes in medical malpractice laws, and they urged Dr. Gleason to help reduce the burden of Federal regulations on doctors.
 Ira C. Magaziner, the manager of the task force, said today that he did not have a reliable estimate of the cost of the President's health-care plan. In a speech to the American Group Practice Association, he seemed to minimize the political difficulty of getting Congress to raise taxes to finance the President's proposals.
 
Options for Nursing Care
 Mr. Magaziner said Mr. Clinton still intended to make "a serious start" in expanding coverage of long-term care, including nursing homes and residential care.
 Confidential work papers from the task force show that the Administration is considering four options for a "long-term care initiative," ranging from modest changes in Medicaid to a new social insurance program costing more than $100 billion a year. The documents offer no suggestions about how to pay for the new benefits.
 In a memorandum in February, Mr. Magaziner said that guaranteeing universal access to health care "could mean $30 billion or $90 billion of additional annual expenditure by the Government by 1997." But now Administration officials say that some of the options proposed by Mrs. Clinton's task force would put the cost at more than $100 billion a year.
 The White House said these people were also members of the health professionals review group:

HEADLINE: Washington Memo;
Clinton's Plan for Economy May Hinge on His Popularity

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 28

 BODY:
Despite some early setbacks and the worries expressed by some of President Clinton's top advisers, his economic plan, on which the ultimate success or failure of his Presidency could ride, has not been derailed by Congress.
But the overall package, with its steep tax increases, deficit reduction and huge shifts in spending away from the military and toward social programs and public works projects, is not -- as the White House maintains day after day -- completely on track either. 
 There are indeed bad signs for the President, many of them emphasized in some accounts of his first 100 days in office. The defeat of his emergency spending bill this month by a Republican filibuster in the Senate was one sign of potential pitfalls ahead. The almost certain rejection of his proposal for an investment tax credit for businesses is another.
 
Some Favorable Signs
 There are favorable signs as well: the nearly unanimous Democratic support in Congress for the general blueprint of the budget, and the fact that the legislation with all the tax measures and some of the toughest spending proposals will not be subject to a Republican filibuster.
In the final analysis, the outcome may depend less on the substance of the proposals than on Mr. Clinton's personal political standing this summer, a matter in which the economy plays only a part. An experienced legislative strategist on the staff of a leading Democratic Senator put it this way: "It's an absolute rule up here: popular Presidents get what they want; unpopular ones don't."
Mr. Clinton's popularity, as measured by opinion polls, has fallen recently. But his political history is one of quick plunges and surges in popularity. Where he stands now may bear little relationship to where he stands in July and August.
 
One Popular Tax
 Some of Mr. Clinton's proposals are viewed more favorably in Congress than others. The idea of higher income tax rates on the wealthy commands broad support. An investment tax credit has almost none. And some proposed tax increases on American companies that do business abroad will probably be dropped because the amount of revenue they would raise is not worth the political grief that goes with tackling the issue.
Other proposals like a new tax on fuel, a tax on more of the Social Security benefits of upper- and middle-income retirees and higher corporate tax rates fall somewhere in between. They are inherently unpopular, but a strong President might be able to muscle them through.
Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen, who has fought countless tax wars in the Senate, told reporters today that Congress had always made changes in tax bills and would surely do so this time. But he said he expected the main elements of the President's proposals to be enacted.
The prevailing view among lawmakers of both parties and lobbyists who work the Capitol corridors daily is that the House of Representatives will approve the Clinton economic package without critical changes. The Ways and Means Committee will begin drafting the tax portion, politically the most difficult part, next week, and the full House is expected to vote by Memorial Day.
But the Senate, which will not vote until July or even August, is a different matter. Its rules prevent a Republican filibuster like the one that killed the spending bill this month. Still, the Democratic margin in the Senate is so narrow and the President's support among Democratic Senators tenuous enough that his personal political strength at the time of the vote will be crucial.
That presumably is what Leon E. Panetta, Mr. Clinton's budget director, had in mind when he fretted aloud this week about the difficulty the Administration faced in winning Congressional approval of the economic plan at the same time it was asking for a new health-care system, the North American Free Trade Agreement and aid to Russia.
Each of those other matters, Mr. Panetta seemed to be saying, requires political muscle, and they might best be set aside for the time being so Mr. Clinton could devote all his clout to getting his economic package passed.
 
Health-Care Complications
 The health-care issue is seen as particularly vexing by the Clinton advisers focusing on budget questions. They believe the President will have to ask for new, unpopular taxes to pay for coverage for Americans with no health insurance.
These advisers, many with roots in Congress, contend that it is foolhardy to raise the question now, when the President is asking for other unpopular tax increases to shrink the budget deficit.
But the White House insisted again today that the health plan would be announced next month. At a Rose Garden ceremony, Mr. Clinton said, "I think what we're talking about is not a risk."
His spokesman, George Stephanopoulos, said the President "wants to go forward and thinks he can go forward and get both his economic and his health-care plans without any risk."
Mr. Clinton's prospects are much better in the House than in the Senate because of the big differences in the way the two houses operate.
In the House, Democrats can pass important legislation on their own. In the Senate, some Republican cooperation is essential.
In the House, amendments to tax bills are limited. In the Senate, almost any amendment is allowed.
Most Representatives see themselves as foot soldiers. Most Senators think of themselves as commanders.
In the end, of course, the differences between the House and Senate are resolved by a conference committee.
It is Mr. Clinton's good fortune that tax bills must originate in the House. And he is particularly fortunate that the chief originator nowadays is Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, the skillful chairman of the Ways and Means Committee and down-the-line Clinton advocate.
Today, Mr. Rostenkowski called all the Democrats on his committee together for a pep talk. On Thursday, he is taking them to the White House to meet with the President. Next week, they will begin writing the legislation, called a reconciliation bill, which will contain about 80 percent of the Federal budget: all the tax measures and spending for big-ticket items like Medicare, Social Security and welfare. The committee is committed to finishing its work by the middle of May.
Rank-and-file committee members said they had no doubt they would approve the basics of what Mr. Clinton wants. "We know we have to pass a bill out of committee, and it will essentially be the President's bill," said Representative Robert T. Matsui, a California Democrat.
 
Limit on Amendments
 The full House will vote under procedures that will allow few if any amendments. With three Democrats in the House for every two Republicans, passage, the Way and Means bill is almost certain to pass.
In the Senate, Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, keeps referring to the fact that the Democratic majority on the Finance Committee, the Senate counterpart of the House Ways and Means Committee, is only 11 to 9. If the Republicans stick together, he says, they can probably count on a Democratic defection and get their way.
Democratic defections, in committee and in the Senate as a whole are commonplace. But what the party's leaders are counting on is the Senate's tradition of forming bipartisan coalitions.
The last time a tax measure so consequential was before Congress was seven years ago, when Republicans controlled the Senate. Senator Bob Packwood of Oregon was chairman of the Finance Committee, and he forged a coalition with Democrats like Bill Bradley of New Jersey and Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York. The result was the Tax Reform Act of 1986.
Senator Moynihan is now chairman, and he is counting on Senator Packwood and his allies to return the favor. His chances are far from certain. He will benefit from the fact that under Senate rules, debate on reconciliation bills is subject to a time limit, meaning a Republican filibuster is impossible.
And Mr. Moynihan will certainly have to rely on President Clinton to twist arms.

HEADLINE: Belgrade Denounces Sanctions; Calls for Meeting

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 28

 BODY:
The President of Yugoslavia today angrily denounced new economic sanctions imposed on his country and called for a multinational summit conference to resolve the "war of annihilation" in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
"These are days of profound, epochal crisis," the President, Dobrica Cosic, said at a news conference. "The Federal Republic of Yugoslavia is almost totally isolated, in what amounts to a concentration camp whose borders are patrolled by NATO planes and ships and by the world police." 
 The Yugoslav Army originally armed and organized Serbian fighters in Bosnia. Yugoslav leaders, including Mr. Cosic, have failed to persuade the Serbs to accept a peace plan drawn up by international mediators.
Today Mr. Cosic said he still believed that Bosnian Serbs "will find the strength and the ways and means to accept the plan, which is something we will continue to insist on."
As he spoke, sporadic fighting continued on several fronts in Bosnia. United Nations spokesmen reported fighting between Muslim and Croatian forces near Sarajevo, and between Muslims and Serbs near Srebrenica. There were also several clashes near Bihac, a Muslim-controlled city that was attacked by Serbs on Tuesday.
Bosnian Serbs told the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees today that they would not permit the transport of any relief supplies to another Muslim-held town, Gorazde, for at least two weeks because of dangerous conditions in the area. There are an estimated 60,000 people in Gorazde.
Preparations for possible bombing raids against Serbian targets, either in Bosnia or in Serbia itself, intensified in European capitals. Newspapers in Britain and France reported that those countries were preparing planes and pilots. In Spain the Defense Minister, Julian Garcia Vargas, announced that the Western European Union was opening a satellite center near Madrid that could pinpoint targets for air raids.
Asked about the prospect that bombing could soon begin, Mr. Cosic replied, "I still cannot believe that such a senseless act could occur."
In an interview after his news conference, Mr. Cosic said a new international conference was the best way to inject "new ideas and new methods" into the search for peace. He proposed that participants include the United Nations Secretary General, the United Nations and European Community mediators who drafted the peace plan, the leaders of the three factions fighting in Bosnia (including the Government) and the heads of state from 11 countries: Yugoslavia, Croatia, the five permanent members of the Security Council (the United States, Russia, China, France and Britain) and India, Egypt, Brazil and Zimbabwe.
Mr. Cosic said he would send letters on Thursday to all the parties, asking them to convene a meeting as soon as possible. "If heads of state are willing to declare war, carry out military intervention, bring the NATO fleet into the Adriatic and take other difficult and costly steps, they should be ready to meet to talk peace," he said. 

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Another Rebuke for Yugoslavia
 UNITED NATIONS, April 28 (Special to The New York Times) -- The Security Council recommended to the General Assembly today that Yugoslavia be dropped from the Economic and Social Council, the body that coordinates and directs most of the economic, educational, cultural and health-related activities of the United Nations.
The vote was 13 to 0, with China and Russia abstaining. The 181-member General Assembly is expected to adopt the measure as early as Thursday.
Yugoslavia's deputy representative to the United Nations, Dragomir Djokic, called the action "legally and politically unacceptable." Mr. Djokic said that "Yugoslavia is not a party to the conflict in Bosnia-Herzegovina" and that it is working to end the fighting.
In September, the General Assembly concluded that the present Federal Republic of Yugoslavia, consisting of Serbia and Montenegro, was not entitled to the United Nations membership held by the former six-republic Yugoslav federation and would have to reapply.

HEADLINE: Parents in Bronx District Urge Voter Turnout as a Way to Improve Schools

BYLINE: By LYNDA RICHARDSON

 BODY:
Every day for the last few weeks, Mildred Bonilla and a gaggle of black and Hispanic parents have hit the streets of the South Bronx in a campaign they call Mothers on the Move.
Armed with fliers and petitions, interrupting afternoon naps and lunches, they are telling parents that the coming school board elections are their best chance to challenge a political system that they say has left the schoolchildren of their hard-pressed neighborhood shortchanged. 
 The group's members are not running themselves running for election. Nor are they formally supporting a specific slate of candidates in the election on May 4. But in a district that has seen little change on the school board -- and little voter interest -- in recent years, they represent an unusual bit of grass-roots activism. Their hope, they say, is that greater turnout in the South Bronx will insure that attention be paid to improving their schools.
"People have already seen our faces 100,000 times," said Ms. Bonilla, as she strode briskly down a corridor the other day with two parents close on her heels. "We feel like we're not getting an equal share. It's time to put in people with a new vision."
 
Condoms a Distraction
 From the mean streets of the South Bronx to the more prosperous neighborhoods in the borough's northeast, Community School District 8 has a collection of schools that seem to illuminate the best and the worst that New York City has to offer. And the central issue of the campaign there -- how to share the school system's scarce resources -- is one being debated in economically diverse districts throughout the city, from Jamaica and Forest Hills in Queens to Canarsie and Flatbush in Brooklyn.
For several candidates and the South Bronx parents as well, the fervent arguments over condoms and the Rainbow Curriculum that have defined so much of the citywide election debate are mere distractions.
A far larger issue, they say, is that many children in the poorer parts of the district are being taught by inexperienced teachers, with chronic shortages of supplies, in crumbling buildings. And they point to a local school board in which five of the nine members are from the Throgs Neck area, where the district's only major school construction project in the last three years -- a $10 million, 300-seat addition to Public School 72 -- is being erected.
"We need more school board members from the southern end of the district who can make sure there is an equitable distribution of resources," said Sandra Love, a board candidate and a health-care administrator from the South Bronx. "It's a critical issue for District 8."
 
Analysis Shows Discrepancies
 The teachers union agrees.
"In all of these districts, there are tensions about the inequitable distribution of resources," said Susan Amlung, a spokesman for the United Federation of Teachers. "Certainly by all appearances, there is a division in the district between these two ends of Throgs Neck and Hunts Point. It's something that we have been complaining about."
But some incumbent board members and school officials insist that appearances are not entirely what they seem. An analysis of district records shows that the schools in the north, with a significant number of white students, indeed have fewer inexperienced and uncertified teachers, and the school conditions there are somewhat better.
But those schools also have larger class sizes and receive the same or less money for each pupil than do other schools in the district.
Basic spending for each pupil was on average $200 or so lower in the 4 of 27 schools in the northern area, which all have higher white populations, the analysis shows. When Federal funds intended for schools in impoverished neighborhoods are included, the figure is $583 less.
And while the schools in the better-off neighborhoods consistently have scored better on math and reading tests than the rest of the district, mirroring a common trend among middle class students, there are also pockets of high achievement in some of the poorer, southern schools.
According to Rose Foley, an incumbent board member from Throgs Neck, the arguments of inequity is "a terrible rumor." She adds: "It's become, I hate to say it, almost a racial issue when it shouldn't be."
 
'Color Means Nothing'
 "Color and gender make no difference to me," she said at a recent candidates' forum.
Other candidates insist that racial equity is indeed an issue.
"It's a big issue for black and Hispanic candidates," said Virginia Senai Daniels, an incumbent board member who lives in the southeastern Bronx. "When I speak of equity, I'm dealing with the quality of teachers in the schools."
Dennis Coleman, the president of the New York City School Boards Association and a 23-year veteran of the District 8 board, shares the sentiment. Mr. Coleman, who lives in the East Bronx, said voters in the northern part of the district had voted in a bloc to elect candidates representing their interests. He said it was time for voters in the south to do the same.
 
Bringing Encouragement
 Mr. Coleman said the schools needing the most help were neglected and he put much of the blame on the longtime superintendent, Max Messer, who he said caters to the members from the Throgs Neck area. "The whole system stinks," he said.
Mr. Messer's contract expires in June 1994, and Mr. Coleman opposes its renewal. The superintendent did not return telephone calls.
Mr. Coleman, for one, takes heart in the efforts of South Bronx parents to shake up the school district. "Parents have begun to wake up," he said.
The parents' group, which has about 15 members, most of them mothers, was spawned one year ago from adult literacy classes at the Bronx Educational Services, a nonprofit social service organization located in an old school building on bustling Longwood Avenue. The parents were all products of New York City schools and began to ask why they had not learned to read or write.
Their questions led to forming of the Parents Organizing and Education Project: Mothers on the Move.
Since last year, the parents have organized workshops on leadership development and parental involvement. They have sponsored forums attended by school board members. More than 50 parents demonstrated at the district office, urging that more attention to paid to their schools.
 
An Electoral Challenge
 Ms. Bonilla, a coordinator of the group, is currently challenging the right of two board membersfrom Throgs Neck to be on the ballot.
Ms. Bonilla had succeeded in getting the candidates knocked off the ballot when she determined that many of the signatures on their nominating petitions were from non-registered voters. But a few days later, the names were returned to the ballot by the Board of Election commissioners.
When she complained, the executive director of the Board of Elections, Daniel DeFrancesco, said, in a letter on April 14, that while the commissioners appeared to have used incorrect information in restoring the names, the deadline for "judicial intervention has expired."
The Manhattan District Attorney's office is investigating Ms. Bonilla's charge. The candidates, Steven Eskow and Ciro Guerra, did not return a reporter's telephone calls.
As the parents canvass the streets every day, they are often met with questions that remind them of the daunting nature of their task.
"Is this the election for the schools chancellor or something?" said one mother, Vivian Jenkins, upon opening her door.
The mother, whose 11-year-old daughter attends Intermediate School 52, said sheepishly that she did not know who was running for office. Ms. Bonilla patiently explained the election, and the value of participating. The mother signed a pledge to vote, one of about 200 to do so.
Down the hall, April O'Toole, toting a thick bundle of leaflets, rapped on another door. When there was no answer, she moved quickly down the hall. Ms. O'Toole, 31, mother of a 9-year-old in Public School 62, said her enthusiasm was fueled by frustration with the schools.
"It's important," she said. "A majority of the school board has been there too long. We need money for resources, books, supplies, all kinds of different things. How can a teacher teach without that?"

HEADLINE: Auto Makers Ask White House for Broad Range of Help

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 28

 BODY:
The chief executives of the Big Three auto makers asked top Administration officials today for help on a broad range of issues including international trade, regulations, technology and health insurance.
John F. Smith Jr. of General Motors, Harold A. Poling of Ford Motor and Robert J. Eaton of Chrysler urged the joint development of a comprehensive plan to help the auto industry regain its global preeminence. 
 In a joint statement after the meeting, the executives said: "We urged Government leaders to move forward on a full range of issues vital to the success of the domestic auto industry, including health care, international trade and technology projects. Our shared goals are a strong competitive domestic industry and economic recovery which has job creation as its centerpiece."
Representative Sander M. Levin, Democrat of Michigan, who helped set up the meeting, said in an interview: "We've never had any kind of Government strategy. We're now moving toward a comprehensive plan rather than a piecemeal approach."
Mr. Levin said he had proposed legislation to create a commission to study the auto industry's problems, similar to one that will study the problems of the airline industry.
Today's meeting was suggested and led by Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown and also attended by Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich and Laura D'Andrea Tyson, chairwoman of the Council of Economic Advisers. Also present were representatives of the Defense, Treasury, Transportation, Energy, State, Health and Human Services Departments and officials from the Environmental Protection Agency, the National Science Foundation and the office of the United States trade representative.
The meeting was the second in a series with industry executives. Aerospace industry executives attended the first session three weeks ago.
On international trade, auto executives have asked for reclassification of mini-vans and sport utility vehicles as light trucks for customs purposes, instead of as cars. This would raise the tariffs on these vehicles to 25 percent from 2.5 percent.
On regulation, General Motors has indignantly resisted a Government proposal to recall 4.7 million pickup trucks with side-mounted gasoline tanks. The National Highway Transportation Safety Administration, which seeks the recall, said those trucks were especially vulnerable to fatal fires when hit on the side. G.M. contends that the trucks are safe.
John Guiniven, a Chrysler spokesman, said that the meeting was a continuation of a dialogue begun during the Presidential campaign.
"We share a common goal with the Administration: a competitive domestic industry," he said.
The auto executives were especially heartened by the Administration's comprehensive approach to the industry's woes. "It looks like in this Administration, the left hand is going to know what the right hand is doing," Mr. Guiniven said.

HEADLINE: Gold's Modest Ascent

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Gold is rallying. Gold traders are busy. Gold analysts are smiling and predicting higher prices -- yes, higher prices.
That is quite a change for gold, which was banished to the minor leagues in the mid-1980's after enjoying major league status in the 1970's and especially in 1980, when prices hit $850 an ounce. Every rally has been quashed as the price moved relentlessly lower, slumping to $326.90 on March 10, its lowest level in more than eight years. 
 This time, prices appear to be rising because of fundamental changes in supply and demand that have been lacking in past rallies. Inflation fears, however, which have pushed up the price of gold in the past, are not a major driving force in the West but could be stimulating the buying seen in China. Whatever the cause, analysts say, the support is not there to take gold to lofty new price levels.
The price of gold on the Commodity Exchange in New York has jumped more than 8 percent, or $27.50 an ounce, from its year low to its highest level since last August. Almost half that increase has come in the last four trading days and that is what is grabbing the attention. On the Commodity Exchange, gold was up $2.30 to $354.40 yesterday.
Ian MacDonald, manager of precious metals at Credit Suisse, is saying things he has not uttered for years. "I am seeing a very dynamic turnaround," he said. "The bear market has ended."
But this is still, at best, a late-inning rally in a minor league park. Mr. MacDonald's predictions, which are in line with those of several other gold analysts, put the price of gold up an additional 7 percent by the end of the year. "Realistically, there is nothing that says we cannot go to $380, easily," he said.
That means that half the rally is past. And even at that level, the price would still be well below the $427 that gold hit early in 1990. As of now, Mr. MacDonald and others are not talking of returning to those levels soon.
"I can only go by how it looks now and it looks decent," a gold trader said, asking that his opinion remain anonymous. But he added that gold had hurt a lot of people before.
 
Two Big Gold Deals
 The rally still means a lot for traders, who thrive on price movements. And for investors like Sir James Goldsmith, the British-French financier, and George Soros, a renowned fund manager and speculator, it could mean large profits. The two completed a deal last week under which funds managed by Mr. Soros would buy a 10 percent stake in the Newmont Mining Company, which Sir James controls. He used proceeds from the sale to buy options on gold.
The rumor of the buying of options on Friday, the report of the sale on Monday and, possibly, Mr. Soros's appearance on Cable News Network's "Business Day" morning program all contributed to gold's rise. Some traders said they jumped in because they believed Mr. Soros and Mr. Goldsmith might know something they did not.
At the least, by publicly disclosing their investment, Mr. Soros and Mr. Goldsmith have certainly increased their own paper profits, for now. Mr. Soros was unavailable and executives with his fund management firm declined to comment.
The other factors in the rally are the reports of heavy buying of gold in Asia, especially in China, where many Chinese are reaping the benefits of the opening of the economy and are buying gold because they lack options for investing. According to some estimates, the Chinese could buy 1,000 metric tons of gold this year, which is more than South Africa and the United States produce.
 
A Technical Reason
 From a technical view, which is also important in the market, buying was also set off when gold passed $343 dollars an ounce last Thursday, which pushed the price above the line of a 13-year downtrend.
Joseph Rosta, the research director at CPM Group, a precious metals consulting group, said money was flowing into gold because some investors had decided that the bond and stock markets had topped out. He also argued that investors have chosen "to take a fresh look" at gold, in part because prices have fallen so low.
One reason for the slump in the price of gold in the 1980's was an oversupply caused by overproduction and large sales by Russia and others. But there have been recent signs that this supply glut is beginning to turn. Gold Field Mineral Services, which compiles the industry's most detailed report on gold each year, recorded a decline in supply in its 1992 report. The Russians said yesterday that their mine production dropped 8.5 percent last year, to 129.5 million metric tons. In addition, the Government said that production fell by six million metric tons in the first quarter of 1993.
Mr. MacDonald and others have also cited the expectation of a slowdown in gold sales by central banks.

HEADLINE: U.S. Tries to Calm Japan Over Role in Yen Price

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 28

 BODY:
A day before the Group of Seven's finance ministers gather in Washington, American officials sought today to ease Japanese anger over the value of the yen, repeating that they wanted to avoid exchange-rate volatility.
Japanese officials have complained that remarks by President Clinton and other American officials have pushed the yen to a record level against the dollar, which they fear will make their exports expensive and hurt their ailing economy. 
 American Treasury officials have made clear that they will keep the heat on Japan about its big trade surplus. Still, they had sought to comfort Tokyo on Tuesday, when they asked the Federal Reserve to intervene by buying dollars to stop the yen from soaring further.
The Fed did intervene, and also on Tuesday, Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen said that attempts to "artificially influence" exchange rates were inappropriate. The dollar then rebounded from its record low against the yen.
At a news briefing today, Mr. Bentsen said he thought that "things went well" in reaction to that remark, adding that Japan's Finance Minister, Yoshiro Hayashi, was pleased with the statement. "What we wanted to see," Mr. Bentsen said, "was a further stabilization of the situation. Excessive volatility at the currency exchanges has a tendency to hurt growth."
 
Aid for the Russians
 The Secretary also pressed Japan to provide more aid to Russia, saying that with a strong budget position, it was in a good position to do so. "Hopefully, we are going to see more than we have heard thus far" from Japan, he said.
Mr. Bentsen said aid to Moscow would be one of the main topics at Thursday's session of the leading industrial nations that meet regularly as the Group of Seven. The United States has pledged $1.8 billion in aid in addition to the $1.6 billion that Mr. Clinton promised during his meetings early this month in Vancouver with Russia's President, Boris N. Yeltsin.
Tokyo has promised $1.8 billion, but American officials have criticized this, saying that only $320 million is direct aid with the rest in the form of loan guarantees.
Mr. Bentsen, asked why he chose to make his currency remarks on Tuesday, said he did so because the Group of Seven meeting was coming up. Finance ministers are often eager to calm currency markets before such meetings because markets can become especially volatile at such times unless existing tensions have been defused.
Economists and currency traders said the Treasury asked the Fed to intervene not just to soothe the Japanese, but also because it was worried that the dollar's plunge was roiling credit markets and pushing up interest rates on Treasury bonds.
"The interest-rate decline is about the only stimulus package the Administration has," said C. Fred Bergsten, director of the Institute for International Economics, a Washington research group. "If that reversed on them, they would really be in the soup."
 
Arguments to Clinton
 Administration officials have made the point to Mr. Clinton that a strong yen is an important tool to help reduce Japan's $49 billion trade surplus because it makes Japanese exports more expensive and American goods cheaper in Japan.
A strong yen, though, presumably stirs some ambivalence within the Administration, and not just because it helps feed inflation. "A stronger yen sets up a conflict inside the Treasury," said Scott E. Pardee, a former senior Federal Reserve staff official who is chairman of Yamaichi International America. "The Treasury is responsible for managing the nation's debt, and some people from the debt-management side said this is not a good policy because they saw it pushing up rates."
Japanese officials have also expressed frustration recently toward suggestions from the Clinton Administration that their Government's $116 billion economic-stimulus package is not large enough, and also that its value might be exaggerated.
In his remarks today, Mr. Bentsen praised Tokyo's stimulus package, saying it would help spur growth both at home and around the world. Nonetheless, he said, the Japanese should pursue additional economic-stimulation programs in the future so that "they can get more consumption in Japan and therefore help provide a better market for our products and in turn hopefully cut the deficit in trade that we have with them."
Administration officials have denied that they had any target for the exchange value of the yen. But the sense among many currency traders is that Washington regarded 110 yen to the dollar as a convenient floor, at least for now, and moved to intervene once the dollar fell to that level.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Ford First-Quarter Profit Is Better than Expected

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, April 28

 BODY:
The Ford Motor Company reported improved first-quarter earnings today, far exceeding analysts' estimates, but still short of what the auto maker said it would deem acceptable.
That was the sort of talk investors loved to hear, and Ford shares rose $1.875, to $54.50, on the New York Stock Exchange. More than three million shares traded hands. 
 Ford reported income of $572 million, or $1.02 a common share, compared with a profit of $223 million, or 36 cents a share, for the comparable period a year ago. Automotive analysts had projected earnings of 59 cents a share for the first quarter of this year. Earnings in the first quarter of 1992 involved a restatement to account for retiree health benefits, which created a loss of $6.7 billion.
Revenue for the period was $26.76 billion, up 9 percent from $24.56 billion in the first quarter of 1992. David N. McCammon, the vice president for finance, said Ford would like to achieve a 5 percent after-tax return on revenue. The current return is about 2 percent.
Last week the Chrysler Corporation reported stronger than expected earnings. The General Motors Corporation is scheduled to report its earnings on Friday.
 
'Intense Competition'
 Harold A. Poling, the chairman of Ford, said the nation's economic recovery was slow and that global economies had remained weak. Worldwide, Ford was also contending with "intense competition and excess industry capacity, all of which make achievement of improved financial results more difficult," he said.
Analysts had underestimated the profit gains of the financial services subsidiaries of the auto maker: the Ford Motor Credit Company; the Associates, and the First Nationwide Bank. Lower loan losses and higher net interest margins helped the financial-services units increase earnings to $396 million in the first quarter, compared with $249 million in the comparable period a year ago, excluding the cumulative effects of the accounting changes. With those changes, net income for the first quarter of last year was $460 million.
Analysts also did not expect as much of an improvement as was reported by the European operations of Ford, which still lost about $100 million in the quarter. "Ford's restructuring in Europe benefited more than I guessed," said Ron Glantz, an automotive analyst for Dean Witter in San Francisco.
Worldwide automotive earnings were $176 million, compared with a loss of $26 million for the comparable period a year ago. In the United States, automotive earnings were $113 million, compared with a loss of $59 million in the first quarter of 1992.
Analysts seemed heartened by narrowed losses at Jaguar, the troubled British subsidiary of Ford. The first-quarter operating loss at Jaguar was $55 million, compared with an operating loss of about $100 million in the comparable period a year ago.
Mr. McCammon said deteriorating economic conditions in Europe had led Ford to withdraw its prediction that it would break even in Europe for the year. The auto maker lowered its annual sales projection to 13.1 million vehicles, from 13.7 million. In the United States, Ford is projecting sales of 13.5 million vehicles. It considers sales of 15.5 million vehicles to be a normal year.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Bond Prices Are Mixed

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Despite a well-received Treasury auction, bond investors yesterday continued to demonstrate doubts about the Clinton Adminstration's ability to make significant cuts in the Federal deficit.
Unexpectedly strong demand at the Treasury's sale of five-year notes helped lift secondary market bond prices off their lows. But the key long bond posted a modest loss while short- and intermediate-term securities rose only slightly. 
 The price of the Treasury's main 30-year bond lost 1/8 point, or $1.25 per $1,000 in face value. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from price, rose to 6.91 percent from late Tuesday's 6.90 percent.
It was the bond's highest yield in about three weeks and reflected bearish sentiment that has confined trading to a narrow price range recently.
The bond market's rally had come largely because of prospects for a lower Federal budget deficit, which would reduce the number of bonds issued by the Government to cover the debt.
But Leon Panetta, Clinton's budget director, was quoted in several newspapers Tuesday as saying he had become increasingly discouraged about the outlook for passage of the deficit-reduction plan.
Andy Brenner, a bond trader at Nomura Securities International Inc., said the market was concerned about the "credibility of the current adminstration in getting their act together. There seems to be a lot of indecision in Clinton's own cabinet."
Despite that bearishness, the Treasury sold more than $11 billion in five-year notes at a lower-than-expected high yield of 5.18 percent. Demonstrating the brisk demand, the bid-to-cover ratio, a measure of Treasury auction demand that compares the number of bids offered to those accepted, was 3.09-to-1, up from an average of 2.4-to-1 in the seven previous auctions.
Participants said the strong demand came partly because the market was coming off Tuesday's poorly received offering of two-year Treasury notes. This helped lift yields higher and made bonds more attractive across the board.
 
Debt Management Study
 John Canavan, an analyst with Stone & McCarthy Research Associates Inc. in Princeton, N.J., said the market remained nervous ahead of the Treasury's debt management study and its refunding announcement due out next week, which should give more definite indications of how the Treasury plans to pare its issuance of longer-term bonds.
Short-term Treasuries were 1/32 point to 1/16 point higher and intermediate maturities were unchanged to 1/32 point higher, the financial information service Telerate Inc. reported.
The Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index, reflecting price movements on bonds with maturities of a year or longer, rose 0.42, to 1,294.38.
Yields on three-month Treasury bills rose to 2.96 percent as the discount rose .01 percentage point to 2.91 percent. Six-month yields fell to 3.07 percent as the discount fell .02 point, to 2.99 percent. One-year yields held at 3.24 percent with the discount at 3.13 percent.
In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds closed at 10025/32 , down 1/16 from late Tuesday. The average yield to maturity edged up to 5.97 percent from 5.96 percent.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rides on Momentum To Slight Gain Against Yen

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar eked out another gain against the Japanese yen yesterday, riding on momentum from Tuesday when the Federal Reserve intervened to halt the currency's slide.
But dollar buyers began to lose enthusiasm as they looked toward today's meeting of the Group of Seven nations, where finance officials are expected to discuss exchange rates. 
 The dollar slipped against the German mark and was mixed against other European currencies, although Germany and other European nations cut key short-term interest rates.
The dollar has risen by about three yen since the Fed's intervention Tuesday lifted it from a postwar low of 109.15 yen in New York. But the attempt to slow the dollar's 12 percent plunge this year seemed to falter yesterday.
The dollar rose to a high of 112.50 yen in New York before falling back amid reports of strong selling interest at the 113-yen level. It settled at 112.12 yen from late Tuesday's 111.70 yen.
Earlier yesterday in Tokyo, the dollar closed at 111.88 yen, up 1.40 yen from Tuesday's close. In London, the dollar rose to 112.25 yen.
 
Waiting on Japanese Holidays
 Many traders refrained from major moves ahead of Golden Week in Japan, a seven-day span beginning today that includes four national holidays.
"We're not really seeing much evidence of anyone really positioning for an immediate surge in the dollar," said Ronald Leven, a global currency analyst at the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company.
"The general attitude seems to be that the central banks are trying to slow and control the descent of the dollar, but are not prepared to defend a particular level."
The dollar slipped against the German mark despite a steeper-than-expected cut in the Germany Bundesbank's securities repurchase rate and cuts by Norway, Belgium and the Netherlands in key short-term rates. The move was traced to heavy cross-trading, in which traders sold yen and bought marks.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.5720, from $1.5770 late Tuesday. By 4 P.M. in New York, the pound was quoted at $1.5730, more than late Tuesday's $1.5775.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
The Big Three may get a Clinton goodie, but perhaps not on trade.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
"I WAS astonished that the Bush Administration overruled its own Customs Office and gave a $300 million-a-year freebie to the Japanese for no apparent reason," President Clinton told reporters at his first news conference. "And we got nothing, and I emphasize nothing, in return."
The words were Mozart to the ears of Big Three auto executives, who want Uncle Sam to classify imported mini-vans and sporty, four-wheel-drive vehicles as light trucks -- and thus require importers to fork over a 25 percent tariff. But the message sounded more like chalk on a blackboard to the President's economic advisers, who know that Americans did indeed get something -- mini-vans and sport utility vehicles from both America and Japan for thousands of dollars less than they would otherwise have had to pay. 
 Mr. Clinton's economists have thus been happy to duck the issue since candidate Clinton wooed Michigan with a promise to play hardball with the Japanese. At an interagency meeting last Friday, they reiterated their "general agreement" that "there is no trade justification for the reclassification." But the group was pressed by Rahm Emanuel, a White House political operative, to come up with something very quickly. A good guess now is that it will recommend something unrelated that Detroit covets -- perhaps on technology subsidies or a break on fuel economy standards.
The origin of this tale lies in a spat over chickens with the European Common Market in the 1960's. To retaliate for discriminating against American poultry, Washington put a 25 percent tariff on imported light trucks -- then, mostly Volkswagens.
The bird brouhaha is long forgotten (as are Volkswagen's trucks), but the 25 percent tariff on light trucks lingers. And when two new sorts of multipurpose vehicles came into vogue in the 1980's, Detroit saw an opportunity to protect its markets by demanding "harmonization" in the way the vehicles were regulated.
For purposes of safety and exhaust emissions, mini-vans and sport utility vehicles are classified as light trucks -- a decision, incidentally, that serves the Big Three's interests as well as Tokyo's. Thus in the view of Ford, G.M. and Chrysler, all those swank Mazda MPV's, shown in the ads full of tots on their way to Playorama, were really trucks. So were the Toyota 4-Runners, which always seem to be carting skiers off to their condos.
The Bush Administration squirmed, then settled on the Solomonic compromise. Mini-vans would remain cars for tariff purposes, as would four-door sport utility vehicles; two-door sport utility vehicles would be reclassified as trucks.
That satisfied nobody save, perhaps, a few hundred thousand Americans in the market for one of the newfangled people movers. Meanwhile, the whole issue of "harmonizing" regulation is becoming irrelevant, since light trucks will soon be required to meet the same safety standards as cars. But the politics turned decisively in Detroit's favor with the election of a New Democrat, who seems sufficiently old at heart to fear being labeled a wimp on trade.
The Big Three have been banging their protectionist drums on multipurpose vehicles, a priority that might strike some as strange in light of the fact that Chrysler dominates the mini-van market and all three American auto makers are cleaning Japan's clock on sport utility sales. Robert Lutz, the president of Chrysler, did not make the industry's focus any less opaque in a recent interview on CNN. "We've really crowded the Japanese back into a corner," he told the interviewer. "It's just a matter of principle to us."
Detroit may simply crave a symbolic victory to show it still has lobbying clout. The more cynical interpretation is that, in spite of very modest sales, the Japanese still represent a potential marketing threat that makes it problematic for the Big Three to raise prices. Whatever the reason, though, the White House is likely to deliver something.
The President could do what Detroit asks. That option, however, is bitterly opposed by the State Department, which still believes that America has bigger strategic fish to fry with the Japanese than the definition of a light truck -- for example, aid to Russia. The diplomats also worry that the Japanese would appeal the issue to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, and win. But even if the Japanese swallowed the bitter medicine, the decision would embarrass Laura D'Andrea Tyson, the President's chief economist, who has been careful to differentiate her "cautious activism" on trade from garden variety protectionism.
That leaves the possibility of negotiating some modest market-opening initiative with Japan -- the "something" George Bush did not get. More likely, the President will offer Detroit a bonbon from his domestic goodie bag. He may, for example, decide that cleaner cars are in everyone's interest, and throw in some money for joint research. Or, he could take a stand against pushing mileage requirements beyond levels justified by energy security or environmental requirements.
Come to think of it, with a little deft stitching, the President might yet transform this chewed-over sow's ear into a silk purse.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Tax-Exempt Yields Jump While Taxables Are Level

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields of tax-exempt money market funds rose smartly in the latest reporting week, while taxable-fund yields were flat.
A survey covering the week ended Tuesday by IBC's Money Fund Report showed the average seven-day compounded yield for a tax-exempt fund up 7 basis points, to 2.04 percent, and the average seven-day simple yield up 6 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 2.01 percent. The 30-day average compounded yield was 1.97 percent, and the 30-day simple yield was 1.94 percent. 
 Investors withdrew $1.4 billion from tax-free funds in the week, with total assets falling to $99.4 billion. Analysts at the Money Fund Report noted that the week's withdrawals were considerably less than the previous week's, when investors pulled out about $2.7 billion and yields increased an average of 8 basis points.
In the week, fund managers shortened the average days to maturity of securities held in their portfolios to 48, from 49, as yields moved higher for the second consecutive week. The average is near the year's low.
Not including state and local taxes, the taxable-bond equivalent yield for the average seven-day tax-free yield is 2.83 percent for investors in the 28 percent tax bracket and 2.96 percent for those in the 31 percent bracket.
Among the tax-exempt funds with assets greater than $100 million, the Money Fund Report said the Dreyfus Basic Municipal Money Market Fund was the best performer in the week, with a yield of 2.73 percent, up 12 basis points from the previous week's best.
 
Taxable Funds
 For taxable funds, the average seven-day compounded yield slipped a basis point, to 2.65 percent, and the seven-day simple yield fell 2 basis points, to 2.61 percent, according to IBC/Donoghue's. The compounded average yield over 30 days is 2.68 percent, while the simple yield is 2.65 percent.
For the week ended yesterday, assets of taxable money market funds declined $2.7 billion, to $487.8 billion, with assets of institutional funds down $1.6 billion, to $171.4 billion, and retail assets down $1.1 billion, to $316.4 billion.
Analysts said the average days left to maturity of securities in taxable money market portfolios was unchanged at 63, indicating that money managers were still confident that yields would not take a significant turn soon.
Walter S. Frank, chief economist for the Money Fund Report, said yields in the week reflected the absence of activity by the Federal Reserve to influence the market, leaving it to bounce around on technicals.
For the second consecutive week, the Dreyfus Basic Money Market Fund had the highest yield among general-purpose taxable money funds with a yield of 3.46 percent, down 2 basis points from last week.
Yields at banks, which compete directly with money market funds for investors' cash, averaged 2.57 percent in the week, down a basis point.

HEADLINE: New York State Issue Is Priced

 BODY:
New York State's spring borrowing, which temporarily bridges the gap between state operating expenditures and anticipated revenues, was priced yesterday through competitive bidding.
Several underwriters were awarded portions of the $850 million offering of tax and revenue anticipation notes due on Dec. 31. 
 The bulk of the issue, or $625 million, was bought with a coupon of 2 3/4 percent and repriced to yield 2.05 percent.
Among the companies reoffering the notes at the 2.05 percent yield were J. P. Morgan, Chemical Securities, Paine Webber, First Boston and Morgan Stanley.
Merrill Lynch bought $125 million of the notes and priced them to yield 2 percent, while Bear, Stearns bought $100 million, reoffering them at a price to yield 2.10 percent.
Underwriters said the notes carried the highest short-term rating of MIG-1 by Moody's Investors Service and the highest short-term rating of SP-1+ by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

HEADLINE: A Shotgun Wedding Startles Milan Design

BYLINE: By SUZANNE SLESIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MILAN, Italy, April 26

 BODY:
Like a couple who have been living together for some time without making a serious commitment, modern Italian design and traditional handicrafts have finally decided to tie the knot.
One might call it the shotgun wedding of the decade. 
 And what did the results of the union of high technology and handmade look like? A-six-and-a-half-foot-tall rattan lamp that resembles a giant closed umbrella or a slim towerlike wood cabinet that would not be out of place if Shakers had home offices.
The shakers and movers at the Salone Internazionale del Mobile, the mammoth annual Italian furniture fair that closed here on Sunday, had no choice in the matter.
Italian design is at a significant crossroads. With the recession in the furniture business being felt on an international scale, the closings and cutbacks of the home-furnishings magazines and, most important, the wholesale rejection of cutting-edge design by the buying public, the Italian manufacturers seemed to realize that they had to reinvent themselves or face a slow and painful death.
The Salone, with its 1,806 exhibitors and 147,500 visitors -- buyers, retailers and journalists from 130 countries -- remains the most important marketplace of its kind in the world. The six-day event, held in a country that exported $5.1 billion in furniture last year, also included Eurocucina, a kitchen show, and the Salone del Complemente d'Arredo, an accessories and rugs exhibition.
The Milan fair is also the world's most influential show in terms of style, that volatile yet basic ingredient of modern furniture. Lower prices and collections aimed at a younger clientele were widely adopted strategies. Even so, buyers seemed to be on their guard.
"We come to look -- then we go home to pound it out," said Mitchell Steinberg, one of the owners of the Lee's Art Studio stores in New York. "And we're very conservative these days. There's no room for mistakes."
The new look in Milan is emerging as a strong stylistic statement in its own right, one that is reassuringly recognizable. In an uncertain world people are reaching out for basic, old-fashioned values, with a bit of cute thrown in. A chair with its upholstery tied around its base -- midriff style -- elicited smiles. So did a wing chair covered in cheery checked fabric.
One thing is sure: the hard-edge esthetic has been given the ultimate heave-ho. The furniture of the 90's must be strong but not aggressive, soft but not sentimental, plain but certainly not boring.
"New is quiet," said Paola Navone, one of the owners of Mondo, the company that was one of the leaders in the new design evolution. "Now, everyone is accepting what they were fighting when we started Mondo." Four years ago, Mondo redefined the look of contemporary furniture when it dropped Adirondack chairs onto the Milan design scene.
"Digesting the past instead of being scared of it is now just one of the many components of the new design," Ms. Navone added. "We still accept the industrial look in a car, but absolutely not in the things we like to keep close to home."
Even plastics are trying to change their image. At Kartell, an Italian company known for its avant-garde plastic furniture, Claudio Luti, the chief executive, was standing in a forest of pastel-hued wastepaper baskets made from recycled plastic garbage. "Each one is different," Mr. Luti said proudly.
The international ecological love affair with all things natural was reflected in the widespread use of cane and rattan. They appeared on headboards and lamps, on chair seats and sofas. They were applied to the fronts of chests and transformed into table bases.
But the emphasis on the low-key was disappointing to those still looking for design thrills.
"It looks like no one is putting any effort into their presentations," said Ilan Pivko, an Israeli architect who was touring the show with one of his clients in search of the usual fireworks. "Many things look like last year's festivities. I guess design is out anyway."
Well, not completely. One might just have to accept that furniture is beginning to look, well, normal. "I call it very low tech," said George Beylerian, a senior adviser to the Steelcase Design Partnership in New York. "That's where the Italians are going. To me it's a riot."
But it's not a joke. Companies like Boffi, for example, which have been in the furniture business for generations, are energetically looking for new business and asking style-conscious designers to put together new collections. "We have to offer an alternative market to those who like to go to flea markets," said Aldo Cibic, whose Antologia collection for Boffi is a motley but amusing group of exaggerated versions of classic pieces.
The results include bright blue Regency-style library steps, as well as Geranio, a bulging red chest inspired by a French boule chest. "I call them new antiques," Mr. Cibic said. "A room must be made up of a combination of all the things you love. That's the new culture."
At Xilard, an Italian company that usually manufactures traditional dark walnut furniture, the message was: "Look for these pieces in your attic or your memory." This year, the company introduced a collection of painted chairs, tables and glass-doored cabinets.
"The furniture is poor and sweet, naively painted in natural and pale colors," said Giulio Falcier, the company's export manager, touting Xilard's hand-forged nails and glue made from animal skins.
Ms. Navone was not impressed. "Some manufacturers thought that all you had to do was bring back something from the past and clean it up," she said. "I don't want any of that grandmother stuff anymore."
In her own Mondo collection, Ms. Navone has taken off in more exotic directions, traveling to Morocco. Her idea was to reinterpret the mosaic tile craft she saw there. Ms. Navone designed a series of tables set on iron legs made in Italy. The tops, in colorful carpetlike patterns, are made to Ms. Navone's specifications in Morocco.
"The tables are neither folkloric or old-fashioned, but optimistic," she said. "Is this not really a new way of making furniture?"
It might be. So might Antonio Citterio's multifaceted approach. Mr. Citterio, who seems to have replaced the French designer Philippe Starck as the ubiquitous presence at the fair, put his imprimatur on a plethora of sofas and chairs. His presence was felt most strongly at B & B Italia, one of the most important furniture companies in Italy.
Near the front of the booth stood variation upon variation of his new and seductively youth-oriented seating: plump and round-armed, covered in bright colors or a zany mix of polka dots. Called Indo, Cina, Cubis and Oriente, the chairs and sofas had the essential ingredient so important for mass-produced furniture today: charm.
Mr. Citterio also wrestled with the idea of providing less budget-minded customers with a place to stash their computers. "Everyone is always looking for something like an antique secretary," he said, "but that's not an up-to-date product. I wanted to keep this feeling, of looking for something rich, but design something for our time."
B & B Italia's Maxalto division, which employs 40 artisans, provided the craftsmanship for Mr. Citterio's intricately outfitted four-foot-wide cabinet with a marquetry front. And if that elegant piece was to your liking, then what about a Biedermeier-inspired table to accompany it? And then, of course, you might need dining chairs to complete the decor.
But what should they look like? Mr. Citterio remembers hesitating, but not for long. The light bulb snapped on when he and his wife, Terry Dwan, an architect, were looking up at a bronze statue of a seated man in a leafy Milanese piazza. "I copied the chair nearly exactly from the statue in Largo La Foppa," Mr. Citterio said.
Ms. Dwan added: "The espresso bar on the corner is one of our favorite places to go for coffee. It certainly came in useful."

HEADLINE: Critic's Notebook;
In the Know and Willing to Talk

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
All clear, cowed news fans. The assault by television experts has subsided, and for the moment it seems safe to tune in your favorite interview shows. But watch your head; this is likely to be just a Serbian truce.
After the invasion of experts on terrorism set off by the bombing of the World Trade Center, there was only a brief respite before the little war in Waco, Tex., called forth a swarm of experts on cultism. These cadres, swooping straight from producers' Rolodexes onto the nation's screens, were in a thriving television tradition of know-it-alls expatiating at the summons of the evening news on why a catastrophe they never predicted could now easily be foreseen. 
 The most accomplished of the breed are the foreign-policy pontificators. A nation's destruction can be the making of a reputation. You may not recall any of these people announcing before the event that Communism would collapse or that Yugoslavia would become a killing ground, but once they noticed what was happening, they were ready with policy pronouncements adorned with geopolitical phrases and sometimes delivered in a Middle European or Middle Eastern accent. Is it possible that the accent is adapted to the milieu?
Economists may be the most serviceable experts for television purposes, since they can readily be found on all sides of any issue. They resemble those doctors and engineers who rent themselves out in accident cases, some customarily testifying for the prosecution, others for the defense, a nice example of science accommodating itself to the market.
In like manner, economists have been proving to audiences for years that there is a recession and there is no recession, that it is over and it has hardly begun. Nothing that George F. Will or Sam Donaldson does can divert these practitioners from the incessant promotion of their appointed panaceas.
Psychologists have moved in on the downscale talk-show circuit like an occupying army. Some of the terrorism experts and cult experts came from their discipline, but the psychologists' main attraction for the afternoon believe-it-or-nots lies in sexier areas. The Mia Farrow-Woody Allen free-for-all brought out regiments of them, subspecialists in marriage, child care and celebrityitis. So many had been hired by the principals themselves that shaky New Yorkers faced a therapy shortage.
Unfortunately, descriptions of goings-on in the Farrow-Allen households did not enhance practitioners' pretensions to having bolstered their clients' mental health or emotional stability. And recent allegations that specialists in child abuse, a hot new line, have been coaxing young children to accuse parents or day-care workers of sexual hanky-panky have not added to the profession's luster. For the purposes of television, however, fantasy is at least as useful as fact, so you can count on the performing psychologists to continue to do their acts on all channels.
When the expert industry was young, producers ransacked universities and think tanks for presentable people with credentials and an authoritative manner. They found hurricane experts here and earthquake experts there and raided the ranks of retired generals to give blow-by-blows of the war in the Persian Gulf. But when it comes to terrorism and cultism, my suspicion is that the event creates the experts. After all, what university has an Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini Chair in Hostage-Taking or a Jim Jones School of Bartendry from which producers can draw?
No, it must work the other way. Every news program and talk show must have an emergency facility, where all-purpose pros sit around like fire fighters, playing cards until disaster strikes, the alarm sounds and they speed to the cameras with buckets of jargon. A few appearances on "Nightline" or "The MacNeil/Lehrer Newshour" can do wonders for a reputation; a good performance may bring a book contract, a lecture tour, an invitation to be a senior something-or-other at a think tank, a partnership in a consulting operation, an invitation to contribute to op-ed pages. The new line for academic careerists: perform or perish.
What the experts are peddling, along with the usual mix of unexceptional observations and pop formulations, is themselves. When the terrorism expert tells an interviewer that more money must be invested in security, when the cult expert pleads for more attention to religious eccentrics, when the psychologist leads the wailing about domestic disarray, they are cultivating their gardens. The fertilizer is a blend of real troubles and the usual ingredient.

SECTION: Section A; Page 22; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 577 words

HEADLINE: Bill Clinton's Hundred Days

 BODY:
All Presidents since Franklin Roosevelt have had their reputations stretched or shortened by a Procrustean journalistic device known as the "first hundred days." The hundred days test is, of course, fundamentally silly. As Arthur Schlesinger pointed out on the Op-Ed page recently, Roosevelt assumed office at a time of such calamity that Congress "dared not say him nay." No President since has faced a comparable crisis.
Yet so durable is the standard that not even the White House, which might prefer to forget some of Bill Clinton's first hundred days, can ignore it. To mark the occasion Mr. Clinton's p.r. apparatus churned out a little pamphlet called "Season of America's Renewal," the title lifted from the President's hopeful address to Congress in February. The Republicans responded with a less flattering exegesis, "On the Wrong Track." 
 The hundred days tag, according to most accounts, was invented by newspapermen, who compared Roosevelt's domination of Washington in the spring of 1933 to another 100-day period embracing Napoleon's escape from exile, his army's triumphant sweep across France and his shattering defeat at Waterloo. Democrats like to recall the triumph; Republicans enjoy the Waterloo bit.
The truth of Mr. Clinton's hundred days is rather more provisional. There have been several large accomplishments. He steered his $1.5 trillion budget outline through Congress in record time, and responded boldly and generously to Boris Yeltsin's cry for help. There have also been less dramatic gestures that nevertheless bespeak a kinder, gentler and less ideological Administration, including the family leave bill and the dismantling of the Reagan-Bush restrictions on abortion.
There have also been many missteps, beginning with his snakebit search for an attorney general and continuing on through the bungled sales job on his stimulus package. One result has been a flurry of articles bemoaning a lack of focus in the White House and a general dulling of the sharp sense of purpose outlined in Mr. Clinton's campaign.
No less a loyalist than Leon Panetta, his Budget Director, told reporters on Monday that Mr. Clinton must do "a better job of picking and choosing the battles he wants to go through." Specifically, Mr. Panetta implored Mr. Clinton to delay health care reform until the fall, and said that piling a revolution in health care on top of everything else, including new taxes on energy and Social Security, could invite general legislative carnage and threaten the deficit-reduction strategy on which Mr. Clinton has staked his Presidency.
Mr. Panetta's advice was rejected out of hand by Donna Shalala, the Secretary of Health and Human Services; the President's wife and health care expert, Hillary Rodham Clinton, and then by the President himself. Their view is that health care reform is an essential component of any serious deficit reduction strategy, and they may be right. Even so, Mr. Panetta is hardly alone in his belief that Mr. Clinton, a noted trencherman, may have heaped far too much on his plate at this early stage.
Mr. Clinton won the election in part because he focused on one message ("It's the economy, stupid"), despite his policy-wonk tendency to move in a thousand directions at once. It's still early, and a hundred days really don't mean all that much, but one lesson he can learn from his slump in Washington and at the polls is not to confuse motion with progress.
